Trump’s protective detail in late 2019 when the culture of internal strife that Mr. Trump fostered throughout his term left the president’s top advisers frantically searching for a candidate to fill a key role: deputy White House chief of staff for operations.

headline: N.Y.C. Becomes First to Offer Paxlovid at Mobile Testing Sites
abstract: New York City launched the first mobile testing units in the United States that will immediately prescribe the antiviral treatment Paxlovid to people who test positive for the coronavirus.
lead_paragraph: New York City launched the first mobile testing units in the United States that will immediately prescribe the antiviral treatment Paxlovid to people who test positive for the coronavirus.

headline: The Perils of Slow Vote-Counting and Delayed Election Results
abstract: Slow vote counts were the bane of the 2020 elections, inviting bogus fraud charges. But they’re not going away anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: What happens when Election Day lasts for weeks?

headline: Oklahoma Plans to Execute 25 Prisoners in 29 Months
abstract: The executions are scheduled to begin in August. The state had suspended capital punishment for several years because of botched executions and a lawsuit over one of the drugs used.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma court on Friday set execution dates for 25 death row prisoners, setting up a string of executions that would take place nearly every month over the next two years.

headline: Trump Eyes Early 2024 Announcement as Jan. 6 Scrutiny Intensifies
abstract: Donald Trump has accelerated his campaign planning, hoping a White House bid will blunt a series of damaging revelations. Some Republicans are worried.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are bracing for Donald J. Trump to announce an unusually early bid for the White House, a move designed in part to shield the former president from a stream of damaging revelations emerging from investigations into his attempts to cling to power after losing the 2020 election.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in July
abstract: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to their libraries. Here are our picks for some of July’s most promising new titles.
lead_paragraph: (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: What Is the ‘Abortion Abolitionist’ Movement?
abstract: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.
lead_paragraph: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.

headline: Baby’s Father Arrested in Shooting of Woman Who Was Walking Stroller
abstract: Azsia Johnson, 20, was shot to death on a quiet section of 95th Street on Wednesday evening. The father of their child was arrested on Friday evening and charged with murder.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old man was arrested in connection with the death of Azsia Johnson, a 20-year-old mother who was fatally shot at point blank range on Wednesday as she pushed her 3-month-old daughter in a stroller while on a walk on the Upper East Side, the police announced.

headline: Kentucky Man Shoots 6 Officers, Killing 3, Police Say
abstract: The authorities say the suspect, Lance P. Storz, 49, had barricaded himself in his home in Allen, Ky., a town so small it lacks its own police force.
lead_paragraph: Three law enforcement officers were killed and three other officers were shot on Thursday night after a man barricaded in his home opened fire with a rifle in Allen, Ky., a rural town so small that it lacks its own police force, the authorities said.

headline: Tick or Tock
abstract: Evan Kalish breaks into Saturday with an artful challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is a neat accomplishment. It’s Evan Kalish’s first Saturday puzzle, and he has now hit for the cycle as a constructor of at least one daily puzzle for all seven days of the week, plus a variety puzzle (a vowel-less crossword, if you’re interested in trng smthng nw).

headline: How to Watch Fourth of July Fireworks in New York City
abstract: From the Macy’s display to Coney Island, here are the spots across the city where you can celebrate Independence Day with dazzling light displays.
lead_paragraph: While a number of cities are canceling Fourth of July fireworks this year because of staff and supply shortages, among other reasons, New York City will still celebrate the holiday with a fiery show.

headline: Ill Prepared for Combat, Volunteers Die in Battles Far From Home
abstract: Many of the fighters for Ukraine’s western territorial defense units were assigned benign tasks away from the fighting when they first joined. Then they were called to the front to fight.
lead_paragraph: RUDNE, Ukraine — Yurii Brukhal, an electrician by trade, did not have a very dangerous role when he volunteered for Ukraine’s territorial defense forces at the start of the war. He was assigned to make deliveries and staff a checkpoint in the relative safety of his sleepy village.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Long Live the Theater’ in Mariupol, Now Gone
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “There is a saying: ‘The king is dead. Long live the king.’ So, the theater died. Long live the theater.”

headline: Corrections: July 2, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 2, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the Supreme Court ruling that allows the Biden administration to end a Trump-era immigration program that forces asylum seekers at the southwestern border to await approval in Mexico described incorrectly the history of immigration legislation. Congress has made changes to immigration law since 1986, but it has not passed any law to legalize undocumented immigrants since that year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: The Federal Government Subsidizes Abortions. Will That Last?
abstract: Individuals can often use health insurance or flexible spending accounts to pay for abortions or deduct the cost on tax returns. Congress might weigh in.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, you can get a tax deduction for your abortion if your overall health care expenses are high enough. That didn’t change with the Supreme Court’s ruling last week.

headline: Inflation Is Posing 19 Problems for One Central Bank
abstract: After more than a decade of worrying about low inflation, the European Central Bank is trying to tackle the problem of high inflation across the eurozone’s economies.
lead_paragraph: SINTRA, Portugal — For central bankers, the world has changed abruptly. After more than a decade of low inflation and interest rates, policymakers are now in an environment of high inflation, where there isn’t time for ponderous decisions, only swift and decisive action.

headline: How the Russian Media Spread False Claims About Ukrainian Nazis
abstract: An analysis of nearly eight million articles about Ukraine from Russian websites shows that references to Nazism have spiked to unprecedented levels during the war.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of nearly eight million articles about Ukraine from Russian websites shows that references to Nazism have spiked to unprecedented levels during the war.

headline: How Do I Prove That I Can Pay the Rent if I Don’t Have a Monthly Salary?
abstract: For seniors, recent graduates and new hires, finding a home in this market without pay stubs is hard, but not impossible.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m a retiree with no income but significant liquidity, and I’m wondering how a person without a traditional source of income can qualify for an apartment when landlords typically require renters to show proof that they earn 40 times the monthly rent. I have to believe that mine is not an uncommon situation. What are other ways I can prove to a prospective landlord that I can pay the rent?

headline: Did the Supreme Court Open the Door to Reviving One of Its Worst Decisions?
abstract: Lochner v. New York, a 1905 decision on labor law, is imprinted on today’s law students as an example of bad jurisprudence. But those old days could be returning.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of the Supreme Court, few opinions have been more reviled than the 1905 decision in Lochner v. New York.

headline: N.Y. Beaches Step Up Shark Patrols With Drones, Trackers and Tourniquets
abstract: Amid an increase in shark sightings, lifeguards are increasing patrols and adopting new strategies, but marine experts say “the danger to people is infinitesimal.”
lead_paragraph: LIDO BEACH, N.Y. — It was a classic early summer Friday at Point Lookout Beach on Long Island, with beachgoers frolicking in the frothy waves and basking under the sunny skies.

headline: Yellowstone to Weigh Climate Change Risks When Rebuilding From Flood
abstract: The country’s oldest national park is considering whether to route its north entrance road away from the Gardner River.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: When Where You Work Determines if You Can Get an Abortion
abstract: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.
lead_paragraph: When Breanna Dietrich was 18 and working at a restaurant in West Virginia, she got pregnant. The father was a man she knew she wouldn’t marry. She considered getting an abortion. But the nearest clinic was four hours away and she couldn’t afford to take off work — so she had the baby girl.

headline: Seeing Norma: The Conflicted Life of the Woman at the Center of Roe v. Wade
abstract: Norma McCorvey, the plaintiff in the case that made abortion legal, struggled with her role. Her personal papers offer insight into her life, her thinking — and her continued relevance.
lead_paragraph: Norma McCorvey, the Jane Roe at the center of Roe v. Wade, was an imperfect plaintiff.

headline: Spurred by the Supreme Court, a Nation Divides Along a Red-Blue Axis
abstract: On abortion, climate change, guns and much more, two Americas — one liberal, one conservative — are moving in opposite directions.
lead_paragraph: Pressed by Supreme Court decisions diminishing rights that liberals hold dear and expanding those cherished by conservatives, the United States appears to be drifting apart into separate nations, with diametrically opposed social, environmental and health policies.

headline: Webb Telescope Will Look for Signs of Life Way Out There
abstract: The first question astronomers want to answer about exoplanets: Do they have atmospheres friendly to life?
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of NASA’s new James Webb Telescope images here.

headline: Japan’s Secret to Taming the Coronavirus: Peer Pressure
abstract: The country has never mandated masks or vaccinations, but it’s evaded the worst of Covid, thanks to a fear of public shaming and the “self restraint police.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — To understand how Japan has fared better than most of the world in containing the dire consequences of the coronavirus pandemic, consider Mika Yanagihara, who went shopping for flowers this past week in central Tokyo. Even when walking outside in temperatures in the mid-90s, she kept the lower half of her face fully covered.

headline: Skyrocketing Global Fuel Prices Threaten Livelihoods and Social Stability
abstract: Around the world, from South Asia and Africa to Europe and Latin America, the cost of filling a car’s tank, getting to work and cooking dinner has spiked.
lead_paragraph: “NO ES SUFICIENTE” — It’s not enough. That was the message protest leaders in Ecuador delivered to the country’s president this past week after he said he would lower the price of both regular gas and diesel by 10 cents in response to riotous demonstrations over soaring fuel and food prices.

headline: Five Boroughs, Five Days, One Question
abstract: What’s the vibe right now?
lead_paragraph: “New York City is dead forever,” that one headline declared. But the truth is, even though the coronavirus pulled the emergency brake and forced the city to a screeching halt, New York soon lurched right back into motion.

headline: Ukraine dreams of rebuilding the world’s largest airplane. Can Richard Branson help?
abstract: A Virgin Group spokesperson said the effort would turn to finding ways the international community could support the project.
lead_paragraph: Four months ago, at the beginning of the war, countless Ukrainians were demoralized when they learned that the world’s largest cargo airplane, built in Ukraine, was destroyed in a fierce battle.

headline: Tropical Storm Colin Expected to Weaken After Dousing the Carolinas
abstract: Colin could be downgraded to a tropical depression on Saturday night or Sunday, and the system was expected to dissipate by Sunday night, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Colin formed early on Saturday morning just off the coast of South Carolina, becoming the third named storm of the 2022 Atlantic hurricane season and threatening to drench outdoor activities over the long Independence Day weekend.

headline: Russia Repeatedly Strikes Ukraine’s Civilians. There’s Always an Excuse.
abstract: The Kremlin’s explanations have sometimes satisfied the Russian people, but they fall apart under closer scrutiny abroad.
lead_paragraph: Since late February, when Russia began pummeling Ukraine with missiles and artillery on a scale unseen in Europe for decades, civilian deaths have been as inevitable as the Russian excuses that follow.

headline: Japan Swelters Through a Punishing Heat Wave
abstract: Temperatures in Tokyo surpassed 95 degrees for the eighth straight day on Saturday, a streak seen only once before since 1875.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is enduring one of its worst heat waves on record, raising concern about potential power shortages amid surging demand, even as officials urged people to keep their air-conditioners running to ward off heat stroke.

headline: A Guide to the Weekend
abstract: Recommendations for a summer holiday — movies, podcasts, “Stranger Things” and cobbler.
lead_paragraph: The most reliable way I’ve found to discover books I love is by seeking out the recommendations of writers whose work I admire. So when I saw that Patrick Radden Keefe, the author of the riveting “Empire of Pain,” was discussing his favorite writers in The Times Book Review, I broke out my note-taking app to add Emmanuel Carrère’s “The Adversary” to my ever-lengthening list of titles to read.

headline: Ukraine accuses Russia of dropping white phosphorus on Snake Island after its retreat.
abstract: Some observers speculated that the strike was a move to destroy equipment that Russia had abandoned on the island and to complicate any future Ukrainian presence there.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s army has accused Russia of dropping incendiary white phosphorus on Snake Island on Friday, the day after Moscow’s forces retreated from the strategic rocky outcrop on the southwestern part of the Black Sea that is key to the Kremlin’s war aims.

headline: Searching for Gold, Miners Discover a Frozen Baby Mammoth
abstract: Experts believe that the woolly mammoth, unearthed in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon of Canada, had been preserved in the frozen ground for more than 30,000 years.
lead_paragraph: About a half-hour before his lunch break one June morning, Travis Mudry was operating an excavator and digging through permafrost in the Klondike gold fields of the Yukon in Canada.

headline: The Republican War on Sex
abstract: In the America where I came of age, I was told my life was worth more than my ability to have babies. And my sexuality was nothing to be ashamed of.
lead_paragraph: One day I hope to become a mother. But for now, I have sex just because I like it. Sex is fun.

headline: What to Do Now to Prepare for the Next Recession
abstract: Rushing in to confront a crisis is always better than letting it simply unfold.
lead_paragraph: In the face of rising inflation, the Federal Reserve is trying to cool down the economy, raising interest rates by 0.75 percentage point in June, the biggest increase since 1994. Jerome Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, has vowed to try to engineer a “soft landing” — in which demand drops, bringing prices down, without tipping the economy into a recession and throwing hundreds of thousands of Americans out of their jobs.

headline: Ukrainian students are hopeful and defiant as they graduate amid war.
abstract: For these students, this coming-of-age moment amid the war is especially poignant.
lead_paragraph: UZHHOROD, Ukraine — The teenagers, all wearing white sashes with the word “graduate” draped across them, clustered together and laughed as they walked through the Old City looking for somewhere to go out.

headline: Brittney Griner’s Detention in Moscow Is Latest in Hostage Diplomacy
abstract: The United States believes the charges against the basketball star are spurious and tied to American support of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. athlete facing criminal drug charges in Russia, may be merely the latest victim of a practice so common it has its own name: hostage diplomacy.

headline: In Pakistan, a Leader in Trans Rights, Reality Is Slower to Change Than Law
abstract: Four years after the country became one of the few to protect transgender people’s rights in statute, violence against them has surged and discrimination remains common.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Four years ago, Pakistan stepped to the forefront of transgender rights worldwide, enacting a law that prohibits discrimination against transgender people in schools, workplaces and public settings, and guarantees them the right to choose their gender on official documents.

headline: His Union Went on Strike. His Interviews Went Viral.
abstract: At a time of rampant inflation and wage stagnation, Mick Lynch, the force behind Britain’s largest railway strikes in three decades, has found success that has surprised even his colleagues.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has branded him a “union baron,” but Mick Lynch, the union leader who is orchestrating the largest railway strikes in Britain in three decades, has emerged from work stoppages that disrupted the plans of millions of people as an unexpected media sensation.

headline: Texas Supreme Court Lifts Freeze on Abortion Ban
abstract: The decision, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked the ban, allowed a 1925 law to take effect.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Supreme Court allowed a 1925 law banning abortion to take effect late on Friday night, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked it.

headline: An Anti-Abortion Victory, but ‘at What Price’?
abstract: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat and a guest essay by an anti-abortion advocate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Let’s Not Pretend We’re Keeping Our Promises on Asylum
abstract: The most powerful countries decided that people were entitled to seek asylum. Now they undermine those promises without consequence.
lead_paragraph: In this restive age of unprecedented human displacement, 100 million people have fled disaster and oppression to try their luck in a world that’s increasingly tired of dealing with them.

headline: El Salvador’s Bitcoin Paradise Is a Mirage
abstract: The country’s cryptocurrency is nothing more than authoritarian propaganda.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — Bitcoiners — enthusiasts of the world’s most popular cryptocurrency — aren’t supposed to trust government. After all, one of Bitcoin’s premises is to separate money from the state.

headline: The Democrat Who’s Flipping the Campaign Script
abstract: A candidate for Congress is speaking out against the government red tape that is reviled in parts of rural America.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HALL, Md. — When Dave Harden decided to run for Congress as a Democrat on Maryland’s conservative Eastern Shore, a friend gave him a piece of free advice.

headline: The American Flag Belongs to Me, Too, and This Year I’m Taking It Back
abstract: Old Glory has become such a strong a feature of Trump rallies that many liberals have all but rejected it.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — We bought our house from a military veteran who hauled his flag out on every officially patriotic occasion. It hung from a flag mount embedded in the bark of a maple tree, and during our first years in the house we followed suit, at least on the Fourth of July.

headline: This regional leader is a symbol of Ukrainian defiance.
abstract: Vitaliy Kim is the head of the regional military administration in the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
lead_paragraph: To win the war, says Vitaliy Kim, you need to love the war.

headline: Will Reactionaries Impose a Red-State Social Order on the Rest of Us?
abstract: The Supreme Court has freed Republican-led states to try to extend their authority beyond their borders.
lead_paragraph: One way to understand the work of the Republican Party and its six-member majority on the Supreme Court is to think about the American political system in terms of its defensive and offensive potential. Here, a historical example is in order.

headline: Gridlock in Congress Has Amplified the Power of the Supreme Court
abstract: What was once a dialogue between the branches has become almost entirely one-sided, with the justices accumulating clout at lawmakers’ expense.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the last day of a turbulent term that included rulings on what the Constitution has to say about abortion, guns and religion, the Supreme Court issued another sort of decision, one that turned on the words of the Clean Air Act.

headline: Russia Steps Up Pace of Missile Attacks on Residential Targets
abstract: The Russians’ growing use of imprecise Soviet-era missiles to terrorize civilians reflects the daunting outlook of its offensive despite incremental gains, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — An attack on a shopping mall on Monday, killing 19 civilians. A missile strike on a sleepy resort town on Friday, claiming the lives of at least 21 residents. Cluster bombs on Saturday hit a residential block in an industrial hub, leaving four dead.

headline: Swiatek, the World No. 1, Falls at Wimbledon, Ending a Long Win Streak
abstract: Frustrated by low bounces on the grass courts that took away her most powerful weapons, the top-seeded women’s singles player lost in straight sets to Alizé Cornet of France.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Iga Swiatek, the world No. 1 and the top seed at Wimbledon, did something she had not done in more than four months Saturday. She lost a tennis match.

headline: Tesla Sales Slow as the Pandemic Hobbles Production
abstract: The decline in deliveries by the electric carmaker in the second quarter was the first drop since the beginning of 2020. The main culprit was factory shutdowns in China.
lead_paragraph: Tesla said Saturday that vehicle deliveries from April through June fell 18 percent from the first quarter of the year, a rare slowdown for the company caused by production problems in China.

headline: Ukraine’s Lesia Tsurenko Plays Tennis for the Money
abstract: She used to compete because she loved tennis, but now Tsurenko wants to win as much prize money as possible to help people in her war-torn country.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Lesia Tsurenko’s Wimbledon campaign ended Friday during a match in which her head was someplace else.

headline: The fight for the last city in Luhansk under Ukrainian control reaches a pivotal point.
abstract: WARSAW, Poland — Ukraine appeared to be pulling some troops and equipment out of Lysychansk as Russia-allied forces said Saturday that they had advanced to the center of the strategic city in eastern Ukraine after days of heavy fighting, according to Russian state media and interviews with Ukrainian troops.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Poland — Ukraine appeared to be pulling some troops and equipment out of Lysychansk as Russia-allied forces said Saturday that they had advanced to the center of the strategic city in eastern Ukraine after days of heavy fighting, according to Russian state media and interviews with Ukrainian troops.

headline: On a Long Climb to the Top, She Makes Short Work of an Opponent
abstract: Kayla Harrison easily dispatched her rival in their Professional Fighters League bout on Friday. She wants to take on the best women in mixed martial arts, but contracts stand in the way.
lead_paragraph: Kayla Harrison’s second bout of the Professional Fighters League regular season unfolded as predictably as the betting odds — tilted heavily in her favor — suggested.

headline: In City Where ‘Europe Starts,’ Ethnic Russians Start Questioning Putin’s War
abstract: Narva, in northeastern Estonia, is the E.U.’s most ethnically Russian city, with a population supportive of President Vladimir Putin. But the conflict in Ukraine has set off a “mental war” between old and young.
lead_paragraph: NARVA, Estonia — Like many of the ethnic Russians who live along Estonia’s eastern border with Russia, Stanislava Larchenko could not believe that President Vladimir V. Putin had gone on a killing spree in Ukraine.

headline: Former Georgetown Tennis Coach Sentenced to More Than 2 Years in Varsity Blues Case
abstract: The sentence is the harshest punishment yet in the college admissions scandal.
lead_paragraph: A former Georgetown University head tennis coach who pleaded guilty last fall to accepting bribes to help prospective students gain admission to the school was sentenced Friday to more than two years in prison, according to the U.S. attorney’s office for the District of Massachusetts.

headline: The Long Path to Reclaim Abortion Rights
abstract: The Supreme Court decision to reverse Roe, far from settling the matter, instead has launched court and political battles across the states likely to go on for years.
lead_paragraph: Attempting to recover from their staggering loss in the Supreme Court, abortion rights groups have mounted a multilevel legal and political attack aimed at blocking and reversing abortion bans in courts and at ballot boxes across the country.

headline: Bruce Katz, Pioneer of the Walking Shoe, Is Dead at 75
abstract: A third-generation shoe manufacturer, he built Rockport with his father and, before selling it to Reebok, campaigned to turn walking into a fitness movement.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Katz, who with his father started the Rockport Shoe Company in 1971 and established walking shoes as a vibrant footwear category, died on June 26 in Greenbrae, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Akron Police Officers Placed on Leave After Fatal Shooting of Black Man
abstract: A lawyer for the family of the victim, Jayland Walker, said he was struck dozens of times. The Ohio city braced for protests as footage of the shooting is expected to be released Sunday.
lead_paragraph: An unspecified number of police officers in Akron, Ohio, were placed on administrative leave after the fatal shooting of a 25-year-old Black man who the police said continued to drive after they tried to pull him over for an unspecified traffic violation.

headline: Palestinians Give U.S. Experts Bullet That Killed Journalist
abstract: Officials believe that the bullet, which killed Shireen Abu Akleh, could hold essential clues as to who is responsible for her death.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian Authority has handed over to a team of American investigators the bullet it says killed the Palestinian American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh, Palestinian officials said on Saturday, in a move meant to clarify the circumstances of the reporter’s death.

headline: A Mother and Her 3 Children Are Found Dead in a Minnesota Lake
abstract: The authorities said the case was being investigated as a “possible triple murder-suicide” and was believed to be connected to another suicide on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The bodies of a mother and her three children, two boys and one girl, were recovered in a lake outside Saint Paul, Minn., and the authorities said they were investigating it as a “possible triple murder-suicide.”

headline: Expansion Pack
abstract: Tom McCoy's Sunday puzzle might be hard to get a handle on, but it’s worth it!
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid marks the Sunday return of Tom McCoy after a far-too-long absence — nearly two years — that likely corresponds to a period of intense study. Mr. McCoy, who lives in Wexford, Pa., recently defended his doctoral dissertation in cognitive science at Johns Hopkins University, on the subject of how language is represented in artificial intelligence systems and what that tells us about language in humans. This fall, he will begin a postdoctoral program at Princeton, which might be easier to juggle with crossword construction (probably wishful thinking on my part).

headline: Thousands of Flights Are Delayed or Canceled as Holiday Travel Kicks Off
abstract: Airlines, dealing with bad weather and staffing shortages, struggle to keep up with high demand over the July 4 weekend.
lead_paragraph: Travelers across the country faced the prospect of canceled or delayed flights on Saturday as airlines and airports dealt with a combination of high demand, bad weather and staffing shortages.

headline: Uvalde Schools Police Chief Resigns From City Council
abstract: Pete Arredondo announced he was stepping down “to minimize further distractions.”
lead_paragraph: Pete Arredondo, the chief of the school district police force in Uvalde, Texas, resigned as a member of the Uvalde City Council on Friday amid continued outrage over the slow police response to a shooting at Robb Elementary School in May.

headline: Supreme Court Marshal Asks Officials to End Protests at Justices’ Homes
abstract: One official criticized the request, saying that the federal government was primarily responsible for ensuring the safety of justices and their families.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief security officer of the Supreme Court has asked that Virginia and Maryland officials enforce laws that would prohibit protests outside the homes of justices after weeks of demonstrations favoring abortion rights.

headline: Man Dies After Truck Propelled by Jet Engines Crashes at Michigan Air Show
abstract: The vehicle, called a Shockwave Jet Truck, was racing two planes when it crashed, killing the driver, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The driver of a truck that could top 350 miles per hour because it was powered by jet engines died after the vehicle crashed on Saturday while racing two airplanes at an air show in Michigan, officials said.

headline: Investigators of War Crimes in Ukraine Face Formidable Challenges
abstract: International agencies are joining Ukrainian prosecutors in what may be the biggest effort ever to hold war criminals to account. But the difficulties and dangers they face are exceptional, too.
lead_paragraph: KOROPY, Ukraine — Four men tugged at long strips of fabric to lift a coffin out of the gaping hole in the backyard of a small house. They flung the lid open to reveal the moldy corpse of Oleksiy Ketler, who had been killed instantly by shrapnel when a mortar fell on the road in Koropy, a village outside Kharkiv in northeastern Ukraine, in March.

headline: Corrections: July 3, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about George Michael misstated the location of his childhood home. It was in Edgware, not East Finchley.

headline: Four killed after explosions in a Russian city near the Ukraine border.
abstract: The Russians said its air-defense systems shot down three missiles, but one fell to the ground in central Belgorod.
lead_paragraph: Explosions hit the center of a Russian city just north of Ukraine early Sunday, killing four, officials said, in the deadliest known episode affecting civilians in Russia since the start of the war.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘She Wanted to Celebrate by Eating at Her Favorite Hot Pot Restaurant’
abstract: A long walk to Queens, a sidewalk singalong and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How a Military Base in Illinois Helps Keep Weapons Flowing to Ukraine
abstract: Thousands of logisticians are responsible for making sure that U.S. military aid reaches its destination, on planes, trains and ships.
lead_paragraph: SCOTT AIR FORCE BASE, Ill. — In a room dimly lit by television screens, dozens of airmen tapped away at computers and worked the phones. Some were keeping watch over a high-priority mission to move a Russian-made Mi-17 helicopter from a base in Arizona to a destination near Ukraine’s border.

headline: Once a Crucial Refuge, ‘Gayborhoods’ Lose L.G.B.T.Q. Residents in Major Cities
abstract: Many are choosing to live elsewhere in search of cheaper housing and better amenities. They are finding growing acceptance in other communities after decades of political and social changes.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Cleve Jones has lived in the Castro neighborhood for nearly 50 years, almost from the day he graduated from high school in Phoenix and hitchhiked to California.

headline: ‘The Pro-Life Generation’: Young Women Fight Against Abortion Rights
abstract: Many American women mourned the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe, but for others it is a moment of triumph and a matter of human rights.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The rollback of abortion rights has been received by many American women with a sense of shock and fear, and warnings about an ominous decline in women’s status as full citizens.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Gayborhoods’ Falling Victim to Rents and Social Change
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 3, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Gayborhoods are going away. People need to pay attention to this. When people are dispersed, when they no longer live in geographic concentrations, when they no longer inhabit specific precincts, we lose a lot. We lose political power.”

headline: Father Figure: The Tortured Life of George Michael
abstract: James Gavin’s engrossing biography of the singer takes the measure of a gifted, tragic and infuriating man.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Princess Diana asked her friend George Michael to help organize a benefit concert for World AIDS Day. He came through magnificently, lining up the other acts and delivering a strong and heartfelt headlining set of his own. Then when it came time for the show to air as a TV special, the English singer insisted on seeing the footage, altering the sequence of performers and recutting the shots of himself onstage because he thought his butt looked big. According to a former BBC producer, “‘Never work with children, animals or George Michael’ became an industry mantra after that.”

headline: Pay Attention to These Old Women. You’ll Learn Something.
abstract: Alice Elliott Dark’s ambitious new novel, “Fellowship Point,” explores a lifetime of lessons about friendship, loyalty and land.
lead_paragraph: Novels featuring older characters are well suited to an exploration of questions about time, history and change. Unlike younger protagonists, they already know who they’ve become and what they’ve made of their lives. They’re not finished yet, but they are as busy reckoning with the past as they are living in the present. They are in full possession of the bulk of their life’s trajectory, so their primary aim is to resolve and make sense of things before they die.

headline: A Mermaid Makes for a Strange Kind of Immigrant
abstract: Equal parts fairy tale, ghost story and history, Monique Roffey’s new novel explores the legacy of colonialism and enslavement on a Caribbean island.
lead_paragraph: Off the shores of Black Conch, an imagined island in the Caribbean, in 1976, two American white men and a crew of Black island sailors hook a mermaid and wrestle her out of the water. Almost all the sailors experience a deep unease, “a sense of blasphemy,” at the act of capture: “So close, she was terrifying, a person there, no doubt about it; a trapped and dying woman.” The mermaid, Aycayia — huge, wounded, furious, utterly vulnerable, “crawling with sea-lice” — brings out powerful impulses in the men: to harm, to possess, to touch, to mark her, despite or even because of the hatred in her “tinfoil eyes.” This violent, mesmerizing scene begins “The Mermaid of Black Conch,” signaling the book’s ambition. Monique Roffey’s sixth novel is a fairy tale: The mermaid casts off her tail, regains her legs, falls in love, battles an ancient curse. But it is a ghost story too, the people and the very land of Black Conch haunted by the island’s legacy of colonialism and enslavement.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: 76 Fake Charities Shared a Mailbox. The I.R.S. Approved Them All.
abstract: The tax agency is the gatekeeper for America’s charity system, but reduced vetting has opened the door to scams.
lead_paragraph: The “American Cancer Society of Michigan,” state authorities say, was a fake charity. And not even a good fake.

headline: 3-D Printing Grows Beyond Its Novelty Roots
abstract: With the technology improving and costs falling, 3-D printing could be poised to play a major role in manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: DEVENS, Mass. — The machines stand 20 feet high, weigh 60,000 pounds and represent the technological frontier of 3-D printing.

headline: Suing New York, Over and Over, for Transgender Rights
abstract: Mariah Lopez first sued the city at age 13. Her latest settlement has forced the city to overhaul how it treats transgender people who are homeless.
lead_paragraph: Mariah Lopez has been suing New York City for transgender rights since she was a child.

headline: A Clunky Mask May Be the Answer to Airborne Disease and N95 Waste
abstract: Experts say the U.S. government has unintentionally encouraged a dependency on imported masks by failing to promote elastomeric respirators, a reusable mask that is domestically produced.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, long before P.P.E., N95 and asymptomatic transmission became household terms, federal health officials issued guidelines for how medical workers should protect themselves from tuberculosis during a resurgence of the highly infectious respiratory disease.

headline: An American’s Murky Path From Russian Propagandist to Jan. 6
abstract: Charles Bausman, a former financial executive who runs websites that promote far-right views, recorded footage in the Capitol for a Russian television producer. Soon after, he fled to Moscow as a “political refugee.”
lead_paragraph: In security footage from Jan. 6, it is easy to overlook the thin man wearing a red Trump hat who filters into the U.S. Capitol Building to record the mayhem with his phone.

headline: Buffalo’s ‘Other Story’ Is Told in Redevelopment and Growth
abstract: A decade-long effort to transform industrial relics is showing signs of progress and expanding the city’s population for the first time in 70 years.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Buffalo was riding a decade-long economic turnaround when a racially motivated attack by a gunman killed 10 people in May, overshadowing the progress. While the city grieved, it also had to reckon with unflattering portrayals of the East Side, the impoverished neighborhood where the massacre took place.

headline: Summer’s Soft Return
abstract: The heat rises at parties for The Drift, New Wave New York and the Swedish consulate’s Midsummer Festival.
lead_paragraph: Summer is here, officially. There are signs: There’s the solstice of course, and the L.G.B.T. Pride March. But there are more subtle markers around the city: conviviality on fire escapes; weekends that are thinner with locals and thicker with tourists; and no one wears a thing. This last ritual was challenged on June 23 as writers, agents and editors ambled uptown to celebrate the second anniversary of the literary magazine The Drift, hosted at the David Zwirner gallery on East 69th Street. Guests in demure dress listened to speeches from The Drift’s editors, the novelist Joshua Cohen and a beshorted Hilton Als, who curated the gallery’s current show of Frank Walter’s work.

headline: The Race to the Start Line: Returning to Running After Having Covid-19
abstract: It’s not easy to tell runners to slow down when many of their goals are to speed up.
lead_paragraph: In March 2020, Dr. Niall Elliott was planning for the Summer Olympics with his colleagues at the British Olympic Association. Plans were drawn for what to do if an athlete suffered a catastrophic injury or a mental health crisis in the final lead-up to the Games. There were meetings on how to move some of the world’s finest athletes across the globe and how to address logistical snafus.

headline: The Far Right and Far Left Agree on One Thing: Women Don’t Count
abstract: Tolerance for one group doesn’t need to mean intolerance for another.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it makes sense that women — those supposedly compliant and agreeable, self-sacrificing and everything-nice creatures — were the ones to finally bring our polarized country together.

headline: My O.C.D. Diagnosis Was a Blessing, Until It Became Too Central to My Identity
abstract: Getting a mental health diagnosis can be a huge relief. But can the label become a problem?
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, seemingly out of nowhere, my brain fell into an abyss of unrelenting intrusive thoughts — What if I harm myself? What if I harm others? What if I’m crazy? — each of which was accompanied by electric shocks of anxiety and full-on sensations of dread. It was, by far, the most terrifying, vexing and isolating period of my life. My first moment of relief came four weeks later, when I finally got in to see a psychiatrist.

headline: The Persistent Myth That Restricting Abortion Rights Won’t Affect the Rich
abstract: The notion that rich women will be fine, regardless of what the law says, is probably comforting to some. But it is simply not true.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one assumption about abortion rights that’s accepted across the ideological spectrum, it’s this: The Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade will mostly affect the poor; rich women will still have access to abortions when they need them.

headline: An Ode to the Queen City of the Hudson
abstract: When the snow gives way to the dog days of summer, many locals find some relief at the swimming hole on Wappinger Creek.
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — When I accepted a job to teach literature and writing at Vassar College in the summer of 2005, a colleague told me that Poughkeepsie — lesser known to some as the Queen City of the Hudson — was a city caught in postindustrial decline. I had a vague notion of what that looked like: boarded-up homes and offices, the husk of dead factories with broken windows and overgrown grass, rusted cars, businesses gone to seed.

headline: A Season on the Line
abstract: The Chicago White Sox have been slowed by injuries and mocked for odd decisions. A 19-game stretch against division rivals could make or break their year.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — Andrew Vaughn, the Chicago White Sox outfielder, grew up in Santa Rosa, the Northern California town best known for its wineries and as the home of the cartoonist Charles M. Schulz. Vaughn said his father knew Schulz, the creator of the “Peanuts” comic strip, a little and spent a lot of time at Snoopy’s Home Ice, an ice rink in town.

headline: The Week in Business: Spending More, Getting Less
abstract: The stock market had its worst first six months of a year since 1970. The Supreme Court dealt a blow to Biden’s climate plans. And the June jobs report is coming.
lead_paragraph: Consumers kept spending in May, but they got less for their money. Adjusted for inflation, spending fell in May for the first time this year — by 0.4 percent, as spending rose less than prices. Spending was also weaker in the first four months of 2022 than previously believed. Though Americans have hardly stopped making purchases even as prices for gas, groceries, travel and just about everything else rise, there are signs that high prices may be starting to take a toll on demand. Big-ticket items, in particular, have been affected, starting with the housing market, which has cooled off in recent weeks as high prices have combined with rising mortgage rates.

headline: Peter Brook, Celebrated Stage Director of Scale and Humanity, Dies at 97
abstract: He was called “the greatest innovator of his generation,” leaving an indelible mark with plays, musicals, opera and a relentless curiosity.
lead_paragraph: Peter Brook, whose ambitious, adventurous and endlessly creative stage work ranged across seven decades on both sides of the Atlantic and earned him a place among the greatest theater directors of the 20th century, died on Saturday. He was 97.

headline: Women who were raped by Russian soldiers yearn for justice.
abstract: Rapes were among the many atrocities Russian troops inflicted on Ukrainian civilians during weeks of occupation in the Kyiv suburbs and elsewhere. But the challenges of prosecuting the assaults are daunting.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Every day, Viktoriya has to walk past the house where she was raped by a Russian soldier the same age as her teenage son.

headline: Florida Man Posing as Disney Worker Charged in Removal of R2-D2 at Hotel
abstract: David Proudfoot told investigators he had applied for a security job at Walt Disney World and hoped to prove himself by highlighting lapses in Disney’s oversight.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who said he applied for a security job at Walt Disney World in Florida wanted to impress his would-be bosses.

headline: New Dementia Prevention Method May Be Behavioral, Not Prescribed
abstract: As experimental drugs prove ineffective against increasing dementia cases in the U.S., researchers argue that improving eyesight can have an effect.
lead_paragraph: Dementia cases are climbing along with an aging world population, and yet another much-anticipated Alzheimer’s medication, crenezumab, has proved ineffective in clinical trials — the latest of many disappointments. Public health experts and researchers argue that it is past time to turn our attention to a different approach — focusing on eliminating a dozen or so already known risk factors, like untreated high blood pressure, hearing loss and smoking, rather than on an exorbitantly priced, whiz-bang new drug.

headline: Big Ben’s Bongs Will Soon Ring Out Again Across London
abstract: Next to the Houses of Parliament, the tower that houses the enormous bell has been undergoing renovation since 2017.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For five years, the most famous clock tower in Britain was hidden behind an ugly fortress of scaffolding, and its hourly bong was rendered mute.

headline: In Northern Ireland, Old Passions Are Smoldering Anew
abstract: Brexit and so-called legacy legislation are reviving sensitive issues of Catholic and Protestant identity that civic leaders have sought to dampen.
lead_paragraph: DERRY, Northern Ireland — Few cities are as caught between hope and history as Derry, the birthplace of the modern Troubles but also the backdrop for “Derry Girls,” the exuberant, wildly popular British TV series that chronicles the lives of five teenagers as that bloody period was drawing to an end in the 1990s.

headline: Abortion Laws Around the World
abstract: The U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion quickly led to bans in at least eight states, a shift toward criminalization that runs counter to recent easings in countries that had longstanding bans.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s elimination of the constitutional right to abortion, after nearly a half-century, has made the United States one of the few countries actively strengthening abortion restrictions.

headline: ‘Demand Is Robust.’ Fireworks Come Roaring Back This Summer.
abstract: Pyrotechnic companies say they’re staging July Fourth shows at prepandemic levels, even as some cities cancel celebrations because of supply-chain and drought concerns.
lead_paragraph: During the early months of the pandemic, the Grucci fireworks business, which has operated from the United States for more than a century, saw the demand for its Independence Day shows plummet at a rate the family hadn’t seen since the Great Depression.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the Supreme Court
abstract: Getting a sense of the mood after a momentous term.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I asked Adam Liptak — The Times’s Supreme Court correspondent — to preview the major cases that would make up the end of the court’s term. Adam was prophetic, correctly forecasting every big ruling. Today, he returns to the newsletter, answering my questions about the behind-the-scenes atmosphere at the court.

headline: James Bardeen, an Expert on Unraveling Einstein’s Equations, Dies at 83
abstract: A scion of a renowned family of physicists, he helped set the stage for what has been called the golden age of black hole astrophysics.
lead_paragraph: James Bardeen, who helped elucidate the properties and behavior of black holes, setting the stage for what has been called the golden age of black hole astrophysics, died on June 20 in Seattle. He was 83.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Just before a holiday full of family and friends, take a moment to cook for yourself.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. What a gift a Sunday meal before a national holiday is, if you’re lucky enough not to be working. Monday’s for cookouts and family, for fireworks real and metaphorical. Sunday’s for you.

headline: America the Imperfect, on the Fourth of July
abstract: Reflections on America, in response to a column by Pamela Paul. Also: School safety; Microsoft and unions; abortion pills; God and miscarriages.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Russia appears to be taking steps toward two industrial cities.
abstract: Russia’s capture of the strategic city of Lysychansk means the front line in Ukraine’s east will shift as Russian forces regroup before pushing further south and west, military analysts and Ukrainian officers said Sunday, ensuring that the next phase of the battle will be just as bloody as the last.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s capture of the strategic city of Lysychansk means the front line in Ukraine’s east will shift as Russian forces regroup before pushing further south and west, military analysts and Ukrainian officers said Sunday, ensuring that the next phase of the battle will be just as bloody as the last.

headline: The Culture War That More Christians Should Be Fighting
abstract: If we don’t talk about economic justice, we are advancing an emaciated view of Christian political engagement.
lead_paragraph: Let’s talk about the culture war we should be fighting. When we think of what’s important to the “religious right” or to “white evangelicals,” the focus tends to be on social issues: abortion, the role of religion in public life, conflicts around sexual orientation and gender identity, and lately, controversy over critical race theory.

headline: The eastern city of Lysychansk is a big prize for Putin.
abstract: Controlling the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk means Russia could position its forces to mount offensives on cities to the southwest.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s complete control of the Ukrainian city of Lysychansk appears to be a foregone conclusion: Soviet flags are flying in the center and Ukrainian troops have withdrawn.

headline: Nick Kyrgios, a Dream and a Nightmare for Wimbledon, Is Winning
abstract: The Australian’s matches and news conferences have become irresistible theater — some call them a circus — that is a blessing and a curse for a sport battling for attention.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — All white is the dress code at Wimbledon, the oldest and most traditional of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments. So when Nick Kyrgios wears a black hat for his on-court interview, he is sending a message.

headline: Amid Ukraine War, Orchestras Rethink ‘1812 Overture,’ a July 4 Rite
abstract: Some ensembles have decided not to perform Tchaikovsky’s overture, written as commemoration of Russia’s defeat of Napoleon’s army.
lead_paragraph: With its earsplitting rounds of cannon fire and triumphal spirit, Tchaikovsky’s “1812 Overture” has been a staple of Fourth of July festivities across the United States for decades, serving as a rousing prelude to glittering displays of fireworks.

headline: 3 Dead in Copenhagen Mall Shooting, Police Say
abstract: The police said that one person was in custody but that it was too early to suggest a motive for the shooting, which happened at the Field’s shopping center on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed and at least three others were critically hurt in a shooting in Copenhagen on Sunday that sent terrified shoppers fleeing for safety in Denmark’s largest shopping center, the authorities said.

headline: At the Met, Protest and Poetry About Water
abstract: As climate change and government actions lead to water scarcity and desecration, Native American artists send an urgent message.
lead_paragraph: In a transfixing two-minute video called “River (The Water Serpent)” in the Metropolitan Museum’s American Wing we see a drone shot of a snow-flecked landscape where a crowd has gathered. Each of its members holds a vertical mirrored panel. Together, on cue, they place the panels horizontally over their heads, reflective side skyward, and begin a procession. At first, it’s loose and tidally pooling and eddying. Then it tightens into a stream of light, gains velocity, and spirals like a whirlpool.

headline: At Least 7 Die in Glacier Collapse in Italy’s Dolomites
abstract: The glacier has been shrinking for years, and climate change contributed to the tragedy, Italy’s prime minister said. Fourteen people are missing.
lead_paragraph: At least seven people died, eight were injured and 14 were missing after a chunk of a glacier collapsed in the Dolomites in Italy on Sunday, according to Maurizio Fugatti, the president of Trento Province.

headline: Justice Dept. Braces for Summer of Violent Crime
abstract: Top officials at the department met with prosecutors and the local police in Philadelphia in an effort to help cities prepare for a hot-weather crime wave marked by the Fourth of July.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The motorcade carrying Lisa O. Monaco, the No. 2 law enforcement official in the United States, maneuvered between potholes, and people, on Kensington Avenue when her driver braked for a man wandering into traffic with a hypodermic needle dangling from his arm.

headline: Listeria Outbreak Is Linked to Ice Cream, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Big Olaf Ice Cream products, which are made in Florida, have sickened people across 10 states, the federal authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A listeria outbreak blamed for the death of one person and the hospitalization of 22 people across 10 states has been linked to ice cream made in Florida, the federal authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Hunter Reynolds, Artist Who Dressed Up AIDS, Dies at 62
abstract: After he learned he was H.I.V. positive, he began making art — often performing as his gown-wearing alter ego — that told stories about the condition.
lead_paragraph: One night in 1989, Hunter Reynolds, then a 30-year-old artist living in New York City, made himself up at home with the help of a friendly drag queen. He was intrigued with the results: his handsome face embellished and transformed, neither man nor woman, like an androgynous cabaret star in Berlin during the Weimar years. He tossed on a tweed coat and headed out to various art-world events. Friends didn’t recognize him, so he pretended to be a performance artist visiting from Los Angeles.

headline: Review: In Pam Tanowitz’s ‘Song of Songs’ the Beloved Is Beauty
abstract: Her new dance at Bard, a collaboration with the composer David Lang, is a refined, restrained and sometimes breathtaking response to the biblical poem.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “Kiss me.” No sooner has the biblical Song of Songs begun than the speaker is making a move. For scripture, the poem is pretty salacious, which is one reason it has inspired many interpretations.

headline: Abortion, Like Prohibition, Has a Clear Racial Dimension
abstract: How long before this unpopular repression also loses favor and falls into decline?
lead_paragraph: Last week, David Frum wrote a fascinating article for The Atlantic comparing our current abortion battle to Prohibition, another contentious issue that bitterly divided the nation. After a long, “titanic” struggle, the temperance movement succeeded in imposing a nationwide ban on alcohol — only to have it decline and collapse 13 years later.

headline: Prosecutors Defend Decision to Place R. Kelly on Suicide Watch
abstract: The singer, who was given a 30-year sentence last week for sex trafficking and racketeering, is challenging the decision by jail authorities.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Saturday defended the decision to place the R&B artist R. Kelly on suicide watch at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, where he has remained since being sentenced to 30 years in federal prison for sex trafficking and racketeering.

headline: Music’s Towering Intellectual, With an Appetite for Trouble
abstract: Richard Taruskin, who died on Friday, is remembered by his former editor at The New York Times and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: His keeper, not his editor, I used to call myself in affectionate jest — and with enormous pride and respect.

headline: Argentina’s Economy Minister Abruptly Quits, Exposing Rifts in Government
abstract: Martin Guzmán had negotiated a deal to restructure $44 billion of the country’s debt. His departure threatens to destabilize an already shaken economy.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES (Reuters) — Argentina’s economy minister abruptly resigned on Saturday night, a move that threatens to further destabilize an economy already shaken by sky-high inflation, rising energy costs and growing fears over possible new defaults on debt.

headline: As City Falls, Ukraine’s Last Hope in Luhansk Falls With It
abstract: Lysychansk managed to hold out for a week after its twin city, Sievierodonetsk, was captured. But on Sunday a pro-Russian flag flew there, as well.
lead_paragraph: The last major city held by Ukraine in the heavily contested eastern province of Luhansk has fallen, military officials on both sides said Sunday, giving Moscow a milestone victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, the mineral-rich region bordering Russia that has long been in President Vladimir V. Putin’s sights.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seizes Lysychansk
abstract: Plus a heat wave engulfs Japan and transgender activists in Pakistan debate protections.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military said Sunday that it had withdrawn from the key eastern city of Lysychansk, the last city in Luhansk Province still held by Ukraine.

headline: ‘Dom Juan’ Review: The Perks of Being a Professional Hypocrite
abstract: Piety is just a pose in Ashley Tata’s gender-swapped production of Molière’s tragicomedy at Bard’s SummerScape festival.
lead_paragraph: It’s a funny feeling and not always a welcome one when a play reaches out across the centuries and punches you in the throat. This happens toward the end of “Dom Juan,” Ashley Tata’s gender-swapped production of Molière’s 1665 tragicomedy at Bard’s SummerScape festival.

headline: When It Comes Down to It
abstract: Celebrate the holiday with Bruce Haight’s patriotic puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Happy Independence Day, solvers! Today we have a puzzle from Bruce Haight, who is making his 59th appearance in the New York Times Crossword. Mr. Haight has constructed a timely and thematically appropriate puzzle to celebrate the Fourth of July.

headline: Videos of Jayland Walker Shooting by Police Raise More Questions
abstract: Mr. Walker’s family urged calm as protests continued in Akron, Ohio.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — A 25-year-old Black man who was killed last week by police officers in Akron, Ohio, suffered more than 60 gunshot wounds but was unarmed at the time, the police chief said Sunday.

headline: Australia’s new prime minister promises increased aid during visit to Ukraine.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky described the visit as the first by an Australian prime minister to his country during their history of diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: The new prime minister of Australia, Anthony Albanese, promised more military aid and more sanctions against Russia during a visit to Ukraine on Sunday that signaled continued resolve by liberal democracies to support Ukraine’s effort to rebut the Russian invasion.

headline: Jannik Sinner Beats Carlos Alcaraz in a Match Befitting the Stage
abstract: The young talents made their Centre Court debuts hours after Wimbledon celebrated the main stage’s 100th anniversary, and they provided a foil to a contentious match the day before.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It was a long weekend full of contrasts at the All England Club.

headline: In Ukraine, U.S. Veterans Step In Where the Military Will Not
abstract: Special Operations veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia, despite warnings from the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could spark a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.

headline: Mounting Flight Delays. Stranded Fliers. Airlines Struggle With Surging July 4 Demand.
abstract: Carriers were dealing with a combination of staff shortages and passenger volume that approached or in some cases exceeded prepandemic levels.
lead_paragraph: Air passengers across the United States faced extensive flight cancellations and delays this weekend, caused by a boom in travel demand coupled with widespread staffing shortages.

headline: New Insights Into Trump’s State of Mind on Jan. 6 Chip Away at Doubts
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump has weathered scandals by keeping his intentions under wraps, but recent testimony paints a stark portrait of a man willing to do almost anything to hang onto power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He was not speaking metaphorically. It was not an offhand comment. President Donald J. Trump had every intention of joining a mob of supporters he knew to be armed and dangerous as it marched to the Capitol. And there had even been talk of marching into the House chamber himself to disrupt Congress from ratifying his election defeat.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: A Russian assault on eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Lysychansk, the last major city held by Ukraine in the eastern province of Luhansk, has fallen, giving Moscow a victory in its campaign to capture the Donbas, a mineral-rich region bordering Russia. Pressure is now redoubling on the U.S. and its allies to get the more powerful weapons they have promised Ukraine to the front.

headline: The Mother of Strange Fashion
abstract: A new exhibition in Paris on the designer Elsa Schiaparelli shows how her Surrealist “little jokes” still inspire weirdness today.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A woman wears a long thermometer on a hook hanging from her ear, her chin upturned and eyes gently closed, in a photograph taken by the artist Man Ray around 1920, not long after the influenza pandemic of 1918.

headline: When Will Federer and the Williams Sisters Call It Quits? Maybe Never.
abstract: Advances in physical preparation keep their bodies in the game, and so can the changing nature of sports business and celebrity.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Most tennis professionals are retired by their mid-30s. But last week, there was Serena Williams, at almost 41, grinding against a competitor a little more than half her age for more than three hours at Wimbledon.

headline: A 2,700-Mile Cycling Race Is Now Even More Extreme
abstract: The Tour Divide, a bikepacking race from the Canadian Rockies to the U.S. border with Mexico, has always been a test of fortitude. But extreme weather is making it much more dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Latta pushed his bike forward, following the Bull River down a ridge in the Canadian Rockies. The tire tracks from riders ahead of him had disappeared.

headline: No Corrections: July 4, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 4, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Strategic Shift in Bid to Regain Abortion Rights
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 4, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “We’re in a chess game and we haven’t gotten checkmate. We’re doing check, check, check, check. Unfortunately, we’re doing check, check, check with pregnant people and their families’ lives.”

headline: The Founders Bequeathed Us Something Radical
abstract: Why a culture that has bred cynicism and placed a premium on the performance of virtue is in need of new ideas to build a better America.
lead_paragraph: The heart does not exactly swell with patriotic pride this Independence Day, as the gut absorbs one dizzying, disorienting blow after the next. Our sense of who we are, our very identity as Americans, feels assaulted and violated. Amid profound, painful regression on issue after issue, we are left gasping for breath.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Macy’s Fireworks and ‘America Outdoors With Baratunde Thurston’
abstract: The annual fireworks display airs on NBC. And a new outdoor adventure series has its debut on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: The World Needs More Than Crumbs From the G7’s Table
abstract: The Group of 7 missed a chance to act, but it’s not too late.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 7 summit in Germany ended last week with leaders of the world’s richest countries pledging to support Ukraine for “as long as it takes.”

headline: Longing for Roger Federer at Wimbledon
abstract: Federer said he hoped to return to the tournament he has won eight times before. His absence from the field this year left a void over Wimbledon’s early rounds.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — There he was, a surprise, perhaps the biggest of this Wimbledon fortnight: Roger Federer in the flesh Sunday on Centre Court.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A ‘Moral Role in Society’ and Little Enforcement? You Have This Reporter’s Attention.
abstract: David Fahrenthold of The Times discusses why the world of nonprofit charities is prime for investigative reporting.
lead_paragraph: In 2017, David Fahrenthold, who was working for The Washington Post at the time, won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on the Donald J. Trump Foundation’s misappropriation of charitable funds. (Two years later, President Trump had to pay $2 million to a group of charities as part of a settlement.) Exploring — and scrutinizing, when appropriate — the world of charities made Mr. Fahrenthold interested in diving even deeper, and in January, he joined The New York Times to investigate nonprofit organizations. He reported in May that a little-known United Nations agency had doled out millions of dollars in questionable grants and loans. His latest article, which he worked on with the Times journalists Julie Tate and Troy Closson, is about one man who was accused by prosecutors of operating a long-running charity fraud and getting dozens of fake charities approved by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Mall Shooting Shocks Denmark on a Joyful Summer Weekend
abstract: The suspect in the attack that killed 3 people was known to mental health services, the police said, and the victims appeared to be random.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — It was a festive weekend in Denmark, as Danes cheered on the unusual spectacle of the Tour de France starting in their country, listened to the Strokes at the Roskilde music festival, and hiked, picnicked, shopped and enjoyed the summer sun.

headline: America Is Failing Refugees, and Itself
abstract: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.
lead_paragraph: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.

headline: In a Post-Roe World, We Can Avoid Pitting Mothers Against Babies
abstract: Especially in hard cases like ectopic pregnancy, we can offer more love and material support to mothers and children.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, states face a new reality about where to draw the line in pregnancy for when abortion is permitted. In these debates, ectopic pregnancy is a key issue.

headline: Meet Joan of Arc, Action Hero
abstract: In her new novel, Katherine Chen puts a fresh spin on the oft-examined life of the girl who saved France.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to name a historical figure who has inspired more writers than Joan of Arc. Yet it’s equally difficult to imagine a character more incomprehensible to the modern ear than the 15th-century French mystic, martyr and war hero.

headline: America Is Failing Refugees, and Itself
abstract: How the United States treats refugees is one of the greatest tests of the American experiment.

headline: In This Debut Novel, Family Ties Bind, Even From Afar
abstract: Taymour Soomro’s “Other Names for Love” is about a Pakistani teenager sent abroad to be educated who does not want to come back, even when sorely needed.
lead_paragraph: One of the great things about writing is that, in the end, it doesn’t matter where you came from or went to school. Walt Whitman, Jessica Mitford, Truman Capote, Maya Angelou and Hart Crane had not a semester of college between them.

headline: How Can We Still Be Talking About Trump?
abstract: Biden can’t possibly like the chatter about him, either.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Happy Independence Day, Bret! Want to celebrate by talking about the Supreme Court?

headline: Our Gun Myths Have Held America Hostage for Too Long
abstract: Proponents of gun reform in this country are up against more than a powerful gun lobby. They are up against our most durable national myth.
lead_paragraph: Like so many Americans, I have been called into relationships with guns since I was a child and have been made to understand, even long before I could articulate it, that guns represented something essential about what it means to become a fully realized American man.

headline: Updated Covid Shots Are Coming. Will They Be Too Late?
abstract: The government has greenlit new vaccines to defend against the latest Omicron variants. But the shots won’t arrive until the fall, and cases are rising now.
lead_paragraph: Roseann Renouf, 77, has grown tired of the current generation of coronavirus shots. Having “never been one for a lot of vaccination,” she decided to forgo the latest round of boosters after watching vaccinated friends contract Covid-19, even though the doses offer a critical extra layer of protection.

headline: Keep Czars Far Away, in Moscow or Mar-a-Lago
abstract: Things worth fighting for on the Fourth of July.
lead_paragraph: A great-grandfather on my mother’s side had a big mouth. The trait seems to run in the family.

headline: Two Homes That Nourish a Family’s Many Creative Pursuits
abstract: A businesswoman with a husband, three children, three restaurants and a publishing venture has a home upstate and a studio in Manhattan to make it all work.
lead_paragraph: Before Hurricane Sandy, Nhi Mundy had a good life in the financial district with her family. She and her husband, Michael Mundy, were raising three children while he worked as a photographer and she partnered with him to start “An Afternoon With,” a blog that featured intimate images of individuals and families in their homes.

headline: A Refreshing Look at Egypt’s Ancient Pyramids
abstract: A downpour, a dust storm and an encounter with a lively dig team offered a photographer a new perspective on the country’s celebrated tombs.
lead_paragraph: “Yallah, yallah, yallah! Woooo!”

headline: Nazi Tapes Provide a Chilling Sequel to the Eichmann Trial
abstract: Sixty years after the execution of Adolf Eichmann, the logistics chief of the Holocaust, an Israeli documentary airs his confessions in his own voice.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Six decades after the historic trial in Jerusalem of Adolf Eichmann, one of the chief engineers of the Holocaust, a new Israeli documentary series has delivered a dramatic coda: the boastful confessions of the Nazi war criminal, in his own voice.

headline: Army Bases That Honor Confederate Traitors Could Soon Be Renamed for These Heroes
abstract: The names “embody the best of the United States Army and America,” a commission established by Congress wrote in announcing its choices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the Jim Crow era, nine Southern Army bases were named for treasonous Confederate generals who fought to preserve slavery and white supremacy. Now a commission established by Congress has suggested new names for the bases that “embody the best of the United States Army and America.”

headline: A Damp Independence Day Weekend Continues for Much of the Country
abstract: Heavy rainfall and thunderstorms are in the forecast for a large portion of the United States, with the potential for hail the size of golf balls in Montana.
lead_paragraph: A mixed bag of severe weather and dangerously hot temperatures was expected for parts of the United States on Independence Day, after Tropical Storm Colin doused the Carolinas over the weekend.

headline: At Nathan’s Hot Dog Contest, One Champion Keeps His Title and Another Reclaims Hers
abstract: Joey Chestnut secured his 15th win, while Miki Sudo won back her title in the women’s contest after sitting out in 2021 to have a baby.
lead_paragraph: One competitor won his 15th contest and another reclaimed her title as the world’s top ranked female eater during the Nathan’s Famous International Hot Dog Eating Contest on Monday.

headline: Chosen Families
abstract: Spending the holiday with those who support you.
lead_paragraph: Today, as we observe the Fourth of July holiday in the U.S., I’m thinking about the permutations of family, the people we invite to the cookout, the ones we’ll be watching the fireworks with. Perhaps you’ll be with your parents and siblings, your kids, your kids’ kids. Perhaps you’ll gather with close friends, with neighbors, reunite with your pandemic pod.

headline: Five Years After Vanishing, Chinese Canadian Billionaire Faces Trial
abstract: The case against the financier Xiao Jianhua is widely seen as part of a crackdown on the debt-fueled excess that drove China’s economic growth.
lead_paragraph: More than five years after his mysterious disappearance from a luxury hotel in Hong Kong, a Chinese Canadian billionaire and onetime trusted financier to China’s political elite has been put on trial in a case that epitomizes the ruling Communist Party’s efforts to rein in an earlier era of freewheeling capitalism.

headline: Kool & the Gang Get the Dance Floor Moving. Have They Gotten Their Due?
abstract: The group’s funk, disco and pop songs have been sampled over 1,800 times, but haven’t collected the same accolades as many contemporaries. A new boxed set takes a look back.
lead_paragraph: “Do something,” the producer Gene Redd instructed the drummer George Brown and the saxophonist Ronald Khalis Bell during an early recording session in New York. “Say something! Sing something.”

headline: $2.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.

headline: $2.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A four-bedroom house in San Diego, a three-bedroom condominium in San Francisco and a 1929 Spanish-style home in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: This house is 10 minutes from Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve, 1,750 acres of rugged coastline with a lagoon and walking trails that draw locals and tourists. Also nearby is Torrey Pines State Beach, a public beach popular with surfers, and Torrey Pines Golf Course, the site of regular PGA Tour events.

headline: The Mets May Finally Get Their Aces Back
abstract: Jacob deGrom’s first rehab start went well, and Max Scherzer is slated to return to the starting rotation on Tuesday. Will that be enough to offset an offensive downturn?
lead_paragraph: The struggling Mets got yet another dose of optimism on Sunday when Jacob deGrom, the team’s co-ace who has been sidelined all season, struck out five of the six batters he faced in a rehab start for Class A St. Lucie.

headline: Macron Adjusts His Cabinet, Seeking a Fresh Start
abstract: The new appointments by President Emmanuel Macron of France are unlikely to help him push his agenda through a fragmented lower house of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Emmanuel Macron of France lightly shuffled his cabinet on Monday in a bid to jump start his second term, weeks after elections that significantly weakened his parliamentary majority and bolstered his political opponents.

headline: Bullet Too Damaged to Prove Who Killed Palestinian American Journalist, U.S. Says
