abstract: The State Department said Shireen Abu Akleh, the Al Jazeera broadcaster killed in the West Bank in May, was likely hit by shots fired from Israeli military positions.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The bullet that killed Shireen Abu Akleh, the Palestinian American journalist shot in the occupied West Bank in May, was most likely fired from Israeli military lines but was too damaged to say for sure, the State Department said on Monday.

headline: The Problem Decoded
abstract: The problem can now be solved on the original board.
lead_paragraph: The problem can now be solved on the original board.

headline: Recasting the Problem
abstract: June Huh found this problem much easier to solve.
lead_paragraph: June Huh found this problem much easier to solve.

headline: Where the Risks of Pregnancy Meet Abortion Laws and Health Care
abstract: Even before the wave of abortion bans, medical treatment and advice for pregnancy has largely focused on fetal safety over the mother’s.
lead_paragraph: As the United States has grappled with the unfolding consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overruling Roe v. Wade, one question lurks between the lines of court opinions and news stories alike: Why are the risks of pregnancy so rarely discussed anywhere, even though that information is relevant not just to individual decisions but to policies about abortion, pregnancy, and health care for women?

headline: A spate of arrests suggests the Kremlin is further clamping down on dissent.
abstract: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.
lead_paragraph: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.

headline: A Last-Minute Menu for the Fourth
abstract: Enjoy Hawaiian mac salad alongside burgers, grilled vegetables or huli huli chicken.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I remember a Fourth of July a few years ago when I flew into New York in the evening, and I could see fireworks all over the surrounding counties on the approach to the airport: soundless explosions of twinkling lights, beautiful and maybe even moving. (Emotions are heightened on planes.) When I got home, I made myself a hot dog and ate it with a glass of Champagne. Independence!

headline: ‘Swimming Wasn’t for Us’
abstract: The nation’s first Black-owned pool club aims to teach hundreds of children to swim this summer, helping to close a dangerous racial gap in the process.
lead_paragraph: YEADON, Pa. — On a hot summer afternoon in 1959, hundreds of Black families in this little town just outside Philadelphia gathered on Union Avenue to cool off and make some history.

headline: What I Learned While Talking to Strangers
abstract: Encounters with strangers; U.S. policy in Asia; what the police need; living in nature; artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A joyful July Fourth event turns into a scramble to survive.
abstract: Crowds of people fled, and officials in the Chicago suburb canceled festivities. It was unclear if anyone had been injured.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — It sounded at first like fireworks to the parents who had brought excited children to a charming Fourth of July parade in their town. Or perhaps a military salute to the flag.

headline: No Guns, No Dragons: Her Video Games Capture Private Moments
abstract: Nina Freeman, a leading indie game designer, infuses her work with a poetic sensibility far from the tone of mainstream shoot-’em-ups.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Ipswich, Mass., Nina Freeman spent a lot of time playing video games with a pair of close friends, twin sisters whose basement served as an arena for marathon sessions. “My friends and I were nerds,” she recalled. “We played a lot of games. ‘Final Fantasy 11’ was like a second life to me.”

headline: Germany Posts First Monthly Trade Deficit in 30 Years
abstract: High energy prices and disrupted supply chains dent the image of “Made in Germany,” as May imports exceeded exports for the first time in decades.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — For the first time in more than three decades, Germany has posted a monthly trade deficit, the most recent sign that Europe’s largest economy is facing stress because of interrupted supply chains and record energy prices linked to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Kurt Markus, Photographer of Cowboys and Models, Is Dead at 75
abstract: He traveled the world and shot celebrities and fashion luminaries. But he never abandoned his roots in the open spaces of the American West.
lead_paragraph: The award-winning photographer Kurt Markus led a life and career that seemed as vast and varied as the Western landscapes he captured on film.

headline: What Becomes a Star Most? For Tom Cruise, It’s Control.
abstract: Sheer force of will is now part of his potent mix of athleticism and charisma. That combination goes a long way to explain why “Top Gun: Maverick” is a hit.
lead_paragraph: “In order to do my job,” Ben Stiller, as Tom Cruise’s stunt double Tom Crooze, muses in a video made for the 2000 MTV Movie Awards, “I have to ask myself: Who is Tom Cruise? What is Tom Cruise? Why is Tom … Cruise?”

headline: For Francis, a Papacy Complicated by the Shadow of Resignation
abstract: Benedict’s exit changed expectations that the papacy would always be a lifetime assignment, fueling speculation the current pope has tried to push away.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Over the last few weeks, close watchers of the Roman Catholic Church have carefully studied shadows on the Vatican walls for proof that Pope Francis is about to retire.

headline: Shooting at Fourth of July Parade Leaves Several Dead
abstract: Police said multiple people were killed and dozens were wounded after a gunman opened fire from a rooftop onto a parade in Highland Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Police said multiple people were killed and dozens were wounded after a gunman opened fire from a rooftop onto a parade in Highland Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago.

headline: She Inspired ‘A League of Their Own.’ At 95, She’s Far From Done.
abstract: Maybelle Blair is still dedicated to including women and girls in baseball. And she still loves the “clicketyclack” sound of baseball cleats on her feet.
lead_paragraph: Maybelle Blair walked into a sporting goods store in her early 90s with a mission: to try on a pair of spikes.

headline: How to Protect Bristol Bay’s Salmon for the Long Haul
abstract: E.P.A. action, legislation and land conservation together can permanently protect Alaska’s Bristol Bay, the salmon and a way of life.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Bristol Bay is a place defined by salmon. For those of us who live and work in this region of wetlands, rivers and tundra, our lives revolve around this amazing fish. This spring the Environmental Protection Agency proposed a ban on the disposal of mining waste — a widely celebrated move to protect the bay and its salmon from the infamous Pebble Mine project, which has sought to extract precious metals from beneath the bay for decades. But this ban, while powerful, will not, on its own, fully protect Bristol Bay if it’s approved.

headline: In Putin’s Russia, the Arrests Are Spreading Quickly and Widely
abstract: One by one, Russians deemed insufficiently patriotic are being snatched up by security forces as the Kremlin tightens the noose.
lead_paragraph: They came for Dmitri Kolker, an ailing physicist, in the intensive care ward. They came for Ivan Fedotov, a hockey star, as he was leaving practice with a film crew in tow. They came for Vladimir Mau, a state university rector, the week he was re-elected to the board of Gazprom.

headline: The Nick Kyrgios Show, Also Known as Wimbledon, Gets Another Encore
abstract: Kyrgios, the big, talented Australian, has taken over Wimbledon with his antics and psychological warfare. It’s working.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Going up against the tennis talents of Nick Kyrgios, the powerful Australian with hands as soft as a masseuse’s, is plenty difficult in its own right.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Mass Shooting Near Chicago
abstract: Plus Russia regroups in the east and China arrests a mysterious tycoon.
lead_paragraph: At least six people have been killed in a mass shooting at an Independence Day parade in Highland Park, Ill., an affluent, mostly white suburb north of Chicago. The police said at least two dozen more people were injured yesterday. Here are live updates on the shooting.

headline: Clifford L. Alexander, Adviser to Presidents, Is Dead at 88
abstract: He was the first Black secretary of the Army — just one of many jobs, both high- and low-profile, that he held over nearly 20 years in government.
lead_paragraph: Clifford L. Alexander Jr., whose long career as a leading adviser to Democratic presidents ranged from working behind the scenes on landmark legislation like the Voting Rights Act to high-profile roles like serving as the first Black secretary of the Army, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Zhang Sizhi, Lawyer Who Defended Chinese Dissidents, Dies at 94
abstract: He shed tears over the challenge of defending clients in a system stacked against them. But even in defeat, admirers said, he set a lasting example.
lead_paragraph: Zhang Sizhi, a Chinese lawyer who defended politically contentious clients, including Mao Zedong’s underlings, Tiananmen-era dissidents, purged officials and victims of police frame-ups, inspiring generations of human rights lawyers with his advocacy, died on June 24 in Beijing. He was 94.

headline: Russia Advances Behind Brutal Barrage, but Will Its Strategy Keep Working?
abstract: The Russian and Ukrainian armies have both been badly mauled, raising questions about how long they can keep fighting as they have, particularly the outgunned Ukrainians.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s capture of the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, a significant victory for Moscow’s campaign to conquer eastern Ukraine, demonstrates the success of the Russian military’s grinding strategy based on superior firepower and incremental advances.

headline: Joe Turkel, the Spectral Bartender in ‘The Shining,’ Dies at 94
abstract: Also memorably seen in “Blade Runner,” he was a favorite among directors looking for someone who could bring zealous professionalism to even the smallest role.
lead_paragraph: Joe Turkel, a gaunt-faced yeoman character actor who appeared in scores of movies but is best known for two of his final performances — as Lloyd the bartender in “The Shining” and Dr. Eldon Tyrell in “Blade Runner” — died on June 27 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.

headline: Another Step Toward Climate Apocalypse
abstract: The Supreme Court does its bit to make the earth unlivable.
lead_paragraph: We’re having a heat wave, a tropical heat wave. Also a temperate heat wave and an Arctic heat wave, with temperatures reaching the high 80s in northern Norway. The megadrought in the Western United States has reduced Lake Mead to a small fraction of its former size, and it now threatens to become a “dead pool” that can no longer supply water to major cities. Climate change is already doing immense damage, and it’s probably only a matter of time before we experience huge catastrophes that take thousands of lives.

headline: Highland Park Victim Was a Grandfather Who Hadn’t Wanted to Attend the Parade
abstract: Nicolas Toledo was sitting in his wheelchair along the parade route, between his son and a nephew, when the bullets started flying.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Toledo, 76, didn’t want to attend the Highland Park July 4th parade, but his disabilities required that he be around someone full-time. And the family wasn’t going to skip the parade — even going so far as positioning chairs for a choice viewing spot at midnight the night before.

headline: Brittney Griner to Biden: ‘I’m Terrified I Might Be Here Forever’
abstract: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, sent a letter to President Biden on Monday, asking him to help free her from prison in Russia. She has been in custody since February.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, sent a handwritten letter to President Biden on Monday asking him not to forget about her.

headline: As Young Blood Enters South Korean Politics, New (and Old) Barriers Emerge
abstract: A new law allowed a record number of young people to run in local elections this year. But they face skepticism, cultural hurdles and problems as old as politics itself.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — Jung Seong-hoon, 22, shared the frustrations of young South Koreans looking at a bleak future: Jobs are scarce, rent is high, and debt is climbing. So last month, he ran for a spot on his local city legislature and won.

headline: The attack in Highland Park was not the only shooting over a violent holiday weekend.
abstract: As of early Monday morning, at least 57 people had been shot in Chicago alone over the Fourth of July weekend, nine of them fatally.
lead_paragraph: The attack at the Highland Park Fourth of July parade was the largest and highest-profile shooting, but far from the only one, over the holiday weekend.

headline: Mischievous Creature of Folklore
abstract: Malgorzata Nowakowska and Eileen Williams constructed this puzzle all too well.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to the crossword-constructing duo Malgorzata Nowakowska and Eileen Williams, who are both medical students making their New York Times debut today with a puzzle that pays tribute to an artist whose way with words makes her the perfect subject for a crossword.

headline: When the Czarinas Ruled the Front Row
abstract: A group of Russian women were once the hottest things at couture, embraced not just by fashion, but by the watching world. Where are they now?
lead_paragraph: Around this time just over a decade ago something happened in fashion that was as rare and unexpected as the sight of Kate Moss in a tutu.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Russia’s tightening grip in the Donbas.
lead_paragraph: After Russia’s capture of the cities of Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, Moscow controls the Luhansk province in eastern Ukraine. The Russian military relies on its superior firepower and on making grinding incremental advances — a strategy that is paying off.

headline: In Wimbledon’s Queue, Waiting Is a Pleasure, and the Point
abstract: In a world of online ticketing, camping overnight for tennis seats is an anachronism, but it is also about community and a sense of belonging.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It was nearing 10 p.m., and Richard Hess, an 81-year-old American, was sitting inside his small tent and merrily preparing for his latest sleep-deprived night in the Wimbledon queue.

headline: ‘Get the Stretcher!’ Life and Death on Ukraine’s Front Line
abstract: On another day of scorched-earth artillery barrages in the east, a team of Ukrainian medics did their best to stabilize and assure the survivors, with the din of war all around.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Between the cracks of mortar fire and the metallic bangs of Russian self-detonating mines, Yurii, a Ukrainian Army medic, readied an intravenous line for the soldier sprawled on the stretcher below him.

headline: Is Liz Cheney Politically Brave? Joe Manchin? Mike Pence? 10 Voters Debate Courage.
abstract: Ten Americans talked about leadership and bravery — or the lack of it — in politics today.
lead_paragraph: Ten Americans talked about leadership and bravery — or the lack of it — in politics today.

headline: Israel’s Coalition Didn’t Fail. It Set a New Bar.
abstract: The departing coalition was created out of necessity — it was the only path to unseat Benjamin Netanyahu — but it almost immediately came under vicious attack.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV —  There’s little joy in witnessing one of the most intriguing political experiments of Israel’s recent history come to an end.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Russia Advances in East, but Win Takes Harsh Toll
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “There is a problem with ammunition. For example, for our one shot, they would fire 50 shots. How can you fight this?”

headline: No Corrections: July 5, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, July 5, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Ukraine’s prime minister says rebuilding will cost $750 billion.
abstract: World leaders are mapping out the monumental effort to restore a war-battered nation.
lead_paragraph: For Ukrainians living through war, the cost of the conflict is hard to measure: Thousands of people killed, countless homes and buildings destroyed by missiles, families displaced, livelihoods lost. But international leaders are gathering in the lakeside Swiss town of Lugano for a second day on Tuesday in an attempt to do just that.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Amid Scrutiny of N.Y.P.D.’s Sex Crimes Unit, Discipline for Two Former Supervisors
abstract: Inspector Paul J. Saraceno and Sergeant Keri L. Thompson of the Special Victims Division admitted to misconduct and were removed from their posts.
lead_paragraph: Two former supervisors in the New York Police Department’s troubled sex-crimes division were disciplined in recent months amid an internal affairs investigation into misconduct by the unit’s leadership, according to department records posted online.

headline: Has Biden’s Top Diplomat in Mexico Gone Too Far, Officials Ask?
abstract: Administration officials fear that the U.S. ambassador’s cozy relationship with the Mexican president has backfired, and may be setting back American interests in the region.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s election czar delivered a message to the American ambassador: The Mexican president was mounting an all-out assault on the national elections authority, sowing doubt about a pillar of the country’s democracy.

headline: Britain Gears Up for a Summer of Labor Discontent
abstract: With energy costs and inflation surging, and taxes and the cost of loans increasing, British workers are demanding higher pay and going on strike with a militancy not seen in years.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was one of the more unusual public displays in a city long used to noisy and colorful demonstrations: protesters wearing flowing black gowns and curled horsehair wigs waving placards on Monday outside a London courthouse.

headline: On Conservative Radio, Misleading Message Is Clear: ‘Democrats Cheat’
abstract: Election fraud claims from 2020 are widespread on talk radio, contributing to the belief that the midterm results cannot be trusted.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Nuclear Power Gets New Push in U.S., Winning Converts
abstract: With challenges in meeting clean energy goals and new electricity demands, politicians in both parties seek to prolong and even expand reactor use.
lead_paragraph: Driven by the difficulty of meeting clean energy goals and by surging electricity demands, a growing number of political leaders are taking a fresh look at nuclear power — both extending the life of existing reactors and building new ones.

headline: Will the Abortion Debate Keep Moderate Women in the Democrats’ Camp?
abstract: Worried about inflation and dissatisfied with President Biden, many moderate women have been drifting away from Democrats. Now the party hopes the fight for abortion rights will drive them back.
lead_paragraph: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — As Gov. Gretchen Whitmer prepared to kick off a round-table discussion about abortion rights at a brewery recently, Alisha Meneely sat at one corner of the table, feeling politically abandoned.

headline: An Embattled N.Y.P.D. Unit
abstract: It turns out that two supervisors of the Special Victims Division were disciplined in recent months amid an internal affairs investigation into misconduct by the department’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll take another look at the Police Department’s embattled Special Victims Division. We’ll also meet a dinosaur that was found in Montana and will be auctioned in Manhattan at the end of the month.

headline: June Huh’s monochrome chess puzzle paved the way for chromatic geometry.
abstract: He wanted to be a poet, then a science journalist. Only in his last year in college did Dr. Huh discover math as a calling.
lead_paragraph: Most top mathematicians discovered the subject when they were young, often excelling in international competitions.

headline: Maryna Viazovska: Second to none in any dimension.
abstract: Dr. Viazovska works on a variation of a conjecture introduced 400 years ago by Johannes Kepler, and she is the second woman to win the Fields Medal.
lead_paragraph: Maryna Viazovska, a Ukrainian who is now a professor at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne, is known for proofs for higher-dimensional equivalents of the stacking of equal- sized spheres. She is also only the second woman ever to win the Fields Medal.

headline: Can Fashion Still Shock?
abstract: From trompe l’oeil to the metaverse, Schiaparelli, Dior and Iris van Herpen offer some answers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — What’s shocking now?

headline: U.S. veterans are training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia.
abstract: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could incite a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.
lead_paragraph: A democracy came under attack. The United States saw a threat to an ally and also to the entire world order, but it feared that sending troops could incite a nuclear war. So, instead, it supplied weapons. And a small number of American Special Operations trainers started quietly working with the local military.

headline: As BA.5 becomes dominant among new U.S. cases, reduced state reporting is blurring the real-time look at the virus.
abstract: As states report less frequently, changes in the trajectory of the virus are slower to reveal themselves.
lead_paragraph: At a glance, the pandemic picture in the United States may seem remarkably stable. The average number of new confirmed coronavirus cases per day has hardly budged for weeks, hovering between 95,000 and 115,000 a day each day in June.

headline: Krista Tippett Wants You to See All the Hidden Signs of Hope
abstract: “I see the damage and the pain,” says the longtime host of “On Being.” “I also see people tending to that.”
lead_paragraph: “I see the damage and the pain,” says the longtime host of “On Being.” “I also see people tending to that.”

headline: How to Ask a Stranger For Help
abstract: It might feel socially risky, but ask anyway. Keep your request simple and direct.
lead_paragraph: “Asking for help is hardly ever as bad as you imagine it will be,” says Vanessa Bohns, a social psychologist and associate professor of organizational behavior at Cornell University. For research purposes, she and colleagues have sent help-seekers out into cities all over the world to request things from 15,000 strangers. Appealing for assistance “feels socially risky,” Bohns says. Ask anyway. When asked for help, most people are happy to comply. “We are a social species,” Bohns says. “We default to being agreeable rather than disagreeable.”

headline: I’m a High-Risk Obstetrician, and I’m Terrified for My Patients
abstract: A high-risk obstetrician explains what his patients will have to endure.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I practice in medical fields — obstetrics and pediatrics — that should be filled with happiness. And often they are, though we have selected sub-specialties that are often shrouded in sadness — high-risk obstetrics for me, and pediatric oncology for my wife. We have both watched children die while held in their mother’s arms.

headline: Forbidden Art and Star-Crossed Lovers in ‘The Earthspinner’
abstract: In Anuradha Roy’s latest novel, several lives are shattered after the creation of a ceramic sculpture in 1970s India.
lead_paragraph: “What just happened?” I found myself asking aloud upon coming to the end of “The Earthspinner,” Anuradha Roy’s fifth novel. For several days after reading, I held on to a pinching disappointment — the novel closes without resolve, and I found myself returning to the book, wondering why Roy had built a world of such rich possibilities just to leave so many unrealized. Little did I know that this was just the beginning of what would become a complicated journey with the novel, leading me to a deep gratitude for this work.

headline: Liberals Need a Clearer Vision of the Constitution. Here’s What It Could Look Like.
abstract: The legal scholar Larry Kramer on why the left’s embrace of judicial supremacy was a mistake.
lead_paragraph: For decades now, the conservative legal movement has been on a mission to remake this nation’s laws from the bench. And it’s working. On Friday we released an episode with the legal scholar Kate Shaw that walked through case after case showing how conservative Supreme Court majorities have lurched this country’s laws to the right on guns, voting, gerrymandering, regulatory authority, unions, campaign finance and more in the past 20 years. And if the Dobbs majority is any indication, this rightward shift is just getting started.

headline: How Gun Violence Changed My Father, Ronald Reagan, and Our Family
abstract: There are people in America who want the rest of us to be afraid. History shows that every democracy that has crumbled did so in an atmosphere of fear.
lead_paragraph: Forty-one years ago, on a cold, drizzly day in Washington, four people were shot by a young man who had concealed a gun in his jacket. This was long before mass shootings became a frequent reality of our lives. It was long before semiautomatic weapons became commonplace. There were many “good people with guns” there that day. It made no difference. Four men were shot in a matter of seconds. I am the daughter of one of those men, Ronald Reagan, who came incredibly close to losing his life because the bullets John Hinckley loaded into his gun were devastator bullets, meant to fragment. Meant to kill more efficiently. One of those bullets blew apart James Brady’s head; he was never the same.

headline: In This Novel, America and the Weather Are Both Extreme
abstract: In Bruce Holsinger’s latest novel, “The Displacements,” the world’s first Category 6 hurricane prompts a reckoning.
lead_paragraph: The novel of future catastrophe tends to create some distance between where we are now, where we have been and where we are afraid we might be heading. Margaret Atwood has said that she put nothing in her 1985 dystopian classic, “The Handmaid’s Tale,” that hadn’t already happened. Octavia Butler claimed she was partly inspired by her news-junkie ways to write “Parable of the Sower” (1993) but had hoped it would never have the ring of prophecy. In J.G. Ballard’s 1962 novel, “The Drowned World,” which is set in 2145, the author imagined a punishing climate in which the icecaps have completely melted, and where, for the humans left to study them, “the vast swamps and jungles had been a fabulous laboratory, the submerged cities little more than elaborate pedestals.”

headline: As Her Album Takes Off, a Musician Struggles to Get Pregnant
abstract: In “Human Blues,” Elisa Albert explores the lengths one woman will go to for a baby.
lead_paragraph: A musician friend once spent hours in a greenroom with Robin Williams. He said Williams started riffing, and that was it. No one spoke and everyone watched, amazed at the ferocity and speed with which his brain spun out like a racecar on an oil slick.

headline: My Wife and I Lied About Our Son’s Death. Can I Come Clean if She Won’t?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on revealing a family secret, complaining about a tour guide and more.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, my son died from an accidental overdose when he took a fentanyl-laced pill. When we got the autopsy report, his mother (we are divorced) wanted to keep the cause of his death a secret. I was reluctant, but in the throes of grief did not make a stand for the truth. We lied and said his death was due to a bad heart.

headline: Christian Nationalists Are Excited About What Comes Next
abstract: The way the movement’s leaders see it, Dobbs is just a way station.
lead_paragraph: The shape of the Christian nationalist movement in the post-Roe future is coming into view, and it should terrify anyone concerned for the future of constitutional democracy.

headline: Is Makeup Messing Up My Sunscreen?
abstract: There’s good news and bad news when it comes to sun protection and cosmetics.
lead_paragraph: Q: I wear a full face of makeup on top of a layer of sunscreen each day. Does that diminish my protection from UV rays?

headline: His PTSD, and My Struggle to Live With It
abstract: After my partner was brutally beaten on the street, I became one of the many thousands of Americans caring for someone with post-traumatic stress disorder — and our relationship changed forever.
lead_paragraph: The night our world changed, I was in a copper baron’s palatial Adirondack home, writing about the history of the poorhouse. That afternoon, with the stained-glass reflections of autumn colors blazing through my window, I pored over an 1832 vendue contract auctioning the care of three female paupers to the lowest bidder in Sandown, N.H.

headline: Famous for Happiness, and Limits on Tourism, Bhutan Will Triple Fees to Visit
abstract: As Venice and other European hot spots explore permit systems and daily fees to limit the number of tourists, the tiny Buddhist kingdom will require a $200 tax on international visitors when it reopens this fall.
lead_paragraph: The tiny Buddhist kingdom of Bhutan on the eastern edge of the Himalayas, often referred to as “the last Shangri-La” for its abundance of natural beauty, sustainable development and rich cultural heritage, has long resisted the quick financial returns of mass tourism in favor of conservation. The approach is aligned with a cultural philosophy where the country’s wealth and prosperity is measured, through a national happiness index, as an alternative to the gross domestic product.

headline: How Wall Street Escaped the Crypto Meltdown
abstract: As cryptocurrency prices plunged and funds failed, strict rules on risky assets helped Wall Street companies sidestep the worst. Retail investors weren’t as lucky.
lead_paragraph: Last November, in the midst of an exuberant cryptocurrency market, analysts at BNP Paribas, a French bank with a Wall Street presence, pulled together a list of 50 stocks they thought were overpriced — including many with strong links to digital assets.

headline: Veterans of Carter-Era Inflation Warn That Biden Has Few Tools to Tame Prices
abstract: President Biden and Democrats face political peril as costs keep rising and midterm elections loom.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When inflation surged in the late 1970s, President Jimmy Carter convened his top economic advisers for weekly lunch meetings in which they tended to offer overly optimistic forecasts of how high prices would rise.

headline: An N.F.L. Star’s C.T.E. Diagnosis Offers Only Partial Insight
abstract: Demaryius Thomas had C.T.E. when he died in December at 33, but the posthumous diagnosis alone does not explain what role football had in the charismatic N.F.L. star’s quick decline.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ga. — Demaryius Thomas’s parents see their son every day.

headline: Lonely Last Days in the Suburban Office Park
abstract: Yes, downtown offices are struggling. But there is a different kind of emptiness in suburban settings that were already isolated and lightly populated by design.
lead_paragraph: The wooded campus that once housed the global headquarters of Toys “R” Us in Wayne, N.J., is 85 percent vacant today. On a weekday, the parking spots for 1,900 cars are mostly empty. The helipad is unused. So is the corporate dining hall, with its views of the serene grounds. Hundreds of cubicles — the spacious old-school kind with the high walls, not the little hot desks popular with employers today — sit empty as the property awaits redevelopment into something entirely new.

headline: What We Know About the Shooting in Highland Park
abstract: Prosecutors lodged first-degree murder charges on Tuesday against a suspect who was taken into custody Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: A gunman shooting from a rooftop killed seven people and wounded dozens more during a Fourth of July celebration in Highland Park, Ill., on Monday morning. A 21-year-old man who was taken into custody Monday evening after an extensive manhunt was charged on Tuesday with seven counts of first-degree murder.

headline: The Promises and Pitfalls of the New Gun Law
abstract: After yet another mass shooting, will the bipartisan legislation actually work?
lead_paragraph: President Biden has heralded the recent gun safety bill as the most significant federal attempt to reduce gun violence in 30 years.

headline: A Bluer Picture
abstract: The midterm campaigns for the House and the Senate are shaping up quite differently.
lead_paragraph: The midterm polls continue to look dark for Democrats, as we explained in a newsletter last week. Inflation and Covid disruptions, as well as the normal challenges that a president’s party faces in midterms, are weighing on the party. As a result, the Republicans are heavily favored to retake control of the House.

headline: Covid Outbreak Emerges in China’s Anhui Province
abstract: The country recently began to recover from a surge that shut down Shanghai for two months.
lead_paragraph: As China gradually emerges from a Covid-19 surge that shut down Shanghai for two months, an outbreak in eastern Anhui Province is posing a new challenge to efforts to balance economic growth with the government’s “zero Covid” policy.

headline: SAS, the Scandinavian airline, files for bankruptcy protection after pilots strike.
abstract: The carrier’s woes are part of a summer full of problems for Europe’s travel industry, including staffing shortages and walkouts by fed-up employees.
lead_paragraph: A day after its pilots went on strike, SAS, the Scandinavian airline, said on Tuesday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States, the latest reverberation in a summer of turmoil for European airlines.

headline: Russia turns its attention to Donetsk Province as it prepares for the next major offensive of the war.
abstract: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — With Luhansk Province firmly in Russia’s grasp after weeks of brutal fighting, the country’s military forces were already setting their sights on the next target. On the outskirts of Bakhmut, a key supply hub for Ukrainian forces, the Russian Army was ramping up its shelling as an apparent prelude for an inch-by-inch offensive into the province of Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — With Luhansk Province firmly in Russia’s grasp after weeks of brutal fighting, the country’s military forces were already setting their sights on the next target. On the outskirts of Bakhmut, a key supply hub for Ukrainian forces, the Russian Army was ramping up its shelling as an apparent prelude for an inch-by-inch offensive into the province of Donetsk.

headline: For U.S. Women’s Team, One Tournament Offers Two Prizes
abstract: The Americans can qualify for the 2023 Women’s World Cup and the 2024 Olympics by winning a regional championship. Their first step was a win over Haiti.
lead_paragraph: The Women’s World Cup is a year away and the Paris Olympics don’t start for more than two, but both tournaments are the primary focus of the United States women’s national team over the next two weeks.

headline: Twitter, Challenging Orders to Remove Content, Sues India’s Government
abstract: Twitter’s lawsuit is part of a broadening battle between the biggest tech companies and governments around the world over who gets to control information and how.
lead_paragraph: Twitter said on Tuesday that it had sued the Indian government, escalating the social media company’s fight in the country as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks more control over critical online posts.

headline: Crypto Crashed. Wall Street Won.
abstract: Plus, a legal twist for collapsed investment firm and founder Bill Hwang.
lead_paragraph: As Bitcoin prices have plunged and cryptocurrency start-ups have failed, Wall Street’s biggest banks and their wealthiest clients have barely taken a hit. Some have even managed to turn a profit on the collapse. In the great cryptocurrency blood bath of 2022, writes The Times’s Emily Flitter, Wall Street is winning.

headline: What to Know About California’s Landmark Plastics Law
abstract: The new legislation requires plastics makers to foot the bill for recycling and restricts single-use plastics.
lead_paragraph: California approved the most sweeping restrictions on plastics in the nation late last week, a move that will most likely reshape the way we shop and recycle over the next decade.

headline: Shifting Policy, France Brings Home French Wives of Jihadists
abstract: The country repatriated 16 women from Syria, in a move it had long ruled out. Thirty-five children, including some orphans, accompanied them.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France brought home 16 wives of jihadists from sprawling detention camps in northeastern Syria on Tuesday, breaking with a policy that for years had ruled out repatriating and trying adult women who had left to join the Islamic State.

headline: A Poor Country Made Bitcoin a National Currency. The Bet Isn’t Paying Off.
abstract: It brought El Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, the adulation of the tech community, but reduced scarce funds and moved the nation closer to default.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin was meant to transform El Salvador’s economy, catapulting the poor Central American nation into an unlikely harbinger of a financial revolution.

headline: In a big potential breach, a hacker offers to sell a Chinese police database.
abstract: For about $200,000, an unidentified person or group is offering what is described as data on a billion Chinese citizens. A sampling seemed to show the data to be genuine.
lead_paragraph: In what may be one of the largest known breaches of Chinese personal data, a hacker has offered to sell a Shanghai police database that could contain information on perhaps one billion Chinese citizens.

headline: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel’s Upstate Escape
abstract: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.

headline: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel: On the Zen of Escaping City Life
abstract: The artistic director of American Ballet Theater and the former dancer ‘drink in the calm’ at a 1904 house in Woodstock, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McKenzie and Martine van Hamel were standing in the dining room of their weekend house in Woodstock, N.Y., trying to figure out when they got married.

headline: B.A. Parker Can’t Get Enough of K-Dramas
abstract: The new host of NPR’s “Code Switch” podcast counts Donny Hathaway’s voice, 50-minute naps and Otterbein’s Cookies as her essentials.
lead_paragraph: B.A. Parker was a film professor in her 20s when she had to rush her students out of the hall so that she could speak with Ira Glass. She was interviewing for a fellowship with his show, “This American Life.”

headline: A former employee of Archegos, the collapsed hedge fund, sues for millions in lost pay.
abstract: A former analyst at the firm said it had forced employees to contribute to a $500 million deferred compensation plan that it told them was guaranteed.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of Archegos, the investment firm that caused a brief market panic when it lost more than $10 billion in a matter of days last year, is suing the firm and its founder, Bill Hwang, plus five former top executives. The lawsuit was filed on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the DealBook newsletter reports.

headline: Infertility Patients and Doctors Fear Abortion Bans Could Restrict I.V.F.
abstract: The new state bans don’t explicitly cover embryos created outside the womb, but legal experts say overturning Roe could make it easier to place controls on genetic testing, storage and disposal of them.
lead_paragraph: Anna Nibley Baker, a mother of four in Salt Lake City, is reasonably certain that she and her husband are done building their family. Yet for eight years, since the birth of her last child, conceived through in vitro fertilization, she has thought tenderly of the couple’s three remaining embryos, frozen and stored at a university clinic.

headline: Brittney Griner’s wife says the White House is not doing enough to secure the basketball star’s release.
abstract: The W.N.B.A. player’s wife, Cherelle, said that she would “not be quiet anymore,” adding that Brittney Griner wrote to her family about her poor physical health.
lead_paragraph: The wife of Brittney Griner, the detained W.N.B.A. star who has been held in Russia since February, accused the White House on Tuesday of not doing enough to secure her release, a day after the basketball player sent a handwritten letter to President Biden asking him not to “forget about” her and other American detainees.

headline: Is gas green?
abstract: Climate advocates are warning against a European proposal to subsidize the fossil fuel.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Union has an ambitious climate law to slash its greenhouse gas emissions by 55 percent by 2030.

headline: A Vietnamese Menu Worth the Wait
abstract: After more than two years of delays and pivots, Saigon Social is serving traditional food from Vietnam on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of delays and pivots, Saigon Social is serving traditional food from Vietnam on the Lower East Side.

headline: Restaurant Review: Saigon Social Looks Back at Vietnam
abstract: At her Lower East Side restaurant, the chef Helen Nguyen conjures the country her family left behind.
lead_paragraph: Order the banh beo chen at the downtown Vietnamese restaurant Saigon Social and six will show up, arranged in a circle around a dish of seasoned fish sauce. This is as it should be. Like Mormon missionaries, banh beo chen never travel alone. Typically, each of these soft disks of steamed rice flour is the size of an oyster, and a single banh beo would be about as satisfying as a single bluepoint. One is not a serving. Six is a good start.

headline: Ford quarterly sales were up slightly from last year, when chip shortages hurt output.
abstract: The automaker sold 483,688 vehicles in the United States in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said Tuesday that it sold 483,688 cars and light trucks in the United States in the second quarter, slightly more than it sold a year earlier, when it was hit particularly hard by the global shortage of computer chips.

headline: Ready-to-Sear Skewers From Xiao Chi Jie in Seattle
abstract: The Chinese street food restaurant ships nicely spiced marinated boneless beef, lamb and chicken nationally.
lead_paragraph: Xiao Chi Jie, a Chinese street food restaurant in Seattle owned by Caleb Wang and Jen Liao, turned to frozen takeout when the pandemic began. They specialized in soup dumplings, which they began shipping nationally in late 2020. Now they have introduced shao kao skewers with nicely spiced marinated boneless beef, lamb and chicken to sear in minutes on a stovetop, grill or even in an air fryer. They’re an easy nibble with drinks; cook a few for a quick supper, and a platter of them makes a feast. The company also sells dipping sauces.

headline: Salumi and Jerky for Summer Snacking
abstract: Cured meats from Dickson’s Farmstand Meats include flavors like cacio e pepe and za’atar, and they ship nationwide.
lead_paragraph: In early spring, Jake Dickson of Dickson’s Farmstand Meats created a salumi bar at his Chelsea Market store using locally raised meats. The specialties available on their site now include jerky for the trail and salami for picnics, or summer snacking. The company makes 10 or so salumi in flavors like tres chiles, cacio e pepe, pistachio and orange peel, and finocchiona, along with a wide assortment of jerky, including za’atar, honey and anise, and ghost pepper. All of them are available for nationwide shipping, $10 and up; sizes vary. A gift assortment is $81.

headline: Sardine Soap for Fishy (or Garlicky) Hands
abstract: Hang this lemon-scented soap shaped like a fish next to the sink.
lead_paragraph: Naâma Laufer and Luis Correia, who import wines from Mr. Correia’s native Portugal, started a second company, My Portuguese Market, last year, selling handcrafted goods from Portugal. They have just introduced a lemon- and sea salt-scented, sardine-shaped soap on a rough cord. It’s ideal for hands that have been working with seafood, garlic and onions, and it’s easy to hang near the sink. The cute box makes it giftworthy.

headline: Nearly 90 Years Later, Kossar’s Expands Its Bialy Operation
abstract: The Lower East Side fixture since 1936 will open stores on the edge of Hudson Yards and on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: There’s no end of bagel stores across New York but for bialys, one name stands out: Kossar’s Bagels & Bialys. It’s been a fixture on the Lower East Side since 1936, first as Mirsky and Kossar’s Bakery, then, as of 1953, just Kossar’s. Now the company is branching into other neighborhoods, first with a store on the edge of Hudson Yards this week and on the Upper East Side in the fall. The bialy, named for the town of Bialystok, Poland, is not ring-shaped like a bagel, but round and chewy with more of an English muffin texture. They are made with a central depression typically filled with onions and, these days, you-name-it, like everything spices, olives and sun-dried tomatoes. The new store has no seating but also sells pletzels, a type of onion and poppy seed flatbread; bagels; and bagel and bialy sandwiches.

headline: Highland Park Suspect Was Known to Police; Bought Guns Legally
abstract: The 21-year-old man was charged with seven counts of first-degree murder a day after the shooting at a Fourth of July parade.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — The man accused of killing seven people and wounding dozens of others in a shooting that terrorized a Fourth of July parade had been investigated by the local police before. Officers had responded in 2019 after someone reported that he had tried to kill himself. And they came to his home a few months later — seizing a knife collection — after a family member reported that he had pledged to “kill everyone.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Larry Kramer
abstract: The July 5, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Larry Kramer. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A Conductor’s Career, Cut Short, Still Blazes on Recordings
abstract: With an abundance of albums out on multiple labels, we have as complete a portrait of the Toscanini protégé Guido Cantelli as we are ever likely to.
lead_paragraph: Frost glazed the ground, and mist hung in the air, as a brand-new Douglas DC-6B took off from Orly Airport near Paris early on Nov. 24, 1956. The plane was headed for Shannon, Ireland, and then New York.

headline: U.S. Aims to Expand Export Bans on China Over Security and Human Rights
abstract: The Biden administration is applying lessons learned from controls on Russia during the Ukraine war to try to limit China’s military and technological advances.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Russian forces invaded Ukraine nearly five months ago, the Biden administration led dozens of governments in banning the export of advanced technology to Russia to hobble its economic and military development.

headline: The euro hits a 20-year low and U.S. bonds flash a warning sign as economic fears mount.
abstract: Oil prices tumbled and other markets around the world reflected renewed recession worries.
lead_paragraph: The euro fell to a 20-year low against the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, as fears about the European economy weighed heavily on the currency. It was one of several signs of renewed economic worries around the world, which were also reflected in stocks wobbling, bonds flashing warning signals and oil prices falling sharply.

headline: After Another Mass Shooting, New Jersey Tightens Gun Laws
abstract: The legislation, which Gov. Phil Murphy signed on Tuesday, comes amid a push by states with strict gun laws to work around a Supreme Court ruling aimed at dismantling them.
lead_paragraph: Newly signed legislation will make it more difficult to obtain a handgun license and buy high-capacity rifles in New Jersey, the latest in a patchwork effort by states with strict gun laws to work around a sweeping Supreme Court ruling aimed at dismantling them.

headline: Will Euro 2022 Be the Payoff on England’s Investment in Women’s Soccer?
abstract: At least a half-dozen nations will arrive at this summer’s European Championship thinking they can lift the trophy. But the pressure to win might be the highest on the host nation.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of the Euro 2022 final.

headline: Matthew Modine Isn’t Sure if ‘Stranger Things’ Is Done With Him
abstract: The Hollywood veteran returned to the Netflix hit this season, but not even he knows his character’s fate. “I would love to have the opportunity to come back,” he said.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the entire fourth season of “Stranger Things.”

headline: The Jumbled Dream of U.S. Chips
abstract: It’s even harder now to understand what the U.S. wants to accomplish with its computer chip plans.
lead_paragraph: A global shortage of computer chips had stalled the manufacturing of cars, computers and even dog-washing machines. But there are now signs the shortage of chips — the teeny parts that function like the brain or memory in everything electronic — is ending.

headline: At Wimbledon, Novak Djokovic Escapes Against Jannik Sinner
abstract: After dropping the first two sets to the young Italian player, Djokovic rallied to win three straight sets.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Novak Djokovic has pulled off some masterly escape acts on Centre Court.

headline: Judge Clears Distributors of Blame for Opioid Crisis in Hard-Hit County
abstract: Often described as ground zero for the epidemic, the communities of Cabell County and Huntington, W. Va., had opted out of a settlement and lost their case at trial.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ruled that the nation’s three largest drug distributors cannot be held liable for the opioid epidemic in one of the most ravaged counties in the country — a place where 81 million prescription painkillers were shipped over eight years to a population of less than 100,000.

headline: ‘Growing Up Getty’ Shakes the Dust Off a Family’s Aristocratic Name
abstract: James Reginato’s new book about the oil baron J. Paul Getty and his many descendants argues that the family isn’t especially dysfunctional — by the standards of the very rich.
lead_paragraph: How cheap was the oil tycoon J. Paul Getty, once known as the richest man in the world?

headline: Alternate-Side Parking Is Back in Full Force: ‘It’s a Pain in the Neck’
abstract: After a hiatus of twice-a-week street cleanings earlier in the pandemic, New York City has started enforcing full alternate-side parking rules again.
lead_paragraph: After a reprieve of more than two years, full alternate-side parking is back in New York City, requiring some drivers who park on the street to play musical chairs twice a week instead of just once.

headline: ‘Our Little Town’: A Fourth of July Parade Turned Deadly
abstract: “Must each of us lose a loved one before the gun lobby is stopped?” a reader asks. Also: Justice Jackson’s tough task; threats against election workers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sleep Your Way to Better Heart Health
abstract: Sleep is now considered an essential factor in good heart health.
lead_paragraph: Sleep is now considered an essential factor in good heart health.

headline: Biden Awards Medal of Honor to Vietnam Soldiers for ‘Incredible Heroism’
abstract: “They went far above and beyond the call of duty,” the president said as he bestowed America’s highest military honor upon four recipients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday honored four Vietnam-era soldiers for what he called “acts of incredible heroism,” bestowing on them the Medal of Honor, America’s highest military honor, nearly half a century after the end of the conflict in Southeast Asia.

headline: Who is Rishi Sunak?
abstract: Boris Johnson appointed Mr. Sunak chancellor, the government’s chief financial officer and often second in power only to the prime minister, in February 2020.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rishi Sunak, who resigned on Tuesday as Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, has been arguably the most prominent figure in Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s cabinet, seen for a time as Mr. Johnson’s most likely successor.

headline: The departures come at a perilous time for the U.K. economy.
abstract: London’s financial markets had closed by the time the resignations of Rishi Sunak and Sajid Javid were announced on Tuesday evening, so most market reaction, if any, will come on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: London’s financial markets had closed by the time the resignations of Rishi Sunak and Sajid Javid were announced on Tuesday evening, so most market reaction, if any, will come on Wednesday.

headline: Bad Bunny, a Streaming Heavyweight, Returns to No. 1
abstract: The Puerto Rican rapper, singer and pop star’s latest album, “Un Verano Sin Ti,” tops the Billboard chart again in its eighth week of release.
lead_paragraph: In its eight weeks on the Billboard album chart so far, the Puerto Rican rapper, singer and pop star Bad Bunny’s latest release, “Un Verano Sin Ti,” has remained a streaming steamroller, frequently topping 150 million online plays per week. This time, the album’s 160 million streams were enough for a return to No. 1, despite two new releases in the Top 5 and just 657 copies of “Un Verano Sin Ti” sold as a full album.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘If You Decide to Flirt With a Stranger’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: If you decide to flirt with a stranger by sliding into his Twitter DMs, brew a cup of tea first. Then, sit. Sip the tea. Breathe deeply. Allow yourself to swell with giddiness. Don’t charge forward, rushing with new messages, just because you cannot tolerate the vulnerability of reaching out. That will result with you picking words in a frenzy, words that you’ll pore over later as you wonder why he stopped replying. It might not be flirtatious to point out dead links on a person’s website; it’s sometimes a conversation ender to ask, “Do you have a wife?” — Jay Vera Summer

headline: ‘Ready to Rock, You Guys?’ The Winklevoss Twins Play Amagansett.
abstract: At the end of a tour that drew some social media mockery, the billionaire brothers’ rock band received a friendly reception at a venue close to their parents’ beach house.
lead_paragraph: The 40-year-old billionaire twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss have been on the road with their rock band, Mars Junction, since early last month, crisscrossing the country to offer their versions of songs by Blink-182, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, the Police, Pearl Jam and Journey. Tyler sings; Cameron plays guitar. On Saturday, they rolled into Amagansett, N.Y., the Long Island beach town not far from where they spent their childhood summers.

headline: Here is what we know about the victims of the Highland Park shooting.
abstract: Seven people have died and more than 30 were wounded.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — In the chaotic aftermath of the attack at a Fourth of July parade on Monday, Lauren Silva stumbled upon a bloodstained toddler lying beneath a dying man. As her boyfriend and son frantically attempted first aid, she cradled the little boy, who kept asking about his parents. As hours passed, word spread of the tiny child found at the scene of a massacre.

headline: Nick Kyrgios to Appear in Court on Assault Allegation in Australia
abstract: The accusation landed on the eve of perhaps the most important match of Kyrgios’s controversy-filled career, a quarterfinal showdown with Cristian Garín.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The spotlight on the Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, whose confrontations with opponents and Wimbledon officials have made his matches can’t-miss theater for the past week, grew hotter Tuesday when news emerged that the police have begun legal proceedings against him after a former girlfriend accused him of assaulting her in December.

headline: Review: ‘The Rise and Fall of … Jean Claude Van Damme’ Revives an Action Hero
abstract: A gleefully juvenile show about the Belgian star, from the writer Timothy Haskell, barrels through his life and oeuvre using toy action figures.
lead_paragraph: The New York International Fringe Festival is no more, but its spirit lives on at a second-floor black box theater on the edge of the garment district. There you will find “The Rise and Fall, Then Brief and Modest Rise Followed by a Relative Fall of … Jean Claude Van Damme as Gleaned by a Single Reading of His Wikipedia Page Months Earlier,” a new show whose descriptive title takes us right back to the heady days of such Fringe delights as “Theater of the Arcade: Five Classic Video Games Adapted for the Stage” and “Harvey Finkelstein’s Sock Puppet Showgirls.”

headline: 7 Trump Allies Subpoenaed in Georgia Criminal Investigation
abstract: Rudy Giuliani, Lindsey Graham, John Eastman and several others in the former president’s orbit were subpoenaed in the election meddling inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Seven advisers and allies of Donald J. Trump, including Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Lindsey Graham, were subpoenaed on Tuesday in the ongoing criminal investigation in Georgia of election interference by Mr. Trump and his associates. The move was the latest sign that the inquiry has entangled a number of prominent members of Mr. Trump’s orbit, and may cloud the future for the former president.

headline: Palestinian Outrage After U.S. Says Journalist Was Killed by Accident
abstract: The U.S. government said Shireen Abu Akleh was likely hit by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines in the occupied West Bank, but unintentionally, fueling claims that Washington isn’t impartial.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Palestinians expressed disappointment and anger at the United States on Tuesday, after Washington said it had concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist killed while reporting in the occupied West Bank, was likely shot unintentionally by a bullet fired from Israeli military lines.

headline: As Russia Moves on Another Province, Ukrainians Leave Ghost Towns Behind
abstract: Vast stretches of eastern Ukraine are now largely devoid of people and industry. If Ukraine is ever to have a vibrant postwar future, it is unlikely to sprout from these ruins.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Nina Zakharenko cried when she boarded a minibus evacuating civilians as the Russian Army advanced toward the town where she went to college, met her husband and raised two daughters.

headline: Reader Questions: Globe-Trotting Vegetarians and More
abstract: Looking for old-school Cantonese? Dinner in a beautiful room? We have options.
lead_paragraph: Before I hop into the questions, a special thanks to my colleague Becky Hughes for filling in last week. I feel well rested and energized to answer another round of reader questions. Today we have a newbie looking to try different cuisines, a visitor seeking great Cantonese and a diner who wants to eat in a beautiful space.

headline: Analysis: Another loyalty test for Johnson could shine a light on a successor.
abstract: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has survived scandals and setbacks that would have sunk many other politicians, in part because he maintained the support of his cabinet. But that changed in dramatic fashion on Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson has survived scandals and setbacks that would have sunk many other politicians, in part because he maintained the support of his cabinet. But that changed in dramatic fashion on Tuesday evening.

headline: Cooking Online, Arab Women Find Income and Community
abstract: Across the Middle East and North Africa, home cooks are using YouTube and their favorite recipes to transform their families’ lives.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Cory Booker Wants You to Give Up the White Stuff (Sugar, That Is)
abstract: Over the long weekend, the New Jersey senator asked his followers to join him in having a “Sugar Free Summer.”
lead_paragraph: On the morning before the Fourth of July, Senator Cory Booker, Democrat of New Jersey, sent a mass email with the subject line “Sugar Free Summer.” It detailed the harms of processed sugar, including the taxes that fund it through subsidies, its health risks and the attendant health care bills.

headline: Where the War Is Headed
abstract: Russia sets its sights on the next target in the Donbas.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia’s Next Offensive
abstract: Plus Boris Johnson’s fight for political survival and Twitter’s lawsuit against India
lead_paragraph: With Luhansk Province firmly in its grasp, Russia set its sights on the next target in eastern Ukraine. Russian forces ramped up shelling on the outskirts of the city of Bakhmut as an apparent prelude to an offensive into the province of Donetsk.

headline: Boris Johnson quickly fills vacancies, including the health secretary, trying to stabilize his government in crisis.
abstract: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.

headline: Sharks Hire Mike Grier as N.H.L.’s First Black General Manager
abstract: Two days before the annual draft, Grier takes over a team in transition: San Jose missed the past three postseasons and recently fired its coach.
lead_paragraph: Mike Grier, who spent 14 seasons in the N.H.L. as a gritty right wing, on Tuesday was named general manager of the San Jose Sharks, becoming the first Black general manager in the history of a league that just completed its 105th season.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: California Woman Pardoned 27 Years After Killing Abuser as a Teen
abstract: Sara Kruzan was 16 in 1994 when she killed a man who she said had sexually abused and trafficked her for years. A year later, she was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole.
lead_paragraph: When Sara Kruzan was 17, she was convicted of murdering a man she said had abused her beginning when she was 11 and had trafficked her for sex at 13. She served nearly two decades in prison.

headline: The suspect and his family had long ties to Highland Park and a troubled past.
abstract: The suspect’s father recently ran for mayor of the city, where the family has had a presence for generations.
lead_paragraph: The family of the 21-year-old man identified as the gunman who fired into a crowd celebrating the Fourth of July in Highland Park, Ill., appeared to have deep roots in the community. His father ran for mayor; his grandfather was born in the city and was buried in a cemetery 13 miles outside of town.

headline: Much More Than Bragging Rights at the Next Barbecue Are at Stake
abstract: Neither Tatjana Maria nor Ons Jabeur had been to a Grand Slam singles semifinal until this week. The close friends will play each other at Wimbledon on Thursday for a place in the final.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — A working mother of two, Tatjana Maria had the child care under control on Tuesday.

headline: Built to Thrive: Four Mindsets Revealed
abstract: Curious, motivated, optimistic, flexible. We spoke to four passionate achievers about how they found their version of success.
lead_paragraph: Curious, motivated, optimistic, flexible. We spoke to four passionate achievers about how they found their version of success.

headline: One of the Few Potential Bright Spots for Democrats in 2022: The Senate
abstract: Democrats hope to portray Republican Senate candidates in some of the most competitive midterm races as too far outside the mainstream. For now, it seems to be working.
lead_paragraph: When asked to share their candid thoughts about the Democrats’ chances of hanging onto their House majority in the coming election, party strategists often use words that cannot be printed in a family newsletter.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues Arizona Over Voting Restrictions
abstract: It is the latest instance in which the Justice Department under Attorney General Merrick B. Garland has sued a state over its voting laws.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department sued Arizona on Tuesday over a new state law requiring proof of citizenship to vote in a presidential election, saying the Republican-imposed restrictions are a “textbook violation” of federal law.

headline: Lawmakers ask F.T.C. chair to investigate TikTok’s data practices.
abstract: Questions are surfacing once again about whether TikTok poses a national security threat because it is owned by a Chinese company.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee asked the Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday to investigate whether TikTok, the Chinese-owned video app, had misled the public about whether Beijing could have access to American user data.

headline: Jan. 6 Hearings to Resume Tuesday With Focus on Domestic Extremists
abstract: Representative Jamie Raskin, Democrat of Maryland, has said he plans to show ties between Donald J. Trump and militias that helped orchestrate the Capitol attack.
lead_paragraph: Update: This article has been updated with the revised time for the July 12 hearing.

headline: Hudson River Tunnel Project Moves Ahead as States Agree to Share Costs
abstract: A project to build new tunnels from New Jersey to Penn Station moved a step closer to construction with an agreement between New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: For the last 20 years, the plan to dig new train tunnels under the Hudson River — among the most ambitious and important transportation projects in the country — has been repeatedly tripped up by political wrangling.

headline: Boris Johnson Fights to Hold Power After 2 Top Ministers Jump Ship
abstract: Two top cabinet members resigned from the scandal-scarred British prime minister’s government. Some wondered if the master of political survival could pull off another save.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain suffered a potentially lethal political blow on Tuesday when two of his most senior ministers quit in an apparently coordinated rebellion against his scandal-tainted leadership.

headline: Before Shooting, Highland Park Was Considered Chicago’s ‘Mayberry’
abstract: Intended from the start as an oasis, the suburb is struggling to comprehend its new identity as the latest site of a mass shooting
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — It was intended, from its very origins, to be an oasis.

headline: Funeral Home Operator Pleads Guilty in ‘Illegal Body Part Scheme’
abstract: Megan Hess, who pleaded guilty to mail fraud, sold body parts without families’ consent in a business she operated with her mother, officials said.
lead_paragraph: The operator of a Colorado funeral home who was accused of stealing body parts and selling them to medical and scientific buyers, making hundreds of thousands of dollars in what the authorities called an “illegal body part scheme,” pleaded guilty to mail fraud on Tuesday, the Justice Department said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Wall St.’s Great Crypto Escape
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Pandora’s box is opened — you can’t close it.”

headline: Corrections: July 6, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 6, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about American Special Operations veterans training Ukrainians near the front lines in the fight against Russia mischaracterized the group that helps evacuate Americans from Ukraine. It is a nonprofit organization, not a volunteer group.

headline: Go Off in Two Directions
abstract: Sam Koperwas and Jeff Chen perform a bit of prestidigitation.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Sam Koperwas, who is making his first appearance in the New York Times Crossword today, and to Jeff Chen, who is making his 133rd. Incredibly, this is also Mr. Chen’s 88th collaboration, and Mr. Koperwas is Mr. Chen’s 50th collaborator. That kind of dedication to mentorship of new constructors is unparalleled among New York Times Crossword constructors — the person with the next-most collaborators has 20 fewer than Mr. Chen.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Shock resignations in the British government.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, is battling for his political survival after the bombshell resignations yesterday of two top cabinet officers: Rishi Sunak, the chancellor of the Exchequer, and Sajid Javid, the health secretary. In the hours that followed, Alex Chalk, the solicitor general, and several people in junior government posts also quit.

headline: Directing the Beatles Was Just One Part of His Long and Winding Career
abstract: The filmmaker Michael Lindsay-Hogg, who attracted some social media scrutiny after his appearance in Peter Jackson’s “Get Back,” finds peace in New York’s Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — Of course I wanted to talk with Michael Lindsay-Hogg about the Beatles. Everyone wants to talk with him about the Beatles, especially since his star turn in “Get Back,” Peter Jackson’s epic documentary, which debuted last fall on Disney+.

headline: A Core Ritual Returns: Twice-Weekly Alternate-Side Parking
abstract: In New York, “your life revolves around alternate-side parking,” one driver lamented.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at the return of twice-a-week alternate-side parking for drivers in Manhattan, the Bronx and much of the rest of the city. And we’ll eavesdrop on one awe-struck but ambivalent fireworks-watching party on Brooklyn’s waterfront.

headline: What’s the Most Curious and Fraught Job in Tennis?
abstract: Coaches in tennis have one of the odder existences in sports. Some players go for long periods without even using one, and others change coaches like socks.
lead_paragraph: It was, by the usually secretive standards of coach-player relationships in tennis, an unorthodox move.

headline: The Knicks Stumbled Last Season. Here’s How They Can Recover.
abstract: With free agency beginning, the Knicks have several options to build on what’s working and to move on from what is not.
lead_paragraph: Good news for Knicks fans: The franchise has lured one of the best free agents, a rare occurrence for the team this century.

headline: A Prized Recruit Shows the Shoe Circuit Is Not the Only Path
abstract: Xavier Booker, in an unusual move, is sidestepping the carnival of tournaments put on by shoe companies to showcase elite men’s basketball players.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Few could have foreseen Xavier Booker, who as a sophomore barely got off his high school team’s bench, in his current position: being scrutinized by N.B.A. scouts and recruited by Kansas, Kentucky, Gonzaga, Duke, Michigan State, Michigan, Indiana and a cadre of others.

headline: How War in Ukraine Roiled Russia’s ‘Coolest Company’
abstract: The decline of Yandex, the Russian version of Google, is emblematic of the economic and cultural troubles spawned by the invasion.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a war makes.

headline: Tell Me if You’ve Heard This Story Before
abstract: The deaths of migrants in Melilla, a Spanish enclave in northern Morocco, are gut-wrenching.
lead_paragraph: The border guard stood beside a small, cinder-block building, squinting in the sunlight. From where I sat in the back seat of my parents’ old Renault, he seemed tall and a little scary. But with only a quick look inside, he waved us through on our day trip to Melilla, a Spanish enclave in northern Morocco.

headline: The decline of Yandex, a Russia tech giant, reflects the domestic troubles stirred by the invasion.
abstract: What a difference a war makes.
lead_paragraph: What a difference a war makes.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Next Front Line in the Abortion Wars: State Supreme Courts
abstract: Court challenges to sweeping rollbacks of abortion rights must go through state supreme courts, many of which have been shaped by years of conservative activism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Fresh from the political thicket of the United States Supreme Court, the struggle over abortion is now moving to venues that are poised to become the next front line in the country’s partisan warfare: state supreme courts.

headline: Mass Funeral Deepens Mystery: Why Did 21 South African Teens Die in Tavern?
abstract: Survivors of the tragedy last month recounted in interviews the presence of a mysterious gas and then a crush to escape. Officials say the stampede didn’t kill them.
lead_paragraph: EAST LONDON, South Africa — Before he passed out amid the crush of bodies, Simbongile Mtsweni gasped for air as a gas that felt like fire crept into his nose and lungs. “When I came to,” he said, “I was on the second floor and started vomiting when I realized I was lying next to dead people.”

headline: Chanel and Armani: Playing for Keeps in a Barbie World
abstract: Plus Paco Rabanne’s plastic-fantastic dystopian dressing.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — These days it’s hard to see any bright pink item of clothing and not think: “Barbie!”

headline: What happens next if Johnson quits?
abstract: If Boris Johnson resigns, here is what could happen next.
lead_paragraph: If Boris Johnson were to resign, there would not automatically be a general election to replace him.

headline: Boris Johnson quickly fills the two cabinet vacancies in an effort to stabilize a government in crisis.
abstract: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson moved quickly to plug the holes in his cabinet caused by Tuesday’s resignations of two senior ministers, including the critical job of chancellor of the Exchequer, which went to Nadhim Zahawi, who had been the education secretary.

headline: Global factors outweigh British political turmoil in the financial markets.
abstract: The long-running trends of rising inflation, worsening energy security and a weakening growth outlook are overshadowing the sudden political upheaval.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, as London’s financial markets reopened after the resignations of senior ministers put Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s tenure in doubt, Britain’s benchmark stock market index rose more than 1 percent, alongside increases in other European markets.

headline: Most Americans Say Life Is Starting to Return to Pre-Covid Normal, a Poll Shows
abstract: In the survey, 54 percent of adults said their lives are somewhat the same.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans say their lives are at least approaching prepandemic normalcy, according to a recent study.

headline: How Talking to the Dead Dislodged Some of My Sorrow
abstract: Voice mail helps a daughter cope with her mother’s death.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Descended From Shamans and Ghost Whisperers
abstract: In her debut memoir, Ingrid Rojas Contreras summons stories from the living and the dead to connect her own experiences to those of her Colombian ancestors.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Ingrid Rojas Contreras traveled to her mother’s hometown, Ocaña, Colombia, to exhume her grandfather Nono’s body at the request of a spirit who family members said had appeared to them in dreams. Researching her ancestry while there, she picked up a book so old that it disintegrated in her hands, leaving nothing but dust. “It’s like I watched history erase itself,” she despaired, reflecting on her failed hunt for family documents. Her mother laughed in her face. “Who do you think we are,” she scoffed, “the type of people to be in the public record?”

headline: Americans Are Losing Their Right to Not Conform
abstract: The freedom to define oneself has deep roots in the American traditions of pluralism and independence.
