lead_paragraph: On June 24 the Supreme Court laid waste to Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey on the grounds that the right to an abortion is not enumerated in the Constitution and is not deeply rooted in the history and traditions of the United States. As many commentators have noted, similar objections could be lodged against precedents like Griswold v. Connecticut, Lawrence v. Texas and Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognize constitutional protections for contraception, sex and marriage.

headline: The End of the Illusion That Smoking Is a Choice
abstract: An F.D.A. proposal to lower nicotine levels in cigarettes could save millions of lives.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration recently proposed lowering the nicotine content in cigarettes to less addictive levels. If adopted, this regulation would finally test one of the tobacco industry’s favorite claims: that smoking is a choice. Portraying smoking as a willful, personal decision has long allowed tobacco companies to promote cigarettes even while acknowledging their deadly risks. But the paradigm of individual choice has also guided cigarette regulation, ironically strengthening the industry’s key talking point — until now.

headline: The Rise of the Professional-Athlete Podcast
abstract: Does getting game analyses straight from the source take away some of the magic?
lead_paragraph: Postgame analysis is an integral part of the sports experience. After the final buzzer, fans take to the internet, television and radio to learn what their teams did to win (made their shots, played defense) or lose (missed their shots, didn’t play defense). Even the sports-averse can easily picture what this traditionally looks like: four men (maybe three men and one woman), seated behind a long desk, offering sage insights like “I thought they struggled with catching the ball,” to solemn nods of agreement. And yet, for the entirety of the recently concluded N.B.A. Finals, won by the Golden State Warriors over the Boston Celtics, this kind of analysis was also delivered by a more intimate source: the Warriors’ own Draymond Green, who, following every contest, left the court to analyze the game he’d just played, as the host of a podcast called “The Draymond Green Show.”

headline: For Black Girls, Womanhood Comes Too Early
abstract: In Mecca Jamilah Sullivan’s debut novel, an 8-year-old girl in Harlem is forced to change her body to fit someone else’s standard.
lead_paragraph: What is a child’s body worth when it is big, Black and female — when it is under constant demand to be something other than what it naturally is? In Mecca Jamilah Sullivan’s achingly beautiful coming-of-age debut novel, “Big Girl,” this body carries the weight of an entire neighborhood.

headline: Republicans May Have Set Themselves Up for a Showdown With the Supreme Court
abstract: Two conservative critiques of the administrative state are in contradiction with each other.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s Supreme Court decision in West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency limiting the E.P.A.’s ability to regulate a shift to a less carbon-intensive economy should have surprised no one familiar with conservative complaints about the administrative state. The alphabet soup of federal executive branch agencies — from the F.D.A. to the S.E.C. — that regulate much of American economic life have long been the targets of Republican criticism.

headline: Roe Is Dead. How Will Democrats and the G.O.P. Evolve Without It?
abstract: Michelle Goldberg and Ross Douthat on what comes next for Democrats and Republicans.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, the issue of abortion has driven voters of all persuasions to the polls. But now that Roe v. Wade has been overturned and the question of reproductive rights has been returned to the states, America’s political parties are going to have to figure out how to metabolize that energy in the years ahead. To discuss what comes next for Democrats and Republicans alike, host Jane Coaston is joined by Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg. As colleagues, they’ve been debating abortion with each other, on this podcast and in the pages of the paper, for years.

headline: A Great Biscuit Is a Miracle of Care
abstract: Savory with kimchi and Cheddar, these biscuits taste like an act of generosity.
lead_paragraph: A good biscuit is a miracle. Its own holy ritual and a hangover cure-all. No matter how foolproof your recipe may be, or how many generations have passed it down, the moment a biscuit departs an oven follows a familiar pattern: expectation, followed by suspense, before the elation payoff. Success is immediately recognizable, weightless in your hands. You know it when you see it. You remember it when you taste it.

headline: Read Your Way Through Berlin
abstract: The German author Daniel Kehlmann, most recently of the novel “Tyll,” recommends books that explore the city’s painful past and dynamic present.
lead_paragraph: Berlin is not pretty. You should know that beforehand. You don’t come here for the beautiful architecture of an old European city.

headline: With Rising Book Bans, Librarians Have Come Under Attack
abstract: Caustic fights over which books belong on the shelves have put librarians at the center of a bitter and widening culture war.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks
abstract: Researchers are trying to figure out the right hour of the day to do everything. Can their studies sync us up with better health?
lead_paragraph: “Time,” when we give it any thought, tends to strike us as extrinsic, a feature of our landscape: We track our passage through it as if traversing an invisible geography, our progress charted by wristwatch, clock, calendar. Humans didn’t invent time, of course, but you might reasonably argue that because we invented the units we use to keep track of it — hours, minutes, seconds — we have every right to tinker with them when we want to. This, at least, was the position the Senate took on March 15, when in a surprise, and surprisingly uncontested, vote it passed the Sunshine Protection Act. The new law would, if the House concurs and the president signs, make daylight saving time permanent, beginning on Nov. 5, 2023.

headline: Disinformation Has Become Another Untouchable Problem in Washington
abstract: Numerous federal agencies agree that widely promoted falsehoods threaten the nation’s security. Doing something about them is another matter.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The memo that reached the top of the Department of Homeland Security in September could not have been clearer about its plan to create a board to monitor national security threats caused by the spread of dangerous disinformation.

headline: With Housing Limited, a Gecko and a Possum Family Became Roommates
abstract: They won’t eat each other, and the family of marsupials does not seem to mind that the lizard is using them for warmth.
lead_paragraph: When Alex Hams, a land conservation manager at Bush Heritage Australia, was giving a tour to visiting scientists and volunteers in mid-June, he got more than he bargained for. He opened the lid of a nest box for western pygmy possums at the Monjebup Nature Reserve, which his organization manages in southwestern Australia. There, among the leaves, he found not just a family of pygmy possums, but also a small, orange-eyed lizard known as a western spiny-tailed gecko.

headline: How One Restaurateur Transformed America’s Energy Industry
abstract: Charif Souki’s longshot bet on liquid natural gas, or L.N.G., paid off handsomely — and turned the United States into a leading fossil-fuel exporter.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to tell the story of how the United States became one the world’s largest exporters of fossil fuels, you could start in the Middle Devonian period, around 400 million years ago, when a warm inland sea dense with primitive aquatic organisms covered parts of the northeastern United States and Appalachia; you could explain that as these creatures lived, reproduced and died, their remains settled on the ocean floor and were compressed beneath layers of sedimentary rock, until eventually they transformed into a gas trapped thousands of feet below what is now Pennsylvania.

headline: The Rise of the Far-Right Latina
abstract: Representative Mayra Flores is one of three Republican Latinas vying to transform South Texas politics by shunning moderates and often embracing the extreme.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, Texas Republicans tried to win the Hispanic vote using a Bush-era brand of compassionate conservatism. The idea was that a moderate’s touch and a softer rhetoric on immigration were key to making inroads with Hispanic voters, particularly in Democratic strongholds along the southern border.

headline: In Your Enthusiasm for Planting, Don’t Forget About the Trees
abstract: Trees can take a lot of punishment, but they have their limits. Here’s how to work around them safely.
lead_paragraph: If trees could talk, they’d probably start by saying, “Enough with the insults already.”

headline: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies. Single Moms Don’t Qualify.
abstract: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.
lead_paragraph: When Chan Zhang heard about the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, she was baffled that Americans were still arguing over abortion rights.

headline: Pass the Chowder, and the Curry: Jamaican Chefs Add to Cape Cod’s Culinary Delights
abstract: Thanks to Jamaican seasonal workers, the taste of Cape Cod now extends beyond the known lineup of Yankee favorites, to golden patties, jerk-rubbed meats and turmeric-rich curries.
lead_paragraph: At the Jerk Cafe, a storefront tucked into a strip mall in the Cape Cod village of South Yarmouth, Mass., sweet-smelling smoke greets guests as soon as they open the front door. So does the cafe’s proprietor, Glenroy Burke, who bounces around the wide-open kitchen stirring pots, tending the grill and plating dishes. “I don’t like to be hidden in the kitchen,” Mr. Burke said, who’s also known as “Chef Shrimpy.”

headline: Living In ... Gardiner, N.Y.
abstract: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one reason New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.
lead_paragraph: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one reason New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.

headline: The Shrinking of the Middle-Class Neighborhood
abstract: Americans are increasingly living in areas that are either much richer or much poorer than the regional norm.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — When Ashley Broadnax thinks of the East Nashville neighborhood she grew up in during the ’90s, the images that rush in have a modest, middle-class tinge.

headline: Gardiner, N.Y.: Open Space and Mountain Views in Ulster County
abstract: The 50-mile Shawangunk Ridge is just one of the reasons New Yorkers are flocking to this Ulster County town, which is also prized for its wide-open spaces.
lead_paragraph: When Laura Phillips was planning her retirement after 30 years of teaching art to elementary school students and living in Seaford, N.Y., on Long Island, she and her husband started looking for a more tranquil place to live.

headline: A Viable Third Party Is Coming, and It’s Starting With a New Jersey Lawsuit
abstract: A way for dismayed voters in the middle to get a voice.
lead_paragraph: On June 7, I won the Democratic Party primary in New Jersey’s Seventh Congressional District, on my way to what I hope will be my third term in the House. The same day, I also accepted the nomination of the new Moderate Party, formed substantially by state Republicans fed up with the extremism of a party led by Donald Trump.

headline: More officials resign, including a minister who defended Johnson two days earlier.
abstract: A growing number of officials in Boris Johnson’s government are stepping down, adding to the pressure on the prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s minister for children and families resigned on Wednesday morning, becoming the latest in a growing exodus of officials from the scandal-engulfed government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

headline: How Brittney Griner Became a Political Pawn
abstract: Growing public pressure to free the W.N.B.A. star, who has been detained in Russia for months, comes with risks.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February, recently sent a letter to President Biden. “I’m terrified I might be here forever,” she wrote.

headline: A 19th-Century Stone Villa on Majorca
abstract: This eight-bedroom manor on the Spanish island of Majorca, with a mix of modernist, Majorcan and French styles, is on the market for $2.7 million.
lead_paragraph: This eight-bedroom manor on the Spanish island of Majorca, with a mix of modernist, Majorcan and French styles, is on the market for $2.7 million.

headline: Nadhim Zahawi, the newly appointed chancellor, affirms his support for the prime minister.
abstract: Mr. Zahawi, Britain’s new top finance minister, defended Boris Johnson on Wednesday’s morning news shows, but said that his focus was on tackling inflation.
lead_paragraph: The newly appointed chancellor of the Exchequer, Nadhim Zahawi, came to the defense of Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain as he made the rounds on the morning television circuit on Wednesday, only hours after succeeding the recently resigned Rishi Sunak.

headline: Europe Calls Gas and Nuclear Energy ‘Green’
abstract: Critics say the decision is likely to reverberate beyond Europe’s borders and hamper its efforts to lead the global climate negotiations.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark vote for Europe’s climate and energy policies, the European Parliament on Wednesday endorsed labeling some gas and nuclear energy projects “green,” allowing them access to hundreds of billions of euros in cheap loans and even state subsidies.

headline: Three War Scenarios
abstract: And what will influence the outcome in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Avril Haines, the U.S. director of national intelligence, recently outlined three plausible scenarios in Ukraine.

headline: Parents of 8-Year-Old Were Accused of Her Murder. Now, So Are 12 More People.
abstract: Elizabeth Struhs of Queensland, Australia, died in January because, according to the police, she was denied medical care.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The police have charged 12 members of a religious group with murder in connection with the death of Elizabeth Struhs, 8, of Queensland state several months ago. The police say she was denied care over a period of days for an underlying medical condition.

headline: The battlefields of eastern Ukraine are largely abandoned fields and streets.
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign to capture Ukraine’s mineral-rich Donbas region was justified as a quest to protect the area’s Russian-speaking people. But only a fraction of them have stuck around as the Russian Army sweeps in.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military campaign to capture Ukraine’s mineral-rich Donbas region was justified as a quest to protect the area’s Russian-speaking people. But only a fraction of them have stuck around as the Russian Army sweeps in.

headline: ‘Fire of Love’ Review: A Volcanic Romance
abstract: Sara Dosa’s new documentary chronicles the lives and deaths of the French scientists Katia and Maurice Krafft.
lead_paragraph: The subjects of Sara Dosa’s new documentary “Fire of Love” are Maurice and Katia Krafft, married French scientists who devoted their lives to the study of volcanoes. Really, though, it might be more accurate to describe the couple, who died in a volcanic eruption in 1991, as co-directors, since they were the ones who captured the most arresting images in this curious and haunting film.

headline: Cancer Drug Greatly Reduces Deaths in Hospitalized Covid Patients
abstract: A new study found that sabizabulin reduced the risk of death by 55 percent, but some experts were cautious about overinterpreting the results.
lead_paragraph: An experimental drug initially developed to fight cancer cut the risk of death for people hospitalized with Covid by half, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: With a Culture War Raging Around Education, Where Does Art School Fit In?
abstract: T’s 2022 Art issue looks at how art is taught — if it can be taught at all — and what the future holds for aspiring talents.
lead_paragraph: Of all the areas of modern life that have been disrupted as of late, arguably none have suffered quite so absurdly as America’s system of education. Even to merely list, in oblique terms, a few of the basic problems of schools of all kinds in this country is to stare into the maw of a culture in decline. One major political party has decided the right to own semiautomatic rifles is more important than the lives of children, while the other has done little to counter it; state and federal policy has left young, economically vulnerable adults mired in unnecessary debt that many have no hope of repaying; increasingly mainstreamed extremists want to police behavior among students and teachers and rewrite history books in their favor.

headline: $830,000 Homes in Ohio, Connecticut and the District of Columbia
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.
lead_paragraph: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.

headline: $830,000 Homes in Ohio, Connecticut and the District of Columbia
abstract: A Spanish-style house in Oakwood, a 1764 Colonial in Lyme and a three-bedroom rowhouse in Washington.
lead_paragraph: In the years after the 1913 flood in Dayton, Ohio, many wealthy residents made their way to nearby Oakwood, where builders advertised lots as occupying higher ground than those in Dayton. This house is about half a mile from Hawthorn Hill, the former home of the inventor Orville Wright, and from the University of Dayton, a private Catholic school with around 12,000 students.

headline: A Brief Guide to the Wide, Wild World of Art Schools and Residencies
abstract: Thinking about applying? Not sure which route to take? Here’s an overview of 12 programs stretching from Frankfurt to Dakar to rural Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Future doctors are required to learn anatomy and much else. Lawyers must have a basic grasp of civil and criminal procedure and, in the United States, prove it by passing a bar exam. For professional artists, the path is less clear. Today, as the scholar Nicholas Houghton wrote in a 2016 paper on art school curriculums, “there are ever more things that could be taught without there being anything which has to be.” While particular skills — a mastery of perspective, say — may have been essential in some eras, in some places, artists now do anything and everything, from cooking food to social justice work to having specialists fabricate supersize sculptures for them and even, at least in the case of Sergio Muñoz Sarmiento, attending law school, as part of their practice.

headline: Creature Comforts
abstract: Animal life may not be the first thing that comes to mind about New York City, but look and you’ll find it.
lead_paragraph: In my first years in New York, summer, for me, always started with the seals.

headline: House Hunting on Majorca: A Stone Manor Mixing Spanish, French Styles
abstract: Unrelenting demand from foreign investors has drained the Spanish island’s inventory, spurring the government to take cooling measures.
lead_paragraph: This eight-bedroom stone manor house is in the town of Sóller, near the northwest coast of Majorca, one of Spain’s Balearic Islands in the heart of the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: Amazon strikes a deal with Grubhub as the food-delivery business struggles.
abstract: The e-commerce giant could take a stake in Grubhub, which is under pressure as delivery demand falls, labor shortages bite and new regulations reduce profits.
lead_paragraph: Financial turmoil in the food-delivery industry is presenting new opportunities for Amazon.

headline: Sajid Javid says ‘the problem starts at the top’ as more Conservatives call for Johnson to quit.
abstract: In explaining to Parliament why he stepped down from Boris Johnson’s government, Mr. Javid said, “Treading the tightrope between loyalty and integrity has become impossible in recent months.”
lead_paragraph: Sajid Javid, whose decision to step down as health minister on Tuesday helped plunge Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain into further political tumult, said in Parliament on Wednesday that he was “deeply concerned” about how the next generation would see Mr. Johnson’s Conservative Party.

headline: How to Prepare for California’s Wildfire Season
abstract: Tips for readying your home and packing your emergency bag.
lead_paragraph: By many accounts, this year’s fire season will be brutal.

headline: Mohammad Barkindo, OPEC’s top official, dies.
abstract: As secretary general, he steered the oil producers group in a turbulent era.
lead_paragraph: A prominent figure in the international oil industry, Mohammad Sanusi Barkindo, the secretary general of OPEC, died Tuesday in Nigeria, his home country, according to the oil producers group.

headline: A Darkened Outlook for Britain
abstract: The political instability comes as Britain gears up for a difficult summer, amid surging energy prices and labor shortages.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s political position continued to be on the rocks this morning as several lower-ranking ministers’ resignations followed two shattering defections last night. The moves raise questions about how long he can cling to power and what a change in leadership would look like for the British economy.

headline: ‘I Don’t Want to Help Him’: Joe Rogan Says He Refused Trump as a Podcast Guest
abstract: The commentator, who is no stranger to controversy, claimed he had declined several times to have the former president on his influential podcast on Spotify.
lead_paragraph: Joe Rogan, whose contrarian views on vaccines and political conspiracy theories have made him popular with many supporters of former President Donald J. Trump, revealed that he had declined to host Mr. Trump on his influential podcast several times.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 2: On ‘Why Strangers Are Good for Us’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Sophene Avedissian, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions
lead_paragraph: We received 815 entries from students from around the world for the second week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Sophene Avedissian as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: When Paying Dues Doesn’t Pay the Rent, How Does the Theater Survive?
abstract: Frank talk about salaries and the end of unpaid internships are positive steps, but the cost may be fewer opportunities to learn the ropes.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: They Loved Volcanoes and Each Other
abstract: A new documentary examines the work and lives of the French volcanologists Katia and Maurice Krafft, helped mightily by their own magnificent footage.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: These New Breastfeeding Guidelines Ignore the Reality of Many American Moms
abstract: On the heels of Roe being overturned, a formula shortage and the failure to pass the PUMP Act, the recommendation to breastfeed for “two years or beyond” was ill timed.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the American Academy of Pediatrics released an updated policy statement on breastfeeding that suggested increasing the duration of breastfeeding to two years or more from one year or more. As my Times colleague Catherine Pearson explained, this is the first update to the breastfeeding recommendations in a decade.

headline: ‘The Daily’ podcast looks at Brittney Griner’s detention in Russia.
abstract: In a new episode of “The Daily” podcast, Michael Crowley, a diplomatic correspondent for The New York Times, discusses the case of Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.
lead_paragraph: In a new episode of “The Daily” podcast, Michael Crowley, a diplomatic correspondent for The New York Times, discusses the case of Brittney Griner, the American W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.

headline: Real Estate Firm Tied to Trump Inquiry Fined for Contempt of Court
abstract: The firm, Cushman & Wakefield, was ordered to pay $10,000 a day until it complies with a subpoena. It appraised several Trump properties that are at the center of the New York attorney general’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: A New York state judge on Tuesday held one of the world’s largest real estate firms — which appraised several of former President Donald J. Trump’s properties — in contempt of court in connection with a civil investigation into whether he falsely inflated the value of his assets.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Secures Deal for Cipollone to Be Interviewed
abstract: The former White House counsel pushed back on President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election and was in the West Wing to witness his actions on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Pat A. Cipollone, the White House counsel to President Donald J. Trump who repeatedly fought Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election, has reached a deal to be interviewed by Friday before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Have a Pizza Party
abstract: Wednesdays can be rough. Order delivery and garnish the pie just how you like it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’d wager I cook more than your average newspaper editor. I enjoy feeding my family and appreciate the break it offers me from thinking about facts and figures, stories and consequences.

headline: ‘The Golden Age of Thrifting Is Over’
abstract: A glut of fast fashion has made its way into local thrift stores, making it hard for women who have been purchasing secondhand for decades to find quality garments they can wear.
lead_paragraph: Tina Koeppe grew up thrifting. When she was younger, she would spend weekends going to thrift stores with her mother, hunting for unique trinkets and garments but mostly looking for quality items to fit into her family’s tight budget. Now in her 40s and with a daughter of her own, Ms. Koeppe has carried the thriftiness of her youth into adulthood. Most of the furniture and décor in her home came from thrift stores. All of her clothes, except for her socks and underwear, were purchased secondhand.

headline: Job openings eased, in a sign of the cooling labor market.
abstract: The number of U.S. positions available was 11.3 million in May, the second straight monthly decline.
lead_paragraph: Employers became slightly less desperate for workers in May as job openings declined for the second straight month from a record high in March.

headline: When a Bra Won’t Cut It
abstract: For outfits that call for more than your typical undergarments, there’s tape.
lead_paragraph: Human beings are outliers in the animal kingdom in having permanently enlarged breasts — which is either a huge boon or a crushing burden, depending on how you look at it.

headline: U.K. Museums Face a Sticky Problem From Climate Protests
abstract: Activists are gluing themselves to the frames of iconic paintings. They say it does not matter whether their actions are popular — only whether they are noticed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Room 34 of the National Gallery in London was jammed with tourists Monday afternoon studying the masterpieces of British art on its walls, including J.M.W. Turner’s “The Fighting Temeraire,” which depicts a warship being towed to a breaker’s yard, and George Stubbs’s “Whistlejacket,” a huge painting of a horse rearing skyward.

headline: F.D.A. Lets Juul Appeal Ban and Stay on the Market During a Review
abstract: The F.D.A. has suspended its order to stop the company from selling its vaping products.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has decided to allow Juul Labs’ vaping products to stay on the market temporarily, citing “scientific issues” that warrant a review of the agency’s ruling last month to ban the company’s e-cigarettes.

headline: Biden administration seeks to curb student loan interest and simplify relief programs.
abstract: New rules would undo Trump administration actions and give borrowers an easier path through loan forgiveness programs.
lead_paragraph: The Education Department is preparing a raft of new rules for federal student loans that aims to expand access to various relief programs and undo changes made during the Trump administration.

headline: Her ‘Chagall’ Is Headed for the Trash. How’s That for Caveat Emptor?
abstract: Stephanie Clegg paid $90,000 for a Marc Chagall painting at a Sotheby’s auction in 1994. It was reappraised for $100,000 in 2008. Now an expert panel in France wants to destroy it as a fake.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether a valuable artwork is genuine can be surprisingly fluid, changing over time based on evolving and sometime competing evaluations.

headline: America at 246: An Unvarnished Look
abstract: Several Americans and a foreigner weigh in on the state of America today. Also: Legal, safer cannabis.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Highland Park Shooting Reveals Limits of Illinois’s Gun Restrictions
abstract: Legislators and gun control advocates are asking how the 21-year-old suspect was able to buy several weapons despite alarming police encounters and relatively strict state laws.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — On Monday morning, Julie Morrison, an Illinois state senator, was sitting in the back of a convertible, waving to Fourth of July paradegoers, her grandchildren walking alongside the car. Ms. Morrison, a Democrat, had made combating gun violence a priority in her legislative career, and had been the chief sponsor of the state’s “red flag” law, which set up a system in which guns can be taken from someone found to be dangerous.

headline: The Shape-Shifting Sherlock Holmes, Now Playing the Villain
abstract: The world’s first consulting detective has appeared in many disguises, including clergyman, sailor and old woman. Now, in a new podcast, he is cast as a monster.
lead_paragraph: Sherlock Holmes was born, magnifying glass in hand, in the 1887 edition of Beeton’s Christmas Annual. In the first chapter of that entry, Arthur Conan Doyle’s “A Study in Scarlet,” a character described Holmes this way: “He is a little queer in his ideas — an enthusiast in some branches of science. As far as I know he is a decent fellow enough.”

headline: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who is accused of killing Nipsey Hussle.
abstract: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who was accused of murder in the 2019 shooting death of the Los Angeles-based rapper Nipsey Hussle, according to court officials.
lead_paragraph: The jury has reached a verdict in the trial of Eric R. Holder Jr., who was accused of murder in the 2019 shooting death of the Los Angeles-based rapper Nipsey Hussle, according to court officials.

headline: Democrats Offer Plan to Cut Drug Costs, Seeking Climate and Tax Deal
abstract: The drug-pricing plan was negotiated with Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, but Democrats remain short of agreement on what else would be included in any domestic policy package.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top Senate Democrats on Wednesday released an updated plan aimed at lowering the cost of prescription drugs, signaling progress on a crucial piece of their bid to salvage some of President Biden’s stalled social safety net, climate and tax bill.

headline: Art School Confidential
abstract: David Salle, Miranda July, Mariko Mori and others talk about their experiences attending (or leaving or forgoing) the academy.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not one decides to go to art school depends on a great number of factors, including, of course, one’s ability to get in, which sometimes has more to do with luck than with talent, not to mention an awareness that art school even exists and that being an artist is a viable option, which for many people, especially those from disadvantaged communities, can be a discovery in itself. This aside, it’s usually a matter of weighing the benefits — namely training and time and space to think and make work — against the often literal and sometimes substantial costs. There’s no clear answer, but what is clear is that art school alone cannot make you an artist, or shield you from self-doubt, uncertainty or rejection. Perhaps for this reason, some artists are most grateful for the sense of community provided by those they met while students — often a classmate or teacher becomes a lifelong friend, collaborator or mentor, someone who shows up regardless of the state of the other person’s career.

headline: Tobias Kratzer Is Leading Opera’s Next Generation of Directors
abstract: With concurrent productions in France that are fresh yet faithful, Kratzer is “renewing opera, but renewing it intelligently,” says one colleague.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — Scan the programming of Europe’s biggest opera houses, and you’ll see familiar names among the directors.

headline: The Latest on Abortion in the States
abstract: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.

headline: In Newport, Artists Turn Tables on the Gilded Age
abstract: In historic mansions where Sargent and Boldini reigned, a new generation of portraitists unites against the Old Guard for a summer show.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT, R.I. — When visitors tour Stanford White’s Rosecliff this summer, one of the storied historical mansions where HBO’s “The Gilded Age” is filmed, they will find, among the antique heirlooms, a freshly painted life-size portrait of a woman wearing a casual gray pantsuit, a leopard-patterned fedora, and dark sunglasses.

headline: Bryannita Nicholson testified that she drove Eric R. Holder Jr. to and from the scene of the crime.
abstract: Bryannita Nicholson, who had been casually seeing the defendant, Eric R. Holder Jr., testified that she had driven him to and from the scene of the shooting, providing one of the prosecution’s key accounts of the episode.
lead_paragraph: Bryannita Nicholson, who had been casually seeing the defendant, Eric R. Holder Jr., testified that she had driven him to and from the scene of the shooting, providing one of the prosecution’s key accounts of the episode.

headline: Biden Speaks to Cherelle Griner About Her Wife’s Detention in Russia
abstract: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris told Cherelle Griner they would pursue “every avenue” to bring her wife, Brittney Griner, home from Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris spoke on Wednesday with Cherelle Griner, the wife of the W.N.B.A. star Brittney Griner. Brittney Griner has been detained in Russia on drug charges since February, and her trial began Friday.

headline: The Latin of Software Code Is Thriving
abstract: Next time you laugh at musty old tech, remember that new technologies are often built on it.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Mooney is 24 years old and infatuated with technology that dates to the age of Sputnik.

headline: Man Who Shot the Rapper Nipsey Hussle Is Convicted of Murder
abstract: A jury found Eric R. Holder Jr. guilty of first-degree murder for the 2019 killing of Hussle, an artist who devoted his adult life to championing his South Los Angeles neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than three years after the fatal shooting of the rapper Nipsey Hussle, whose 2019 killing in front of the local clothing store he owned scarred the South Los Angeles neighborhood he had devoted his adult life to championing, a jury on Wednesday found Eric R. Holder Jr. guilty of first-degree murder in the case. The verdict closes a painful chapter in recent hip-hop history.

headline: The Real Reason the Minions Have Taken Over the World
abstract: Wordless, antic, physical: The film franchise’s comedy is nothing like prevailing family entertainment, and that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Photos: Battling the Electra fire in Northern California.
abstract: The wildfire is burning 50 miles southeast of Sacramento in the Sierra Nevada foothills
lead_paragraph: A wildfire burning 50 miles southeast of Sacramento in the Sierra Nevada foothills had exploded by Wednesday to 3,900 acres, prompting evacuation orders for thousands of people and injuring an emergency medical worker.

headline: Global oil prices dip below $100, a sign that recession fears are taking hold.
abstract: Oil prices have been slipping over the last two weeks, but the drop has accelerated in recent days.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The global benchmark for oil dropped below $100 a barrel on Wednesday for the first time since late April as fears of a looming recession spread among traders.

headline: A team of Ukrainian medics navigates life and death on the battlefield.
abstract: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Between the cracks of mortar fire and the metallic bangs of Russian self-detonating mines, Yurii, a Ukrainian Army medic, readied an intravenous line for the soldier sprawled on the stretcher below him.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK REGION, Ukraine — Between the cracks of mortar fire and the metallic bangs of Russian self-detonating mines, Yurii, a Ukrainian Army medic, readied an intravenous line for the soldier sprawled on the stretcher below him.

headline: China Seeks to Pre-Empt Sanctions in Case of Taiwan Clash, F.B.I. Chief Says
abstract: Looking ahead to a possible conflict, Beijing wants to shield itself from the kind of economic penalties levied against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, the F.B.I. director says.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Learning from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, China is looking for ways to protect its economy from the threat of international sanctions should a confrontation over Taiwan occur, “a clue” to Beijing’s view of what the future holds, the F.B.I. director said Wednesday.

headline: Fed officials, spooked by data, fretted in June about inflation becoming entrenched.
abstract: Central bankers raised rates by the most since 1994 last month, and minutes from the gathering explained their logic.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials made their biggest interest rate increase since 1994 at their June meeting, after incoming inflation data spooked them, minutes from the meeting showed, with policymakers expressing concern that stubbornly persistent price pressures posed a “significant risk” of becoming a more permanent feature of the economy if the central bank did not act decisively.

headline: A Year Since a President’s Murder, Haitians Keep Waiting to Hit Rock Bottom
abstract: In the year since President Jovenel Moïse was killed, the country’s despair has deepened. Gangs now vie with the government for control.
lead_paragraph: The warring gangs took over several neighborhoods around Port-au-Prince weeks ago, going door to door, raping women and girls, killing the men, beheading many of the adults and then forcing the newly orphaned children into their ranks.

headline: Ethnic Killings in Ethiopia Add to Crisis
abstract: Allegations of a second recent ethnic massacre in the restive region of Oromia further destabilize a country already coping with civil war in a northern region.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Crises are multiplying across Ethiopia: hunger from the worst drought in four decades, skirmishes with neighboring Sudan and a brutal 20-month-long civil war in the northern region of Tigray.

headline: A Neurologist’s Tips to Protect Your Memory
abstract: A new book by a renowned brain expert says there are a few simple things we can do to prevent memory decline as we age.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: ‘Son of Elsewhere,’ a Funny and Frank Story About Life After a Big Move
abstract: In his “memoir in pieces,” Elamin Abdelmahmoud writes about the years after he and his family emigrated from Sudan to Canada when he was 12.
lead_paragraph: As an immigrant kid in Kingston, one of the whitest cities in Canada, Elamin Abdelmahmoud learned pretty quickly that he was Black. At first this was news to him: He had spent the first 12 years of his life in Sudan identifying as Arab — when he thought about his identity at all.

headline: 70 million Americans are under heat warnings or advisories.
abstract: Overnight temperatures won’t drop off during the heat wave as much as usual, raising concerns about the health of vulnerable people.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures across the middle of the United States were called “oppressive” by the National Weather Service on Thursday, as cities throughout the region dealt with a spike in heat-related health emergencies and tried to offer relief in cooling centers.

headline: The Thirst for Merch
abstract: Virgil Abloh fans, art lovers and resellers flocked to the opening of “Figures of Speech” at the Brooklyn Museum, hoping to take home a piece of fashion history.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, a cloudless sky stretched above the Brooklyn Museum. As the sun marked the arrival of a sweltering July, clusters of people lined up an hour before opening to be the first ones inside.

headline: The Economy Is Already Cooling, So Why Is the Fed Dousing It With Cold Water?
abstract: The bank’s aggressive rate-raising could lead to a recession.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve would do well to remember the old saying: Two wrongs don’t make a right. Its first wrong was ignoring inflation. The second — the one it’s committing right now — is fighting inflation too hard.

headline: Former President of U.S.A. Softball Accused of Abusing Minors
abstract: The Sacramento County Sheriff’s Office said the allegations were not related to the softball federation itself.
lead_paragraph: The former president of U.S.A. Softball, John Gouveia, was arrested in April and charged with a number of sex acts with minors.

headline: Johnson follows a familiar playbook in his response to the latest scandal.
abstract: The British prime minister’s blueprint for dealing with a crisis, his critics say, almost never begins, and rarely ends, with simply telling the truth.
lead_paragraph: This latest scandal, over a deputy whip in Parliament accused of sexual misconduct, is just one in a long, wearyingly similar series of self-inflicted troubles to befall Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government.

headline: Steam Deck Review: A Game Console for the Quintessential Gamer
abstract: This new hand-held gaming device by Valve is lots of fun. But perhaps not as much if you’re a casual gamer.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new hard-to-get game console this year that’s not a PlayStation or an Xbox. It’s sold online only. Most casual gamers probably haven’t heard of it.

headline: The Academy Museum Names Jacqueline Stewart as New Leader
abstract: The film historian and preservationist specializes in Black cinema and silent movies. She had been serving as the institution’s chief artistic and programming officer.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures on Wednesday named Jacqueline Stewart, a film scholar who worked to make the long-delayed project a reality, as its new director and president.

headline: U.S. pharmacists receive permission from the F.D.A. to prescribe Pfizer’s Covid pills.
abstract: Previously, only doctors, nurses or physician assistants were allowed to prescribe the treatment, known as Paxlovid.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration added pharmacists on Wednesday to the list of health care professionals who are allowed to prescribe Pfizer’s pills for treating Covid-19. The move, aimed at making it easier for patients to get the drug, will significantly increase the number of prescribers who can order the treatment, known as Paxlovid.

headline: Europe, Facing Energy Shortages, Moves to Shore Up Providers
abstract: Berlin and Paris are preparing bailouts as Europe braces for further cuts to gas supplies next week and economists warn of a recession.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Leaders in Europe, facing their worst energy crisis in decades, are taking extraordinary steps to secure supplies for winter amid fears of fuel shortages and near-record electricity and natural gas prices.

headline: Will Nadal Be Ready for His Wimbledon Semifinal and Kyrgios?
abstract: Nadal struggled with an abdominal injury in his grueling quarterfinal victory over Taylor Fritz, a rising American star who pushed Nadal to five sets.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — It was Wednesday evening on Centre Court, and Rafael Nadal was back in the semifinals of Wimbledon after proving once again that his threshold for pain and ability to improvise under duress are far beyond the norm.

headline: Yankees’ Update on Aaron Judge: There Will Be No Updates
abstract: Hal Steinbrenner, the team’s managing general partner, said he, like Judge, did not want any contract-related distractions while the team pursued a championship. But he wouldn’t mind more pitching.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was the midpoint of the Yankees’ 2022 season. Through 81 games, they not only had the best record (58-23) in Major League Baseball, but they also were on a pace to match the 1906 Chicago Cubs and the 2001 Seattle Mariners for the most wins (116) in a 162-game regular season.

headline: ‘Do It, I Dare You.’
abstract: Step inside the secret, beautiful world of a nanny in New York City and his tiny companion.
lead_paragraph: In his early 20s, Kevin Renn moved to New York City with dreams of making it as a playwright. When money got tight, he decided to fall back on a familiar option: babysitting.

headline: As Russia cuts gas shipments, Europe moves to bail out energy providers.
abstract: BERLIN — Leaders in Europe, facing their worst energy crisis in decades, are taking extraordinary steps to secure supplies for winter amid fears of fuel shortages and near-record electricity and natural gas prices.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Leaders in Europe, facing their worst energy crisis in decades, are taking extraordinary steps to secure supplies for winter amid fears of fuel shortages and near-record electricity and natural gas prices.

headline: Ukraine’s Herculean Task: Helping Millions Whose Homes Are in Ruins or Russia’s Hands
abstract: Millions of Ukrainians have fled their homes as Russia has slowly advanced in the east. Many may not have a home to go back to when the war is over.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When she fled her home in eastern Ukraine, Hanna Obuzhevanna, 71, gave her keys to her neighbor to water the blooming cyclamen on her balcony, thinking she’d be back in just a few weeks.

headline: France, Hoping to Weather Energy Crisis, Will Renationalize Electricity Giant
abstract: The state already has a majority stake in France’s main electricity and nuclear company. The move reflected President Emmanuel Macron’s desire to champion economic and energy sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France said on Wednesday that it would renationalize its state-backed electricity giant to help ensure the country’s energy sovereignty as Europe faces a worsening energy crisis from Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: Nakedness Is Everywhere in Fashion, Even the Heel of a Shoe
abstract: Four fake legs held up two real legs at Alaïa.
lead_paragraph: All fashion week, we will be spotlighting the small details we saw on the runways that surprised or delighted us: Bring on the portable fog machines and antique fork jewelry.

headline: Bird Flu May Have Caused Seal Strandings
abstract: Unusually high numbers of the marine mammals were found stranded in the last two months along Maine’s coast. Samples from four seals tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza.
lead_paragraph: The highly pathogenic avian influenza strain that has whipped through flocks of domestic poultry and wild birds this year may also be to blame for a spike in seal strandings in Maine, U.S. officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: War Displaces Millions of Ukrainians
abstract: Also, Boris Johnson battles to keep his job and Europe labels gas and nuclear energy “green.”
lead_paragraph: An estimated third of Ukraine’s population has been forced from home since Russia invaded in February, including an often unseen group of more than six million people who have been displaced within the country.

headline: Derecho Brings Green Sky and ‘Tornado-Like’ Winds to South Dakota
abstract: Meteorologists recorded winds of up to 99 miles per hour in parts of the state, with minor damage reported.
lead_paragraph: South Dakotans are accustomed to the storms known as derechos — they’ve had two recently. What they’re not used to seeing is skies that turn green right before severe weather tears through the region.

headline: With infections surging, Cyprus reinstates an indoor mask mandate.
abstract: The mandate will be enforced with spot inspections and fines of up to 300 euros ($305) for violators.
lead_paragraph: Bucking a global trend away from mandatory pandemic safety measures, Cyprus said on Wednesday that face masks would once again be required in indoor public settings.

headline: Lesley Gore’s Archive, Open to All, Arrives at the New York Public Library
abstract: The collection, which includes family photos, scrapbook pages and annotated music, traces the singer’s arc from releasing bubble gum hits to creating a powerful feminist statement.
lead_paragraph: As a teenage singer in the 1960s who fit the all-American girl mold, Lesley Gore may have seemed like an unlikely figure to carve out a lasting legacy of feminist resilience and independence. The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts has now made the musician’s archive available for anyone interested in her artistic evolution, giving fans a chance to browse through notated music sheets and an unfinished memoir.

headline: Kyrgios, Under a Hotter Spotlight, Stays Quiet and Wins Again
abstract: A day after the emergence of allegations that he assaulted a former girlfriend, Kyrgios found a way to advance to a Wimbledon semifinal but declined to address the accusations afterward.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The tennis career of Nick Kyrgios has long been an exercise in torture and turmoil, featuring battles with tennis officials, rivals, the news media, alcohol and a psyche that never seems at peace, even when he swears it is. Kyrgios said he contemplated suicide in 2019.

headline: Willie Lee Morrow, Barber Who Popularized the Afro Pick, Dies at 82
abstract: He built an empire around hair care products aimed at African American consumers, including a softener that inspired the Jheri curl.
lead_paragraph: Willie Lee Morrow, a son of Alabama sharecroppers who built a business empire around hair care products aimed at African American consumers, among them a comb designed to work with the natural styles that exploded in popularity in the 1960s — a tool he called the Afro Tease, but which came to be known as the Afro pick — died on June 22 at his home in San Diego. He was 82.

headline: White House Communications Director Plans to Step Down
abstract: Kate Bedingfield will be the latest senior adviser to leave the Biden administration, whose messaging has faced growing criticism from Democrats.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kate Bedingfield, the White House communications director, will step down from her position this summer, White House aides said on Wednesday, marking the latest departure of a senior adviser from the Biden administration.

headline: What Amazon Prime’s Deal With Grubhub Means for Consumers
abstract: A new collaboration between the retailing giant and the food distribution service includes free restaurant delivery for Prime members.
lead_paragraph: Under earnings pressure after a big loss last year, the food distribution company Grubhub struck a deal with Amazon on Wednesday, offering restaurant delivery services without a fee for Amazon Prime members.

headline: ‘Hello, Goodbye and Everything in Between’ Review: Break Cute?
abstract: In this adaptation of Jennifer E. Smith’s young adult novel, two high school seniors agree to split up in a year. Will they honor their pact?
lead_paragraph: Early in the teenage-targeted romantic comedy “Hello, Goodbye, and Everything in Between” — based on Jennifer E. Smith’s young adult novel — a senior, Aidan (Jordan Fisher), performs a Ferris Bueller-like rendition of “Twist and Shout” at a house party to the amusement of a new classmate, Clare (Talia Ryder). Before the evening ends, the two have shared a kiss and make a pact to dissolve whatever relationship might follow in a year’s time. (Having seen the downside of her divorced parents’ high school romance, Clare insists and Aidan signs on.)

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Read the document
abstract: These are the letters that James B. Comey and Andrew G. McCabe received from the I.R.S.
lead_paragraph: These are the letters that James B. Comey and Andrew G. McCabe received from the I.R.S.

headline: Jake Paul Gets New Opponent After Tommy Fury’s Travel Troubles
abstract: Fury was denied entry to the United States as his family faces questions about connections to Daniel Kinahan, a promoter who the U.S. says is also the head of a drug cartel.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in eight months, a Jake Paul and Tommy Fury fight has been canceled.

headline: Comey and McCabe, Who Infuriated Trump, Both Faced Intensive I.R.S. Audits
abstract: The former F.B.I. director and his deputy, both of whom former President Donald J. Trump wanted prosecuted, were selected for a rare audit program that the tax agency says is random.
lead_paragraph: Among tax lawyers, the most invasive type of random audit carried out by the I.R.S. is known, only partly jokingly, as “an autopsy without the benefit of death.”

headline: N.Y.C. Ferry System Lost Track of $224 Million, Audit Finds
abstract: The city’s comptroller, which conducted the audit, said that the semi-independent city agency that runs the ferry network had made decisions resulting in millions of dollars in unnecessary expenses.
lead_paragraph: The agency in charge of running New York City’s ferry system failed to report nearly a quarter-billion dollars in costs during the administration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, the city comptroller announced on Wednesday in a 50-page audit.

headline: Six Million Uprooted
abstract: Ukraine faces a humanitarian crisis from mass displacement.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Explosion Destroys Mysterious Monument in Georgia, Authorities Say
abstract: For more than four decades, the Georgia Guidestones near Elberton Ga., have been an enigma. On Wednesday, the authorities said, “unknown individuals” destroyed a large part of the structure.
lead_paragraph: An explosive device that “unknown individuals” detonated early Wednesday destroyed a granite monument in Georgia that was built under mysterious circumstances more than four decades ago and promoted by state officials as “America’s Stonehenge,” the authorities said.

headline: Parents Sue TikTok, Saying Children Died After Viewing ‘Blackout Challenge’
abstract: The suit, involving girls ages 8 and 9, claims TikTok knew or should have known that its product was “addictive” and was directing children to dangerous content.
lead_paragraph: The parents of two girls who said their children died as a result of a “blackout challenge” on TikTok are suing the company, claiming its algorithm intentionally served the children dangerous content that led to their deaths.

headline: Fed Moves Toward Another Big Rate Increase as Inflation Lingers
abstract: As the Federal Reserve battles rapid inflation, officials are likely to stay on an aggressive path even as signs of economic cooling emerge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, determined to choke off rapid inflation before it becomes a permanent feature of the American economy, is steering toward another three-quarter-point interest rate increase later this month even as the economy shows early signs of slowing and recession fears mount.

headline: What Is Prosopagnosia, a Condition That Causes ‘Face Blindness’?
abstract: Brad Pitt has said he might have prosopagnosia, which affects his ability to recognize people. Here’s what to know about the condition.
lead_paragraph: The actor Brad Pitt said in a recent interview that he has prosopagnosia, a rare neurological disorder commonly referred to as face blindness. While Mr. Pitt, 58, has never been formally diagnosed with the condition, he said in an interview with GQ that he had struggled for years to recognize people’s faces.

headline: A Feminist, Neorealist, Communist Film, and a Plain Great Movie
abstract: “One Way or Another,” from 1974, is a class-conscious love story involving a macho worker and a well-to-do schoolteacher in Cuba.
lead_paragraph: Dialectical from opening title to final image, “One Way or Another” — the first and only feature by the Afro-Cuban director Sara Gómez — introduces itself as “a film about real people, and some fictitious ones.” That’s one way to describe this deft mixture of cinéma vérité, ethnographic documentary, feminist social realism and class-conscious revolutionary romance.

headline: Bradford Freeman, Last of the ‘Band of Brothers,’ Dies at 97
abstract: The exploits of his World War II paratroop company were chronicled in a best-selling book and then in an acclaimed HBO mini-series.
lead_paragraph: Bradford Freeman, the last survivor of the World War II paratroop company whose combat exploits were described in the best-selling book and subsequent mini-series “Band of Brothers,” died on Sunday in Columbus, Miss. He was 97.

headline: Allies Abandon Boris Johnson Amid Latest Scandal, but He Vows to Go On
abstract: A wave of resignations — more than 50 by Thursday — and calls for him to step down showed the prime minister’s support within his Conservative Party melting away, but he remained defiant.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson will resign as his party’s leader. Follow live updates.

headline: What are the symptoms of an infection with BA.5?
abstract: BA.5 has become dominant in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: In July, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that the Omicron subvariant BA.5 had become overwhelmingly dominant in the U.S.

headline: Steve Ballmer Is Building a ‘Moneyball’ for Government
abstract: The former Microsoft chief executive, N.B.A. franchise owner and self-professed data nerd has big plans for his young nonprofit.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Ballmer retired from Microsoft in 2014, his wife, Connie Snyder, informed him his next job would be to help run the family philanthropy, which fosters upward economic mobility among children from lower-income families.

headline: The subvariants of summer
abstract: BA.4 and BA.5 are taking over.
lead_paragraph: The troublesome hits just keep coming from the Omicron strains — and each sequel is more contagious than the last.

headline: Biden Promised to Stay Above the Fray, but Democrats Want a Fighter
abstract: President Biden’s measured approach at a time of political tumult has left him struggling to inspire his supporters and allies to action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Forty-eight hours after a horrific mass shooting on the Fourth of July, President Biden flew to Ohio on Wednesday for a speech on pension plans.

headline: Jerry Harris Sentenced to 12 Years for Sex Crimes Involving Minors
abstract: Mr. Harris, who shot to reality-TV fame in the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” had pleaded guilty to federal charges related to soliciting child sexual abuse imagery and illegal sexual conduct with a minor.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Chicago sentenced Jerry Harris, the Navarro College cheerleader who became a breakout star of the Netflix documentary series “Cheer,” to 12 years in prison on Wednesday on guilty pleas to two of seven federal charges related to sex crimes involving minors in February.

headline: Witnesses in Young Thug Case Have Been Threatened, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Following a May indictment accusing the rapper and 27 others of gang-related crimes, defense lawyers must now withhold witnesses’ contact information from their clients.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Citing “numerous threats to kill or harm witnesses,” prosecutors in the case against the rapper Young Thug and a group of his associates who are accused of being part of a violent street gang have secured an order that forces defense lawyers to withhold witnesses’ contact information from their clients, court documents show.

headline: The Strident Writings of a Young Blake Masters Dog His Senate Run
abstract: As a Stanford student in 2007, the Arizona candidate, now 35, chose a CrossFit chat room to express his opposition to U.S. involvement in World War II and downplay Al Qaeda as a threat to Americans.
lead_paragraph: Blake Masters, a Republican candidate for the Senate in Arizona who won the endorsement of former President Donald J. Trump, has been dogged by a trail of youthful writings in which he lamented the entry of the United States into the First and Second World Wars, approvingly quoted a Nazi war criminal and pushed an isolationism that extended beyond even Mr. Trump’s.

headline: Food insecurity and hunger afflicted 2.3 billion people in 2021, and the war will add more, the U.N. says.
abstract: Global hunger and the chronic inability to access food skyrocketed in 2021, with 2.3 billion people facing moderate or severe food insecurity around the world, the United Nations said in a report released Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Global hunger and the chronic inability to access food skyrocketed in 2021, with 2.3 billion people facing moderate or severe food insecurity around the world, the United Nations said in a report released Wednesday.

headline: Show the Carnage
abstract: Would images from mass shootings shock the country out of its morbid malaise and into action to address the public health crisis guns have created?
lead_paragraph: In an interview with CNN on Tuesday, Dr. David Baum, an obstetrician in the Chicago suburb of Highland Park, described the “horrific scene” when a gunman rained rifle shots down on a Fourth of July parade through the community on Monday.

headline: Corrections: July 7, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 7, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the Justice Department’s lawsuit against Arizona because of a new state voting law misstated the number of times the department, under Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, has challenged a state’s voting law. It is four times, not three.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Two Adversaries of Trump Faced Major I.R.S. Audits
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 7, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Lightning strikes, and that’s unusual, and that’s what it’s like being picked for one of these audits. The question is: Does lightning then strike again in the same area?”

headline: Opening in a Magic Act
abstract: Philip Wolfe makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There are certain pastimes that make it easy for people to fall down a rabbit hole. When I take up a new hobby, I find myself reading everything I can get my hands on about it, and, more often than not, that research will lead me to try something related. This is why I have so many half-finished knitting projects strewn about the house.

headline: A top Russian official threatens the U.S. with the ‘wrath of God’ over war crime investigations.
abstract: One of Russia’s leading political figures on Wednesday rattled his country’s nuclear capabilities and threatened the United States with the “wrath of God” for pursuing war crimes investigations against Russia.
lead_paragraph: One of Russia’s leading political figures on Wednesday rattled his country’s nuclear capabilities and threatened the United States with the “wrath of God” for pursuing war crimes investigations against Russia.

headline: Europe is heating up faster than other ‘hot spots,’ a study finds.
abstract: A new study confirmed that European heat events are increasing in frequency and cumulative intensity over the last four decades.
lead_paragraph: The extreme heat wave that has enveloped Spain and Portugal and is spreading to the north and east is just the latest such event in Western Europe, which now experiences periods of potentially lethal hot weather almost every summer. This year, parts of the region suffered through intense heat even before summer began.

headline: Doubles Tennis Is Wimbledon’s Best Kept (and Most Fun) Secret
abstract: Doubles takes a back seat to the singles game on both tours, but famous players like Coco Gauff revel in the variety, pace and joy of tennis’s hidden gem.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Coco Gauff toed the line to serve, eyes focused, shoulders back, ready to go. It was a moment of peril in her semifinal mixed doubles match here on Wednesday. Break point. One game all, third set.

headline: Start-Up Funding Falls the Most It Has Since 2019
abstract: The drop was another fallout of rising inflation and widespread economic uncertainty, and a retreat after years of a funding boom.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the first time in three years, start-up funding is dropping.

headline: For Foreign Fighters in Ukraine, a War Unlike Any They’ve Seen
abstract: Small groups of Western combat veterans are on the front lines, but many more with fewer skills are left trying to find a role to play.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Four months after Russia invaded Ukraine, foreign combat veterans who answered the Ukrainian president’s call to fight are grappling with the grueling reality of a war unlike any they have seen.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Boris Johnson’s crumbling support.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson, the British prime minister, has resisted calls to resign, even as a delegation of cabinet members yesterday went to Downing Street to plead with him to step down. More than 30 government ministers and aides have so far quit — yet Johnson has vowed to fight on, insisting he has a mandate from voters to steer Britain into its post-Brexit future.

headline: Boris Johnson Made a Terrible Mistake: He Apologized
abstract: The prime minister’s contrition opened the floodgates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson’s time as prime minister has at last reached its denouement.

headline: What the Gateway Deal Means for New Yorkers
abstract: A Times reporter breaks down how the long-stalled Hudson River train tunnel project could help the city, and why it might now actually happen.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at the nuts and bolts of the Hudson River tunnel project that just cleared a major hurdle, and why it’s so important to New York, New Jersey and even the country. And we’ll dig into the money and transparency problems the city comptroller just revealed in New York’s ferry system.

headline: On the London Stage, Families in Disarray
abstract: Two new plays, “The Southbury Child” and “Mad House,” explore domestic discord with contrasting degrees of success.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Families are having a hard time on the London stage of late, and in one instance, at least, balloons are partly to blame. That’s the unusual starting point of “The Southbury Child,” a lively if uneven new play from Stephen Beresford that has arrived at the Bridge Theater (through Aug. 27) after its premiere south of London last month at the Chichester Festival Theater.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Ken Auletta Finally Wrote the Harvey Weinstein Story He Wanted to Tell
abstract: The New Yorker writer talks about his new Weinstein biography, and the worst person he ever covered. It’s someone else.

headline: The Largest Ever Exhibition on African Fashion Just Opened in London
abstract: A landmark exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum charts the influence of the African fashion scene.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The influence of Africa and its fashion scene has redefined the geography of the fashion industry in recent years, breaking barriers with its vitality and its reimagining of what creativity can be.

headline: Officials Balked at a Drug Company’s Tax Shelter. Auditors Approved It Anyway.
abstract: Court documents show the potential conflicts of interest when accounting firms simultaneously help clients avoid taxes and audit their finances.
lead_paragraph: The drug company Perrigo had a problem.

headline: Blockbusters at Balenciaga and Margiela
abstract: Plus performance art at Viktor & Rolf. Sometimes a fashion show is not just a fashion show.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was just a regular Wednesday afternoon — except the sidewalks of the normally sedate Avenue Georges V were clogged by a shrieking mass of teenagers, smartphones aloft, free hands waving over police barriers in a frenzy. It was the sort of scene that wouldn’t be surprising outside a rock concert or a major movie premiere or even the Oscars, except that this was none of the above. It was a Balenciaga couture show.

headline: The Pincher scandal is only the latest in a long line of controversies for Johnson.
abstract: The fallout from Boris Johnson’s appointment of Chris Pincher to a government post, and Downing Street’s shifting account of the circumstances around the decision, dominated the recent political conversation in Britain.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from Boris Johnson’s appointment of Chris Pincher to a government post, and Downing Street’s shifting account of the circumstances around the decision, dominated the recent political conversation in Britain.

headline: What the BA.5 Subvariant Could Mean for the United States
abstract: The most transmissible variant yet of the coronavirus is threatening a fresh wave of infections in the United States, even among those who have recovered from the virus fairly recently.
lead_paragraph: The most transmissible variant yet of the coronavirus is threatening a fresh wave of infections in the United States, even among those who have recovered from the virus fairly recently.

headline: A Studio on the East Side of Manhattan for Less Than $500,000? These Were His Options.
abstract: When a Philadelphia-area native headed north to New York, he wanted enough space for a bed and a sofa — and room to do some cooking. Here’s what he found.
lead_paragraph: When a Philadelphia-area native headed north to New York, he wanted enough space for a bed and a sofa — and room to do some cooking. Here’s what he found.

headline: Can You Answer These Sex Ed Questions? A Post-Roe Quiz
abstract: The key concepts every person should know.
lead_paragraph: The key concepts every person should know.

headline: Poem: Sister Song
abstract: A longing for and memory of a murdered brother
lead_paragraph: The ghazal is a formal poem that has roots in seventh-century Arabia and was often sung by musicians. The poet Agha Shahid Ali introduced the form to America. “Ghazal” literally means “the cry of a gazelle” as it is being chased and about to die. Like many formal poems such as the sonnet, the ghazal, with its restrictions, can paradoxically illuminate and parse difficult emotions. In López’s poem, the emotion is grief — a longing for and memory of a murdered brother. This poem mostly follows the parameters of a ghazal with its repeated end word, “song,” and the inside rhyme of “forever,” “far,” “marred,” etc., as well as the poet’s name or reference to the poet (“Sister”) in the final line. One way this poem breaks the rules is that each couplet doesn’t stand alone as if it were its own poem. Instead, the end of the couplets often bleed into the next stanza, linking the narratives. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Crass Bumper Sticker
abstract: A husband and wife disagree about how to decorate the car.
lead_paragraph: Grace writes: My husband’s car has a bumper sticker that reads: “Please don’t fart around my kids.” I drive this car often and am mortified when I see people looking at the bumper. My husband loves the sticker, and I believe a lot of his enjoyment comes from my hating it so much. Can you please order him to remove it?

headline: The Cultural Dread of the Bad Mother
abstract: The narrator of Katixa Agirre’s “Mothers Don’t” obsesses over a distant acquaintance who murdered her two infant children.
lead_paragraph: Midway through “Mothers Don’t,” by the Basque author Katixa Agirre, two mothers, the unnamed narrator and her college friend Léa, go out to get drunk and eat oysters. On the surface it’s a standard mothers’ night out — sundresses, scandalous confessions and the relief of escaping the domestic — but the evening is haunted by their former friend Alice, who is on trial for killing her twin infants.

headline: In Russia, Gay People Are Routinely Targeted. That’s Why This Ukrainian Soldier Is Fighting.
abstract: When Putin invaded, Oleksandr Zhuhan chose to defend a country that hasn’t always defended him.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginning of the war, Ukrainians of all backgrounds have come together to fight their common enemy, Russia. But for some Ukrainians, that enemy holds particular terror. In Russia, gay people are routinely targeted for their identity — arrested without cause and even tortured. That’s what motivated Oleksandr Zhuhan to join the volunteer Territorial Defense Forces, despite experiencing homophobia in Ukraine.

headline: What’s Wrong With Health Insurance? Deductibles Are Ridiculous, for Starters.
abstract: Cost-sharing is not working as intended.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 million Americans have medical debt, according to a recent Kaiser Health News-NPR investigation. And about a quarter of American adults with this debt owe more than $5,000. This isn’t because they’re uninsured. More often, it’s because they’re underinsured.

headline: It’s Time to Stop Living the American Scam
abstract: We’ve been “productive” enough — produced way too much, in fact. And there is too much that urgently needs to be done.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, I wrote an essay called “The Busy Trap,” about the curse of “busyness” that seemed endemic at the time. The treadmill had been imperceptibly increasing its speed for a while, and people were nervously starting to notice. As happens with a lot of unavoidable evils, they tried to rebrand their frantic busyness as a virtue. “Busy — so busy, crazy busy,” was the answer you got whenever you asked how they were. I came out, in my essay, as anti-busy; I advocated idling, daydreaming, hanging out and goofing off. My conclusion: “Life is too short to be busy.”

headline: Erika L. Sánchez Wishes More Authors Would Write About Money
abstract: “I grew up working class and money was a factor in everything we did,” says the poet and novelist, whose new book is the memoir “Crying in the Bathroom.” “That’s why I always write about the financial realities of my characters.”
lead_paragraph: “Memphis,” by Tara M. Stringfellow, “The School for Good Mothers,” by Jessamine Chan, and “All the Flowers Kneeling,” by Paul Tran.

headline: Renters Face Fiercest Competition in Florida and the Northeast
abstract: Demand for apartments in Florida has intensified, followed by markets in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, as Americans embrace remote work.
lead_paragraph: As pandemic restrictions ease and remote work becomes a permanent fixture, Americans continue to seek homes in communities with more relaxed lifestyles — particularly in Florida and the Northeast, home to the country’s most competitive markets for renters, according to a new analysis of real estate data.

headline: How a Long-Sought Bill Could Make Construction Work Less Deadly
abstract: Carlos Moncayo, 22, died seven years ago at a Manhattan construction site. A bill on Gov. Kathy Hochul’s desk aims to make conditions safer for workers like him.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Moncayo was just 22 when he was crushed to death by thousands of pounds of dirt at a construction site in Manhattan’s meatpacking district.

headline: Is the Future of American Opera Unfolding in Detroit?
abstract: Yuval Sharon’s wildly innovative stagings, already celebrated in Berlin and Los Angeles, reach new heights in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Last September, as cultural organizations began their fall seasons in a state of crisis, unsure if audiences would venture from their homes in the midst of a pandemic, Yuval Sharon, the artistic director of the Michigan Opera Theater, decided to mount a show called “Bliss.” A restaging of a marathon piece by the Icelandic performance artist Ragnar Kjartansson, “Bliss” requires its performers to replay the final three minutes of Mozart’s “The Marriage of Figaro” without pause for 12 hours.

headline: How a Failed Screenwriting Career Forged a Best-Selling Author
abstract: Before he wrote “The Silent Patient,” Alex Michaelides tried and tried again to make movies.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know why I’m writing this” happens to be the first line of Alex Michaelides’s debut thriller, “The Silent Patient,” which is now in its 46th week on the trade paperback best-seller list. This statement appears in a character’s diary, but one can imagine it crossing the author’s mind after his screenwriting ambitions fizzled.

headline: ‘Evolution Gone Crazy’: What Makes Sea Dragons So Strange
abstract: In the genomes of the bizarre fish that are related to sea horses, scientists found certain key growth genes were missing.
