lead_paragraph: Among the ocean’s menagerie of bizarre creatures, sea dragons stand out. Relatives of sea horses and pipefish, sea dragons have long narrow snouts that they use like a straw to suck up meals of microscopic crustaceans. Instead of scales, the fish are covered in bony armor, and their backbones are kinked. Like their sea horse cousins, male sea dragons  gestate a female’s fertilized eggs in a pouch.

headline: Glacier Tragedy Shows Reach of Europe’s New Heat
abstract: A collapse at the top of one of Italy’s tallest peaks offered the latest evidence of the deadly threat posed by rising temperatures.
lead_paragraph: CANAZEI, Italy — Days before a glacier in the Italian Dolomites broke off with the force of a collapsing skyscraper, crushing at least 10 hikers under an avalanche of ice, snow and rock, Carlo Budel heard water running under the ice.

headline: In Miami, a Pandemic-Fueled Boom
abstract: A Michelin-starred Korean steakhouse, new public art installations and native-plant gardens under the Metrorail: Here is what’s new in the Magic City.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many cities, Miami has boomed over the course of the pandemic. Thousands relocated to South Florida where restaurants, attractions and retail shops remained open, with Miami’s tropical sparkle seemingly a panacea for life in lockdown.

headline: Siberia or Japan? Expert Google Maps Players Can Tell at a Glimpse.
abstract: In a game called GeoGuessr, competitors try to pinpoint where in the world a Google Street View image has been taken. Some can do it in seconds.
lead_paragraph: An unremarkable stretch of highway and trees, as seen on Google Maps’ Street View, appeared on the screen. It could have been anywhere from Tasmania to Texas.

headline: For People Just Leaving Prison, a Novel Kind of Support: Cash
abstract: Joining a raft of initiatives aimed at helping the formerly incarcerated, a program gives money to defray expenses they face, including court fines and rent.
lead_paragraph: Alwin Jacob Smith became a free man last summer after being locked up for 21 years because of what he calls “my little old rocky past” — most notably, robbery and drug possession.

headline: Beach Bunny Is Building an Indie-Rock Career in a Time of TikTok
abstract: The singer-songwriter Lili Trifilio has had two songs connect — and get slightly misconstrued — on the app. With more ears on her band’s second album, what message will she deliver?
lead_paragraph: One morning last August, Lili Trifilio was feeling emotional.

headline: Quitting Oil Income Is Hard, Even for States That Want Climate Action
abstract: Dozens of state and local budgets depend heavily on tax revenue from oil, gas and coal to fund schools, hospitals and more. Replacing that money is turning out to be a major challenge in the fight against climate change.
lead_paragraph: TAFT, Calif. — Every five years, this city of 7,000 hosts a rollicking, Old West-themed festival known as Oildorado. High schoolers decorate parade floats with derricks and pump jacks. Young women vie for the crown in a “Maids of Petroleum” beauty pageant. It’s a celebration of an industry that has sustained the local economy for the past century.

headline: The Mental Health Benefits of an Inclusive Outdoor Escape
abstract: Amid pandemic stress and racial violence, many communities of color have turned to wilderness areas for healing.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Beijing Introduces a Local Vaccine Pass and Urges Older People to Get Shots
abstract: The city announced the change months after other countries had put vaccine passports in place.
lead_paragraph: Beijing is introducing vaccine requirements to enter libraries, museums and other public gathering places on Monday, the city government said, as it encouraged older people to get vaccinated.

headline: An Anti-Abortion Campaigner on the Movement’s Historic Win
abstract: James Bopp, chief lawyer for the National Right to Life Committee, says that overturning Roe v. Wade is only the halfway point.
lead_paragraph: After Roe v. Wade was decided in 1973, a group of conservative lawyers embarked on what would become a decades-long mission to reverse the ruling.

headline: Here are the contenders to become the next prime minister.
abstract: A small group is stepping to center stage as Britain’s political crisis intensifies, including the rival Boris Johnson beat last time.
lead_paragraph: With Boris Johnson poised to step down as the leader of the Conservative Party, the spotlight is on who might succeed him as prime minister.

headline: The head of France’s nuclear power giant will step down as nationalization looms.
abstract: Jean-Bernard Lévy of EDF will leave before his term ends, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Bernard Lévy, the chairman and chief executive of Électricité de France, the French state-backed electricity giant, plans to step down before his term is up next year, the company said on Thursday.

headline: Internal Inconsistencies
abstract: The people who claim widespread election fraud have made little effort to put together a logical argument.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 Republican nominees for statewide office or Congress this year have falsely claimed that election fraud helped defeat Donald Trump in 2020. Almost 150 members of Congress — more than half of the Republicans serving there — went so far as to vote to overturn the 2020 election result.

headline: Alaska Kills 4 Bears That Entered Homeless Camp
abstract: The bears had been rummaging through tents at a park managed by the city of Anchorage. No one was injured, according to a city spokesman.
lead_paragraph: Four black bears that had repeatedly entered a campground for homeless people in Anchorage, Alaska, and rummaged through tents in search of leftover food and trash were killed on Tuesday because the authorities said they posed “a risk to human safety.”

headline: ‘About time!’: In London, many welcome Johnson’s pending departure.
abstract: In the capital, many Britons expressed a sense of relief after learning that the prime minister’s days were numbered.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the news of Boris Johnson’s intention to resign as Conservative Party leader started to spread in central London on Thursday, many residents expressed a sense of relief.

headline: What happens next?
abstract: After the latest in a series of scandals prompted a rebellion by members of his Conservative Party, Boris Johnson said he would step down. Now what?
lead_paragraph: The resignation of Prime Minister Boris Johnson as leader of Britain’s Conservative Party does not prompt a general election. Instead, it kicks off a process to select a new party leader, who will then move into 10 Downing Street.

headline: ‘This is Ukraine!’ The national flag is raised on Snake Island, officials say, in a symbol of Kyiv’s defiance of Moscow.
abstract: Ukraine has raised its blue and yellow national flag over Snake Island, the authorities said on Thursday, signaling the reconquest of a scrap of land in the Black Sea that has become a symbol of the country’s resistance to Russia’s invasion.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has raised its blue and yellow national flag over Snake Island, the authorities said on Thursday, signaling the reconquest of a scrap of land in the Black Sea that has become a symbol of the country’s resistance to Russia’s invasion.

headline: ‘This Much I Know to Be True’ Review: Nick Cave Prepares for the Stage
abstract: A new music documentary by Andrew Dominik explores the collaboration of Cave and Warren Ellis.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter (and novelist and screenwriter) Nick Cave is a longtime chronicler of dread, erotic obsession, morality and mortality. The director Andrew Dominik, not exactly a screwball comedy guy himself (“Killing Them Softly”), proved an apt collaborator with Cave on the 2016 documentary “One More Time With Feeling.”

headline: ‘Cop Secret’ Review: Bang Bang, Kiss Kiss
abstract: In this Icelandic spoof of Hollywood action movies, two rival police officers make a love connection.
lead_paragraph: The big reveal in “Cop Secret” is out from the moment the unkempt Bussi (Audunn Blondal), Iceland’s toughest police officer, is forcibly partnered with Hordur (Egill Einarsson), his suave rival from a neighboring precinct. As Hordur strolls toward Bussi in swoony slow-motion, impeccable jacket slung roguishly over one bulging shoulder, Bussi’s stubbled jaw softens. The two may be vying for top dog, but it’s clear that — grooming discrepancies aside — copulation will soon take precedence over competition.

headline: ‘Dreaming Walls: Inside the Chelsea Hotel’ Review: Bohemia’s Holdouts
abstract: This documentary offers an immersion in the lives of residents who keep the building’s spirit as a home for artists alive through a protracted renovation.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Dreaming Walls: Inside the Chelsea Hotel,” a construction worker says that the famed building has “a lot of ghosts.”

headline: ‘Both Sides of the Blade’ Review: Who Do You Love?
abstract: In the latest film from Claire Denis, Juliette Binoche plays a Parisian radio journalist in a romantic quandary.
lead_paragraph: When we first meet Sara and Jean, they are enjoying a vacation. To be precise, they‘re making out in the waters of a sun-dappled lagoon, the very picture of midlife romantic fulfillment. The fact that Sara and Jean are played by Juliette Binoche and Vincent Lindon, two of the most charismatic actors of a certain age in modern cinema, makes their apparent bliss look all the more enviable.

headline: Why Are We Still Talking About Black Mountain College?
abstract: In 1933, a handful of renegade teachers opened a school in rural North Carolina that would go on to shape American art and art education for decades to come.
lead_paragraph: Among the most enduring and evocative images of Black Mountain College — the experimental liberal arts school in rural North Carolina that was founded during the depths of the Great Depression, and that fostered the talents of numerous artists during the uniquely hopeful and propulsive period that followed World War II — are several photographs of R. Buckminster (Bucky) Fuller, the eccentric inventor and designer, attempting to construct his first large-scale geodesic dome. It was the summer of 1948, and Fuller, who was a faculty member in residence at the school — along with the likes of Willem and Elaine de Kooning, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Peter Grippe, Beaumont Newhall and Richard Lippold — had brought with him rolls of aluminum Venetian-blind scrap stock and enlisted students and faculty to help him build.

headline: Chinese Police Database Was Left Unsecured Long Before Hackers Seized It
abstract: The breach is “a big black eye” for the Chinese security apparatus, one expert says, exposing the risk of the state’s vast effort to amass citizens’ personal data.
lead_paragraph: A Shanghai police database with a vast trove of personal data that was seized by a hacker or group had been left online, unsecured, for months, security researchers said, in what is probably the largest known breach of Chinese government computer systems.

headline: Kazuki Takahashi, Yu-Gi-Oh! Creator, Dies at 60
abstract: The manga artist won international fame with a story that inspired a trading card game rivaling Pokemon as one of Japan’s most recognizable cultural exports.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Kazuki Takahashi, the creator of the international smash hit manga and trading card game Yu-Gi-Oh!, was found dead in southern Japan, the country’s Coast Guard said on Thursday. He was 60.

headline: Shell sees refining profits nearly tripling, adding $1 billion to its bottom line.
abstract: The oil giant is benefiting from high prices in energy markets.
lead_paragraph: Shell, Europe’s largest oil company, indicated Thursday that it was continuing to profit handsomely from oil market conditions that have motorists screaming.

headline: A Year of Language Play: Our Vocabulary Challenges and How You Can Use Them
abstract: We invited students to invent new words and investigate old ones, tell stories, make videos, draw pictures and take quizzes.
lead_paragraph: The Learning Network has been through many iterations in its 23-year history, but there’s one feature that has always been part of our offerings: our Word of the Day.

headline: Bangladesh Sees Jump in Covid Cases Before Eid Celebrations
abstract: The average number of new cases has risen to the highest since February, signaling a new wave. The country’s health system nearly collapsed in August.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Rebeka Beshra should be on a packed bus for the 150-mile journey to her parents’ home to celebrate Eid al-Adha, one of the biggest Muslim holidays.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of the Self-Taught Artist
abstract: For centuries, those who eschewed formal training have been either marginalized or obsessed over. Why are we so enthralled by people who create on their own terms?
lead_paragraph: ART SCHOOL, AT least as it exists in the U.S., is a relatively new invention. The availability of a degree in fine arts, and the expectation that an artist earn one, became typical around the end of World War II, when the G.I. Bill afforded veterans the ability to attend colleges and universities. Before then, aspirants to the art world largely figured out the mechanics themselves, through apprenticeships, maybe, or informal classes at independent schools like the Art Students League of New York, where working artists like the painter Thomas Hart Benton instructed Jackson Pollock, even if the instruction shaded toward the antagonistic (Benton despised abstraction; Pollock said the only thing that he learned from the older artist was how to drink a fifth of whiskey a day).

headline: A wave of resignations finally pushed Johnson to resign.
abstract: Despite everything stacked against him, Mr. Johnson did not go quietly.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Late Wednesday night, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain was defiant, refusing to quit, rejecting entreaties from cabinet colleagues who told him the game was up and even sacking one of them, Michael Gove, a friend and rival since their days together at Oxford University.

headline: The Big 4’s Tax Problem
abstract: The S.E.C. is reportedly reviewing conflicts of interest at top accounting firms.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are turning up the heat on the Big 4, the largest accounting firms in the U.S. — Deloitte, PwC, EY and KPMG. Increasingly, their size and the variety of services they offer, like tax consulting, are raising questions about the independence of their audits and landing the firms in hot water, writes The Times’s Jesse Drucker.

headline: What to Know About California’s Latest Covid Surge
abstract: Coronavirus cases appear to be rising as a highly transmissible variant takes root.
lead_paragraph: Do you know someone with Covid right now? You’re not alone.

headline: The British pound rises after the prime minister resigns.
abstract: Markets in Britain rose slightly after Boris Johnson said he would step down, but global economic factors have been more important to investors.
lead_paragraph: The British pound rose slightly after Boris Johnson said he would resign as Britain’s prime minister on Thursday, in a choppy trade at a time of great political turmoil in London.

headline: How Do We Get Rid of Our Teenage Daughter’s Gun Safe?
abstract: A reader wonders what to do after her daughter responds to a breach of privacy by investing in a locker meant for weaponry, not diaries.
lead_paragraph: Our 15-year-old daughter is very headstrong. She’s never been in real trouble, but she bristles against rules and authority: curfews, homework, appropriate clothing — you name it! Recently, she exploded when her younger brothers discovered her journal in the family room. Now, she keeps it locked in a heavy black box she found at a secondhand store. The problem: The black box turns out to be a gun safe! (A friend of my husband told us.) We’re not worried that she has a gun; she helped organize a school rally to tighten our state’s gun laws. But she refuses to give up the safe, and we don’t want it in our house. Help!

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Alekhine
abstract: Take on Alexander Alekhine in a recreation of a 13th World Championship game in The Hague, 1929. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

headline: A Culinary Retreat in the Berkshires
abstract: Plus: beauty tips from the chef Daniela Soto-Innes, zoological rugs and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: What if Juliet Lived? A Pop Hitmaker’s ‘& Juliet’ Heads to Broadway.
abstract: The jukebox musical, which is already running in London, features songs by the Swedish writer and producer Max Martin, including “Since U Been Gone” and “ … Baby One More Time.”
lead_paragraph: Come on, Mr. Shakespeare. Did Juliet really have to die in that tragic play of yours?

headline: Homes for Sale in Westchester and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s available properties include a five-bedroom house in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a three-bedroom house in Weston, Conn.
lead_paragraph: This week’s available properties include a five-bedroom house in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a three-bedroom house in Weston, Conn.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York City
abstract: This week’s available properties are on Roosevelt Island, in Maspeth and in Clinton Hill.
lead_paragraph: This week’s available properties are on Roosevelt Island, in Maspeth and in Clinton Hill.

abstract: This week’s available properties include a five-bedroom house in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a three-bedroom house in Weston, Conn.

headline: Behind the fight between Ben & Jerry’s and its owner, Unilever.
abstract: The ice cream maker is suing its corporate parent in an effort to stop sales in Israeli-occupied territories, thanks to an unusual deal that gives the founders control of the brand.
lead_paragraph: Ben & Jerry’s is suing its owner, the consumer products giant Unilever, in an unusual case that seeks to stop Unilever from selling the distribution rights of the ice cream brand in Israel to a local licensee.

headline: Read Boris Johnson’s resignation speech.
abstract: “I want you to know how sad I am to be giving up the best job in the world,” the British prime minister said in announcing that he was stepping down. “But them’s the breaks.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced on Thursday that he would step down. This is a transcript of his speech, lightly edited for spelling, as reported by Reuters.

headline: ‘Moon, 66 Questions’ Review: Daddy Issues
abstract: This elliptical drama by the Greek writer-director Jacqueline Lentzou rousingly summons the inner turmoil of a young woman who returns home to care for her ailing father.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Jacqueline Lentzou’s “Moon, 66 Questions” takes cues from astrology, using Tarot cards to represent each new chapter of a story about a young woman, Artemis (Sofia Kokkali), who returns to Athens to care for her ailing father.

headline: A Walk in Their Heels: Meet the Hustle Evangelist
abstract: Abdiel Jacobsen, a former Martha Graham dancer, found freedom in hustle, which offers a progressive, gender-neutral vision of partnered social dance.
lead_paragraph: On a humid weekday evening last month, as shade began to slant across Central Park, a small crowd made a dance floor out of the Bethesda Fountain’s brick terrace. Disco rhythms pulsed from a DJ booth on one side of the plaza, crowned by a pink-tinted mirrorball. There were moments of voguing and house dancing, and a few children wiggling joyfully. But most in the group paired off, in every combination of genders, to do the hustle.

headline: Mike Grier, the N.H.L.’s First Black General Manager, Started as a College Benchwarmer
abstract: Grier worked from being a reserve at Boston University to an N.H.L. mainstay. Now the league’s first Black general manager hopes to rebuild the Sharks and “open some doors for someone to follow.”
lead_paragraph: Mike Grier spent the first game of his freshman season at Boston University not on the ice but in the stands, unready for the lineup, minding a high school recruit checking out the program. He saw little ice time in the next three games and then was told that was what he could expect for the rest of the season, too.

headline: The pandemic has eroded Americans’ trust in experts and elected leaders alike, a survey finds.
abstract: The survey, conducted in May, also found that people were growing less worried than before about catching or spreading the virus.
lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic entered its third year, the American public had lost much of its trust both in public health experts and in government leaders, and was less worried than before about Covid-19, according to a survey conducted in early May and released Thursday by the Pew Research Center.

headline: How Unlikely Is It That the Audits of Comey and McCabe Were a Coincidence? A Statistical Exploration.
abstract: The chances are minuscule. But minuscule is not zero.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has reported that the Internal Revenue Service gave one of its most rigorous types of audits to James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and to Andrew G. McCabe, his former deputy.

headline: An Irish regulator puts Facebook data policies back in the spotlight.
abstract: A decision from Ireland’s Data Protection Commission is likely to add to pressure on U.S. and European negotiators to finish a deal on trans-Atlantic data transfers.
lead_paragraph: A draft decision by Irish regulators on Thursday threatened to block Facebook and Instagram from moving data about European Union users to the United States, the latest round in  a yearslong  dispute about protecting the data of European citizens from American spying.

headline: Ni Kuang, Prolific Hong Kong Novelist and Screenwriter, Dies at 87
abstract: Best known for fantastical thrillers that doubled as political allegories, he also wrote hundreds of martial arts films for Bruce Lee and others.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Ni Kuang, a prolific author of fantasy novels imbued with criticism of the Chinese Communist Party and a screenwriter for more than 200 martial arts films, died here on July 3.  He was 87.

headline: How Wish Built (and Fumbled) a Dollar Store for the Internet
abstract: The number of users has plummeted, and its stock price has dropped. Former employees point to an emphasis on short-term growth over customer service.
lead_paragraph: There were unbelievable bargains on “bestdeeal9,” a store hosted on the e-commerce platform Wish, including a $2,700 smart TV being sold for $1 and a gaming computer advertised for $1.30.

headline: A Whale Feeding Frenzy in Antarctica Signals a Conservation Success
abstract: Once hunted to the brink of extinction, fin whales in the Southern Ocean have rebounded and returned to their historical feeding grounds, according to a new survey.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, it looked like thick fog across the horizon. But as the ship drew closer, the ocean bubbled as 150 fin whales, the planet’s second-largest creatures, dived and lunged against the water’s surface.

headline: An American ‘Dystopia,’ After Roe
abstract: “The United States is no longer ‘the land of the free,’ at least not for me, not for people with a uterus,” a college student writes. Also: Exodus from New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Girls Are Outnumbered in Jazz. At This Summer Camp, They Run the Show.
abstract: Jazz Camp for Girls, a four-day program in Denmark, has expanded to Finland, Poland and Sweden this year, giving young musicians a space to play music and build friendships.
lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — On a morning in late June, 16 girls arrived at an urban courtyard for the timeless summer ritual of camp drop-off. Some came clutching their parents’ hands; others raced ahead to greet old friends. One young teenager with strawberry-blond curls, who had come because her working parents told her she couldn’t sit home alone all day, stood nervously waiting for things to get underway. But it wasn’t long before the 13-year-old happily joined an ice-breaking game. “Hi, my name is Anna,” she chanted, as she clapped out a rhythm that the others repeated back to her: “Ba-BAH-ba-ba-BAH.”

headline: ‘The Collaboration,’ About Warhol and Basquiat, Plans Broadway Bow
abstract: The play, by Anthony McCarten, will be presented this fall by the Manhattan Theater Club, following a run earlier this year at the Young Vic in London.
lead_paragraph: “The Collaboration,” a new play exploring the relationship between the painters Andy Warhol and Jean-Michel Basquiat, will transfer to Broadway this fall.

headline: Decoding the Defiance of Henry VIII’s First Wife
abstract: Using a process she called “early modern Wordle,” a scholar claims to have uncovered a hidden message from Catherine of Aragon in a book of jewelry designs.
lead_paragraph: It has long been a beguiling and mysterious treasure of the British Museum: a collection of sketches for jewelry and other lavish ornaments, commissioned during the reign of Henry VIII from the artist Hans Holbein, for a time the court painter.

headline: Jobs Aplenty, but a Shortage of Care Keeps Many Women From Benefiting
abstract: A lack of child care and elder care options has forced some women to limit their hours or sidelined them altogether, hurting their career prospects.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Here’s to Your Health
abstract: In “Doctors and Distillers,” Camper English explores the long-running interconnection between medicine and alcohol in daily life.
lead_paragraph: We have many reasons to be thankful for a nice gin and tonic, but as a malaria-busting beverage, it’s also proved more effective than a previously prescribed cocktail of brandy mixed with animal blood and pepper. As Camper English explains in “Doctors and Distillers,” it did take a few centuries of scientific experimentation to move past those medieval apothecaries. Colonizing observers had to copy the Indigenous peoples’ use of South American cinchona tree bark (which contains the alkaloid quinine), before someone got the notion to mix quinine with carbonated mineral water — along with the juniper-infused gin spirit that had its own medicinal history around Europe.

headline: E.P.A. Describes How It Will Regulate Power Plants After Supreme Court Setback
abstract: Last week’s ruling took away a major tool for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Many regulatory options still remain, but the path will be more difficult.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Following the Supreme Court’s landmark ruling last week limiting the government’s ability to restrict the pollution that is causing global warming, the Biden administration is planning to use other regulatory tools in hopes of achieving similar goals.

headline: The Healing Power of Strength Training
abstract: Everyone knows that weight lifting increases physical strength. But, for some, it can give psychological power, too.
lead_paragraph: When Cheng Xu was serving in the Canadian Armed Forces as a paratrooper and infantry officer, he experienced a series of traumatic events in rapid succession — his best friend and fellow officer took his own life, a soldier under his command was injured during a live fire exercise and a close friend’s father was kidnapped.

headline: Joe Biden Had Better Pay Attention
abstract: Democrats, as well as Republicans, are not holding back.
lead_paragraph: Could J.B. Pritzker be contemplating a run for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2024?

headline: Burna Boy Faces Success and Second Thoughts on ‘Love, Damini’
abstract: On his sixth album, the Nigerian superstar admits some regrets.
lead_paragraph: “Fame puts you there where things are hollow,” David Bowie sang back in 1975, and plenty of performers, before and after, have discovered the same thing. Their songs declare outsized ambitions and make premature boasts as careers begin. But then success, if it happens, brings as many pressures and perks — and, sometimes, a new willingness to confront misgivings.

headline: For Boris Johnson, a Tumultuous Tenure Ends With a Messy Exit
abstract: The risk-taking bravado of Britain’s colorful prime minister was not enough to compensate for his shortcomings, or overcome a catastrophic loss of party support.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The end, when it finally came, was just as chaotic, messy and jaw-dropping as every other chapter of Boris Johnson’s political career.

headline: The Outer Limits
abstract: In “The Shores of Bohemia,” John Taylor Williams explores 50 years in the iconoclastic summer colonies of Cape Cod.
lead_paragraph: There is something ineffable about the appeal of the outer reaches of Cape Cod to generations of writers, artists and architects. Maybe it’s simply that, as Thoreau observed, “a man may stand there and put all America behind him.” Maybe — and this was certainly true for the first part of the 20th century — it was the place’s remoteness and isolation, the sense that as the land reaches out toward the Atlantic, in a single long, crooked limb, the present conventional world slips away, allowing you to rethink, reinvent and get away with all manner of things. Maybe a sort of pre-modern living — with so few amenities and creature comforts — drew the urban cliques who gravitated there, repelled as many were by the excesses of capitalism.

headline: You Don’t Get Office Birthday Cake Over Zoom, Sorry
abstract: Missing a celebration may feel awkward. But leave the boss out of it.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Boris Johnson leaves behind a fraught economy and an uneasy Brexit legacy.
abstract: Britain is in the grips of a cost-of-living crisis, and the departure of its prime minister leaves uncertainty about the government’s next moves.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson has been pushed into giving up leadership of the country during a perilous economic moment, leaving behind a grim outlook and an uncertain Brexit legacy.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz: Covid-19, Face Blindness and Sunscreen
abstract: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Papaya King, a Hot Dog Pioneer on the Upper East Side, Faces a Possible End
abstract: The original Papaya King created the city’s signature combo of franks and tropical fruit juices. But a demolition plan could finish its decades-long reign.
lead_paragraph: The future of Papaya King, an Upper East Side mainstay credited with popularizing New York’s quintessential pairing of hot dogs and tropical fruit juice drinks, is in doubt as its building is set to be razed.

headline: In ‘Living Wine’ Documentary, Natural Wine Transcends the Clichés
abstract: Forget funkiness. The focus here is farming, culture, the environment, climate change and, yes, great-tasting wine.
lead_paragraph: When the polarizing subject of natural wine arises, the discussion generally spirals to the stereotypes: flawed and funky wines, hippie producers and the debate over definitions. But a new documentary film, “Living Wine,” hopes to change that trite discussion.

headline: Show Us Where You’re Seeing Inflation
abstract: Our economics reporter wants to hear about what goods and services are getting more expensive.
lead_paragraph: With inflation at a 40-year high in the United States, our reporters want to know: What goods and services are getting more expensive for you in a way that has made you stop and take note? We’re interested in specifics: Are prices up for cereal? Exterminators? Paper towels? Haircuts? Shoes? Is there one item in particular whose cost has jumped more than you expected, or that particularly shapes your perception of how fast inflation is right now?

headline: Eating Well in the Great Outdoors
abstract: Cold noodle salads, recipes for camping vegans and cooking out of a cooler.
lead_paragraph: Howdy! It’s Tanya, Tejal’s Veggie editor and enthusiastic understudy. While she’s on vacation this week, I’m diving into some reader emails. The question on so many of your minds right now: How does one eat well outside this summer?

headline: A Pop Star Tried to Reconcile Russia and Ukraine. War Ruined That.
abstract: Ivan Dorn, who was born in Russia and grew up in Ukraine, promoted friendship between the two nations for years. Now, he is focused on supporting Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Dorn, a Ukrainian musician, had mostly finished his first album in five years by February.

headline: What’s Next for Jack Harlow?
abstract: He’s one of hip-hop’s biggest emerging stars, and he’s cutting a very different path than the white rappers who came before him.
lead_paragraph: The rise of Jack Harlow has been one of hip-hop’s most curious narratives over the past two years. So far in 2022 he’s had a huge pop hit, “First Class,” and released his second major label album, “Come Home the Kids Miss You,” which debuted at No. 3. He is one of hip-hop’s biggest emerging stars, and one whose aims are purely centrist.

headline: Inside a New Arts Program for Queens Teens
abstract: There's a new yearlong social justice and arts institute for teenagers at the Queens Museum.
lead_paragraph: There's a new yearlong social justice and arts institute for teenagers at the Queens Museum.

headline: Donna Ferrato’s Camera Is a Weapon for Women
abstract: Best known for unmasking domestic violence, the pathbreaking photojournalist has a show timed to coincide with the reversal of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Even with blackened eyes, the women in Donna Ferrato’s photographs look defiant, not defeated. A photojournalist and feminist activist who is best known for her documentation of domestic violence, Ferrato, 73, has also depicted women pursuing sexual pleasure, giving birth, raising children, enticing men and demonstrating in the streets. Her subject is women taking control of their bodies, and in her fiercely empathetic mission, sometimes she turns the camera on herself.

headline: James Caan, Actor Who Won Fame in ‘The Godfather,’ Dies at 82
abstract: A Bronx native, he starred in countless movies and TV shows, but was most closely identified with the volatile character Sonny Corleone.
lead_paragraph: James Caan, who built a durable film career in varied roles across six decades but was forever identified most closely with one of his earliest characters, the quick-tempered, skirt-chasing Sonny Corleone in the original “Godfather” movie, died on Wednesday. He was 82.

headline: Brittney Griner Pleads Guilty to Drug Charges in Russian Court
abstract: “There was no intent,” the American basketball star told a Russian judge, as any resolution of the highly politicized case appeared to shift toward the diplomatic arena.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner pleaded guilty to drug charges in a Russian courtroom on Thursday, as the wrangling over the American basketball star’s fate shifted increasingly to the diplomatic arena — a daunting prospect for Ms. Griner’s supporters amid America’s rift with Moscow over the war in Ukraine.

headline: Tech Is Not Representative Government
abstract: And yet, we demand that it protect us.
lead_paragraph: Americans are treating tech companies like a substitute for effective representative government. It shouldn’t be this way.

headline: How to Follow the News Without Spiraling into Despair
abstract: Name your emotions. Take action. Know your limits. These seven mindfulness-based strategies can help you stay grounded while caring deeply about the world.
lead_paragraph: Following nonstop news in an era of gun violence, war and political divide can become overwhelming. And amid our many ongoing challenges — the pandemic, climate change, economic uncertainty — it’s understandable to feel sad, angry and anxious.

headline: Monkeypox Vaccine Rollout Is Marred by Glitches in New York
abstract: The city has struggled to respond to a growing monkeypox outbreak, the first major public health crisis since the Covid pandemic began.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of New Yorkers spent hours refreshing a city government webpage this week, desperately seeking a monkeypox vaccine that, for now, is mostly going to the web-savvy and connected.

headline: ‘The Sea Beast’ Review: Of Monsters and Men
abstract: In this new animated film from Netflix, a monster hunter and an orphan become unlikely allies at sea.
lead_paragraph: “Live a great life and die a great death,” goes the mantra of the monster hunters in Netflix’s new animated movie “The Sea Beast.” It’s a spirited battle cry, sure, but it’s also a morbid one, made only more grisly by the fact that the first character to say it is a child.

headline: I.R.S. Asks Inspector General to Review Audits of Comey and McCabe
abstract: The agency said its commissioner asked the Treasury Department’s inspector general for tax administration to look into the audits after The Times raised questions about them.
lead_paragraph: The I.R.S. said on Thursday that its commissioner, Charles P. Rettig, had asked the inspector general who oversees tax matters to investigate how James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, and his deputy, Andrew G. McCabe — both perceived enemies of former President Donald J. Trump — came to be faced with rare, exhaustive audits that the agency says are supposed to be random.

headline: Amazon Hub in Newark Is Canceled After Unions and Local Groups Object
abstract: The e-commerce giant planned to build an airport cargo center, hire 1,000 workers and invest hundreds of millions of dollars over 20 years.
lead_paragraph: For the second time, plans by Amazon to substantially expand its presence in the New York area have been abandoned after labor and community groups mobilized in opposition.

headline: Rafael Nadal Withdraws From Wimbledon Ahead of Semifinal Match
abstract: The 22-time Grand Slam champion tore a muscle in his abdomen earlier in the tournament. “I am very sad.”
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — In the end, after a day of contemplation and consideration for what mattered most, health prevailed over the temptations of yet another title.

headline: ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ Review: A God’s Comic Twilight
abstract: The director Taika Waititi injects antic silliness, once again, into this Marvel franchise starring Chris Hemsworth, who swings a mighty hammer and flexes mightier muscles.
lead_paragraph: Every so often in “Thor: Love and Thunder,” the 92nd Marvel movie to hit theaters this year (OK, the third), the studio machinery hits pause, and the picture opens a portal to another dimension: Its star, Chris Hemsworth, embraces wholesale self-parody, a pair of giant screaming goats gallop along a rainbow highway and Russell Crowe flounces around in a flirty skirt and Shirley Temple curls. As the movie briefly slips into a parallel realm of play and pleasure, you can feel the director Taika Waititi having a good time — and it’s infectious.

headline: The candidates to replace Johnson reflect a more diverse Conservative Party.
abstract: Among those expected to vie for the prime ministership are a son of Indian immigrants, an Iraqi refugee, a son of a Pakistani bus driver, and several women.
lead_paragraph: For years, Britain’s Conservative Party was seen mainly as the realm of white men from elite backgrounds. But the contenders to replace Boris Johnson as prime minister reflect the growing diversity at the top of the party’s ranks.

headline: ‘Murina’ Review: Hunting for Independence on Her Terms
abstract: In this coming-of-age tale set off the rugged Croatian coast, a teenage girl strives to catch elusive eels, one of the movie’s hardworking metaphors.
lead_paragraph: The 17-year-old heroine of “Murina” never seems freer than when she’s swimming. Wearing a snorkeling mask, and with a spear gun in one hand, she glides through the water, her strong body propelling her forward. As she descends into the ethereal depths, expertly weaving among the undulating plants and scattering fish, her one-piece suit gleams like a beacon.

headline: ‘Black Bird’ Review: Making Friends With a May-Be Killer
abstract: Paul Walter Hauser of “Richard Jewell” gives a tour-de-force performance in a mini-series inspired by a true story of serial killings and jailhouse intrigue.
lead_paragraph: “Black Bird,” a new mini-series on Apple TV+ (premiering Friday) that dramatizes a creepy Midwestern true-crime story from the 1990s, has some significant names attached to it. It was developed for television by the top-flight crime writer Dennis Lehane (“The Wire,” “Mr. Mercedes”). Its nominal star, Taron Egerton (“Rocketman”), is a candidate to be Marvel’s next Wolverine. And, in a smaller role, it features one of the last performances by Ray Liotta, who died in May.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Dialogues’ and More
abstract: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been reading, listening to and more.
lead_paragraph: I’m a deputy editor on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been reading, listening to and more.

headline: No. 2 Theranos Executive Found Guilty of 12 Counts of Fraud
abstract: The verdict for Ramesh Balwani, who helped lead the failed blood testing start-up, was more severe than the one for his ex-girlfriend Elizabeth Holmes.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Ramesh Balwani, a former top executive at Theranos, was found guilty on Thursday of 12 counts of fraud, in a verdict that was more severe than that of his co-conspirator, Elizabeth Holmes, and that solidified the failed blood-testing start-up as the ultimate Silicon Valley cautionary tale.

headline: The Nihilism of the Minions
abstract: The latest hit children’s movie is nearly devoid of artistic and moral value. Are we OK with that?
lead_paragraph: One of the peculiarities of the collective American memory is that we imagine that moral rigidity steadily declines over time. One generation, through experimentation and immense tolerance, disentangles the hang-ups of their parents, just as their children will ultimately do for them. This, of course, is nonsense. What’s particularly odd to me is that most of us are fully aware — at least on an intellectual level — that cultural moralizing ebbs and flows and there is no clear linearity to any of it. But we hold on to the idea that society got “freer” during our generation (whatever that means) because we want our own youthful indiscretions to have “pushed boundaries” (another useless phrase) and “changed the scope of what was possible” (ditto). And while we can usually imagine our own children will take that “freedom” even further, our narcissism forces us to worry that society will crumble as a result. We, in other words, believe we, and only we, have found the perfect level of moral decline.

headline: Rotterdam Won’t Dismantle Bridge to Allow Jeff Bezos’ Superyacht Through
abstract: The Dutch city faced an uproar as it considered dismantling a section of a 95-year-old bridge. Now the boat’s builder has decided not to apply for a permit.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bezos will not be able to sail a new, more than 400-foot-long superyacht through the waters of the Dutch city of Rotterdam anytime soon.

headline: To Pick Johnson’s Successor, Britain’s Conservatives Confront the Void He Leaves Behind
abstract: The choice of Britain’s next prime minister falls to the governing Conservatives, whose lawmakers pushed Boris Johnson to resign and now have to reinvent their party without him.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rarely free from scandal and never out of the headlines as Britain’s charismatic prime minister, Boris Johnson dominated British politics, overshadowed his rivals and reinvented his governing Conservative Party in his own compelling, polarizing image.

headline: Match Group suspends some political donations after abortion ruling.
abstract: The operator of Tinder, Hinge and other dating sites said it would no longer give money to groups representing Republican and Democratic attorneys general.
lead_paragraph: Facing scrutiny for donations to the Republican Attorneys General Association, whose members supported the overturning of Roe v. Wade, Match Group says it will suspend further contributions to the association as well as the Democratic Attorneys General Association.

headline: Robert Colescott Throws Down the Gauntlet
abstract: His paintings refer to race and racism, pride and prejudice, in ways that startled, seduced, elucidated, and horrified. Now they are at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Watch out. A raucous, enthralling exhibition of the great American painter Robert Colescott (1925-2009) has arrived at the New Museum, to revel in and dissect. “Art and Race Matters: The Career of Robert Colescott” is the first museum exhibition of this artist’s relentlessly provocative work to be seen in Manhattan since a 1989 show (also at the New Museum) and the most complete yet. It reveals a man who was eventually able to meld his own private demons about race with his country’s public ones, creating one of the most compelling, simultaneously personal and socially relevant bodies of work in 20th century American painting.

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a charming new cartoon, a fancy-schmancy real estate show and a dark documentary series.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Owl House’When to watch: Now, on Disney+.

headline: Dallas Cowboys Face Criticism After Partnership With Black Rifle Coffee
abstract: The announcement drew criticism in part for its timing, a day after the deadly mass shooting in Highland Park, Ill.
lead_paragraph: The Dallas Cowboys are facing criticism after announcing a new partnership with Black Rifle Coffee, the veteran-owned brand popular with conservatives and gun owners that sells roasts with names like “AK Espresso,” “Murdered Out” and “Silencer Smooth.”

headline: More Fed officials back a big July rate move, but downplay recession fears.
abstract: A central bank governor and president spoke in favor of a 0.75 percentage point rate increase this month, even as recession worries abound.
lead_paragraph: Two Federal Reserve officials expressed support on Thursday for making a second large rate increase at the central bank’s upcoming meeting and argued that, while there are early signs that the economy is slowing somewhat, data on gross domestic product overstate the extent of any pullback.

headline: How Many Children Does Elon Musk Have?
abstract: Name-change documents filed in Texas show that the outspoken entrepreneur recently fathered twins with Shivon Zilis, a director at one of his companies.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the billionaire Tesla founder, had twins in November with Shivon Zilis, a director at one of his companies, according to court documents made public on Wednesday. Neither Mr. Musk nor Ms. Zilis has spoken publicly about their children.

headline: At the Laundromat Project, Artists Are Ambassadors of Joy and Activism
abstract: A nonprofit that has been supporting community-based artistic ventures inaugurates its new home in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Laundromat Project was founded two decades ago at a kitchen table on MacDonough Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, when Risë Wilson received her first grant money to make art experiences accessible to her neighbors — miles away and a world apart from gatekeeper institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Raiders Make N.F.L. History With Team President Hire
abstract: Reeling from scandal and the exodus of team executives, the Las Vegas Raiders hired Sandra Douglass Morgan as their president. She is the first Black woman to hold the role in N.F.L. history.
lead_paragraph: The Las Vegas Raiders hired Sandra Douglass Morgan, the former chairwoman of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, as the team’s new president on Thursday. She is the first Black woman to hold the position for an N.F.L. franchise.

headline: Killer of George Floyd Sentenced to 21 Years for Violating Civil Rights
abstract: Derek Chauvin, already serving more than 22 years in state prison for murder, pleaded guilty to federal charges that he used excessive force against Mr. Floyd and a 14-year-old boy.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, Minn — A white Minneapolis police officer whose murder of a Black man outside a convenience store touched off protests around the world was sentenced to 21 years in federal prison on Thursday, in a case that signaled a new readiness to hold police officers criminally accountable for misconduct.

headline: Cabaret Champion Michael Feinstein Teams With Café Carlyle
abstract: The performer and entrepreneur is ending his partnership with 54 Below and will perform his first-ever shows at the Upper East Side venue in October.
lead_paragraph: One of cabaret’s most famous champions is about to forge a new collaboration with one of its most storied venues, and end his association with another.

headline: Washington Post names David Shipley as its opinion editor.
abstract: The newspaper said his job would be to expand the section nationally and globally.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post named David Shipley, a senior editor at Bloomberg, on Thursday to oversee its opinion section.

headline: Cleveland Officer Who Killed Tamir Rice Swiftly Exits New Police Job
abstract: Timothy Loehmann left his position as a police officer in a rural Pennsylvania community just two days after he was sworn in.
lead_paragraph: Two days after Timothy Loehmann, the former Cleveland police officer who shot and killed 12-year-old Tamir Rice in 2014, was sworn in as a police officer for a rural Pennsylvania community, he left the position, the borough of Tioga announced on Thursday.

headline: Your Friday Briefing: Boris Johnson Plans to Resign
abstract: Also, Brittney Griner pleads guilty to Russian drug charges and Beijing has a new Covid strategy.
lead_paragraph: Standing alone at a lectern in front of 10 Downing Street, Boris Johnson announced that he would step down after three years as Britain’s prime minister, the result of a wholesale rebellion of his cabinet, a wave of government resignations and a devastating loss of party support prompted by recent scandals.

headline: The Plight of Brittney Griner
abstract: The U.S. says the basketball star is a hostage of President Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Cilantrophilia
abstract: For the illustrator Rachelle Meyer, a love affair with cilantro was rekindled in a Brooklyn bodega.
lead_paragraph: Follow New York Times Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and Pinterest. Get regular updates from New York Times Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.

headline: Harvey Dinnerstein, Proudly Realistic Painter, Is Dead at 94
abstract: He documented the early days of the civil rights movement in evocative drawings. Later, his paintings examined details of the everyday life around him.
lead_paragraph: The Montgomery bus boycott was in its early days when Harvey Dinnerstein and his friend Burt Silverman — two socially conscious Realist painters motivated by the lack of photographic evidence of the protests — took the train from Penn Station in Manhattan to Alabama in 1956 to draw that seminal chapter in the nascent civil rights movement.

headline: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Two books on this week’s list are harrowing works of nonfiction: Keri Blakinger’s “Corrections in Ink,” a memoir, casts a clear eye on drug addiction and time spent in prison. Marie Brenner’s “The Desperate Hours” takes us inside a New York City hospital in the early days of the Covid pandemic.

headline: The Fall of Boris Johnson, Explained
abstract: Britain’s prime minister Boris Johnson said he would step down less than three years after his landslide election victory, following a series of scandals that have ensnared his government.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s prime minister Boris Johnson said he would step down less than three years after his landslide election victory, following a series of scandals that have ensnared his government.

headline: First, the Fish Fell From the Sky. Then They Washed Ashore.
abstract: In the past month, dead anchovies have been spotted on the streets of San Francisco. Last week, thousands appeared at the edge of a lagoon about 30 miles north.
lead_paragraph: One night last month, Britt Gerhard and her husband heard a bang on the roof of their house in San Francisco around 8 p.m. It was so loud, they thought it was an earthquake.

headline: Don’t Let Your Wine Go to the Grocery Store Naked
abstract: Recent research helps explain how clear bottles can result in wine that smells like “wet dog” and “boiled cabbage.”
lead_paragraph: Wine is about experience. It’s about a subtle taste and a pleasant buzz. The slow crafting of a drink over months and years. It can also be about downing cheap fermented grape juice as fast as possible. Who’s to judge?

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Fair Play’ Review: Casting a Floodlight on Invisible Labor
abstract: This documentary, a lucid look at household tasks based on Eve Rodsky’s best seller, pairs actionable guidance with testimony from real families.
lead_paragraph: The advice included within Eve Rodsky’s book “Fair Play,” a guide to sharing domestic labor and achieving harmony in the home, won’t blow your mind. A woman’s time is as valuable as a man’s? Who knew! But there is a fortifying effect to arranging these axioms in sequence.

headline: Germany paves the way to rescue critical energy providers and gas supplies.
abstract: Lawmakers passed a bill to allow bailouts of companies essential to energy security. Uniper, Germany’s largest Russian gas importer, may become the first company saved.
lead_paragraph: German lawmakers approved a measure on Thursday that will allow the government to throw a lifeline to companies struggling with the record-high price of gas and with cuts in supplies from Russia.

headline: Ons Jabeur, an Entertainer Who May Soon Be a Wimbledon Champion
abstract: Jabeur, the first Arab or African woman to reach a Grand Slam singles final in the Open era, will face Elena Rybakina in Saturday’s women’s final.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — In Tunisia, her home nation and inspiration, Ons Jabeur has acquired the nickname “The Minister of Happiness.”

headline: Texas Governor Orders State Police to Return Migrants to Border
abstract: The order by Gov. Greg Abbott calls for the state authorities to take on an immigration role that is typically the purview of the federal government. It comes amid growing conservative pressure over unauthorized migration.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gov. Greg Abbott on Thursday ordered the Texas National Guard and the state police to begin apprehending migrants who illegally cross the border from Mexico and taking them back to ports of entry, a move that could put the state into direct conflict with the federal government over immigration.

headline: Mena, a Well-Received Restaurant in TriBeCa, Will Close
abstract: Less than six months after it opened, a sudden end for the kitchen where the chef Victoria Blamey evoked the flavors of her Chilean childhood.
lead_paragraph: Mena, the TriBeCa restaurant led by the chef Victoria Blamey, will close its doors at the Walker Hotel after its last service on Saturday, less than six months after it opened to enthusiastic reviews.

headline: Why Mass Shooters Do the Evil They Do
abstract: The common answer is often wrong.
lead_paragraph: I will never get over the fact that our society seems to produce a steady stream of young men who think it is heroic to murder innocent people. I read their histories. I look at the social science research. I’ve tried to understand the typical pathway they take to get to their evil behavior.

headline: That Was the Stagflation That Was
abstract: Markets are sounding the all-clear. Is the Fed listening?
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday the five-year breakeven inflation rate fell to 2.48 percent. If that doesn’t mean anything to you — which is completely forgivable if you aren’t a professional economy-watcher — try this: The wholesale price of gasoline has fallen about 80 cents a gallon since its peak a month ago. Only a little of this plunge has been passed on to consumers so far, but over the weeks ahead we’re likely to see a broad decline in prices at the pump.

headline: Biden and the Increasingly Anxious Democrats
abstract: Michael D. Shear, a longtime White House reporter for The New York Times, talks about recent staff turnover in the administration and frustration around the president.
lead_paragraph: Despite signs that Democrats may be in better shape in the midterms than many expected six months ago, a widespread malaise is setting in within the White House. There is a growing sense that President Biden is not prosecuting a political case against Republicans aggressively enough.

headline: Spirit Airlines again puts off a vote on Frontier’s offer as it mulls JetBlue’s.
abstract: The bargain carrier’s shareholders are now scheduled to deliver their verdict on July 15.
lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines said Thursday that it had again delayed a shareholder vote on its proposed acquisition by Frontier Airlines, allowing it to continue discussions with Frontier and with JetBlue Airways, which has made a rival bid.

headline: Boris Johnson Quits Amid Latest Scandal, a Messy End to a Messy Tenure
abstract: In a dizzying two days, Conservative Party lawmakers who had defended the prime minister through crises turned against him, and now some are vying to replace him despite harsh economic headwinds.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Bowing to intense pressure from his own party, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain said Thursday that he would step down, ending a stormy three-year tenure that was marked by a landslide election victory and a successful drive to pull Britain out of the European Union, but collapsed under the weight of relentless scandals.

headline: Brittney Griner’s Supporters Hold Steady After Guilty Plea
abstract: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, pleaded guilty to drug charges in Russia on Thursday. But her supporters are still determined to fight to bring her home.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in a while, Terri Jackson, the executive director of the W.N.B.A. players’ union, felt hopeful about Brittney Griner.

headline: After Roe, South Carolina Considers More Restrictions on Abortion
abstract: The state legislature was the first to step into a post-Roe world, clearing the path for full bans in other conservative states.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Nearly two weeks after the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion established by Roe v. Wade, South Carolina lawmakers became the first to consider more restrictive legislation.

headline: Democrats Propose Raising Taxes on Some High Earners to Bolster Medicare
abstract: The draft plan, which is expected to be unveiled in the coming days, is part of talks over how to salvage pieces of President Biden’s domestic agenda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats will push to raise taxes on some high-earning Americans and steer the money to improving the solvency of Medicare, according to officials briefed on the plan, as they cobble together a modest version of President Biden’s stalled tax and spending package.

headline: ‘This Is America’: Biden Honors 17 With Presidential Medal of Freedom
abstract: Recipients of the nation’s highest civilian honor included the gymnast Simone Biles; John McCain, the former Republican senator from Arizona; and civil rights workers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After conferring the Presidential Medal of Freedom on 17 people, including the gymnast Simone Biles and former Senator John McCain, who was honored posthumously, President Biden said, “This is America.”

headline: The Delightful Implosion of Boris Johnson
abstract: His career is ending the way Donald Trump’s should have.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t much good news in the world these days, so it’s worth taking time to appreciate the delightful implosion of soon-to-be former Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

headline: When Are Expired Drugs Truly Expired?
abstract: Plenty of us have medications that are past their expiration date. But are they still OK to use?
lead_paragraph: I don’t know about your medicine cabinet, but mine is a jumble of mostly expired drugs: the muscle relaxants I got when I threw out my back a few years ago; the anti-nausea medicine I never took during my stomach woes last summer; the Xanax to occasionally help me cope with the dizzying state of the world.

headline: 9 James Caan Movies to Stream
abstract: Drama, comedy, suspense, action, kids’ movies — there was truly nothing he couldn’t do. Who else could star in both “The Godfather” and “Elf”?
lead_paragraph: When James Caan’s family announced his death on Thursday, it sent shock waves through cinematic circles — not because his passing was particularly premature (he was 82), but because he seemed such a vibrant and outsize personality, you figured he just might live forever.

headline: A Month of Shootings, One on Top of Another
abstract: In the U.S., a spate of gun violence in May, including two of the deadliest mass shootings so far this year, came at too fast a pace to grasp.
lead_paragraph: In the U.S., a spate of gun violence in May, including two of the deadliest mass shootings so far this year, came at too fast a pace to grasp.

headline: Secret Service Director to Step Down and Join Maker of Snapchat
abstract: The director, James M. Murray, was appointed by President Donald J. Trump in 2019 and is departing after nearly three decades with the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The director of the Secret Service announced on Thursday that he would retire at the end of the month after a 27-year career with the agency that is charged with protecting the president of the United States.

headline: Offering With a Blessing
abstract: Kyle Dolan returns with a challenging themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — For people first starting to solve crosswords, there is often a feeling of trepidation when they are confronted with a blank grid.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld branches out with a tricky cryptic challenge.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — Daily crossword solvers might recognize this puzzle’s constructor, Alan Arbesfeld, who has been making daily grids for The Times since 1981 — 131 in total, nearly all themed. This is his first variety puzzle and his first cryptic crossword. I love it: On one hand, there is something so mysterious and specialized about cryptics; they’re rare in the United States, and in their native stamping grounds of England their authors (or “setters”) often go by pseudonyms. On the other hand, what better source for a cryptic puzzle, full of puns and letter manipulation, than a mind that’s come up with puzzle themes by the dozen and pun entries by the hundreds? I like to think that this puzzle is composed of outtakes and oddities from all of those years of hard work.

headline: Man Who Swung Bat at Squeegee Workers in Baltimore Is Fatally Shot
abstract: The man, who had a heated confrontation with the workers as he drove through a downtown intersection, parked his car, approached the group with a baseball bat and swung it at them, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man who got out of his car and swung a bat at squeegee workers during a confrontation in downtown Baltimore was killed Thursday when one of the workers pulled out a gun and shot him, the authorities said.

headline: The First Date That Lasted a Week
abstract: Before even leaving Jean Paul Broc Gomez’s Los Angeles apartment for dinner, Charlie Kelly knew he had met the one.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Kelly was so sure of a relationship with Jean Paul Broc Gomez that he began to think of ways to spend more time together before their first date officially got started.

headline: A Compatible Phone Charger Led to a Strong Connection
abstract: Amina Colter and Jason Jones became long-distance pals after he lent her his phone charger during a teen weekend. They began dating 12 years later.
lead_paragraph: When Amina Elise Colter walked into Barcelona Wine Bar 45 minutes late and sat down for her first date with Jason Michael Jones, he sensed that his waitress and nearby tables wanted to cheer. And so did he.

headline: Losing the Pregnancy, the Marriage and the Pearls
abstract: At 18, I didn’t want to be the captain of my own fate. Fourteen years later, I do, and am.
lead_paragraph: My first job after college was as a seasonal sales associate at Macy’s in my hometown of Joplin, Mo. I had already worked there on two separate occasions before moving away for school. Now I was back, invariably ducking behind jewelry displays to avoid being spotted by old classmates.

headline: A Bronx Tale of Persistence
abstract: Tara Cannistraci and Michael Mondrone, both natives of the borough, met five years ago at a Mexican restaurant in Scarsdale, N.Y. He asked her to stay. She said no. Twenty minutes later, he emailed. She returned.
lead_paragraph: Tara Cannistraci was finishing dinner with a friend at El Barrio in Scarsdale, N.Y., in early May 2017, when Michael Todd Mondrone, a part owner of the Mexican restaurant, sent over some sorbet as a way to introduce himself. “She thanked me on her way out,” Mr. Mondrone said. “I asked her to stay.”

headline: Love, but Certainly Not at First Bite
abstract: Tyler Fox shocked Madelyn Krebs by helping himself to some of her lunch during their first meeting as high school students. They went on to become close friends and college roommates anyway.
lead_paragraph: When Madelyn Elizabeth Krebs and Tyler Christopher Fox met in August 2013, she was starting her second year at the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics, a high school in Durham, and he was beginning his first.

headline: A Fresh Start on the Mountain That Changed Her Life
abstract: Reggie Clark and Jamie MoCrazy met in 2017, two years after she suffered a traumatic brain injury during a skiing competition on Whistler Mountain. In May, they returned to marry.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Clark and Jamie MoCrazy were immediately drawn to each other after meeting through a mutual friend in June 2017 at a Bar Named Sue near Salt Lake City, where he lived. They bonded over a shared love for the outdoors.

headline: At Europe’s Largest Port, Russia Sanctions Meet Their Toughest Test
abstract: The Dutch port of Rotterdam and its staff are at the front line of enforcing the European Union’s restrictions on trade with Russia. It’s no easy task.
lead_paragraph: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands — Jolanda Wielenga was checking documents accompanying containers bound for Russia when her heart skipped a beat: One held a substance that could be used to make a chemical weapon.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Boris Johnson plans to resign.
lead_paragraph: Boris Johnson, Britain’s beleaguered leader, said that he would step down as prime minister after a dizzying 48 hours that included a wholesale rebellion of his cabinet, a wave of government resignations and a devastating loss of party support prompted by his handling of the latest scandal to engulf his leadership.

headline: Corrections: July 8, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about widespread claims of 2020 election fraud on right-wing radio shows referred incorrectly to the Sinclair Broadcast Group as a syndicator of radio shows. The company does not syndicate radio shows.

headline: Boris Johnson Was Just Being Boris Johnson
abstract: Many hoped he would change. But that was never going to happen.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I’ve always resisted comparisons between Boris Johnson and Donald Trump. Not anymore.

headline: The 3 Most Important Climate Laws You’ve Never Heard Of
abstract: The Legislature passed some bills that are obscure but significant, in the view of climate activists.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at several low-profile yet important climate laws that Gov. Kathy Hochul signed into law this week. And we’ll hear about a sense of déjà vu as monkeypox spreads in the city, along with confusion over how to get the so-far scarce vaccine.

headline: Videos Show the Moments After Shinzo Abe Is Shot
abstract: Footage shared on social media showed the scene after Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan, was assassinated while giving a speech in western Japan.
lead_paragraph: Footage shared on social media showed the scene after Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan, was assassinated while giving a speech in western Japan.

headline: For foreign fighters, the war is unlike any they’ve seen.
abstract: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Four months after Russia invaded Ukraine, foreign combat veterans who answered the Ukrainian president’s call to fight are grappling with the grueling reality of a war unlike any they have seen.
lead_paragraph: DRUZHKIVKA, Ukraine — Four months after Russia invaded Ukraine, foreign combat veterans who answered the Ukrainian president’s call to fight are grappling with the grueling reality of a war unlike any they have seen.

headline: Divisions over the war play out at a G20 meeting as Russia prepares for an assault on Donetsk in eastern Ukraine.
abstract: As foreign ministers from the Group of 20 industrialized nations met in Bali on Friday to discuss some of the world’s most pressing challenges, including the war in Ukraine, the divisions playing out as a result of the fighting were to the fore diplomatically, too.
lead_paragraph: As foreign ministers from the Group of 20 industrialized nations met in Bali on Friday to discuss some of the world’s most pressing challenges, including the war in Ukraine, the divisions playing out as a result of the fighting were to the fore diplomatically, too.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Dangerous Liaisons’ Review: The Epistolary Novel as Instagram Feed
abstract: A new film adaptation brings Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s 1782 book to the halls of a high school in modern-day France.
lead_paragraph: First published in 1782, Pierre Choderlos de Laclos’s wicked romp of a novel, “Dangerous Liaisons,” requires only a light airbrush to be convincingly transplanted to the halls of a modern-day high school where teenagers wield sex, power and status like weapons. Nevertheless, the director Rachel Suissa runs Laclos’s story through a heavy Instagram filter in this outlandish, flimsy adaptation.

headline: Johnson’s Lies Worked for Years, Until They Didn’t
abstract: The British prime minister thought he could swagger and dissemble his way through any scandal, but found the rules of gravity applied after all.
lead_paragraph: After a lifetime of swaggering and dissembling his way through one scandal after another on the strength of his prodigious political skills — a potent mix of charm, guile, ruthlessness, hubris, oratorical dexterity and rumpled Wodehousian bluster — Boris Johnson has finally reached the end. It seems that the laws of gravity apply to him after all.

headline: When Power Dressing Gets Personal
abstract: Redefining the form at Jean Paul Gaultier, Fendi and Vetements.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Inclusivity, diversity, no gender binaries — he was the first one,” said Olivier Rousteing, otherwise known as the creative director of Balmain, ticking off the issues at the forefront of identity politics.

headline: Gun Violence Is Almost Nonexistent in Japan
abstract: The country has some of the most stringent laws around buying and owning a firearm.
lead_paragraph: The attack on former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was especially shocking because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws around buying and owning a firearm.

headline: What happens next for Brittney Griner?
abstract: The American basketball star still faces the conviction and sentencing phases of her trial in Russia. But experts say her best hope may be a diplomatic deal between the U.S. and Russia.
lead_paragraph: By pleading guilty to drug charges in a Russian courtroom this week, the American basketball star Brittney Griner has potentially accelerated her case’s conclusion, clearing a path for either a deal with the United States or, perhaps, a request for clemency.

headline: Newly Published, From Banksy to Patrick Radden Keefe
abstract: A selection of books published this week.
lead_paragraph: BANKSY, by Stefano Antonelli and Gianluca Marziani. (Rizzoli Electa, $40.) This exhaustive collection showcases hundreds of works by the elusive street artist and global phenomenon, including famous paintings, serigraphs, stencils, installation objects and memorabilia.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 8, 2022
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Be Careful Which Supplements You Take
abstract: A new F.D.A. education initiative suggests supplements can be more trouble than they are worth.
lead_paragraph: A new F.D.A. education initiative suggests supplements can be more trouble than they are worth.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Thor: Love and Thunder."
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of "Thor: Love and Thunder."

headline: Why We Need Bugs
abstract: A graphic review of two new books that explain how the world’s insects came to be in peril.

headline: What a New Supreme Court Review May Mean for Albany’s Culture of Graft
abstract: Joseph Percoco and Alain Kaloyeros, former aides to Andrew Cuomo, could benefit if the court is more skeptical of what constitutes corruption.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Percoco and his taste for “ziti.” Alain Kaloyeros, the flashy tech executive convicted in a fraud. Joseph Bruno and a no-good racehorse named Christy’s Night Out.

headline: How Could This Be Murder?
abstract: In Tom Mead’s “Death and the Conjuror,” a man is found dead in his study, his throat cut. There is no weapon in the room, and the doors are locked — from the inside.
lead_paragraph: I’ve enjoyed the recent miniboom in locked-room mysteries, though I am starting to wonder if the number of “impossible crime” plots are finite. (I’ll add that any crime novel comparing itself to “And Then There Were None” or the film “Knives Out” must meet an exceedingly high threshold.)

headline: Next Time Trump Tries to Steal an Election, He Won’t Need a Mob
abstract: Conservatives want to give state legislatures the power to overturn presidential elections, but their case is built on a fundamentally flawed premise.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Supreme Court announced it would hear arguments in Moore v. Harper, a challenge to North Carolina’s new congressional map.

headline: Democrats Can Win if They Embrace the Politics of Fear
abstract: The right learned to use fear as a political weapon. Now Democrats must beat them at their own game.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to abortion rights, the Democrats need to lean into the politics of fear.

headline: With Roe Overturned, Austin’s Loss Could Be Brooklyn’s Gain
abstract: Cities around the South have challenged the supremacy of coastal supercities, drawing a steady flow of creative young people. Will new abortion bans put an end to that?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that you are a young woman setting out on your adult life in the United States of America in 2022. College is behind you; fulfilling personal and professional ambitions in a stimulating place is meant to come next. Ten or 20 years ago, depending on your interests, you might have moved, as if by reflex, to New York or Chicago, to Los Angeles or San Francisco. But those cities have become only more punishingly expensive. The average rental price of an apartment in Brooklyn is now $3,500, up 12 percent over last year, when we were still lingering in the misguided belief that the pandemic had perhaps changed the city irrevocably toward the softer and more accessible. (In Manhattan, the figure jumped 32 percent to $4,800.)

headline: Michelle Goldberg Grapples With Feminism After Roe
abstract: The Times Opinion columnist considers the current backlash against feminism — and where the movement goes next.
lead_paragraph: “It’s true: We’re in trouble,” writes Michelle Goldberg of the modern feminist movement. “One thing backlashes do is transform a culture’s common sense and horizons of possibility. A backlash isn’t just a political formation. It’s also a new structure of feeling that makes utopian social projects seem ridiculous.”

headline: How to Design a Beautiful, Cruel Universe
abstract: Gabrielle Zevin’s novel “Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow” is a love letter to the Literary Gamer.
lead_paragraph: Most kids who play a lot of video games don’t grow up to become avid readers. Then again, not every kid who reads a lot of books grows up to become an avid reader. Yet, in the diverse taxonomy of the modern gaming audience, there exists the Literary Gamer — someone for whom reading and playing are, and always have been, the same voyage. It would never occur to the Literary Gamer that one activity negates the other. If anything, the Literary Gamer believes, reading and playing enhance systematic thinking and the mysteries of imaginative empathy. This reviewer, for better or worse, is an avowed Literary Gamer — and I call upon my brothers and sisters to join me in a recitation of  Fünke’s Axiom: “There are dozens of us! DOZENS!”

headline: An Interview With San Francisco’s New District Attorney
