abstract: Brooke Jenkins, who helped lead the recall of her predecessor Chesa Boudin, will be sworn in on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A month after San Francisco voters ousted their progressive district attorney, Chesa Boudin, the city has a new top cop.

headline: Start-Up Equity Is a Great Retirement Plan, if You Can Pull It Off
abstract: Many employees of start-ups are attracted to the prospect of a big payout and an early retirement, but the strategy can require more luck than skill.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years ago, Trevor Ford left a job at LendingTree that gave him a 401(k) plan and a generous employer match to work at Yotta, an online banking app.

headline: Before Heading to College, Make a Mental Health Checklist
abstract: Students should not wait until they are on campus to begin thinking about how to protect their emotional well-being, experts say.
lead_paragraph: As fall approaches, new students will arrive on college campuses toting all kinds of things: luggage and school supplies, mini fridges and sports equipment. But in the midst of the preparation for move-in day, many have not considered what tools they will need to support themselves emotionally.

headline: Covering a Pre- and Post-Roe World
abstract: Margot Sanger-Katz, a domestic correspondent who writes about health care for The Upshot, shares how previous reporting helped readers understand the future of abortion access in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In July 2019, The Upshot, an arm of The New York Times that focuses on data-driven journalism, published the article “Where Roe v. Wade Has the Biggest Effect.” Written by the journalists Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui, the article examined what would happen if Roe v. Wade was to be overturned — Where would the number of legal abortions fall? What might happen in states with so-called trigger laws, which would ban abortion almost immediately? Using research, it estimated what could happen under various scenarios, and with maps, displayed what at that point was an alternate reality.

headline: Codependency Is a Toxic Myth in Addiction Recovery
abstract: Love doesn’t enable addiction.
lead_paragraph: With over seven million copies sold, Melody Beattie’s 1986 best seller, “Codependent No More: How to Stop Controlling Others and Start Caring for Yourself,” is considered a self-help classic and continues to sell well in a new 2022 edition.

headline: Rhea Seehorn Is Getting Away With It
abstract: The jig is up for Kim Wexler as “Better Call Saul” nears a close. Meanwhile, the actress who plays her has been quietly stealing the show.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Rhea Seehorn insists she is a rule follower. And not the kind who, like her character Kim Wexler on AMC’s “Better Call Saul,” follows some rules in public while bending others in secret to whatever ends she believes are just.

headline: I Don’t Want to See a High School Football Coach Praying at the 50-Yard Line
abstract: It offends me to see sanctimonious public prayer in any circumstance; still, how do people who believe entirely in science and reason also believe that prayer can heal and restore?
lead_paragraph: Many of us who believe in a reality beyond the visible realms, who believe in a soul that survives death, and who are hoping for seats in heaven near the dessert table, also recoil from the image of a high school football coach praying at the 50-yard line.

headline: What’s Up With the Crazy Housing Market?
abstract: Rising mortgage rates. Faltering home sales. Skyrocketing rents. Here’s how to make sense of a baffling real estate market.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: What Happens When a Rock Star Proposes Onstage?
abstract: Olivia Jean married the celebrated musician Jack White mid-performance, but she has a plan all her own.
lead_paragraph: It was something out of a fairy tale, if everyone in fairy tales wore denim and leather and looked like they smoked American Spirits. One minute, Olivia Jean was a shy kid from Michigan competing in her school’s battle of the bands show, and the next, she’s performing with her boyfriend, the musician Jack White, and he’s proposing to her in the middle of his song “Hotel Yorba” — right before the line “Let’s get married/ In a big cathedral by a priest.” A minute later, Mr. White remembered, come to think of it, one of the guys backstage was a licensed minister — does she want to get married right then?

headline: How Dan Perlman, of ‘Flatbush Misdemeanors,’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: After singing lessons and some basketball, the actor, who is “easing back into standup,” stops by a few comedy clubs.
lead_paragraph: The Showtime comedy “Flatbush Misdemeanors” was originally a low-budget web series created by Dan Perlman and Kevin Iso, two comics who had met at open mic events around the city. Now the show, about two friends struggling to get by in Flatbush, Brooklyn, is into its second season. Mr. Perlman, 32, who is also an executive producer of the series, lives in a one-bedroom apartment in, you guessed it, Flatbush.

headline: Even in Death, Internet Explorer Lives On in South Korea
abstract: Why a country known for blazing broadband and innovative devices remains tethered to a browser that most of the world abandoned long ago.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL — In South Korea, one of the world’s most technologically advanced countries, there are few limits to what can be done conveniently online — except if you’re using the wrong web browser.

headline: Windswept Views and ‘Glories Strung Like Beads’: Exploring Brooklyn by Ferry
abstract: More than 160 years after Walt Whitman extolled the joys of riding the ferry, there are fresh opportunities to explore neighborhoods like Red Hook, Brooklyn Heights and Bay Ridge by boat.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a fresh way to scout Brooklyn’s waterfront? Try a ferry. For $2.75, you can explore ports of call that cradle a bounty of cultural and culinary adventures. Island-hopping from Manhattan can begin at the Pier 11-Wall Street landing, where the salty air is invigorating and anticipation builds as vessels with names like Ferry Godmother, City Fishy and McShiny pull in to whisk you away.

headline: The Robot Guerrilla Campaign to Recreate the Elgin Marbles
abstract: The British Museum has staunchly refused to return the Parthenon Marbles to Greece. A team of archaeologists are working on a technological solution to the dispute.
lead_paragraph: Few cultural disputes inflame British passions more than the disposition of the Parthenon Marbles. Public debate about the statuary has raged since the early 1800s, when the sculptures and bas-reliefs, which date from 447 B.C. to 432 B.C., were stripped from the Parthenon and other Classical Greek temples on the Acropolis of Athens by agents of Thomas Bruce, a Scottish statesman and seventh earl of Elgin. The marbles were purchased — some say looted — by Elgin during his time as ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, the occupying power; they have resided in the British Museum since 1817.

headline: Shinzo Abe Is Assassinated With a Handmade Gun, Shocking a Nation
abstract: In a country with tight gun laws and little violence, the killing of the former prime minister left many in stunned disbelief. “It’s so un-Japanese.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Shinzo Abe, Japan’s most influential former prime minister, was stumping on behalf of a junior politician from his party near a train station in Japan’s old capital city of Nara on Friday morning when he collapsed, bleeding, on the street. He was shot in the neck, doctors said, by a gunman who later admitted he had come to kill him.

headline: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s Longest-Serving Prime Minister, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Abe was shot on Friday during a campaign event. Before he left office in 2020, he helped pull his country out of economic malaise but fell short of his most cherished goal: to normalize Japan’s military after decades of postwar pacifism.
lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Japanese prime minister, who made it his political mission to vanquish his country’s wartime ghosts but fell short of his ultimate goal of restoring Japan as a normalized military power, was assassinated on Friday in the city of Nara, Japan. He was 67.

headline: Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini Acquitted of Fraud
abstract: Blatter, the former president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, and Platini, his onetime ally, were charged over a $2 million payment that prosecutors had labeled a bribe.
lead_paragraph: Sepp Blatter, the former president of FIFA, and his onetime ally Michel Platini were acquitted of fraud on Friday in the latest attempt by Swiss prosecutors to win a conviction in a sprawling, seven-year investigation into corruption at the highest levels of world soccer.

headline: These 8 measures reflect a slowing U.S. economy.
abstract: A growing number of economists are predicting a recession in 2023, but there are signs that a slowdown has already begun.
lead_paragraph: The American economy is showing clear signs of slowing down, fueling concerns about a potential recession.

headline: U.S. Economy Added 372,000 Jobs in June, Defying Slowdown Fears
abstract: The strong Labor Department report comes as consumers and businesses express increasing concern about a downturn.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy powered through June with broad-based hiring on par with recent months, keeping the country clear of recession territory even as inflation eats into wages and interest rates continue to rise.

headline: Quotation of the Day: He Charms, Lies and Blusters: It Always Saved Him, Till Now
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 8, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “People have known that Boris Johnson lies for 30 years. He’s probably the best liar we’ve ever had as a prime minister. He knows a hundred different ways to lie.”

headline: The Final Days of Boris Johnson
abstract: He was famed for his ability to escape a political scandal. What brought down the British prime minister in the end?
lead_paragraph: After a flurry of ministerial resignations and calls from members of his own party for his departure, Boris Johnson agreed on Thursday to resign as prime minister of Britain.

headline: Families of civilian soldiers worry and wait in Ukraine.
abstract: Many of the fighters have no previous military experience.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — As thousands of young men and women are deployed to the front lines in Ukraine, each leaves behind family members and friends who hold their collective breath.

headline: Twitter is ready for a legal battle to force Elon Musk to buy the company.
abstract: Mr. Musk has appeared reluctant to proceed with the $44 billion agreement, citing uncertainty about the number of fake accounts on the platform.
lead_paragraph: [Follow for updates as Elon Musk has said he plans to terminate his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter.]

headline: Everyday Violence
abstract: We look at where most of America’s gun violence happens.
lead_paragraph: Since a gunman killed seven people at a Chicago suburb’s July 4 parade, more than 160 people have died from other gun homicides across the country. In Chicago alone, at least 10 people were killed in multiple shootings during the holiday weekend.

headline: U.S. Qualifies for 2023 Women’s World Cup
abstract: A lopsided victory over Jamaica in a regional championship ensured that the Americans would get to defend their World Cup title next summer.
lead_paragraph: A United States women’s national team that arrived in Mexico this week with two objectives has already achieved the first: After a lopsided victory over Jamaica on Thursday night, the United States clinched a place in the 2023 Women’s World Cup.

headline: Under Pressure, Biden Issues Executive Order on Abortion
abstract: After the Supreme Court’s ruling, some of the president’s supporters have wanted him to push harder to protect abortion access. But details about what his new order will do remain unclear.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to do more to respond to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, President Biden issued an executive order on Friday designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception while preparing for legal fights to come.

headline: Being Marina Abramović, Even When No One’s Looking
abstract: Despite her success, the performance artist has chosen a monastic life in upstate New York, where she falls asleep to Canadian television and eats baby food.
lead_paragraph: The New York-based artist Marina Abramović is sitting in the kitchen of her house just outside of Hudson when she invites me — over FaceTime — to join her in Greece this August for a workshop organized by the Marina Abramović Institute (MAI). “It’s only five days. No food, no talking and heavy exercise,” says the artist, 75, with a chuckle. Abramović founded the institute in 2007, originally intending to convert a derelict theater built sometime around the 1930s nearby into a top-of-the-line Rem Koolhaas-designed performance space, archive and education center. But when the project’s budget ballooned out of her control (Koolhaas’s plans alone were estimated to be $31 million, which didn’t include the handling of the theater’s pre-existing asbestos problem) and her fund-raising efforts fell short (a Kickstarter only got her to a little over half a million dollars), Abramović decided to turn it into something that didn’t depend on a physical location. Its new slogan? “Don’t come to us; we come to you.”

headline: Biodiversity Crisis Affects Billions Who Rely on Wild Species, Researchers Say
abstract: The latest global assessment of the decline in plant and animal life found some bright spots but recommended significant changes to hunting and other practices to address the risks.
lead_paragraph: Billions of people worldwide rely on some 50,000 wild species for food, energy, medicine and income, according to a sweeping new scientific report that concluded humans must make dramatic changes to hunting and other practices to address an accelerating biodiversity crisis.

headline: Assassination Rattles Peaceful Japan
abstract: The violence shook the country’s sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare. “This is so not Japanese.”
lead_paragraph: The stunning assassination of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe rattled Japan and its sense of identity as a peaceful country where violent crime is rare.

headline: This Week in Extreme Weather
abstract: A deadly glacier collapse in Italy, Jello-green skies over South Dakota and a warning about Europe's hot future.
lead_paragraph: A deadly glacier collapse in Italy, Jello-green skies over South Dakota and a warning about Europe's hot future.

headline: The Historically Black College Reconsiders the Studio Art Program
abstract: After decades of being underfunded, H.B.C.U.s see an opportunity to expand their offerings and foster a new generation of artists.
lead_paragraph: The fourth edition of H. W. Janson’s “History of Art,” long the standard introductory text in art history courses, is over 850 pages long, with more than 1,000 illustrations, weighing in at over seven and a half pounds. It aims for the encyclopedic, “from cave paintings of the Old Stone Age to the latest video art.” During the fall of 1992, when the artist Derek Fordjour was 18 years old, he lugged the book to class at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn with earnest intentions of pursuing an artistic career. The child of Ghanaian immigrants who had made a home in Memphis, Fordjour had absorbed his parents’ work ethic and respect for education. But something was missing for him in that hefty tome: nearly the entire history of Black art in America.

headline: Waiting for a Slowdown
abstract: Plus: Elon Musk may be preparing for the next chapter in his Twitter takeover journey — court.
lead_paragraph: This morning, the Labor Department  reported that employers added 372,000 workers to their payrolls in June. Economists were expecting hiring to have slowed last month, as fewer workers are available or willing to take open jobs, and while consumer spending is slowing as higher interest rates, imposed by the Fed to combat inflation, take their toll.

headline: Boris Johnson Hasn’t Left, but the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun
abstract: The Conservative Party must decide not only who should succeed the scandal-tarred British prime minister, but also when he should go.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the surface, it looked like business as usual at the heart of British government on Friday, a day after Boris Johnson was forced to announce he would resign as prime minister when his party turned against him over the latest in a series of embarrassing scandals.

headline: José Eduardo dos Santos, Longtime Angolan Ruler, Dies at 79
abstract: As Angola’s president for 38 years, Mr. dos Santos ended the country’s civil war. He also launched an economic boom, but it mainly benefited his family and friends.
lead_paragraph: José Eduardo dos Santos, a onetime Soviet-trained fighter against Portuguese colonial rule who in nearly four decades as Angola’s president became one of Africa’s longest-serving rulers — and was also accused of corruption on a grand scale — died on Friday in Barcelona, Spain, where he had been living in self-imposed exile. He was 79.

headline: Wages climbed 5.1 percent, a still-rapid pace as Fed awaits slowdown.
abstract: Central bankers are closely watching wage growth, which has been picking up rapidly before accounting for inflation.
lead_paragraph: Wages continued to climb rapidly last month, offering little encouragement to the Federal Reserve as policymakers hope for a slowdown in pay gains that might allow inflation to moderate.

headline: What to Know About Rolling Over Retirement Accounts
abstract: A new report finds that I.R.A.s may charge seemingly modest higher fees than workplace retirement accounts. But over time, the difference can add up to tens of thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Americans who are moving money from a workplace retirement plan to an individual retirement account may be tripped up by seemingly modest increases in fees that can significantly erode savings over time, new research has found.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 5: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 15 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on July 26.
lead_paragraph: Update, July 26: The Week 5 winners have been announced!

headline: Their Wildest Dreams
abstract: Two siblings, a playful teacher’s class and three friends let their imaginations loose in the great outdoors.
lead_paragraph: One summer, when I was a single mother raising my second and fourth graders in Brooklyn and the weeks ahead without child care loomed large, my friend Catherine and I rented a farmhouse in upstate New York for a month. She brought her 9-year-old twins, and we let the kids explore the woods while we worked. We gave them a loud whistle and generous boundaries — the distant stone wall, the serpentine stream, the neighboring field — and sent them off to run wild.

headline: Can a Friendship Offer Redemption?: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Zawe Ashton Isn’t Here to Be a Victim of Your Projections
abstract: The actress was never offered a period piece until “Mr. Malcolm’s List.” She was given 24 hours to decide whether to do it. Now she’s earning raves.
lead_paragraph: “I haven’t necessarily had the privilege of being cast as the hero,” Zawe Ashton said. “And that’s OK.”

headline: A Self-Taught Artist Takes His Roadside Acropolis North
abstract: Outside the art establishment for decades, Charles Smith has sculpted his Black heroes in Aurora, Ill., and now in Hammond, La. At 81, he’s getting his first show in New York.
lead_paragraph: HAMMOND, La. — Along Interstate 55 heading to this small town north of New Orleans, you pass several signs telling you what’s ahead, literally and maybe also metaphorically: Ponchatoula Antique City, Tickfaw State Park, Don’s Seafood, Apocalypse Sports (“Guns, Ammo, Tactical.”)

headline: He Had a Dark Secret. It Changed His Best Friend’s Life.
abstract: Tin Chin and Mo Lin were inseparable at the homeless shelter. But one of the men wasn’t who he seemed to be.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Network Disruption Triggers Internet and Phone Outages in Canada
abstract: The outages affected customers of one of the country’s largest telecommunications companies. Some local police services said customers were unable to call 911.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — An outage on Friday at Rogers, one of Canada’s largest telecommunications companies, caused significant internet, cable and cellphone disruptions, mostly in Ontario and Quebec, the country’s most populous provinces.

headline: Russia sentences a lawmaker to seven years in prison for denouncing the war.
abstract: The Russian authorities have opened dozens of similar cases since the government made denouncing the war a crime, but Aleksei Gorinov was the first to receive a substantial prison term for it.
lead_paragraph: A court in Moscow on Friday sentenced an opposition lawmaker to seven years in prison for denouncing Russia’s war in Ukraine, handing down the first prison term for what the government made a crime shortly after the invasion.

headline: Start Investing Early and Stick With It, Especially When Stocks Fall
abstract: A bear market can be great for your future wealth, if you use broad, low-cost funds to buy stocks and bonds steadily for decades, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: I wouldn’t wish this bear market on anyone.

headline: An improvised firearm was used to assassinate Abe.
abstract: Video shows a device consisting of two tubes, bound together side by side with black electrical tape, similar to a double-barrel shotgun.
lead_paragraph: The weapon used to assassinate former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan was an improvised firearm.

headline: BA.4 and BA.5 power a surge of known infections in Europe, officials say.
abstract: While many European countries have seen an uptick in hospitalizations, “what we’re not seeing is an increase in intensive care unit admissions, so the vaccines are still very much working,” an official with the World Health Organization said this week.
lead_paragraph: The rapidly spreading Omicron subvariants known as BA.4 and BA.5 are driving a summertime surge of the coronavirus in Europe, health officials say, after most Covid policies were removed in spring and a more relaxed approach to the pandemic has become the norm during the warmer months.

headline: Emmy Rossum Dreams of Pink Macarons
abstract: The star and executive producer of “Angelyne” gets a master class at Ladurée.
lead_paragraph: “Look,” Emmy Rossum said, squeezing an excess of rose buttercream onto a waiting meringue. “We can’t all be perfect the first time.”

headline: High Court Sides With Prince Harry in Libel Claim
abstract: The initial ruling clears the way for Harry to pursue a libel claim against The Mail on Sunday over its reporting about his police protection.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A judge in Britain ruled on Friday that parts of an article in a tabloid newspaper about Prince Harry’s fight with the government over police protection were defamatory, in an initial phase of Harry’s libel case against the paper.

headline: The power, and limits, of local action
abstract: In the absence of national climate measures in the United States, how much can be done at the local level? Our reporters talk about the opportunities and barriers.
lead_paragraph: The White House can’t get climate legislation passed. Congress is gridlocked. The Supreme Court has tied the hands of the federal agency entrusted to protect the environment.

headline: Three Tales From the Transfer Market
abstract: Cristiano Ronaldo’s loyalty, Manchester United’s vision and Barcelona’s complete inability to stop spending explain a lot about the business of modern soccer.
lead_paragraph: Let’s try something different in this week’s newsletter: A journey through modern soccer in three (vaguely related) stories.

headline: Kenward Elmslie, Poet and Librettist, Dies at 93
abstract: He collaborated on operas with Jack Beeson and Ned Rorem and published numerous poetry books. Late in life, he was victimized by theft.
lead_paragraph: Kenward Elmslie, who wrote poetry, opera librettos and stage musicals, and who late in life made headlines when his chauffeur bilked him out of millions of dollars and several valuable artworks, including one by Andy Warhol, died on June 29 at his home in the West Village. He was 93.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a romantic do-over, two-minute time travelers and unwanted party guests.
lead_paragraph: Time travel and romance make for a good cinematic combination because we just want to believe that true love is out there, even if you need a temporal do-over or three to finally secure it. In Greg Björkman’s assured debut feature, Laura (Clara Rugaard, from “I Am Mother”) and Harrison (Lewis Pullman, “Top Gun: Maverick”) meet, argue about the band Japanese Breakfast and fall in love. Then a car hits him and he dies.

headline: Wisconsin Supreme Court Prohibits the Use of Most Drop Boxes for Voting
abstract: The ruling by the court, which has a narrow conservative majority, comes as Republicans have tried to limit voting access in the state’s cities.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin Supreme Court on Friday prohibited the use of most drop boxes for voters returning absentee ballots, giving the state’s Republicans a major victory in their efforts to limit voting access in urban areas.

headline: Shinzo Abe tried to move Japan beyond postwar remorse and pacifism.
abstract: Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Japanese prime minister, who made it his political mission to vanquish his country’s wartime ghosts but fell short of his goal of restoring Japan as a normalized military power, was assassinated on Friday in the city of Nara, Japan. He was 67.
lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Japanese prime minister, who made it his political mission to vanquish his country’s wartime ghosts but fell short of his goal of restoring Japan as a normalized military power, was assassinated on Friday in the city of Nara, Japan. He was 67.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Bryan Washington wrote a paean to biscuits and has a new recipe for a kimchi-Cheddar version.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Bryan Washington is in The New York Times Magazine this weekend with a lovely paean to biscuits, along with a terrific new recipe for kimchi-Cheddar biscuits (above) that would make for a lovely late breakfast tomorrow, with some eggs and sausage if you eat such things.

headline: Private-sector employment has recovered to prepandemic levels.
abstract: Service businesses continue to climb back, but government payrolls are still short of February 2020 levels.
lead_paragraph: Job growth in June was driven by industries recuperating from pandemic-induced losses, and continued business investment in sectors still benefiting from formidable demand for their goods and services, even as borrowing costs increase.

headline: Strong Wage and Jobs Growth Keeps Fed on Track for Big Rate Increase
abstract: The Federal Reserve is trying to cool down the economy to bring inflation under control, but the job market is still going strong.
lead_paragraph: A surprisingly robust June employment report reinforced that America’s labor market remains historically strong even as recession warnings reach a fever pitch. But that development, while good news for the Biden administration, is likely to keep the Federal Reserve on its aggressive path of interest rate increases as it tries to cool the economy and slow inflation.

headline: The attack scrambled campaign plans two days before Japan’s election.
abstract: For the time being, political parties across the spectrum are pulling back on their messaging, but the election is still going ahead.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was supposed to be a quiet election for the Upper House of Parliament. But the assassination on Friday of Japan’s longest-serving prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has added an element of chaos to Japanese politics just two days before voters head to the ballot box.

headline: Assassination Shocks a Nearly Gun-Free Japan
abstract: Stringent rules on gun ownership had all but eradicated gun violence in the country.
lead_paragraph: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.

headline: The 1975’s Chamber-Pop Confessions, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear new tracks from Alvvays, Tyshawn Sorey, Killer Mike and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: What’s Next for Abortion Rights in New York?
abstract: Before Roe v. Wade, New York City was a haven for women from across the country. Decades later, a new generation of advocates has vowed that it will remain so.
lead_paragraph: New York has long been at the forefront of the push for abortion access. The state legalized the procedure three years before the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973. Thousands of women flooded in from other states, soon outnumbering the number of New York residents getting abortions.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Michelle Goldberg
abstract: The July 8, 2022 episode of ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Michelle Goldberg. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: In ‘The Bear’ on Hulu, a Kitchen Staff Is Nearly Eaten Alive
abstract: The new FX television show is one of the most vivid, authentic portrayals of what it’s like to work in food service.
lead_paragraph: Movies and TV shows about the inner workings of the culinary world have let us peek into restaurant kitchens before. But FX’s new “The Bear” is the first to force you to work in one.

headline: At the Opera, Humans Bear Witness to Atrocity, or Ignore It
abstract: Whether in works by Mahler, Mozart or Rossini, directors at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France evoke mass death and refugee crises.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — The bodies kept coming up.

headline: Clergy’s Call for an Assault Weapons Ban
abstract: Clergy and spiritual leaders in upstate New York issue a plea for gun control. Also: Learning from Britain; abortion travel; dividing America; museums.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Trigger Point’ Review: Pure Pressure à la ‘Line of Duty’
abstract: A new Peacock series about a London bomb squad bears the mark of its showrunner, Jed Mercurio, Britain’s master of the crime melodrama.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of people in the world: those who haven’t seen or heard of the British cop show “Line of Duty” and those who are rabid fans of it. It isn’t a great television series, or even a very good one, necessarily. But it has a loony, breathless intensity that sucks you in and a willingness to toy with its regular characters’ emotions, and question their motives, that is dramatically suspect but melodramatically potent. Through six seasons, it remains one of Britain’s most popular and honored TV shows.

headline: He’s the N.H.L.’s Next Big Star. He Just Has to Wait a Year.
abstract: The most exciting future N.H.L. player attending this week’s draft wasn’t eligible to be selected, but Connor Bedard will be prepared when his time comes.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Elite teenage hockey players wearing suits, ties and anxious looks were sitting in the stands at Bell Centre and waiting for their names to be called at the N.H.L. draft Thursday night. In a departure from most drafts, no prospect had established himself as the best in his year and rumors and speculation swirled. The last time there had been any real suspense around the first overall pick dated back to the wooden-stick era.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Check Out This Week
abstract: These titles by Sally Rooney, Matt Bell, and more offer a variety of genres and narratives for any reader.
lead_paragraph: These titles by Sally Rooney, Matt Bell, and more offer a variety of genres and narratives for any reader.

headline: Director of the Guggenheim to Step Down
abstract: Richard Armstrong, whose 14-year tenure was shaped by staff complaints of racism, labor issues and a public outcry over a planned offshoot in Abu Dhabi, said he will leave the museum in 2023.
lead_paragraph: Richard Armstrong, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, said he planned to retire from his role next year, capping off more than 14 years leading the institution and its international offshoots.

headline: A Sheet-Pan Chicken Recipe for Lovers of Sweet and Savory
abstract: Roasted chicken thighs are paired with tangy sour cherries and finished with a creamy, cooling cucumber yogurt in this balanced weeknight meal.
lead_paragraph: Every July, I question my sour cherry priorities. Their season is so short, and the fruit so scarce that I rarely get around to making anything beyond one big, gushy pie and a year’s supply of homemade maraschino cherries (must-haves in my manhattan cocktail).

headline: ‘Why Is Everyone Wearing Suits?’: #GentleMinions Has Moviegoers Dressing Up
abstract: A TikTok trend around the release of “Minions: The Rise of Gru” has young people around the globe suiting up for the cinema.
lead_paragraph: Normally when Carson Paskill heads to the movie theater, he opts for a comfortable outfit of sweatpants and a sweatshirt. But last weekend, he arrived in a black suit, white collared shirt and dress shoes.

headline: Larry Storch, Comic Actor Best Known for ‘F Troop,’ Dies at 99
abstract: His well-honed comic timing, and the mimicry skills he had developed in nightclubs, served him well on one of the sillier sitcoms of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Larry Storch, who played a memorable television oddball on the 1960s sitcom “F Troop” and for years carried a secret in his personal life that was odd in an entirely different way, died on Friday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 99.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: A 2,700-mile cycling race is now even more extreme. Also in this edition: exploring Brooklyn by ferry, and a campaign to recreate the Elgin marbles.
lead_paragraph: A 2,700-mile cycling race is now even more extreme. Also in this edition: exploring Brooklyn by ferry, and a campaign to recreate the Elgin marbles.

headline: For Ukraine, Boris Johnson’s Resignation Means Loss of a Personal Ally
abstract: Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, but in Ukraine he is widely adored for his unstinting support since the conflict with Russia.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson may be a polarizing figure in Britain, where his long association with scandal rendered him a lonely man this week as scores of onetime political allies abandoned him, forcing his resignation.

headline: Biden Praises Strong Jobs Report
abstract: The report suggests that the United States was not in recession, but points to ongoing challenges with inflation.
lead_paragraph: The report suggests that the United States was not in recession, but points to ongoing challenges with inflation.

headline: Grime Transformed British Music. A New Exhibition Traces How.
abstract: “Grime Stories: From the Corner to the Mainstream” at the Museum of London highlights the 20-year-old history and far-reaching impact of the British rap genre.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On a wall-mounted screen at the Museum of London, a low-resolution video showed young people rapping quickly and hungrily over syncopated beats. Every so often, a decidedly 2000s graphic flashed on the screen, reading “Risky Roadz 2.”

headline: Glimpses of Brittney Griner Show a Complicated Path to Release
abstract: The W.N.B.A. star’s appearances this week during her trial on drug charges in Russia highlighted the unclear path to her release and heightened her supporters’ concerns for her safety.
lead_paragraph: One hundred forty-one days.

headline: Joyce C. Lashof, Doctor Who Shattered Glass Ceilings, Dies at 96
abstract: In Illinois, she was the first woman to head a state public health department. She went on to become dean of the School of Public Health at Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Joyce C. Lashof, who fought for health equity and broke barriers as the first woman to head a state public health department and the first to serve as dean of the School of Public Health at the University of California, Berkeley, died on June 4 at an assisted living community in Berkeley. She was 96.

headline: ‘A One-Hour Layover Is Not Enough Anymore’: A Flight Attendant’s Tips on Surviving Travel Now
abstract: In two decades of flying, things have never been as stressful as they are now, a cabin insider says. Here, her tips from 30,000 feet for avoiding airline chaos this summer.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, with my life at a serious crossroads, I applied to every single airline, and a few months later I was officially a flight attendant. I loved my new job, and it came with a completely new and exciting life.

headline: Russia’s Lavrov Is Pariah at Group of 20 Event, but Only for Some
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and other Western foreign ministers refused to meet with the Russian diplomat, but for many others it was business as usual.
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — He was like a skunk at the tropical resort party, shunned by many, though by no means all.

headline: Novak Djokovic vs. Nick Kyrgios Makes for a Villainous Wimbledon Final
abstract: Kyrgios is playing in his first Grand Slam singles final, and Djokovic may be playing in his last until next year’s French Open.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — In the last year, Novak Djokovic has experienced the highest of tennis highs, coming within one match of winning a rare calendar-year Grand Slam and the lowest of lows, including detainment and deportation after he arrived in Melbourne in January to try to defend his Australian Open title.

headline: Love Letter: The Pearls She’ll Never Wear
abstract: She bought the necklace when she was desperate. She lost it when she wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: Eliza Smith was only 18 when she found herself back with her ex-boyfriend and, then, unintentionally pregnant.

headline: ‘He Presented Another Path’: Actors and Directors on Peter Brook
abstract: Patrick Stewart, Tarell Alvin McCraney, Tina Landau and Tim Robbins on being challenged and inspired by the legendary theater maker, who died last weekend.
lead_paragraph: The actor Kathryn Hunter heard the news of the director Peter Brook’s death, last weekend at 97, in a telephone call from his longtime collaborator Marie-Hélène Estienne. Then Hunter, an Olivier Award winner who played the witches in Joel Coen’s film “The Tragedy of Macbeth,” set off across London for Shakespeare’s Globe.

headline: At Ballet Theater, Visions of the Natural World and ‘Swan’ Debuts
abstract: Catherine Hurlin makes a major debut as Odette-Odile and the company presents the New York premiere of a mystical work by Alonzo King.
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater’s “Swan Lake,” which wrapped up its performances at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday, can feel choppy, as if its swans were pushing through water that becomes rougher with each passing year. This production, from 2000, was staged by Kevin McKenzie, who will soon retire as Ballet Theater’s artistic director. Is it time for his “Swan Lake” to leave the company, too? Alexei Ratmansky, the artist in residence, has a jewel of a “Swan Lake” in his back pocket, already made.

headline: You Can’t Outrun Athletic Greens
abstract: In the oversaturated world of wellness, the company has forced itself to the front with prolific podcast ads and a network of influencers.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: The U.S. will send another $400 million in military supplies to Ukraine, an official says.
abstract: A senior defense official said Friday that President Biden had authorized up to $400 million in additional military supplies — including precision-guided shells and multiple rocket launchers — to be taken from Pentagon stockpiles and shipped to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A senior defense official said Friday that President Biden had authorized up to $400 million in additional military supplies — including precision-guided shells and multiple rocket launchers — to be taken from Pentagon stockpiles and shipped to Ukraine.

headline: Looking for Aces Guard Jackie Young? She’s Probably in the Gym.
abstract: Young, set to start in her first W.N.B.A. All-Star Game, is known for her competitive drive. “She’s going to try to beat everyone,” one teammate said.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas Aces guard Jackie Young has met success at every level of basketball. She has a high school championship, an N.C.A.A. Division I title at Notre Dame, and last summer, she claimed Olympic gold in the first 3x3 competition. Now, as a first-time W.N.B.A. All-Star, Young, an Indiana native, has added another accolade en route to her ultimate goal.

headline: Wonking Out: Rockets, Feathers and Prices at the Pump
abstract: Yes, market power can worsen inflation.
lead_paragraph: One of the sad paradoxes of politics is that few economic indicators matter more for public opinion — for voters’ evaluation of the government in power — than energy prices, especially the price of gasoline. This isn’t just a U.S. phenomenon: Inflation driven by soaring energy prices has undermined the popularity of leaders across the Western world.

headline: Three Memoirs That Re-examine Challenges in Life and Identity
abstract: Addiction, fatherhood and transgender identity in new books by Cindy House, Will Jawando and Diana Goetsch.
lead_paragraph: On the cover of Cindy House’s new memoir, MOTHER NOISE (Marysue Rucci Books/Scribner, 266 pp., $26.99), a neon-tinged spoon next to spilled milk and colorful cereal artfully hints at the author’s twin themes: drug abuse and motherhood.

headline: Review: Momix’s ‘Alice’ Is a Rabbit Hole (or 22) Too Far
abstract: Momix’s latest show, now at the Joyce Theater, is inspired by Lewis Carroll’s “Alice in Wonderland.”
lead_paragraph: The dance critic Edwin Denby once wrote, “Daily life is wonderfully full of things to see.” That observation came to mind on Thursday during Momix’s “Alice,” a banal and busy 85-minute spectacle now at the Joyce Theater. Not that anything particularly wondrous was going on; quite the opposite. At that point in the show, the thought of simply stepping outdoors into the city night — to look at traffic, or the sunset, or people in the streets — was more enticing than any fantasy depicted onstage.

headline: The U.S. May Be Losing the Fight Against Monkeypox, Scientists Say
abstract: Longstanding weaknesses in the public health system are giving the virus a chance to become entrenched.
lead_paragraph: As epidemics go, the monkeypox outbreak should have been relatively easy to snuff out. The virus does not spread efficiently except through intimate contact, and tests and vaccines were at hand even before the current outbreak.

headline: Uniper, Germany’s largest gas importer, asks for government bailout.
abstract: Russian gas cutoffs are causing huge losses for the utility in the “middle double-digit million” euro area, Uniper’s chief executive said.
lead_paragraph: As Europe’s energy crisis escalates, Uniper, Germany’s largest importer of natural gas, asked the government for help on Friday, hours after Parliament passed a law aimed at keeping the energy provider afloat.

headline: Biden Signs Executive Order to Protect Abortion Access
abstract: President Biden issued an order aiming to protect access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, but details on how those goals would be accomplished were not outlined.
lead_paragraph: President Biden issued an order aiming to protect access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, but details on how those goals would be accomplished were not outlined.

headline: There is no sign of a Russian ‘pause’ for one Ukrainian town under fire.
abstract: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Russia’s defense ministry has said that it is conducting an “operational pause” in the war in Ukraine to allow units that have been fighting to rest, prompting military analysts to suggest that Russia was not ready to press into a full assault within Donetsk Province after its capture of neighboring Luhansk.
lead_paragraph: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Russia’s defense ministry has said that it is conducting an “operational pause” in the war in Ukraine to allow units that have been fighting to rest, prompting military analysts to suggest that Russia was not ready to press into a full assault within Donetsk Province after its capture of neighboring Luhansk.

headline: Where Bobbleheads Are Born
abstract: The Licensing Expo returned in person this year, where characters big and small searched for a match made in consumer heaven.
lead_paragraph: At 10:30 a.m. on the second day of the annual Licensing Expo in Las Vegas, mascots from a wide variety of beloved brands lined up by a small stage in the back of the convention center at the Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino, preparing to march around for a character parade. Sonic the Hedgehog was there, as were several Teletubbies, a Smurf, Peppa Pig, the Elf on the Shelf and Geoffrey, the Toys “R” Us giraffe. Also in attendance: a Dole pineapple with huge eyes and supple pink lips, and a Dole banana who looked very happy, but lacked the pout of its pineapple friend.

headline: Boris Johnson Leaves a Mixed Legacy With His Brexit Gambit
abstract: Departure from E.U. is a clear negative for the U.K. economy, but it could have been worse.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson will be remembered for Britain’s exit from the European Union long after the world has forgotten the tousled hair, the quotations in Homeric Greek, the fibs, fabrications and scandals — not to mention the time he got stuck on a zip line while serving as London mayor, sheepishly waving Union Jacks.

headline: Despite a Wimbledon Ban on Russian Players, a Russian Woman Might Win
abstract: Elena Rybakina was born and raised in Russia but started representing Kazakhstan after the Russian Tennis Federation gave up on her. Does she see herself as Russian? “It’s a tough question.”
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — After all the debate over whether to bar Russian and Belarusian players from Wimbledon, and under pressure from the British government, the women’s singles title may be won on Saturday by a player born in Russia after all.

headline: The Far-Right Christian Quest for Power: ‘We Are Seeing Them Emboldened’
abstract: Political candidates on the fringe mix religious fervor with conspiracy theories, even calling for the end of the separation of church and state.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: From Sad Leftovers to Dream Dinners
abstract: Five recipes for the use-them-or-lose-them ingredients hanging out in your refrigerator.
lead_paragraph: This is Priya Krishna, your replacement captain for this week’s Five Weeknight Dishes. The Priya you see today has come a long way in the kitchen. My young, new-to-New York self had a simple but cost-effective weeknight cooking strategy: Buy the same few ingredients every week (pasta, spinach, tomatoes, feta, frozen dumplings, sausage, yogurt), throw a surprise item (sweet potatoes! cookie butter ice cream! an avocado!) into the cart, and make it all work with the rest of my pantry.

headline: Review Finds Agents Used Unnecessary Force Against Black Migrants
abstract: Four Border Patrol agents face discipline over the confrontation last year. But the 500-page report described deeper problems within the agency amid a crisis at the border.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Border Patrol agents on horseback used “unnecessary” force in September against Black migrants who crossed into Del Rio, Texas, en masse, amid a humanitarian crisis that exposed the Biden administration’s struggle to manage a record number of southwestern border crossings.

headline: Putting the Public Back in Public Service
abstract: A group of academics and lawmakers, citing a new study that found voters feel shut out of congressional deliberations, is pushing to engage citizens more directly in the work of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the most vexing questions about the dysfunction of Congress is why lawmakers cannot find common ground on big issues facing the country when convincing data suggests there is broad public consensus about what should be done.

headline: The Chain of Failures That Left 17 Dead in a Bronx Apartment Fire
abstract: A Times investigation shows how a New York City high-rise became a deadly chimney of smoke.
lead_paragraph: A Times investigation shows how a New York City high-rise became a deadly chimney of smoke.

headline: Why the Overturning of Roe Won’t Lead to a Return of Segregation
abstract: A constitutional slippery slope wouldn’t take the Supreme Court toward revisiting the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Supreme Court, with its ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, has struck down Roe v. Wade, many have argued that the court might begin diminishing or doing away with other expansions of constitutional rights. Much of the reaction traces to Justice Clarence Thomas, who in his concurring opinion in Dobbs argued that “In future cases, we should reconsider all of this Court’s substantive due process precedents, including Griswold, Lawrence and Obergefell.” It was a shot across the legal bow that prompted James Obergefell, one of the petitioners in Obergefell v. Hodges — the case that guaranteed same-sex couples a constitutional right to marry — to respond, in an interview on CNN last week, that Thomas had “put a target” on “the right to contraception, the right to intimacy with the person you love and the right to marry the person you love,” and “that should terrify everyone in this nation.”

headline: Losing the fight against monkeypox
abstract: A troubling replay of the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The monkeypox outbreak should have been relatively easy to snuff out. The virus does not spread efficiently except through intimate contact, and tests and vaccines were at hand before the current outbreak.

headline: Divided Ukrainians
abstract: Residents in Sloviansk are far from united as they brace for a Russian onslaught.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Air Pollution Kills 10 Million People a Year. Why Do We Accept That as Normal?
abstract: Threats often appear larger and more profound the farther off they are and more manageable and even routine once they arrive
lead_paragraph: For every thousand people alive on earth, 973 are regularly inhaling toxins. Only 27 are not. Which means, almost certainly, you are too.

headline: A Special Edition: Shinzo Abe Assassinated
abstract: Japan reels after the former leader’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: A gunman shot Shinzo Abe, Japan’s most influential former prime minister, while he was giving a speech at a campaign event in the city of Nara. Less than six hours later, Abe, the longest-serving leader in Japan’s postwar history, was dead at age 67.

headline: How Can I Dress to Not Look Like a Tourist in France?
abstract: A reader is wondering what clothes to pack in her suitcase.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time it was easy to spot Americans abroad (or so the cliché went, anyway): They were the loud ones in jeans and T-shirts with fanny packs and baseball caps.

headline: The Mayor Who Never Sleeps
abstract: Is Eric Adams revealing himself to be the man the city needs?
lead_paragraph: On a breezy June night in the Bronx, I was on the balcony at the restaurant Zona De Cuba, sipping a mojito, vibing to a salsa band and peeking at a special menu for the plant-based mayor of New York, Eric Adams, who was soon to arrive.

headline: Elon Musk Moves to End $44 Billion Deal to Buy Twitter
abstract: In a regulatory filing on Friday, Mr. Musk said Twitter was in “material breach” of the acquisition agreement.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Less than three months ago, Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, struck a blockbuster $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. He proclaimed that the company had “tremendous potential.”

headline: Russia Votes to Shut Down Last U.N. Aid Route Into Syria
abstract: Millions of Syrians whose lives have already been shattered by more than a decade of war may be left without food, medicine and other supplies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia vetoed a measure on Friday that would have allowed the last U.N. aid route into Syria to remain open for another year, in a vote that diplomats and critics said endangered the lives of millions of people already suffering after more than a decade of war.

headline: 911 Dispatcher Faces Manslaughter Charge After Failing to Send Ambulance
abstract: The authorities in Pennsylvania said the dispatcher told a woman that he would not send an ambulance to her mother unless the mother agreed to go to the hospital. She died the next day.
lead_paragraph: A 911 dispatcher has been charged with involuntary manslaughter after he failed to send an ambulance to a woman in rural Pennsylvania who was bleeding and incoherent and who died a day later, the authorities said.

headline: Remembering James Caan and His Potent Mix of Swagger and Delicacy
abstract: “The Godfather” helped open up a range of roles for the actor that allowed him to play against type and expectation in wonderful ways.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure who owned the book, but eventually it ended up in my sweaty young hands. Someone at school had told me about the scene in Mario Puzo’s “The Godfather,” the one in which Sonny Corleone, the reckless eldest son with a Cupid face and a massive endowment, steals off with one of his sister’s bridesmaids. I remember racing through the passage (“her legs were wrapped around his thighs”). It’s no wonder that when I saw Francis Ford Coppola’s film, I was more than ready for James Caan.

headline: Columbia Loses Its No. 2 Spot in the U.S. News Rankings
abstract: U.S. News & World Report announced that it had “unranked” the Ivy League university after being unable to verify its data.
lead_paragraph: What is the equivalent of “disbarred” or “defrocked” in the world of college rankings?

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: What the Biden Administration Could Do Now to Protect Abortion Rights
abstract: The most urgent step the federal government can take is to ensure access to medication abortion.
lead_paragraph: Barely two weeks have passed since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, and already chaos reigns. Several states are moving to ban abortion almost completely, abortion-rights proponents are challenging those bans in court and in some cases, judges have been asked to issue injunctions that could, for a time, prevent the bans from going into effect.

headline: For Sunday’s Wimbledon Final, ‘Fireworks’ and a Contrast in Style
abstract: Despite their previously contentious relationship, Nick Kyrgios and Novak Djokovic have developed “a bit of a bromance,” Kyrgios said. They meet for the Wimbledon men’s singles title on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — With the Wimbledon title at stake, it will be the maximizer versus the man who seemingly makes it up as he goes along.

headline: Can Lisa Murkowski Fend Off Kelly Tshibaka in Alaska?
abstract: Supporters of the senator hope that the state’s unique nonpartisan primary system will help her, but allies of Tshibaka, a Trump-backed challenger, see a path to victory.
lead_paragraph: Paulette Schuerch, a Native Alaskan who helped Lisa Murkowski’s fabled write-in campaign for Senate in 2010, is now working for the senator’s Trump-backed opponent, Kelly Tshibaka.

headline: As Russia Looms, a Ukrainian City’s Loyalties Divide
abstract: Most residents have fled the eastern city of Sloviansk before an expected Russian assault. About half of the 23,000 remaining are eager to welcome the invaders.
lead_paragraph: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — A woman berated visiting reporters, accusing them of publishing lies. Others turned away, reluctant to talk. Tensions were running high in the central market of Sloviansk, after rocket strikes earlier this week killed seven people and destroyed shops and houses.

headline: Louisiana Judge Allows Abortion Ban to Take Effect
abstract: The fast-changing status in the state is emblematic of the chaotic national landscape that has unfolded in the two weeks since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Louisiana allowed state laws banning nearly all abortions to take effect on Friday, lifting an earlier court decision that had temporarily blocked them.

headline: At BroadwayCon, Hillary Clinton Celebrates Women in the Theater
abstract: The former secretary of state moderated a discussion on Friday afternoon about successes and barriers for women working in the theater.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a lot to worry about right now in our country and the world,” Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, told a packed room of about 500 people gathered at the grand ballroom at the Manhattan Center on Friday afternoon. “And I think we need theater and the arts more than ever.”

headline: Adams Shows Support for Man Charged in Bodega Killing That Caused Outcry
abstract: A deadly confrontation at a Harlem store feeds a broader debate about crime and politics.
lead_paragraph: The chaotic scene inside a Harlem bodega began with a bag of chips and a declined electronic card transaction. It ended in death.

headline: Susie Steiner, Author of Acclaimed British Crime Novels, Dies at 51
abstract: Her books found a worldwide audience, but while she wrote them she had to contend with the loss of her sight and the diagnosis of a brain tumor.
lead_paragraph: Susie Steiner, the author of the critically acclaimed Manon Bradshaw detective novels, who was declared legally blind from a rare disease months before she sold her first book, died on July 2 in London. She was 51.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Influence Was Still Evident Long After He Left Office
abstract: Japan’s longest-serving prime minister became perhaps the most transformational politician in the country’s post-World War II history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his record-breaking run as prime minister, Shinzo Abe never achieved his goal of revising Japan’s Constitution to transform his country into what the Japanese call a “normal nation,” able to employ its military to back up its national interests like any other.

headline: Denali National Park, in Alaska, reinstates an indoor mask mandate in the busy summer season.
abstract: As counties report elevated levels of transmission, national parks are once again requiring masks in gift shops, on tour buses and other indoor spaces.
lead_paragraph: With coronavirus cases increasing in its immediate vicinity in Alaska, the vast Denali National Park and Preserve reimposed a mask mandate on Friday for federal buildings and on park buses.

headline: Tony Sirico, an Eccentric Gangster on ‘The Sopranos,’ Dies at 79
abstract: A familiar face in Woody Allen movies, he became widely known for his portrayal of Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series.
lead_paragraph: Tony Sirico, the actor best known for playing the eccentric gangster Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series “The Sopranos,” died on Friday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Alice Elliott Dark on ‘Fellowship Point’
abstract: Dark talks about her new novel, and Katherine Chen discusses “Joan,” her fictional imagining of Joan of Arc.
lead_paragraph: In Alice Elliott Dark’s second novel, “Fellowship Point,” Agnes Lee and Polly Wister have been friends for about 80 years. Their intertwined families own homes on a Maine peninsula, and some of the book’s drama stems from their efforts to preserve the land and keep it out of the hands of developers.

headline: Illustrious
abstract: Kevin G. Der’s Saturday puzzle comes with very few lifeboats.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I think this is the hardest Saturday grid we have seen in some months, but it’s been years since Kevin G. Der’s last solo Saturday puzzle, published back in 2018. Note the quadruple stacks, technical feats of construction, in this grid’s northeast and southwest corners. Also note the torrent of debuts — 11 in a 66-word puzzle — as well as a big bunch of oddities.

headline: Just Months After the Last Floods, It’s the ‘Same Thing Again’
abstract: The toll of recurring disasters is starting to show among the residents of New South Wales, with many desperate for a break from overflowing rivers and wildfires.
lead_paragraph: “Every time it’s flooded it’s gotten higher and higher,” said April Harley, 38, a resident of Camden who has experienced four floods in the last four months. “It’s scary.”

headline: A shocking crime with many unanswered questions.
abstract: As Japan’s former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, spoke to the crowd in the city of Nara, a man in cargo pants and a grey shirt approached from behind, carrying a crude handmade gun. He shot Mr. Abe twice.
lead_paragraph: As Japan’s former prime minister, Shinzo Abe, spoke to the crowd in the city of Nara, a man in cargo pants and a grey shirt approached from behind, carrying a crude handmade gun. He shot Mr. Abe twice.

headline: Biden Administration Signals Support for Controversial Alaska Oil Project
abstract: The administration issued an environmental review that represents a key step toward starting the Willow project. Opponents say drilling would violate Biden’s pledge to rein in fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration took a key step toward approving a huge oil drilling project in the North Slope of Alaska, angering environmental activists who said allowing it to go forward would make a mockery of President Biden’s climate-change promise to end new oil leases.

headline: The assassination shocked a nearly gun-free Japan.
abstract: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.
lead_paragraph: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe during a campaign rally in western Japan was especially hard to fathom because it involved a gun — a type of crime that is extremely rare in a country with some of the most stringent laws on buying and owning firearms.

headline: Judge and Stanton Will Start for A.L. in All-Star Game
abstract: The Yankees sluggers will join Mike Trout of the Angels in the American League’s starting outfield.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees will have two-thirds of the American League’s starting outfield in this year’s All-Star Game, with Aaron Judge and Giancarlo Stanton taking the corner spots on either side of Mike Trout of the Los Angeles Angels.

headline: ‘It’s Like Parallel Realities’: Rituals of Life and Death Blur in a Vibrant Ukrainian City
abstract: In Lviv, babies are born in a hospital just steps away from the military cemetery where Ukraine’s young soldiers are laid to rest.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — The tiny wail of newborn babies echoes out from the incubators and cribs lining a small room with mint green walls in a maternity hospital in Lviv.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Single Moms Can’t Get Aid From Beijing
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If you really want to have a baby without a man you have to fight for it.”

headline: Corrections: July 9, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 9, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about areas of eastern Ukraine that Russia’s invasion has left largely devoid of people and industry misstated the location of the conference where Ukraine’s prime minister, Denys Shmyhal, described the cost of rebuilding his country. It was in Switzerland, not Italy.

headline: Questions Arise About Abe’s Security Protection After Assassination
abstract: Numerous videos show the gunman walking unobstructed past security before pointing a large handmade gun in the direction of the former prime minister.
lead_paragraph: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was gunned down in broad daylight, a stunned nation is questioning how the gunman was able to approach one of Japan’s most prominent politicians and fire two shots from close range without security stepping in.

headline: Aboard a ‘Hot Dog Bus’ in Hong Kong
abstract: “Hot dog buses,” nicknamed for their lack of air-conditioning, have not picked up passengers in Hong Kong for 10 years.  Join me for a ride on one.
lead_paragraph: “Hot dog buses,” nicknamed for their lack of air-conditioning, have not picked up passengers in Hong Kong for 10 years.  Join me for a ride on one.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Dressing Your Home for Success
abstract: Removing dark curtains or adding plants can attract more buyers to your property — and help you make more money off the sale, industry professionals say.
lead_paragraph: Even in today’s red-hot market, where buyers are fighting tooth and nail for a limited supply of homes, how a property looks — in listing photos and in person — is important. This is where staging comes in. “It doesn’t matter whether it’s a seller’s market or a buyer’s market,” says Monica P. Murphy, the owner of Preferred Staging, a home staging company in Potomac Falls, Va. “What staging does is it makes your home more presentable.”

headline: Companies’ Climate Promises Face a Wild Card: Farmers
abstract: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.
lead_paragraph: Driving rain pelted the windows of “the Tower,” a second-story glass enclosure in Ray Gaesser’s home that provides a view for miles of the gentle, rolling fields around Corning, Iowa. Inside, away from the elements, Mr. Gaesser pondered what the coming year might bring for farmers.

headline: With Sign Language and Sound, an Artist Upends Audience Perceptions
abstract: Christine Sun Kim’s poetic and political art pushes viewers to consider the limits, and misunderstandings, that come with communication in any language, whether spoken or signed.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, a small plane hauled a sign with an intriguing phrase over Manchester, England: “The Sound of Smiling.”

headline: The Postwar Japan That Shinzo Abe Built
abstract: After waging an often lonely fight, Abe died just as the Japanese people were possibly coming to appreciate his vision of a strong state.
lead_paragraph: In January 2007, only a few months after he was elected, at 52, as Japan’s youngest prime minister of the postwar era, Shinzo Abe delivered a speech outlining his policy priorities after the opening ceremony of the 166th session of Japan’s Diet, the country’s parliamentary body.

headline: Abe was a transformational figure in Japan.
abstract: In his record-breaking run as prime minister, Shinzo Abe never achieved his goal of revising Japan’s Constitution to transform his country into what the Japanese call a “normal nation,” able to employ its military to back up its national interests like any other.
lead_paragraph: In his record-breaking run as prime minister, Shinzo Abe never achieved his goal of revising Japan’s Constitution to transform his country into what the Japanese call a “normal nation,” able to employ its military to back up its national interests like any other.

headline: The president has agreed to resign, the speaker of Parliament says.
abstract: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, whose family has dominated politics in Sri Lanka for much of the past two decades, has agreed to resign after months of protests accusing him of running the island nation’s economy into the ground through corruption and mismanagement, the speaker of the country’s parliament said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, whose family has dominated politics in Sri Lanka for much of the past two decades, has agreed to resign after months of protests accusing him of running the island nation’s economy into the ground through corruption and mismanagement, the speaker of the country’s parliament said on Saturday.

headline: An American arrested in Russia last year was sentenced by the court handling Brittney Griner’s case.
abstract: Marc Fogel, a teacher and former U.S. Embassy staff member, was convicted on charges of drug smuggling in Russia. He was sentenced to 14 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: With the spotlight on the case of Brittney Griner, the American basketball star who has been detained in Russia since February, the sentencing of a former U.S. Embassy worker in Russia last month on similar drug charges has his loved ones also pleading for him to be allowed to return home.

headline: Valentino’s Roman Marvels
abstract: Expanding the meaning of couture, one ruffle and feather at a time.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The couture shows came to an end not in Paris but in Rome, with a river of gold ballroom chairs connecting the Piazza di Spagna at the foot of the Spanish Steps — the most famous people-watching and -posing staircase in Europe — to Piazza Mignanelli, where the Valentino headquarters stand.

headline: How Do I Prevent My Newspaper Deliveries From Being Stolen?
abstract: Without the cooperation of building management, a delivery person has no option but to dump papers in a spot where anyone can grab them.
lead_paragraph: Q: When I moved into my rent-stabilized apartment in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, three years ago, my daily newspaper was delivered to my door. The building owner has since died, and his son, who inherited the property, has refused to allow the newspaper delivery person to enter the building, so the papers are now dumped in the outer lobby. If I don’t pick mine up at 6:30 every morning, it’s often filched. What recourse do I have?

headline: 13 Guns Used in Harlem Shootout, Police Say, Underscoring Deadly Threat
abstract: The tally shows how ubiquitous firearms, many illegal, are in New York, with more legal ones anticipated after a recent Supreme Court ruling.
lead_paragraph: Darius Lee, 21, a native son of Harlem and a basketball star at Houston Baptist University, was in a large group of revelers on a Sunday night last month, enjoying a beautiful Father’s Day weekend at a barbecue, when he was killed in a flurry of gunfire.

headline: A Viral Essay Grows into a Hearty, Viable Collection
abstract: In “The Crane Wife,” CJ Hauser delves into issues of identity and connection with humor and grace.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, CJ Hauser’s essay “The Crane Wife” went viral, garnering more than a million views on The Paris Review’s website. Personally, I accounted for at least three of those views, as I read, reread aloud (exclaiming, “God, she’s good!” at the end), and then emailed several friends to demand they also read Hauser’s story about breaking off a wedding engagement, leaving the home she shared with her fiancé in upstate New York and going to Texas to research whooping cranes for her second novel. Still, when I found out Hauser had built a whole essay collection around that piece, I thought, Oh no.

headline: It Hides Under the Soil With a Bottomless Appetite for Meat
abstract: Among the numerous carnivorous pitcher plant species, scientists say this is the first that lays its traps underground.
lead_paragraph: A newly discovered pitcher plant keeps its hunger for insects on the down low: It’s the first such plant known to grow working traps underground.

headline: Ukraine and the Contest of Global Stamina
abstract: The conflict’s long-run trajectory seems increasingly likely to be shaped by whether the United States and its allies can maintain their military, political and financial commitments to holding off Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Another day, another weapons shipment: On Friday, the Pentagon announced a new transfer of precision-guided shells and multiple rocket launchers to Ukraine, the latest armaments heading east. But will there come a day when that system begins to slow?

headline: When the Results of a DNA Test Change the Family Tree
abstract: In their memoirs, Carmen Rita Wong and Chrysta Bilton open up about how they learned of secrets, lies and unkept promises.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, a friend of mine sent a vial of his saliva to a DNA testing company hoping to gain clues about his late father’s Italian ancestry. The results were a shock. He had no Italian blood at all. The man who’d raised him from infancy, and whose name he carried, was not his biological father. After weeks of checking his results against those of cousins with whom he shared no DNA, he mustered the courage to ask his nonagenarian mother about the findings. “So I had an affair!” she said. “Whoever thought there’d be 23andMe, for chrissakes.”

headline: Where Is Pete Panto?
abstract: A union leader on the Brooklyn docks disappeared 81 years ago, presumably murdered by the mob.
lead_paragraph: On a dreary day in the autumn of 2020, Joseph Sciorra took a walk through St. Charles Cemetery on Long Island. Dr. Sciorra, like many trapped inside during the pandemic, had added cemetery strolls to his list of safe activities. But at St. Charles, he was on a mission. He was looking for the grave of a man named Pete Panto.

headline: Amid the Summer Flying ‘Meltdown,’ Add Lost Luggage
abstract: Surging air travel demand and airport staffing shortages have made this a bedeviling season when it comes to missing luggage. Here’s what to know if your bag doesn’t arrive when you do.
lead_paragraph: The Apple AirTag tracking device that Lily Datta had placed in her luggage before leaving Cleveland on June 27 showed the suitcase had arrived in Paris the following day. That perplexed Ms. Datta because she and her family had no plans to go to Paris. Their destination was Vienna, with stops in Washington, D.C., and Barcelona to get there, but not Paris. It was the family’s first foray abroad since the start of the pandemic, a trip to celebrate her son Dev’s high school graduation.

headline: Boris Johnson May Be Fading Out, but Not the Divisions He Stoked
abstract: Long after he is gone, his successors will be wrestling over his signature project, Brexit, and the insoluble issues it raised.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The swift, stinging downfall of Boris Johnson this past week removes a uniquely polarizing figure from British politics. But it does not remove the divisive issues that Mr. Johnson confronted — and in many cases, exploited — as he engineered Britain’s departure from the European Union two and a half years ago.

headline: The Age of Distracti-pression
abstract: The pandemic’s true toll on mental health won’t be known for a long time, but data from the past two years indicates a rise — some of it sharp — in prescription drugs for conditions like A.D.H.D. and depression.
lead_paragraph: If you’re wondering which pills and how many of them Americans have relied upon to make ourselves feel better since Covid-19 arrived, the answer, in short, is yes.

headline: Does Abe Shooting Reflect Success of Japan’s Gun Laws, Not Failure?
abstract: A crude weapon. Minimal security. One death. A closer look at the details of the assassination of Shinzo Abe may actually underscore the effectiveness of Japan’s restrictions.
lead_paragraph: The assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Japan may look like a rebuke of the country’s famously stringent gun laws.

headline: Finding My Joy at Essence Festival
abstract: I relished the community I had been missing on my first trip to the famous New Orleans gathering.
lead_paragraph: The first five notes of “Swag Surfin’” rang out in the cavernous New Orleans Ernest N. Morial Convention Center — a rallying call for a swarm of people to a makeshift dance floor. Doing what one naturally does when the F.L.Y. (Fast Life Yungstaz) 2009 hit comes on, I locked damp arms with a stranger on either side of me — and they with those beside them. Entranced, we swayed in slow, hypnotic harmony until the beat finally crashed down, our cue to rock our beautiful Black bodies back and forth and ride the booming bass as one.

headline: The Nice-Guy Lawyer for America’s Tabloid Villains
abstract: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.
lead_paragraph: Even when there are few cameras around, Arthur L. Aidala, 54, is camera-ready, dressed in a light-blue pinstripe suit with a purple pocket square and tie on a sunny June day. He’s a lawyer who welcomes press attention, but on this particular day he was worried about the way it can make a difficult job harder.

headline: Blinken presses his Chinese counterpart about the war.
abstract: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday, pressing him to “stand up” against Russia’s war in Ukraine while also extending a hand of cooperation amid a Biden administration campaign to stabilize its strained relationship with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday, pressing him to “stand up” against Russia’s war in Ukraine while also extending a hand of cooperation amid a Biden administration campaign to stabilize its strained relationship with Beijing.
