headline: Canada’s Slow and Troubled Path to Rapid Transit
abstract: Partnerships with the private sector were supposed to protect cities from cost overruns and delays. That hasn’t always worked out.
lead_paragraph: Canada is on a mass transit building spree. But to say that things are not going according to plan would be an understatement.

headline: ‘The Sinker Is Going to Be My Ticket’
abstract: Clay Holmes knew what made him special as a pitcher. It took some time — and a trade to the Yankees — for that vision to become reality.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Clay Holmes threw a sinker from the first time he ever played catch. He was seven years old, he guessed, and his fingers felt comfortable along the seams, not across them. In time, the two-seam grip would give his pitches downward, tailing action, and give him a professional career — if only he could keep it.

headline: Summer Travel, Made Easy
abstract: You need not travel far to experience the delights of summer.
lead_paragraph: A friend texted me last weekend from a departure lounge in Kennedy Airport. “Um three hours and counting …” she wrote of her L.A.-bound flight’s delay.

headline: The president is defying calls to step down, despite mounting public pressure.
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has defied intensifying calls for his departure, even as public pressure over the past five months has forced several members of his family, including his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was the prime minister, to resign.
lead_paragraph: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has defied intensifying calls for his departure, even as public pressure over the past five months has forced several members of his family, including his brother Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was the prime minister, to resign.

headline: The suspect will be handed over to prosecutors on Sunday, the Nara police say.
abstract: Tetsuya Yamagami, 41, is accused of killing Shinzo Abe, Japan’s former prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Tetsuya Yamagami, the suspect in the assassination of Japan’s former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will be detained and questioned by the police in the city of Nara for another night, then transferred to the custody of the local prosecutors’ office, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Invisibility, a Hippo and Antiques
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Hello, readers,

headline: Reconstructing the Bronx Apartment Fire
abstract: Reporters, graphics editors and engineering experts collaborated to map how a fire in a Bronx high-rise killed 17 residents in January.
lead_paragraph: Anjali Singhvi said her heart sank when she saw a resident’s video of the stairwells at Twin Parks North West, the Bronx apartment building that in January became the site of one of the city’s deadliest blazes, leading to the deaths of 17 residents.

headline: The New New Haven
abstract: Unexpectedly, the Connecticut city has emerged, both because of and despite its association with Yale, as an affordable and dynamic home for artists of all kinds.
lead_paragraph: On a recent evening in the New Haven, Conn., Dixwell neighborhood, artists, students, academics and locals gathered in a large, state-of-the-art event space for a conversation with the photographer Dawoud Bey, 69, who is known for chronicling unseen facets of the Black experience in America. Using thoughtful, precise words, Bey — who has a rare command of language — described the ways in which a long tradition of Black cultural production informs his work.

headline: Blinken Presses China’s Top Diplomat on Ukraine but Stresses Cooperation
abstract: At a G20 meeting, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken sought to cool tensions with Beijing in an effort to further isolate Russia. He met resistance.
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — The battle in Ukraine shifted to a geopolitical front on Saturday, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with the Chinese foreign minister at the end of a global summit in Indonesia, pressing his counterpart to join the United States  and “stand up” against Russia’s war.

headline: Behind Russia’s ‘pause’ are signs of a troubled effort to regroup.
abstract: The weapons and personnel Russia may be turning to, analysts say, suggest that Moscow’s next assault may not be as fierce as it promised.
lead_paragraph: With Russian forces in the middle of a purported “operational pause,” some Ukrainians in the country’s battered eastern frontline regions are questioning what that means at a time when their towns are still coming under continued shelling.

headline: The Supreme Court Dealt a Terrible Blow to Children’s Health
abstract: We are now learning that climate change and air pollution can act together to increase health effects.
lead_paragraph: Climate change and air pollution — both largely driven by fossil fuel emissions — inflict a huge toll on the health of children. This is especially true within low-income communities and communities of color. The recent Supreme Court decision West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency, which curtails the E.P.A.’s power to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from power plants, will greatly exacerbate this harm.

headline: A Memory That Moves: A Decrepit Hong Kong Double-Decker Bus Gets New Life
abstract: When the pandemic cut their flight hours, two pilots spent months and hundreds of thousands of dollars reviving a vehicle that reminded them of a happier time in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Pedestrians stopped in their tracks and stared. Passengers in vehicles craned their necks and waved. Schoolboys in uniform ran like paparazzi angling for the perfect shot. They were all riveted by a cream-colored double-decker bus with ketchup-red trims on the top and bottom swerving last month into an open-air terminal.

headline: How Mexico’s Top Justice, Raised Catholic, Became an Abortion Rights Champion
abstract: Influenced by feminists close to him, the chief of the country’s Supreme Court helped pave the way for decriminalization of the procedure.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — When the chief justice of Mexico’s Supreme Court began voting in favor of abortion rights, his toughest opponents were the people closest to him.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 4, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: When a Professor Trades the Academy for an Art Career of His Own
abstract: For Thomas Woodruff, retirement from teaching offered the very thing he’d been trying to instill in his students: artistic freedom.
lead_paragraph: When New York City went into lockdown in the spring of 2020, Thomas Woodruff started sketching dinosaurs. Not as a child might doodle a T. rex, but as an artist drawing a self-portrait. At 62, he was 20 years into his career as the head of the illustration and cartooning departments at the School of Visual Arts, and he’d begun to worry that he and his students came from different eras. One class failed to recognize Picasso’s “Guernica” but could name Forky, the Picasso-inspired spork character in Toy Story 4. “It doesn’t count anymore if you’re a gay man of a certain age who went through the AIDS crisis,” he says from the same drafting table in his studio, a repurposed barn in Germantown, N.Y., where for more than a year he taught via Zoom. “It’s something that’s just kind of like, ‘Well, you’re a dinosaur.’”

headline: ‘I Felt Trapped’: Sexual Abuse of Teens in the Military’s J.R.O.T.C. Program
abstract: Former students say military veterans who led J.R.O.T.C. classes in U.S. high schools fashioned themselves as mentors, then used their power to manipulate and abuse.
lead_paragraph: PICAYUNE, Miss. — With the rifle skills she honed in the Mississippi backwoods, Victoria Bauer had a path to escape the trap of drugs and dead-end jobs she saw most everywhere around her. Her future was in the Marines, she decided, and she had an idea about how to get there.

headline: Don’t Toss Those Old Sneakers
abstract: After making a name for itself with $500 handmade sneakers, Golden Goose is turning its focus to repairs: “Someone who feels taken care of will always return,” its C.E.O. said.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: Mourning After a Holiday Shooting
abstract: Highland Park residents are mourning and responding after a Fourth of July mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: Highland Park residents are mourning and responding after a Fourth of July mass shooting.

headline: Bill J. Allen, Alaska Businessman at the Center of Scandal, Dies at 85
abstract: He was one of the state’s most powerful figures, but his extensive corruption schemes brought him down — and took several politicians with him.
lead_paragraph: Bill J. Allen, an itinerant pipe fitter who rose to be one of the most powerful men in Alaska and a dominant figure in the state’s oil industry, then fell from grace in a spectacular bribery and corruption scheme that also took down a U.S. senator, died on June 29. He was 85.

headline: Florida Man Sentenced to 20 Years for Uploading Bomb-Making Video
abstract: Federal prosecutors said the man, Romeo Xavier Langhorne, 32, had pledged support to ISIS and uploaded a video he hoped would help the group make and use bombs.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who had pledged support to ISIS was sentenced on Thursday to 20 years in prison for uploading a video he believed would help the terrorist group make bombs, the federal authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Campaigns make their final push in Japan, undeterred by Abe’s assassination.
abstract: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, was shot while campaigning for a candidate for the Upper House of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Candidates for parliamentary election in Japan on Saturday rushed from rally to rally, hoping to appeal to voters during the final hours of the campaign period, just a day after the assassination of Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, sparked fears the campaign would be disrupted.

headline: Are ‘Women’ Being Erased?
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul that objected to a war on women from both the far right and far left.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, Former President of Mexico, Dies at 100
abstract: He had faced accusations that, as interior secretary, he was responsible for repressing protests before the 1968 Olympics that ended in a massacre.
lead_paragraph: Luis Echeverría Alvarez, who steered Mexico on a stormy left-wing course in the 1970s as president and who never escaped the shadow of a massacre before the 1968 Olympics, died on Friday at his home in Cuernavaca. He was 100.

headline: The Last Days of Suburban Office Parks
abstract: With remote work and new norms, a concept that arose in postwar America is dying off. Emily Badger, who reported on the trend for The Upshot, shares more.
lead_paragraph: The scene is familiar to anyone who has watched “The Office” or worked a 9-to-5 in the last 50 years. Cubicles. Poor lighting. And, out the window, a view of a parking lot and sprawling green grass. This is the image of the classic suburban office building, whose popularity rose in postwar America.

headline: After a Brutal Assassination, Japan Mourns and Carries On
abstract: A day after former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s killing, Japan, where gun violence of any kind is rare, was just beginning to process the shock.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A day after the assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a political rally, the police in Japan faced sharp questions about the adequacy of his security, even as parliamentary candidates resumed campaigning on Saturday in a sign that despite the tragedy, political life was carrying on.

headline: Where My Research Has Taken Me Lately
abstract: What I’m reading, what I’m thinking.
lead_paragraph: Instead of an extended take on a particular issue or question, I thought I would use this weekend’s newsletter to share some of what I’ve been reading this summer. My job for The Times involves a lot of research, and while some of what I learn shows up in my work in the form of quotes and other direct references, a lot of it doesn’t. You can think of this reading list as a glimpse into where my head is at right now, and what I am thinking.

headline: Elena Rybakina Wins Wimbledon and Her First Grand Slam Title
abstract: Rybakina, who was born and raised in Russia, started representing Kazakhstan after the Russian tennis federation gave up on her. She beat Ons Jabeur in three sets to win the women’s singles title.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — There was no way anyone could have known four years ago, when the Russian-born-and-raised Elena Rybakina decided to play tennis for Kazakhstan that the move would pay off as fortuitously as it did in the summer of 2022.

headline: U.C.L.A. and U.S.C., Welcome to the Big Ten. I Already Hate You.
abstract: It will be weird with these California schools in my conference, but I welcome the new rivalries.
lead_paragraph: My favorite college football team is the Michigan Wolverines, which makes the Big Ten my favorite conference. The oldest Division 1 athletic conference in the country, the association that would eventually be called the Big Ten was originally composed of Midwestern universities like Michigan (where, as regular readers know, I went), the University of Illinois and the University of Wisconsin, before adding Penn State in 1990 to make the Big Ten a conference of 11.

headline: The End of Roe Doesn’t Need to Bring an Increase in Maternal Mortality
abstract: Many of Europe’s abortion laws are stricter than many Americans may realize, but maternal health outcomes in Europe are much better.
lead_paragraph: It has been argued repeatedly that without access to abortion, the health of women will suffer and women will die. This fear is expressed overtly by the three dissenting justices in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the decision that overturned Roe v. Wade last month. They cite experts who say that “a ban on abortions increases maternal mortality by 21 percent.”

headline: Why Does It Take Federal Intervention to Fix the N.Y.P.D.?
abstract: The work of holding law enforcement agencies accountable is arduous but vital.
lead_paragraph: The saga of the Special Victims Division is the latest illustration of the extraordinary measures required to meaningfully reform the nation’s largest police department.

headline: Fears of Another Gas Shock Drive Biden to Seek Price Cap on Russian Oil
abstract: Negotiating and selling the plan is a crucial task facing Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen as she travels to Asia in hopes of averting $7 a gallon gasoline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Relief at the gas pump coupled with this past week’s news that businesses continue to hire at a blistering clip have tempered many economists’ fears that America is heading into a downturn.

headline: America Can’t Allow China to Keep Crushing Our Solar Energy Industry
abstract: The Biden administration is taking a gamble that furthers our reliance on China without providing the essential elements to build our domestic solar industry.
lead_paragraph: A robust solar energy industry in the United States is crucial to the nation’s goal of a low-carbon future. But the prospects for solar energy are not looking bright these days, because the United States has allowed China to dominate the industry. Failure to create a strong domestic solar manufacturing industry leaves the United States and our carbon-reduction goals not just dependent on China, but also vulnerable should China block or threaten to block its solar exports as a form of retaliation in the future.

headline: Hank Goldberg, Betting Maven and Sports Radio Star, Dies at 82
abstract: A New Jersey fan of sports and gambling who became one of the country’s top television handicappers: What are the odds?
lead_paragraph: Hank Goldberg, a prickly, bombastic and witty sports talk radio and television personality in Miami who became nationally known for handicapping horse races and N.F.L. games on ESPN, died on Monday, his 82nd birthday, at his home in Las Vegas.

headline: What Are Spam Bots and Why They’re an Issue in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal
abstract: Bots can tweet at people, share tweets, follow and be followed by other people. And there are good bots and bad.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the tech billionaire Elon Musk announced that he was terminating a $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. The reason, he said, was an ongoing disagreement over the number of spam bot accounts on the platform. Now, the issue of what constitutes a spam bot account, and how many currently exist on Twitter, is likely to be at the heart of the legal battles between Mr. Musk and Twitter over the fraught deal.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Leader Will Resign, Ally Says, After Protesters Storm Residence
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa will step down on Wednesday, according to the speaker of Parliament, amid fury over the economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage for the latest on Sri Lanka’s political crisis.

headline: The Rajapaksa family has dominated Sri Lankan politics.
abstract: The Rajapaksas have cast a shadow over politics in Sri Lanka for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, they have increasingly run the government as a family business.
lead_paragraph: The Rajapaksa family has dominated Sri Lanka’s politics for much of the past two decades, and in recent years, it has increasingly run the island nation’s government as a family business.

headline: Jake Paul Is Aiming for Boxing Legitimacy, and Collecting Seashells
abstract: The social media star is preparing to fight his first opponent with professional boxing experience: Hasim Rahman Jr., who is 12-1. “I’ve been waiting to take his head off,” Paul said in an interview.
lead_paragraph: Jake Paul will get a chance next month to prove he’s not a boxing dilettante.

headline: Liz Cheney’s Latest Fans: Democratic Donors
abstract: Despite policy disagreements, donors like Jeffrey Katzenberg are backing the Wyoming Republican because of her role on the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As one of the nation’s biggest Democratic donors, the film producer Jeffrey Katzenberg helped make Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton into Hollywood darlings. But this year, he is backing a surprise candidate: Representative Liz Cheney, the staunchly conservative Wyoming Republican.

headline: Sri Lanka’s prime minister is no stranger to political shifts.
abstract: Ranil Wickremesinghe, who had been in office only since May, said he would resign.
lead_paragraph: One of the political casualties in Sri Lanka on Saturday was Ranil Wickremesinghe, a prime minister six times over whose leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.

headline: Protesters in Sri Lanka Storm Presidential Residence
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to step down after what appeared to be one of the largest protests yet, following months of demonstrations fueled by the nation’s economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka agreed to step down after what appeared to be one of the largest protests yet, following months of demonstrations fueled by the nation’s economic crisis.

headline: Ukraine dismisses its ambassador to Germany after controversial remarks.
abstract: Andriy Melnyk, an outspoken advocate for weapons for Ukraine, denied the role of a Ukrainian nationalist leader in the Holocaust, stoking outrage in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, fired his ambassador to Germany, a week after the diplomat gave an interview in which he defended the legacy of a World War II nationalist leader who collaborated with the Nazis.

headline: 50 million Americans remain under a heat advisory this weekend.
abstract: The dangerous heat wave shows no signs of letting up as it affects states including Texas, Arizona, Alabama and Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans will still be under a sweltering heat wave the rest of this weekend and into much of next week that the National Weather Service described as “oppressive” and “dangerous.” About 50 million people in the nation are under heat warnings or advisories, Frank Pereira, a meteorologist with the Weather Service said in an interview on Saturday.

headline: With a Wimbledon Title, Elena Rybakina Finally Cracks a Smile
abstract: Rybakina’s victory at Wimbledon was deeply impressive but not the outcome that most in Centre Court or on the payrolls of the All England Club were yearning for.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Elena Rybakina’s surprise run to the Wimbledon title — full of overwhelming serves, timely winners and underrated defense — was a thing of cruel beauty.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Questions Cipollone on Pardons and Trump’s Election Claims
abstract: Pat A. Cipollone, the former White House counsel for President Donald J. Trump, appeared before the House committee investigating the Capitol attack for roughly eight hours on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pat A. Cipollone, who served as White House counsel for President Donald J. Trump, was asked detailed questions on Friday about pardons, false election fraud claims and the former president’s pressure campaign against Vice President Mike Pence, according to three people familiar with his testimony before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.

headline: What’s Next in the Elon Musk-Twitter Saga? A Court Battle
abstract: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.
lead_paragraph: Now that Elon Musk has signaled his intent to walk away from his $44 billion offer to buy Twitter, the fate of the influential social media network will be determined by what may be an epic court battle, involving months of expensive litigation and high-stakes negotiations by elite lawyers on both sides.

headline: More Than 1,000 Protesters at White House Call on Biden to Protect Abortion Rights
abstract: The rally on Saturday, in which some demonstrators risked arrest, reflected activists’ growing frustration with the administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day after President Biden issued an executive order designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, more than a thousand protesters gathered in front of the White House, with hundreds risking arrest by sitting at the building’s gates, to urge Mr. Biden to do more.

headline: Mike Brito, Influential Dodger Scout in Mexico, Dies at 87
abstract: He opened the door to the major leagues for many Mexican players, most notably Fernando Valenzuela, who won the 1981 Rookie of the Year and Cy Young Awards.
lead_paragraph: Mike Brito, an influential Cuban-born Los Angeles Dodgers scout who in Mexico discovered the pitcher Fernando Valenzuela, whose sensational 1981 season uncorked the delirious fan reaction known as “Fernandomania,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Arizona Law Bans People From Recording Police Within Eight Feet
abstract: Civil rights and news media organizations have objected to the law, which is set to go into effect in September, as a violation of free speech protections.
lead_paragraph: The governor of Arizona has signed a measure into law that makes it illegal for people to record videos within eight feet of police activity, limiting efforts to increase transparency around law enforcement operations.

headline: Blinken presses his Chinese counterpart about the war.
abstract: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — The battle in Ukraine shifted to a geopolitical front on Saturday, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with the Chinese foreign minister at the end of a Group of 20 summit in Indonesia, pressing him to change positions and join the United States and partners to “stand up” against Russia’s war, while also trying to ease overall tensions with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: NUSA DUA, Indonesia — The battle in Ukraine shifted to a geopolitical front on Saturday, as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with the Chinese foreign minister at the end of a Group of 20 summit in Indonesia, pressing him to change positions and join the United States and partners to “stand up” against Russia’s war, while also trying to ease overall tensions with Beijing.

headline: Sri Lanka’s economy is grinding to a halt without fuel.
abstract: Acute shortages have meant that medicines can’t be transported and fresh produce from farms can’t make it to cities.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest reasons Sri Lankan residents took to the streets on Saturday is the country’s desperate need for fuel and other energy supplies. The South Asian nation has run out of foreign currency to pay for fuel, bringing its economy grinding to a halt.

headline: At 79, Biden Is Testing the Boundaries of Age and the Presidency
abstract: President Biden has said he plans to run for a second term, but his age has become an uncomfortable issue for him and his party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Biden leaves Tuesday night for a four-day swing through the Middle East, he will presumably be more rested than he would have been had he followed the original plan.

headline: Movin’ On Up
abstract: Christina Iverson brings Scott Hogan into the big leagues with a collaborative puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Let this puzzle encourage anyone who’s had a crossword submission (or two, or four) rejected, or anyone who’s sitting on a great theme or clue set but needs a partner in crime to make a puzzle happen. Scott Hogan, a patent lawyer from Midland, Mich., went through the editorial wringer before connecting with Christina Iverson, a beloved Sunday puzzle fixture, via the Cruciverb Facebook group. This grid is the result. It’s a hoot, and there are more forthcoming from this pair.

headline: 15-Year-Old Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of 14-Year-Old in Subway
abstract: The teenager who died appeared to have known his attacker, officials said. A dispute between them in the street spilled into the subway.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old boy was arrested on Sunday and charged with murder in the stabbing death of a 14-year-old boy in a subway station in Harlem, the police said.

headline: Djokovic vs. Kyrgios: How to Watch the Wimbledon Men’s Singles Final
abstract: Djokovic, a six-time Wimbledon champion, plays Nick Kyrgios, who is appearing in his first Grand Slam singles final.
lead_paragraph: Novak Djokovic Defeats Nick Kyrgios to Capture the Wimbledon Title. Read the latest here.

headline: Desperate for Recruits, Russia Launches a ‘Stealth Mobilization’
abstract: Leery of a national draft for the Ukraine war, the Kremlin is offering cash bonuses and employing strong arm tactics.
lead_paragraph: Four Russian veterans of the war in Ukraine recently published short videos online to complain about what they called their shabby treatment after returning to the Russian region of Chechnya, after six weeks on the battlefield.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ukraine War Now a Battle of Endurance
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I worry about the fatigue factor of the public in a wide range of countries because of the economic costs and because there are other pressing concerns.”

headline: Corrections: July 10, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 10, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 this weekend about the new host of NPR’s “Code Switch” misidentifies the platform that hosts “This American Life.” It is delivered to stations by Public Radio Exchange, not NPR.

headline: As they took over the president’s house, Sri Lankan protesters stopped to savor its luxuries.
abstract: Images from Colombo showed demonstrators enjoying a rare moment of levity, after months of economic deprivation.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage for the latest on Sri Lanka’s political crisis.

headline: The president has not been heard from since protesters overran his residence, fueling questions about who is in charge.
abstract: The uncertainty about who is leading Sri Lanka deepened on Sunday, as protesters occupied the halls of the presidential residence and office and President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had not yet addressed reports that he plans to resign later this week.
lead_paragraph: The uncertainty about who is leading Sri Lanka deepened on Sunday, as protesters occupied the halls of the presidential residence and office and President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had not yet addressed reports that he plans to resign later this week.

headline: Sri Lanka needs billions of dollars as it exhausts its sources of financing.
abstract: Funds provided by India are already gone. China has kept its distance. As the crisis deepens, Sri Lanka has even turned to charities in Qatar for help.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka needs $6 billion through the end of the year to buy fuel and other essential goods to stabilize its crumbling economy.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘As the Vehicle Approached, I Stood My Ground and Waved for It to Halt’
abstract: A seaside routine nearly interrupted, a pizza lesson in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: In N.Y.C. Apartments, the Ants Go Marching Up
abstract: Like many ambitious New Yorkers, the ManhattAnt is a social climber.
lead_paragraph: When Katie Guhl traveled at the end of May — to a wedding in New Orleans and a Memorial Day gathering in New Jersey — she left her apartment on East 81st street spotless. So when she returned home to find swarms of ants in her kitchen, she was livid.

headline: One Small Step for Democracy in a ‘Live Free or Die’ Town
abstract: A cautionary tale from Croydon, N.H., where one man tried to foist a change so drastic it jolted a community out of political indifference.
lead_paragraph: CROYDON, N.H. — The tiny New Hampshire town of Croydon fits the New England of the imagination, with its cozy general store, one-room schoolhouse and local museum open by appointment. The only thing missing is supposed to be missing: a stoplight.

headline: In the capital of Sri Lanka, high spirits and curiosity from the protesters.
abstract: Hours after protesters took control the building, it has effectively become a free museum. People stream in and admire the art as Army guards quietly patrol the halls.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Hundreds of people walk around a makeshift protest camp erected outside the presidential mansion, the morning after it was stormed by largely peaceful protesters.

headline: The Many Grievances of the Broke, Tech-Averse Liberal
abstract: It’s a hard world out there for the protagonist of Teddy Wayne’s novel “The Great Man Theory.”
lead_paragraph: Paul, the protagonist of Teddy Wayne’s new novel, “The Great Man Theory,” is an aggrieved Everyman who finds contemporary life unsatisfying. He eschews screens and seeks to preserve his capacity for deep, sustained thought about the things that matter to him — the environment, politics, history and the fight against the tyranny of the ready-made that orders so much of life today. Put another way, he’s the kind of annoying man you sometimes encounter out in the world: overserious, tiresomely enraged and boring at parties.

headline: I Was Betrayed by President Trump
abstract: My career as a Capitol policeman was cut short when I was beaten on Jan. 6 trying to defend our democracy.
lead_paragraph: As one of the Capitol Police officers who defended the United States against the mob on Jan. 6, 2021, I felt it was important for me to be in the committee room on June 28 to hear the former White House aide Cassidy Hutchinson’s testimony. Along with three colleagues, I went, even though I knew it would be difficult to relive the horrors I witnessed. Although I experienced the brutal onslaught of the insurrectionists, I was shocked to hear Ms. Hutchinson explain the extent to which President Donald Trump incited the people who almost killed me.

headline: Inside a Uvalde Classroom: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
abstract: A teacher who survived the mass shooting recounts the harrowing attack and desperate wait for a rescue.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — The first shots came from the hallway outside the classroom. Arnulfo Reyes, a fourth-grade teacher at Robb Elementary School, quickly remembered the active shooter training he had rehearsed so many times and told his 11 students to lie under their desks and “act like you are asleep.”

headline: Despite Repeated Fumbles, Georgia Republicans Say They’re Sticking With Walker
abstract: Republicans are standing behind Herschel Walker, the former football star, despite an array of revelations, missteps and questions about his qualifications for a Senate seat.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Georgia Republicans knew for months before Herschel Walker launched his Senate campaign that he would be a huge risk in one of the party’s most pivotal races. Just how much of a risk has become clear to many of them in recent weeks.

headline: After Another Mass Shooting, Questions Loom About the Role of Parents
abstract: Mothers and fathers of young men accused in shootings, including the 21-year-old charged in the massacre in Highland Park, Ill., have faced scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill. — Days after a gunman opened fire at a Fourth of July parade here, Alberto Fuentes arrived at a downtown memorial for the victims, asking himself a question now haunting many in this shattered Chicago suburb: Could the 21-year-old suspect’s parents have prevented any of this?

headline: Airline Pilots Seek Big Raises, and Broader Changes
abstract: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.
lead_paragraph: Staffing shortages, bad weather, high fuel prices and runaway inflation — airlines face plenty of challenges as they seek to benefit from a strong travel rebound. But there’s at least one other complication in the mix: negotiating new pilot contracts.

headline: In Rust Belt Ohio, the First American Rape Case to Go Viral
abstract: In “Roll Red Roll,” Nancy Schwartzman revisits a teenage girl’s 2012 assault by high school football players, and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: It’s the grim ordinariness of the Steubenville rape case — an August 2012 incident involving an unconscious teenage girl, members of a revered high school football team and the small town that protected the perpetrators — that shines through most brightly in Nancy Schwartzman’s “Roll Red Roll.” A meticulous account of the “first rape case ever to go viral in the United States,” the book moves from the facts of one summer night in Rust Belt Ohio into a broader reckoning with American masculinity and the emerging influence of the internet on sexual assault cases. Schwartzman clearly conveys the brutal banality of what happened in that town, the way rape culture, victim blaming and institutional complicity are the rule rather than the exception in American communities. Steubenville could be anywhere.

headline: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
abstract: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
lead_paragraph: To fight disinformation, California lawmakers are advancing a bill that would force social media companies to divulge their process for removing false, hateful or extremist material from their platforms. Texas lawmakers, by contrast, want to ban the largest of the companies — Facebook, Twitter and YouTube — from removing posts because of political points of view.

headline: Some Surprising Good News: Bookstores Are Booming and Becoming More Diverse
abstract: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”
lead_paragraph: People told Lucy Yu it was a crazy time to open a bookstore in Chinatown. It was early 2021, and the pandemic had devastated the neighborhood, forcing dozens of stores and restaurants to close. The rise of anti-Asian hate crimes had shaken residents and local business owners.

headline: Homes That Sold for $550,000 or Less
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Tennis Is Done With Covid-19, but the Virus Isn’t Done With Tennis
abstract: With testing, quarantine and isolation requirements all but gone, tennis finally seems to have entered a stage of pandemic apathy, much like a lot of society.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — With the final match looming, this year’s edition of Wimbledon has already proven many points.

headline: Show and Tell
abstract: Couture shows spilled out onto the streets of Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — What must the early July tourists think of the crowd that descends on this city for the haute couture shows?

headline: What We Know About the Shinzo Abe Assassination
abstract: The police in Nara, Japan, say a 41-year-old man was responsible for the fatal shooting of the former prime minister, but have given few details about the suspect.
lead_paragraph: Shinzo Abe, the former prime minister of Japan who held the office longer than anyone else, was fatally shot on Friday while giving a speech for a political candidate in the city of Nara.

headline: What a Reckoning at the Supreme Court Could Look Like
abstract: Biden’s Supreme Court commission report offers a thorough and at times exciting way to think about court reform.
lead_paragraph: Late in the lead-up to the 2020 presidential election, as Mitch McConnell rushed to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg with Amy Coney Barrett, the left began pushing Joe Biden to endorse adding seats to the Supreme Court. Biden, in response, did what politicians do when faced with an issue they don’t want to think about: He promised to create a commission to study the issue.

headline: The Most Talented Runner of His Generation Takes the Unexpected Route Back Home
abstract: Forty-four years ago, Henry Rono set multiple world records on the track. Much of his life was later overshadowed by addiction. But at 70, he has no regrets.
lead_paragraph: KIPTARAGON, Kenya — One afternoon in May, as a cold rain pelted the roof of his brother’s rural home, Henry Rono sipped a mug of tea and reflected on what he called his greatest achievement.

headline: If Only John Roberts Would Retire
abstract: To help preserve the credibility of the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John Roberts should resign.
lead_paragraph: If liberal dreams — so endearing, so enduring — really did come true, Chief Justice John Roberts would resign. He’s been at it for 17 years. And he’s been incapable of tempering the Federalist Society-stamped fanatics on the right or leading the court toward any semblance of justice for all.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Rise and Fall of America’s Environmentalist Underground’
abstract: This year, one of the last fugitives of the Earth Liberation Front pleaded guilty to arson — at a moment when climate activists are again flirting with radical ideas.
lead_paragraph: Warning of imminent ecological catastrophe, the Earth Liberation Front became notorious in the late 1990s for setting fire to symbols of ecological destruction, including timber mills, an S.U.V. dealership and a ski resort. The group was widely demonized. Its exploits were condemned by mainstream environmental groups, ridiculed by the media and inspired a furious crackdown from law enforcement.

headline: With schools long shut, a father sees the protests in Sri Lanka as education.
abstract: Mohammad Imran’s children have barely attended school because of the nation’s economic crisis. And he says his salary barely covers the basics.
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, Mohammad Imran’s two children have been unable to attend school regularly in Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka. First it was the pandemic. Now, it’s the economic crisis, where fuel has become scarce and the cost of everything from food to transportation has skyrocketed on the island nation.

headline: The Week in Business: A Rude Awakening for Start-Ups
abstract: Job growth remained strong last month. Company earnings season kicks off. And Elon Musk backs away from his deal for Twitter.
lead_paragraph: For many tech start-ups, the era of seemingly endless optimism and immunity — from scrutiny, skepticism and, most of all, serious legal consequences — began to fray when an exposé on the blood-testing company Theranos was published in 2015 that raised questions about the effectiveness of the company’s technology. On Thursday, a jury found Ramesh Balwani, Theranos’s No. 2 executive, guilty of 12 counts of fraud, delivering another potent warning to Silicon Valley. Prosecutors’ evidence against Mr. Balwani showed that he had been deeply involved in almost every aspect of the company and had knowingly misled investors and customers. The verdict was more severe than that of Elizabeth Holmes, the Theranos founder and chief executive, who in January was convicted of four counts of fraud. It also arrives amid other troubling signs in the start-up world: Tech stock prices have plummeted this year, and investors have become more risk averse.

headline: The G.O.P.’s ‘Wildest Dream’
abstract: The election of Mayra Flores, a Republican and an immigrant, helps explain how Latino voters are shifting to the right.
lead_paragraph: Latino voters have recently shifted toward the Republican Party. Most still vote for Democrats, but the margin has shrunk.

headline: Shinzo Abe’s Party Triumphs in Parliamentary Vote, Extending Legacy
abstract: The Liberal Democrats and their partners gained enough seats to form a supermajority. They can now amend the country’s pacifist Constitution.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Two days after Japan’s former prime minister  Shinzo Abe was gunned down at a campaign stop on Friday, his Liberal Democratic Party and its allies swept to victory in a parliamentary election that gave them a chance to pursue Mr. Abe’s long-held ambition of revising Japan’s pacifist Constitution.

headline: In Eastern Ukraine, Attacks Intensify as Russia Readies New Offensive
abstract: The civilian toll has risen sharply in recent days as rockets and shells strike residential areas in the likely path of Russia’s coming push into Donetsk Province.
lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — Russia’s offensive in eastern Ukraine is intensifying in Donetsk Province, with a string of towns and villages coming under bombardment in the last week as Russian troops turn their firepower farther west after seizing control of the last city under Ukrainian control in Luhansk Province.

headline: A Scooter Mystery Solved
abstract: Wondering who rides a cherry-red Vespa.
lead_paragraph: Wondering who rides a cherry-red Vespa.

headline: At Least 21 Dead After 3 Tavern Shootings in South Africa
abstract: The shootings further highlighted concerns about safety, coming only two weeks after 21 teenagers died mysteriously in a coastal city tavern.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — At least 21 people were killed over the weekend as gunmen opened fire on three taverns in South Africa, in what the police described as “random” shootings.

headline: Biden Will Find a Changed Middle East on His Coming Visit
abstract: On his first trip to the region since taking office, President Biden will begin in Israel, which has been building relations with Arab nations. He will also make a stop in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news on Biden’s trip to Israel and the Middle East

headline: ‘Hollywood Ending,’ a Cradle-to-Jail Biography of Harvey Weinstein
abstract: Ken Auletta looks for Weinstein’s Rosebud in this dispiriting account of the former movie mogul’s life.
lead_paragraph: As you might expect, there aren’t a whole lot of laughs in “Hollywood Ending,” Ken Auletta’s cradle-to-jail new biography of Harvey Weinstein, the movie mogul convicted of third-degree rape and another sex felony in New York and awaiting trial on further charges in California. When Auletta calls Weinstein’s relationship with his brother Bob “Shakespeare-worthy,” he is placing the story squarely in the tragedy column of the ledger.

headline: Canada will return a sanctioned Nord Stream 1 turbine to ease Germany’s gas crisis.
abstract: The turbine — a critical piece of pipeline equipment — had been sent to Canada for repairs, but its return had been held up by sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s government said it would permit the return of a turbine to Germany that’s needed to operate a key Russian pipeline, a step intended to help Berlin ease a natural-gas shortage that has sent prices soaring but one that was taken over the objections of Ukraine.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: One-pot chermoula shrimp, gazpacho and more recipes for the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My pal Kim Severson is a national correspondent for our Food desk. She’s based in Atlanta and, while we jawbone on the phone all the time, we don’t get to spend as much quality time around a dining table as when she worked in New York. The pandemic hasn’t helped matters. I don’t think we’ve been able to see one another in person more than a couple of times since March of 2020.

headline: Goose Bumps Build for the Webb’s First Snapshots of the Universe
abstract: NASA picked five new images of scenes from around the universe that it hopes will knock the public’s socks off. Get ready for astronomical records to be broken.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning, NASA will show off the first pictures and data from the new James Webb Space Telescope. That will bring to an end some 30 years and $10 billion of planning, building, testing and innovating, followed by 6 months of terror, tension and anticipation.

headline: An Ode to Bookstores and Promiscuous Reading
abstract: I believe in bookstores in part because I believe in pluralism.
lead_paragraph: Bookstores, like wines, have different notes, different flavors, each one distinct. There are the musty, quirky ones with haphazard piles and dusty rows, usually with both used and new books. There are the small indie stores, quaint, cozy and scrappy. Then there’s the big-box gleam of long, straight rows, bright and dustless, with a café and a kids section you can get lost in.

headline: A Ruling From Outside the Court: ‘Shame’ on the Justices
abstract: It’s the readers’ turn to judge ... the Supreme Court’s recently ended term. Also: Anti-abortion activists; banning AR-15s; Australian slang.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What We Know About the Protests in Sri Lanka
abstract: Political chaos deepened in the country after it appeared that the unpopular president and his allies were trying to cling to power after the president fled overseas.
lead_paragraph: Months of largely peaceful protests in Sri Lanka turned tense after the president, reviled by critics who say he drove the country’s economy into the ground, fled the country but did not resign.

headline: Novak Djokovic Defeats Nick Kyrgios to Win His Seventh Wimbledon Title
abstract: Djokovic dropped the first set of the men’s singles final, but won the next three to capture his 21st Grand Slam title.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — The opponents and details change from year to year, but the bottom line has remained the same.

headline: Protesters in Sri Lanka Maintain Control of Government Buildings
abstract: Hundreds of people in Colombo, Sri Lanka, continued to occupy President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s home and office, as well as the prime minister’s home, a day after demonstrators stormed the buildings in protest of the island nation’s economic crisis.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people in Colombo, Sri Lanka, continued to occupy President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s home and office, as well as the prime minister’s home, a day after demonstrators stormed the buildings in protest of the island nation’s economic crisis.

headline: In Spite of Pitching Woes, the Red Sox Keep Swinging
abstract: Injuries have hampered the team’s already fragile rotation, but a powerful offense has kept Boston in the postseason hunt.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Chris Sale stopped by his locker at Fenway Park for about a minute on Saturday afternoon, just long enough to shake hands and thank a visitor for wishing him well. He was scurrying between the field and the weight room, slipped a new shirt over his reedy frame — “SALE” tattooed between his shoulder blades — and off he went.

headline: Bannon, Facing Jail and Fines, Agrees to Testify to Jan. 6 Panel
abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, the former Trump campaign manager and White House adviser, made the abrupt about-face after the former president authorized him to talk to investigators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his criminal trial for contempt of Congress approaching, Stephen K. Bannon, an ally of former President Donald J. Trump’s who was involved in his plans to overturn the 2020 election, has informed the House committee investigating the Capitol attack that he is now willing to testify, according to two letters obtained by The New York Times.

headline: We Are Political Hostages
abstract: For most people, “freedom of choice” in elections is an illusion. We are captives of the two-party system.
lead_paragraph: One of our greatest errors as a country has been our nonstop campaign to convince generations of voters that elections are about freedom of choice.

headline: In Metropolis of 5 Million, Rainforest Is a Lifeline and a Junkyard
abstract: An endangered gem of lush greenery in Abidjan, Ivory Coast’s economic hub, is at the center of government efforts to promote ecotourism. Those who live and work there worry about what it means for them.
lead_paragraph: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — The clangs of the men’s chisels and hammers were deafening as they dismantled a rusty truck, the din only fading as it reached the dense forest encircling them.

headline: Defense Firm Said U.S. Spies Backed Its Bid for Pegasus Spyware Maker
abstract: The American contractor L3Harris is said to have cited support from intelligence officials for its effort to acquire NSO, the Israeli spyware company blacklisted by the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: A team of executives from an American military contractor quietly visited Israel numerous times in recent months to try to carry out a bold but risky plan: purchasing NSO Group, the cyber hacking firm that is as notorious as it is technologically accomplished.

headline: Embattled Leaders in Hiding, Sri Lankans Ask: What’s Next?
abstract: Protesters in Sri Lanka roamed the halls and grounds of power without challenge as they waited to see who would take the reins of their economically devastated country.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage for the latest on Sri Lanka’s political crisis.

headline: Russian Airstrike Hits an Apartment Complex in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Emergency crews combed through rubble, looking for survivors, after a deadly Russian attack killed more than a dozen people in Chasiv Yar, Ukraine. Some residents were rescued, but more were trapped under the ruins.
lead_paragraph: Emergency crews combed through rubble, looking for survivors, after a deadly Russian attack killed more than a dozen people in Chasiv Yar, Ukraine. Some residents were rescued, but more were trapped under the ruins.

headline: Cassidy Hutchinson: Why the Jan. 6 Committee Rushed Her Testimony
abstract: Sequestered with family and security, Ms. Hutchinson, 26, has in the process developed an unlikely bond with Representative Liz Cheney, the panel’s vice chairwoman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before Cassidy Hutchinson was deposed for a fourth time by the Jan. 6 committee, the former Trump White House aide received a phone message that would dramatically change the plans of the panel and write a new chapter in American politics.

headline: Wildfire in Yosemite National Park Imperils Century-Old Trees
abstract: Nearly a dozen helicopters and more than 360 firefighters were at the Washburn fire, which has grown to more than 2,000 acres.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire in Yosemite National Park that has spread over 2,000 acres is threatening a grove of hundreds of giant sequoia trees, including some that are centuries old.

headline: A survivor emerges from the rubble of an apartment complex.
abstract: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — The young man had been trapped for more than 20 hours, pinned under the rubble of his devastated apartment complex in the eastern Ukraine village of Chasiv Yar.
lead_paragraph: CHASIV YAR, Ukraine — The young man had been trapped for more than 20 hours, pinned under the rubble of his devastated apartment complex in the eastern Ukraine village of Chasiv Yar.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Sri Lanka in Turmoil
abstract: Plus Shinzo Abe’s allies win a supermajority in Japan’s parliament and Russia bombards Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: An official said President Gotabaya Rajapaksa had agreed to resign as the leader of Sri Lanka after protesters took over his house on Saturday. Rajapaksa hasn’t been seen since.

headline: The war could have you paying more for hummus.
abstract: Russia and Ukraine are two of the biggest exporters of chickpeas, and the global supply is expected to decline this year.
lead_paragraph: Hummus long ago surpassed its roots as a Middle Eastern staple to become a familiar treat around the globe. Now the Russian invasion of Ukraine could have the creamy, chickpea-based dish in short supply.

headline: Brittney Griner is honored by her fellow players at the W.N.B.A. All-Star Game.
abstract: The league made Griner, who has been detained in Russia since February, an honorary starter for the game.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Brittney Griner’s fellow W.N.B.A. players honored her during the league’s All-Star Game in Chicago on Sunday, wearing jerseys bearing her name and number for the second half.

headline: Eureka!
abstract: Discover Roy Greim’s colorful New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Eureka! We’ve found it! The Monday crossword is here at last. Today’s puzzle is a New York Times Crossword debut by the constructor Roy Greim. Joel Fagliano, the senior puzzle editor for The Times, told me that this puzzle stood out to the editors for the “simple yet delightfully creative idea” anchoring its theme.

headline: Built to Be Flexible, Novak Djokovic Bounces Back
abstract: After forgoing a Covid-19 vaccine complicated his schedule, Djokovic’s elasticity this year has gone beyond the reactive shots that helped him win a seventh Wimbledon men’s singles title.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — He is an elastic man, Novak Djokovic.

headline: Mets and Yankees Sending 10 Players to All-Star Game
abstract: Pete Alonso makes his return to the Midsummer Classic (and the Home Run Derby) and he will be joined by three teammates and six Yankees players.
lead_paragraph: Pete Alonso of the Mets, who has become something of a fixture at Major League Baseball’s All-Star week, will come off the bench for the National League in this year’s All-Star Game. Alonso, the two-time defending Home Run Derby champion, will be joined in Los Angeles by three of his Mets teammates and six players from the crosstown Yankees, who led all teams in total selections once the pitchers and reserves were announced on Sunday.

headline: Beanie Feldstein to Depart ‘Funny Girl’ Earlier Than Expected
abstract: The actress announced on Instagram that she would be leaving the musical at the end of July, two months earlier than previously announced.
lead_paragraph: Beanie Feldstein, the lead actress in the first Broadway revival of “Funny Girl,” announced on Instagram on Sunday night that she would be leaving the production at the end of this month, two months earlier than expected.

headline: ‘Into the Woods’ Review: Do You Believe in Magic?
abstract: The Encores! revival of this fairy-tale musical, with songs by Stephen Sondheim, arrives on Broadway with its humor, wonder and humanity intact.
lead_paragraph: After the woods and the wolf and the dark and the knife, Little Red Riding Hood has learned a thing or two. In the first act of “Into the Woods,” while modeling a cloak made from the wolf’s pelt, she shares her wisdom. Be prepared, she advises in “I Know Things Now.” Watch out for strangers. Stephen Sondheim’s bone-dry lyrics supply one more maxim: “Nice,” Little Red concludes, “is different than good.”

headline: Fans Love W.N.B.A. All-Stars, but Cast a Critical Eye on the League
abstract: Fans who traveled to Chicago to celebrate their favorite players called for the W.N.B.A. to improve. The players did, too.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Benita Harrison-Diggs traveled from Virginia Beach to make a weekend out of the W.N.B.A. All-Star Game with friends. She remembered the excitement around the league’s “exceptional” inaugural season in 1997 and was hopeful that 2022 would match it.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Russia seeks new soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces desperately need new soldiers. Already, the government is using what some analysts call a “stealth mobilization” to bring in new recruits without resorting to a politically risky national draft. “Russia has a problem with recruitment and mobilization,” said Kamil Galeev, an analyst specializing in Russia. “It is basically desperate to get more men using any means possible.”

headline: Inside Brazil’s 40-Year Rise to Global Surfing Dominance
abstract: This generation of Brazilian surfers is so dominant, so undeniable, that it has earned a nickname: the Brazilian Storm.
lead_paragraph: Under a brilliant Brazilian sun, as he rode across a perfect peeling wave, the professional surfer Filipe Toledo thumped his chest and shouted toward the beach. Toledo, 27, who grew up around 250 miles west of this stretch of sand, had just won his second World Surf League championship tour event of the year. The win, in Saquarema, Brazil, cemented his place as the top-ranked male surfer in the world, and he was one big step closer to winning the men’s world championship.

headline: Wimbledon Needs More Arthur Ashe Moments, On and Off the Court
abstract: Nick Kyrgios and Ons Jabeur brought a fresh diversity to the men’s and women’s singles finals.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For the first time in nearly a half-century, a weekend at Wimbledon felt, and looked, different.

headline: No Corrections: July 11, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Taunting Gunman and 78 Minutes of Terror
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not going to make it. I’m going to bleed out.”

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Everything’s Trash’ and ‘The Rehearsal’
abstract: New shows from the idiosyncratic comedy creators Phoebe Robinson and Nathan Fielder debut on Freeform and HBO.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: The Story of 2 Homeless Men and the Meaning of Friendship
abstract: A Times deputy managing editor discusses his tale of two immigrants who formed a special bond while surviving on the margins of New York City.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at yesterday’s cover story in the Metropolitan section: the tale of Tin Chin and Mo Lin, Chinese-speaking immigrants who met in a Brooklyn homeless shelter and became inseparable.

headline: The Race for a New Conservative Leader Is On. Not So Fast.
abstract: Are Britons supposed to simply forget what just happened?
lead_paragraph: It is customary, when someone is near death, to reflect on the life that person lived: Was time spent wisely, or wasted? Were good deeds done, or harm caused? It is much the same with a political death. As Boris Johnson’s government gasps its final breaths, many of us are reflecting on how this prime minister and his colleagues have used almost three years in power and the damage they have wrought. Not the candidates for the new Conservative leader, though; they’re ready to move on.

headline: Inside the Amazon Journey That Left a Journalist and an Activist Dead
abstract: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
lead_paragraph: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Random Killing Erodes a New York Block’s Sense of Stability
abstract: John Edwards was a beloved fixture on his Bronx block and another unintended victim of the gun violence that has put many New Yorkers on edge.
lead_paragraph: For years, John Edwards held court from a plastic blue chair outside his basement home on Prospect Avenue in the Belmont section of the Bronx. He kept the sidewalk tidy, talked young people through their troubles, picked up scrap metal and helped neighbors with odd jobs.

headline: Most Democrats Don’t Want Biden in 2024, New Poll Shows
abstract: With the country gripped by a pervasive sense of pessimism, the president is hemorrhaging support.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is facing an alarming level of doubt from inside his own party, with 64 percent of Democratic voters saying they would prefer a new standard-bearer in the 2024 presidential campaign, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll, as voters nationwide have soured on his leadership, giving him a meager 33 percent job-approval rating.

headline: ‘There’s Nothing’: Scarcity Deepens Desperation in Sri Lanka
abstract: The island nation was once an economic hope, with a growing middle class. Now many people are living on the edge, unable to buy even the basics.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage for the latest on Sri Lanka’s political crisis.

headline: One Golfer Not Welcome at the British Open? Greg Norman.
abstract: Norman’s only major tournament victories came in Opens, but his role leading the Saudi-financed LIV Golf series has caused a rift with the R&A.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was only this spring that Greg Norman, who twice hoisted the claret jug as the winner of the British Open, sought a special dispensation to play in this week’s tournament at St. Andrews in Scotland.

headline: We’re Not Asking for the Moon
abstract: Millennials, on their very real fears about money.
lead_paragraph: Millennials, on their very real fears about money.

headline: Jerrod Carmichael Was Scared of Coming Out. He Still Is.
abstract: “I want the love, desperately,” says the comedian, “but not at the cost of not talking about it because that makes me hate myself.”
lead_paragraph: “I want the love, desperately,” says the comedian, “but not at the cost of not talking about it because that makes me hate myself.”

headline: Why So Many Children of Immigrants Rise to the Top
abstract: The American Dream is more about “where” than “who.”
lead_paragraph: The American Dream is more about “where” than “who.”

headline: Merrick Garland Should Investigate Trump’s 2020 Election Schemes as a ‘Hub and Spoke’ Conspiracy
abstract: The Justice Department needs to rethink its approach.
lead_paragraph: The tenacious work of the Jan. 6 committee has transformed how we think about the Jan. 6 rebellion. It should also transform the Justice Department’s investigation into efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: For Millennials in Los Angeles, Bad Thoughts Arise
abstract: Nada Alic’s debut story collection pierces superficial appearances to access deeper human connection.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Nada Alic’s debut fiction collection, “Bad Thoughts,” sunny facades belie strange, dark interiors. The stories feature a privileged millennial milieu in Los Angeles with all its carefully observed trappings — neutral linens at a baby shower, destination bachelorette weekends, social media obsessions, alternative wellness practices and a chic, spare loft “furnished with gray modular furniture resembling life-size Lego pieces.”

headline: Is Society Finally Ready for Male Birth Control?
abstract: We are developing new hormonal contraceptives for men. Post-Roe, our work is more critical than ever.
lead_paragraph: Over 40 percent of the six million annual pregnancies in the United States are unplanned, according to the latest data available, and about one in five pregnancies ends in abortion. With the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade, and the resulting loss of access to safe abortion care for millions of Americans, it is more critical than ever to prevent unplanned pregnancies. The use of an effective method of contraception is the best way to do so.

headline: ‘Stay and Fight’ Isn’t So Easy When a Red State Puts Your Child at Risk
abstract: When their home states are led by zealots, families face tough choices.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Last year, two families in Wilson County, Tenn., signed on as plaintiffs in a federal civil rights lawsuit challenging Tennessee legislation that prohibits transgender students from using bathrooms that align with their gender identities. But as WPLN News reported last week, both families have since left the state, believing their children would not be safe here long enough to see the lawsuit through. Now that the plaintiffs have moved away, a district judge has dismissed the suit.

headline: And the Next President Will Be …
abstract: Well, it won’t be Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Have I ever mentioned to you that I’m not an Elon Musk fan?

headline: Even if Republicans Outlaw Abortion, Americans Will Soon Rebel
abstract: Prohibition couldn’t even last 14 years. Will an abortion ban last that long?
lead_paragraph: A movement that seeks to compel Americans to live according to a stringent moral code may be most vulnerable when it succeeds.

headline: Hochul’s Vow to Fix Albany’s Culture Finds an Unexpected Foe: Herself
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would usher in a “new era of transparency.” But critics, including the state comptroller’s office, said she has failed to do so.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In the last days of the 2022 legislative session, as the State Capitol was abuzz with frenzied pushes to strengthen gun control, abortion rights and environmental regulations, New York lawmakers received a jolting email.

headline: In a Time of Conflict, Ukraine Entrepreneurs Make War Their Business
abstract: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Yuriy Zakharchuk once dreamed up combat costumes for the stage, designing everything from medieval armor to space battle suits.

headline: Shopping for Peg Rails
abstract: The traditional peg rail is one of the simplest and most appealing kinds of storage you can add to a room. Here are five of the best.
lead_paragraph: For such a simple product, a peg rail can solve a surprising number of storage problems. It can easily hold a mountain of coats, as well as various other essentials — hats, bags, umbrellas, brooms.

headline: F.D.A. to Weigh Over-the-Counter Sale of Contraceptive Pills
abstract: The first U.S. application for sale of a nonprescription birth control pill has taken on new meaning after the Supreme Court decision ending the constitutional right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 60 years after the approval of oral contraceptives revolutionized women’s sexual health, the Food and Drug Administration has received its first application for a birth control pill sold over the counter — just as the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has put access to contraception more squarely at the heart of the clash over reproductive rights.

headline: States With Abortion Bans Risk Losing Their Economic Edge
abstract: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
lead_paragraph: As a group of conservative states enacted severe abortion restrictions last year, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sent letters to a handful of corporate executives with close ties to Texas.

headline: The Explosive Ambitions of Kate the Chemist
abstract: At the lecture halls of the University of Texas or on TV, Kate Biberdorf is working to catalyze more people into careers in science.
lead_paragraph: The dream is Vegas.

headline: China’s Economy Stumbles in the Fog of Covid War
abstract: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic engine has shuddered in recent months, hurt by lockdowns imposed to curb the spread of Covid. Housing sales sagged. Many shops and restaurants in some cities shuttered, some maybe for good. Youth unemployment climbed.

headline: A Year After Mass Protest, Cubans Face Stark Choice: ‘Prison or Exile’
abstract: Thousands of Cubans took to the streets last July protesting economic misery. A year later, hundreds are in jail and the financial crisis has only worsened.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — One year after Cubans took to the streets in one of the largest protest movements since the Communist government took power six decades ago, hundreds of demonstrators are languishing in prison while tens of thousands have fled repression and destitution on the island.

headline: The Right to Travel in a Post-Roe World
abstract: In a concurring opinion last month, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh said the Constitution did not allow states to stop women from traveling to get abortions. But the issue is more complicated than that.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh signed the recent majority opinion that overruled Roe v. Wade. He also issued a 12-page concurring opinion, writing only for himself. He wanted to discuss, he wrote, “the future implications” of the decision.

headline: The Business Lunch May Be Going Out of Business
abstract: As remote work persists and business deals are sealed online, many upscale restaurants that catered to the nation’s downtown office crowd are canceling the meal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few people understand the power lunch better than Ashok Bajaj. The restaurateur began his career here in the waning days of Ronald Reagan’s presidency, when he opened the Bombay Club a short walk from the White House.

headline: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
abstract: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.
lead_paragraph: In a quiet corner of the bohemian district of San Frediano, hidden behind an 18th-century iron gate that opens onto a whimsical wisteria-covered alleyway, lies a Florentine cultural treasure: the Antico Setificio Fiorentino, or Antique Florentine Silk Mill, which has been producing precious textiles since 1786.

headline: Where Mantras Trump Medicine, Vaccines Are a ‘Violation’
abstract: The Baduy, an Indigenous group in Indonesia, believe that vaccinations are impure, and unnecessary, and that their beliefs protect them. To skeptics, they note their Covid death toll: zero.
lead_paragraph: KANEKES, Indonesia — When their ancestors warned them, through dreams and a bone-bitingly cold wind, to be careful, the community leaders of the Baduy people in Indonesia knew they needed to protect their villages from something bad that was on its way.

headline: Texans Warned to Reduce Electricity Use Amid Fear of Rolling Blackouts
abstract: About 50 million people in the United States were under heat warnings or advisories over the weekend. The heat index was forecast to soar past 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Monday in about half of Texas.
lead_paragraph: Texas’ electricity regulator warned residents and businesses to reduce the amount of power they use on Monday as the heat index was forecast to soar above 100 degrees Fahrenheit, putting a strain on the state’s grid and potentially leading to rolling blackouts across the state.

headline: On Abortion Laws, It All Goes Back to 2010
abstract: How a “red wave” led to restrictions at the state level that, in most cases, do not reflect the majority opinion of the states’ own citizens.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the court’s conservative majority argued it was simply handing the question of abortion to the states and their voters to decide for themselves.

headline: For Uvalde Families, a Call for Answers Grows Louder
abstract: At City Council meetings and at a protest on Sunday, the relatives of the slain children and teachers have shown their anger and frustration.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Kimberly Rubio and her husband, Felix, took the stage on Sunday evening at Uvalde Plaza next to City Hall while holding a photo of their slain daughter, Alexandria Aniyah Rubio, known as Lexi, and read aloud part of the mission statement of the Uvalde Police Department.

headline: Dueling Weaknesses
abstract: The Times has released its first poll of the 2022 midterm cycle.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, when The New York Times’s pollsters asked Americans whether they planned to vote for Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump, more than 10 percent said they would not support either one. They said that they would instead vote for a third-party candidate or not vote at all.

headline: Security Forces in China Attack Protesters Seeking Frozen Funds
abstract: After a rare mass demonstration, bank depositors demanding their money back were beaten, kicked to the ground and dragged away in the city of Zhengzhou.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A financial scandal in central China has touched depositors across the country, some of whom placed their life savings in four rural banks offering high rates of return, then found their funds frozen as investigators examined allegations of widespread fraud.

headline: Germany on Edge as Russian Gas Pipeline Goes Offline for Repair
abstract: Supplies via Nord Stream 1 dropped to zero as the pipeline began a 10-day maintenance period amid uncertainty over how long the shutdown would really last.
lead_paragraph: The flow of natural gas from Russia to Germany via a crucial undersea pipeline stopped on Monday, as the link went offline for a 10-day scheduled maintenance period, testing Europe’s resolve to wean itself off abundant Russian fuel supplies.

headline: Three cities in China impose partial lockdowns as new cases are reported.
abstract: The cities of Xi’an, Lanzhou and Haikou set restrictions on several million residents. In Macau, the gambling hub, authorities shut casinos and ordered everyone to stay home.
lead_paragraph: At least three Chinese cities put in place partial lockdowns and the gambling hub of Macau shut its casinos for the second time since the start of the pandemic, as authorities tried to stamp out the latest coronavirus outbreaks.

headline: Tanqueray Looks Back at Her Grand and Gritty New York Life
abstract: Stephanie Johnson went from burlesque nights in Times Square to internet stardom. “I did it my way and it worked,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Johnson has had two moments of fame. The first came when she was a burlesque dancer who went by the stage name Tanqueray in the gritty Times Square of the 1960s and 1970s, a time when “10,000 men in New York City knew my name,” as she once put it. She re-entered the spotlight three years ago as an internet sensation after she shared candid tales of her life with Humans of New York, a digital franchise with millions of followers on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.

headline: Gary Player Fears for the Old Course (and Probably Your Breakfast Order)
abstract: Player, who won nine majors during his celebrated career, talked with The Times ahead of the British Open, his favorite top-tier tournament of all.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN SQUARE, Pa. — Surely, Gary Player could have long ago gotten away from being one of golf’s globe-trotting mascots.

headline: A hail of Russian strikes brings terror to Ukraine’s east.
abstract: Russian strikes killed at least eight people in eastern Ukraine in 24 hours and the death toll from an apartment complex hit by Russian rockets grew as well, local officials said on Monday, a chilling reminder of the devastation Russia has inflicted on civilians, even as its military pauses its drive to seize Ukrainian territory.
lead_paragraph: Russian strikes killed at least eight people in eastern Ukraine in 24 hours and the death toll from an apartment complex hit by Russian rockets grew as well, local officials said on Monday, a chilling reminder of the devastation Russia has inflicted on civilians, even as its military pauses its drive to seize Ukrainian territory.

headline: The U.S. government will buy 3.2 million doses of Novavax’s Covid vaccine.
abstract: The vaccine has not yet been authorized but is expected to be soon.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Monday that it would buy 3.2 million doses of a Covid-19 vaccine from the Maryland pharmaceutical company Novavax that is expected to soon receive authorization in the United States.

headline: Why Musk May Be Stuck
abstract: Twitter is in a good position to sue under a legal doctrine called specific performance, which allows courts to force a transaction to be completed, even if one of the parties wants out.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk late last week finally followed through on his threat to try to pull out of his $44 billion deal to buy Twitter. The social media company promptly responded by saying it planned to sue. Most legal experts believe the law is strongly on Twitter’s side, assuming nothing explosive is revealed during trial.
