headline: Sri Lanka’s acting president has a long, and complicated, political history.
abstract: A prime minister six times over, Ranil Wickremesinghe’s leadership has been equated with Sri Lanka’s economic ambitions as well as its collapse.
lead_paragraph: Ranil Wickremesinghe was named acting president of Sri Lanka on Wednesday, after President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled with his wife to the Maldives overnight.

headline: At Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust memorial, a reaffirmation of life.
abstract: President Biden met two survivors on a visit to Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A long line of international dignitaries have paid visits to Yad Vashem, Israel’s official Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem. Even for President Biden, his visit on Wednesday was not his first.

headline: Victoria’s Secret and What’s Sexy Now
abstract: A rebranding and a new documentary have the lingerie company back in the cultural cross hairs.
lead_paragraph: When Victoria’s Secret announced, back in August 2021, that it was rebranding after years of falling sales and falling cultural credibility — that it would become a champion of female empowerment, replacing its bevy of supermodel angels with the VS Collective, ten women of great accomplishment as well as varying ages and body types — the news was met, generally (and understandably), with raised eyebrows.

headline: A Trump Backer’s Downfall as the Target of a Jan. 6 Conspiracy Theory
abstract: Ray Epps became the unwitting face of an attempt by pro-Trump forces to promote the baseless idea that the F.B.I. was behind the attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: IN THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS — Up a winding country road, in a trailer park a half-mile from a cattle ranch, lives a man whose life has been ruined by a Jan. 6 conspiracy theory.

headline: The Power of the Press
abstract: A Los Angeles Times reporter takes on a powerful university — and his own paper.
lead_paragraph: “Bad City,” by Paul Pringle, begins in Pasadena, Calif., in March 2016, with the kind of tip that reporters prize: An unconscious young woman. A drug-paraphernalia-strewn hotel room. An older male companion, reluctant to call for help, who turns out to be the dean of the University of Southern California’s prestigious Keck School of Medicine.

headline: How to Bulgogi Your Tofu
abstract: You don’t always need a recipe.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I may hawk recipes in this space, but I don’t always use them. That’s especially true in the middle of the week when I’m ground down by the realities of a working life and don’t have a moment to browse our app. Time sneaks up on me, and suddenly it occurs to me that dinner needs to be made.

headline: Gates Foundation Adds $20 Billion to Its Coffers
abstract: The organization, still run by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, will eventually spend $9 billion a year, up from $6 billion, on causes like global health and education.
lead_paragraph: When the news emerged last year that Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates were divorcing, the question of whether their foundation would lose ready access to its founders’ substantial resources quickly arose.

headline: Art We Saw This Summer
abstract: From our critics, reviews of closed gallery shows around New York City.
lead_paragraph: Food as politics, as philosophy, as history, as art: “Fruiting Bodies” considers these aspects of the stuff we stuff into our mouths.

headline: Let Them Have Couture
abstract: Balenciaga’s latest experiment attempts to open up the mysterious world of Parisian haute couture.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — I spent quite a long time sniffing the candle, twisting the mirrored jar around in my hands and tilting my head, as if inhaling from different angles might yield new discoveries.

headline: Owner of Sweet & Vicious Bar Will Pay $500,000 for Worker Harassment
abstract: The state attorney general says employees at the Manhattan bar were subjected to repeated slurs and sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: Sweet & Vicious, a downtown Manhattan bar and restaurant popular for its “jargaritas” — frozen margaritas served in giant Mason jars — has been a nest of sexual, racial and gender-based harassment where workers endured racial slurs, had tips taken by the management and went unpaid for work, according to a 16-month investigation by Letitia James, the New York State attorney general.

headline: Brittney Griner and the Limits of American Power
abstract: For Griner, and other Americans held prisoner overseas, the road home may be long, and slow.
lead_paragraph: Brittney Griner is many things. A truly extraordinary basketball player. The embodiment of the promises made by feminism, generally, and Title IX, specifically, to a generation of American girls. A wealthy celebrity. An L.G.B.T. icon.

headline: Secret Service Employee Sent Home After Arrest in Israel
abstract: The employee had a “physical encounter,” a spokesman for the agency said, although it did not involve a sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: A Secret Service employee working in Israel before President Biden’s visit there this week was sent home late Monday after being briefly arrested by the Israeli police in what the U.S. agency called “a physical encounter,” a spokesman for the Secret Service said on Wednesday.

headline: Portraits by Barkley L. Hendricks Will Hang With Old Masters at the Frick
abstract: He is the first artist of color to have a solo show at the 87-year-old museum, organized by Aimee Ng and Antwaun Sargent.
lead_paragraph: The portrait artist Barkley L. Hendricks, who died in 2017, considered the Frick Collection one of his favorite museums. Now Hendricks’s celebratory, large-scale paintings of Black Americans will hang in that institution, long the home of Rembrandt, Bronzino and Van Dyck, as the first artist of color to have a solo show at the 87-year-old Frick.

headline: ‘Desperate Characters’ and the Chaos That Lies Beneath
abstract: Paula Fox, the author of the 1970 novel, writes Sigrid Nunez, had a keen sense of the thin veneer of civilization, and how little it takes to fall through.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of T’s Book Club, a series of articles and events dedicated to classic works of American literature. Click here to R.S.V.P. to a virtual conversation about “Desperate Characters,” to be led by Sigrid Nunez and held on Aug. 4.

headline: With Tennis Style, It’s Hard to Ace the Classics
abstract: While Grand Slam season often forecasts men’s wear innovations, the elegance of a crisp white look is tough to beat.
lead_paragraph: For at least some watching Novak Djokovic win his seventh Wimbledon title and 21st Grand Slam crown on Sunday (surprising almost no one), there was one largely unacknowledged pleasure in the experience.

headline: Computers and Painting’s Identity Crisis
abstract: A show at Nahmad Contemporary is an outgrowth of debates around “tradition” in art. Can artists embrace beauty while reaching for new technology?
lead_paragraph: Every new generation of artists, curators, and critics seems to feel the need to defend painting. It makes sense: paint on canvas, good for little else, is basically synonymous with big-A Art. Painting stands for art’s angels and demons, its optimism and attention, its arrogance and solipsism.

headline: Twist on the Mountain: Vingegaard Grabs Tour de France Lead
abstract: A daring attack near the end of a punishing stage put a Danish rider in the yellow jersey, left Tadej Pogacar in his wake and upended the standings.
lead_paragraph: Jonas Vingegaard turned the Tour de France on its head on Wednesday with a sharp attack on the brutal final climb that won him the race’s 11th stage and snatched the leader’s yellow jersey from Tadej Pogacar.

headline: You Won’t Live Longer by Diet or Exercise Alone, Study Says
abstract: Sprawling new research showed that healthy eating and regular workouts do not, in isolation, stave off later health issues. They need to be done together.
lead_paragraph: Health food or exercise alone isn’t enough to prevent chronic disease, new research shows. Contrary to popular belief, you can’t outrun the toll of a poor diet — and healthy eating, on its own, won’t ward off disease.

headline: Key Revelations From the Jan. 6 Hearings
abstract: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack is laying out evidence that could allow prosecutors to indict former President Donald J. Trump, though the path to a criminal trial is uncertain. Here are the main themes that have emerged in each hearing.
lead_paragraph: The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack is laying out evidence that could allow prosecutors to indict former President Donald J. Trump, though the path to a criminal trial is uncertain. Here are the main themes that have emerged in each hearing.

headline: Bad Planning and Errors, Not Fans, Led to Champions League Chaos, Report Says
abstract: A French Senate inquiry faulted the authorities for blaming large crowds of supporters instead of owning up to their failures, after violence and confusion marred a final near Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Faulty coordination, bad planning and multiple errors by French authorities were responsible for the chaos that marred this year’s Champions League soccer final just outside Paris, according to a parliamentary report published on Wednesday that criticized officials for blaming English fans instead of acknowledging their own failings.

headline: A Homeless Suspect Is Arrested in Stabbings of 3 Homeless Men
abstract: Trevon Murphy, 40, who a cousin said had a history of mental illness, was spotted by a correction officer near a Harlem park.
lead_paragraph: A 40-year-old homeless man was arrested Wednesday on murder and attempted murder charges in the stabbings of three homeless men in Manhattan, one fatally, the police said. The men were all sleeping outdoors when attacked over the course of the last week.

headline: Online Shopping Is Bananas Confusing
abstract: How much we buy online affects the whole economy, but right now there are lots of question marks.
lead_paragraph: The mantra of 2022 should really be: No one knows anything.

headline: 5 Writing Prompts That Got Teenagers Talking
abstract: Here are the news topics students had the most to say about this school year.
lead_paragraph: Here are the news topics students had the most to say about this school year.

headline: Pope Names First Women to Office That Helps Select Bishops
abstract: The three women will serve five-year terms in the Vatican office that vets candidates, enhancing the role of women in the church’s operations.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Wednesday appointed women for the first time to the office that advises him in the choice of bishops across the globe, a move that bolsters efforts to give women a larger voice in the church’s operations.

headline: N.F.L. Players Pay a Small Price When Accused of Violence Against Women
abstract: A peer-reviewed study found that players who are arrested in these cases generally do not suffer major career consequences.
lead_paragraph: How the N.F.L. responds to accusations of violence against women has been discussed anecdotally for years, usually focusing on the short-term punishment individual athletes did or did not receive from their teams or the league. But a recent study examined this issue more comprehensively, asking: Do arrests for accusations of violence against women hurt N.F.L. players’ careers?

headline: As Faith Flags in U.S. Government, Many Voters Want to Upend the System
abstract: Desire for structural changes cuts across both parties, a Times/Siena College poll found, but for starkly different reasons. Even Democrats now question if the government is a force for good.
lead_paragraph: A majority of American voters across nearly all demographics and ideologies believe their system of government does not work, with 58 percent of those interviewed for a New York Times/Siena College poll saying that the world’s oldest independent constitutional democracy needs major reforms or a complete overhaul.

headline: In Designing ‘The Sea Beast,’ Animators Sweat the Details
abstract: A deep dive into the look of the title character in the animated Netflix film.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Covid-19 tests, it’s normal for somebody to have become intimately familiar with the interior of the human nose in the last couple of years. But in doing research for his new animated movie, the director Chris Williams dove deeper into nostrils than most of us have.

headline: How the Colorful Costumes of ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ Were Made
abstract: “The Phantom of the Opera,” “Big Trouble in Little China” and an archaeology museum all played a part, the designer Mayes Rubeo explains.
lead_paragraph: There is a hush-hush building in North Hollywood full of supersuits and scraps, a costume warehouse where Marvel Studios preserves every major outfit that its heroes have worn onscreen during the last decade and a half. For the costume designer Mayes Rubeo, touring the warehouse is always a fun trip, not least because there is an aisle of costume leftovers from her work on “Thor: Ragnarok” that comprises the most colorful section of the entire building.

headline: This Trumpeter’s Legacy Also Includes Composing String Quartets
abstract: A new boxed set of string quartets by Wadada Leo Smith, an anchor of American experimental music, reveals his sustained engagement with the form.
lead_paragraph: The trumpeter Wadada Leo Smith has played an outsize role in American experimental music for the last 50 years.

headline: Gas Prices, a Big Inflation Factor, Are Coming Down Sharply
abstract: A four-week decline has offered some relief to drivers. Weather, war and demand will influence how long the decline lasts.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Gasoline prices, on an upward tear for months, have reversed course in recent weeks, giving consumers a welcome break.

headline: To Fight Book Banning, Support Librarians
abstract: Librarians respond to book bans. Also: The Jan. 6 hearing; a Supreme Court test; anti-abortion states; homelessness in California; acting for change locally.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Investigating Two Murders in the Amazon
abstract: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.
lead_paragraph: Dom Phillips and Bruno Pereira set off deep into the Amazon to meet Indigenous groups patrolling the forest. Then they vanished.

headline: Sunak Takes the Lead in the Voting to Replace U.K. Prime Minister
abstract: The former chancellor of the Exchequer led a pack of candidates after the first round, while an obscure trade minister surprised in second place.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer, stayed at the front of the pack of candidates vying to replace Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain after the first round of the Conservative Party’s leadership contest on Tuesday.

headline: Inflation Soared in June, Pinching Consumers and Challenging Policymakers
abstract: Prices climbed 9.1 percent from a year earlier, ramping up pressure on the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: Prices surged 9.1 percent in June as consumers faced rapidly rising costs for gas, food and rent, a higher-than-expected reading and bad news for Americans at a moment when their wages are falling further behind the nation’s soaring cost of living.

headline: In a New Census, Dance/NYC Wants to Count Every Dance Worker
abstract: The nonprofit organization’s goal is to establish labor standards across the industry, which was hard hit by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Dance/NYC, a nonprofit organization that promotes knowledge and appreciation of dance in New York City, is on a mission to count every dance worker — from choreographers to ballet teachers to Colombian folkloric dancers — and dance organization in New York City and its surrounding areas. The census will be among the largest undertakings of its kind in the performing arts, the organization said.

headline: Police Arrest Owner of South African Tavern Where 21 Teenagers Died
abstract: Two employees were also arrested. Investigators have yet to say what killed the teenagers, who were found one June night collapsed in an overcrowded bar.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The owner and two employees of a tavern in South Africa where 21 teenagers were found dead under mysterious circumstances last month have been arrested and charged with selling alcohol to minors, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: A Mother’s Secret
abstract: He always thought his father was the only one at fault. Until one day, deep into adulthood, his mother asked him if they could go on a walk.
lead_paragraph: Ayad Akhtar’s parents met in Pakistan in the early ’60s, when they were both medical students and “ridiculously attractive” — or so their friends say. Despite having a love marriage (against the wishes of their parents), theirs was rocky from the start.

headline: The Dollar Has Muscled Higher While the Euro Lost Ground
abstract: Why? Part of the answer is interest rates.
lead_paragraph: A $1 bill and a one-euro coin are worth almost exactly the same amount, for the first time in 20 years. The euro has traded above the dollar since 2002, but according to pricing sources tracked by Bloomberg, on Wednesday the euro, used by 19 nations, briefly fell below the buck, touching a low of $0.9998 before rebounding to $1.003 in afternoon trading in London. The dollar has been muscling higher against a broad range of currencies while the euro has been losing ground, especially against the dollar.

headline: Netflix turns to Microsoft to help build its new ad-supported service.
abstract: The streaming giant hopes a less expensive offering will boost subscription numbers, which have dropped for the first time in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Netflix has selected Microsoft to help build its forthcoming ad-supported tier, the streaming giant said on Wednesday.

headline: A Rhode Island State Senator Wants You to #TwerkFor Justice
abstract: Tiara Mack’s TikTok video of her twerking at the beach went viral. Now, she is using that momentum to bring awareness to her political platform.
lead_paragraph: When news broke of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade in June, State Senator Tiara Mack, Democrat of Rhode Island, decided to try a new way of raising awareness for abortion access: She created a TikTok account.

headline: ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’ Review: A Wild Heroine, a Soothing Tale
abstract: Daisy Edgar-Jones stars as an orphaned girl in the marshes of North Carolina in this tame adaptation of Delia Owens’s popular novel.
lead_paragraph: “Where the Crawdads Sing,” Delia Owens’s first novel, is one of the best-selling fiction books in recent years, and if nothing else the new movie version can help you understand why.

headline: Pope Francis says he will meet the head of the Russian Orthodox Church in September.
abstract: Pope Francis plans to meet with the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill I, in September, the pontiff said in an interview with a Spanish-language broadcaster.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis plans to meet with the head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill I, in September, the pontiff said in an interview with a Spanish-language broadcaster.

headline: After a Surprise Firing, University of Michigan Has a New President
abstract: Santa J. Ono will be the university’s first Asian American president. He will take the helm during a contentious time in higher education.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan announced on Wednesday that its next president would be Santa J. Ono, a biomedical researcher known for his leadership on college affordability and action against climate change.

headline: Novavax’s latecomer Covid-19 vaccine gets U.S. authorization.
abstract: The vaccine was authorized as a primary immunization series for adults, rather than a booster, which may limit its market at first.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday authorized a Covid-19 vaccine developed by Novavax, a biotechnology company in Maryland that received significant federal funding to produce the shot. The vaccine will be a new option for Americans as vaccination rates stagnate.

headline: Wake Up, Billionaires: The Occupiers Are Coming for the Hamptons
abstract: Along for an early morning “billionaire wake-up call” with protesters on Meadow Lane.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday morning at 5 a.m., before the day’s oysters were unloaded from their fishing boats and the first bikes churned at SoulCycle, 16 protesters showed up on East Hampton’s Further Lane, one of the mega-richest blocks in one of the country’s mega-richest enclaves. They were there to stage what they described as “billionaire wake-up calls.”

headline: Statue of Black Educator Replaces Confederate General in U.S. Capitol
abstract: Mary McLeod Bethune is the first Black American to be represented with a state statue in the National Statuary Hall. Her likeness replaces a statue honoring one of the last Confederate generals to surrender.
lead_paragraph: Mary McLeod Bethune on Wednesday became the first Black American to be represented with a state statue in National Statuary Hall, a central room of the United States Capitol, honored for her work championing education and civil rights.

headline: Drug-Resistant Infections in Hospitals Soared During the Pandemic, C.D.C. Says
abstract: A new report says the havoc wrought by the coronavirus reversed gains made by health care facilities to combat deadly pathogens.
lead_paragraph: The spread of drug-resistant infections surged during the coronavirus pandemic, killing nearly 30,000 people in 2020 and upending much of the recent progress made in containing the spread of so-called superbugs, according to an analysis by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Mary McLeod Bethune Is Honored With a Statue at the Capitol
abstract: Dr. Bethune was honored for her work championing education and civil rights, and became the first Black American to be represented with a statue in National Statuary Hall, a central room of the United States Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bethune was honored for her work championing education and civil rights, and became the first Black American to be represented with a statue in National Statuary Hall, a central room of the United States Capitol.

headline: A Helicopter Crashed on a Tractor. Its Operator Saved the Pilot.
abstract: The young man was working in a cherry orchard in Washington State when he heard two thumps and looked up. A chopper was coming straight at him.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old man was operating a tractor in a cherry orchard in Washington State last week when, seemingly out of nowhere, a helicopter fell on him. Within minutes, he was able to free himself from the wreckage and save the pilot.

headline: Studies Probe Adenovirus Link to Childhood Hepatitis Cases
abstract: Two new papers add to the circumstantial evidence that a common childhood virus might be involved in the rare hepatitis cases, but many questions remain.
lead_paragraph: For months, scientists around the world have been investigating cases of severe, unexplained hepatitis, or liver inflammation, in previously healthy children. At least 920 probable cases have been detected in 33 countries since October, according to the World Health Organization. About 5 percent have required liver transplants, and 18 deaths have been reported.

headline: Chaos Engulfs Sri Lanka as Protesters Demand Ouster of Interim Leader
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa fled, protesters angered by an economic meltdown overran the interim leader’s offices, and it was unclear who, if anyone, was in charge.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lanka descended into political chaos Wednesday, as the unpopular president fled the country and protesters overran the interim leader’s offices, leaving it unclear who held power or how long it would last.

headline: A Safe Passage for Grain
abstract: A naval expert explains what it would take to demine ports in the Black Sea.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Hawaii, the last state with an indoor mask mandate for public schools, will make masks optional.
abstract: Masks will become optional in Hawaii’s schools when the new academic year starts on Aug. 1, as the state tries for “a more normal classroom experience this fall,” a state health official said.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii has stuck with mask mandates longer than any other state. It waited until late March, when the first Omicron surge was receding, to drop its requirement for most indoor public settings — and even then, the requirement was retained for public schools.

headline: Five Things Learned From the Webb Telescope’s First Images
abstract: There is a lot more universe out there to see than there was before the telescope launched, and there is so much more to explain.
lead_paragraph: NASA on Tuesday released five images from the early work of the James Webb Space Telescope. The pictures highlighted the great potential of the telescope to plumb the secrets of deep space. Below are some of the things we have learned so far.

headline: What Are Your Lessons for the Next Pandemic?
abstract: We’re looking for your best advice for surviving a plague, no matter how big or small.
lead_paragraph: When we look back on the coronavirus pandemic, there were so many mistakes. Leaders initially dismissed masking as a preventive measure, testing was a total mess, and doctors and nurses spent months without the tools they needed to combat the disease.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Thursday Briefing: Sri Lanka’s Leader Flees
abstract: Plus President Biden visits Israel, and negotiations continue over Ukraine’s blocked grain.
lead_paragraph: For hours yesterday, it was not clear who was in charge of Sri Lanka.

headline: The BA.5 Wave
abstract: The most transmissible Omicron variant yet is causing a fresh wave of cases.
lead_paragraph: The most transmissible Omicron variant yet, BA.5, is causing a fresh wave of cases, reinfections and hospitalizations across the country. Some are calling this the “invisible wave” because it’s not registering in some of the metrics we use to track the disease.

headline: Beauty of the Old Course Upstages LIV Golf Angst, for Now
abstract: Seven years is an unusually long gap, but the R&A, which runs the British Open, delayed a return to St. Andrews to ensure that it could host the tournament’s 150th edition, which begins Thursday.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The ruins of St. Andrews’s once-majestic cathedral are a reminder that this gray town by the sea was a pilgrimage site long before golf came along.

headline: Sunlit Apocalypse: The Imperiled World of Robert Adams
abstract: In a magisterial survey at the National Gallery of Art, the photographer discerns poetry even in degraded Western landscapes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert Adams photographs the landscapes of the contemporary American West, no matter how degraded, with the loving attention that his artistic forebears, Timothy H. O’Sullivan and Carleton E. Watkins, bestowed on sublime vistas in the 19th century. To borrow the words of the Polish poet Adam Zagajewski, he tries “to praise the mutilated world.”

headline: Where Does the Fight Over Abortion Rights Go After Roe?
abstract: The politics of abortion are only intensifying as states set about creating their own legal regimes.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

headline: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, Close Ally of Pope Francis, Dies at 87
abstract: An advocate for the poor, he was a force behind the progressive turn taken by many Latin American Catholics in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Cláudio Hummes, a Brazilian prelate in the Roman Catholic Church whose blend of doctrinal conservatism and social progressivism allowed him to move easily between the impoverished slums of Rio de Janeiro and the inner sanctums of the Vatican, especially during the tenure of his close friend Pope Francis, died on July 4 at his residence in São Paulo. He was 87.

headline: Ex-C.I.A. Engineer Convicted in Biggest Theft Ever of Agency Secrets
abstract: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan said Joshua Schulte had engaged in “one of the most brazen and damaging acts of espionage in American history.”
lead_paragraph: A former Central Intelligence Agency software engineer was convicted by a federal jury on Wednesday of causing the largest theft of classified information in the agency’s history.

headline: Royals Will Play Without 10 Unvaccinated Players in Toronto
abstract: Andrew Benintendi, Whit Merrifield and eight others will be placed on the restricted list ahead of Kansas City’s four-game series against the Blue Jays.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Benintendi, an All-Star outfielder and a potential trade target of multiple teams ahead of next month’s deadline, is one of 10 Kansas City Royals players who are unvaccinated against Covid-19 and will be placed on the restricted list before their team’s four-game series in Toronto that begins Thursday.

headline: Biden, Battered at Home, Basks in Unvarnished Praise in Israel
abstract: The U.S. president, on the first day of a trip to the Mideast, received the sort of rapturous welcome he can only dream about in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage on Biden’s trip to Israel and Saudi Arabia

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Will Turn Over Evidence on Fake Electors to the Justice Dept.
abstract: The department has asked the House committee investigating the Capitol attack to share transcripts regarding the false electors scheme, the only topic it has broached with the panel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has asked the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol for evidence it has accumulated about the scheme by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies to put forward false slates of pro-Trump electors in battleground states won by Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2020.

headline: Jan. 6 and the Search for Direct Trump Links
abstract: The House panel investigating the Capitol riot has yet to find a proverbial smoking gun directly connecting the former president to the extremist groups that led the storming of the building. Is there one?
lead_paragraph: The House panel investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol held another blockbuster hearing on Tuesday, which featured previously unseen texts and draft social media posts suggesting that Donald Trump and his aides tried to make the march on the Capitol appear spontaneous even though they knew they were guiding a mob that was likely to turn violent.

headline: Reflecting on a Times Luminary
abstract: Francis X. Clines left a mark on this newspaper and the world around him.
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning and on Saturdays.

headline: Video Deepens Uvalde Families’ Pain as Questions on Response Remain
abstract: A delayed police response to the May 24 school shooting has been described and debated, but a new 77-minute video showing it in painful detail has rekindled outrage.
lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Families of those killed in a mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas, in May voiced a mix of sorrow and anger on Wednesday after seeing a video showing how armed officers stood around waiting before confronting the gunman.

headline: Suspect Is Arrested in Ohio After Rape of 10-Year-Old Girl
abstract: The case became a flash point in the abortion debate after the young victim was forced to travel out of state for the procedure.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio man has been arrested and charged with the rape of a 10-year-old girl, whose travel across state lines to receive an abortion captured national attention.

headline: Delta flew a plane from Heathrow to the U.S. just to deliver 1,000 pieces of stranded luggage.
abstract: The London airport’s capacity troubles because of staff shortages and soaring demand have contributed to delays, cancellations and lost bags.
lead_paragraph: A Delta Air Lines plane packed with luggage but no passengers was flown from Heathrow Airport in London to Detroit this week, a Delta spokesman said on Wednesday. The luggage belonged to Delta customers who had recently traveled through Heathrow and were separated from their bags because of travel disruptions.

headline: In Pictures: Sri Lanka’s Protesters Persist After President’s Departure
abstract: Many digesting the news of Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s exit appeared to relish witnessing a monumental day in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt departure of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka early Wednesday did little to quell the ire of protesters who have been filling the streets of the capital, Colombo, for months demanding his resignation.

headline: Florida Company Recalls Ice Cream Linked to Listeria Outbreak, F.D.A. Says
abstract: The recall by Big Olaf Creamery came as federal authorities are investigating its products, which have been linked to infections that led to one person’s death and the hospitalization of two dozen.
lead_paragraph: A Florida business is recalling its ice cream amid an investigation into a listeria outbreak that has been blamed for the death of one person and the hospitalization of two dozen, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.

headline: A Day of Mourning in Ohio, Where a Young Black Man Was Killed by Police
abstract: Protesters have gathered regularly in downtown Akron since the death of Jayland Walker. The city has imposed a nightly curfew.
lead_paragraph: AKRON, Ohio — Hundreds of mourners filled a downtown Akron theater on Wednesday to pay their last respects to Jayland Walker, a young Black man killed by police officers, in a city that has been on edge since his death.

headline: U.S. Tells Pharmacists Not to Withhold Pills That Can Cause Abortion
abstract: New Biden administration guidance warned that failing to dispense such drugs “may be discriminating” on the basis of sex or disability, citing other conditions that they can treat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration warned the nation’s 60,000 retail pharmacies on Wednesday that they risk violating federal civil rights law if they refuse to fill prescriptions for pills that can induce abortion — the second time this week that it has used its executive authority to set up showdowns with states where abortion is now illegal.

headline: Differing views of a Ukrainian nationalist’s role in the Holocaust expose divisions over the past.
abstract: BERLIN — It was as if Ukraine’s ambassador in Germany was vying for the title of most undiplomatic diplomat: Determined to spur Berlin into more urgent support for his embattled nation, he mocked the chancellor, told a former lawmaker to “shut your trap,” and posted memes on Twitter likening Germany’s lagging weapons deliveries to a snail with a bullet taped to its back.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was as if Ukraine’s ambassador in Germany was vying for the title of most undiplomatic diplomat: Determined to spur Berlin into more urgent support for his embattled nation, he mocked the chancellor, told a former lawmaker to “shut your trap,” and posted memes on Twitter likening Germany’s lagging weapons deliveries to a snail with a bullet taped to its back.

headline: House Passes Bill to Expand Health Benefits for Burn Pit Exposure
abstract: The legislation would make millions of veterans exposed to the toxic pits eligible for medical and nursing home care, one of the largest expansions of benefits in history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Wednesday passed a bill that would make millions of veterans who were exposed to trash burn pits on U.S. military bases around the world eligible for medical care, the most sweeping action by the federal government to recognize that the sites may have caused a range of diseases.

headline: Trump: A Brat, but Not a Child
abstract: Trump should not escape responsibility for his self-imposed ignorance.
lead_paragraph: “President Trump is a 76-year-old man. He is not an impressionable child. Just like everyone else in our country, he is responsible for his own actions and his own choices.”

headline: Storms Drench Southwest Virginia, With Flooding, Landslides and Home Damage
abstract: The authorities in Buchanan County said that the 44 people who were initially reported missing had all been located by Thursday, after flooding damaged more than 100 homes.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people who had been initially reported missing had all been accounted for by Thursday afternoon, after powerful storms swept through southwestern Virginia, bringing heavy flooding and landslides and damaging more than 100 homes, officials said.

headline: Like the Results of Loaded Dice
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld fights fire with … well, you’ll see.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — There is an element in Alan Arbesfeld’s puzzle that may inspire those who are just pushing themselves beyond Wednesday crosswords to say, “Wait, you’re allowed to do that?”

headline: The U.S. accuses Russia of war crimes, alleging hundreds of thousands of Ukrainian deportations.
abstract: Ukrainian officials have long sounded the alarm on Russia’s deportations, but U.S. officials had previously been vague about their scale.
lead_paragraph: Russian authorities have  “interrogated,  detained, and forcibly deported” between 900,000 and 1.6 million Ukrainian citizens, including 260,000 children, from their homes into Russian territory, often to isolated regions in the far east, U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Georgia Mayor Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison for Stealing Covid Relief Money
abstract: Jason Lary used hundreds of thousands of dollars of federal funds to pay off the mortgage on his lakefront home and outstanding taxes, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The former mayor of Stonecrest, Ga., a small city outside Atlanta, was sentenced on Wednesday to four years and nine months in prison for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars in federal money intended to help his city cope with the pandemic, the authorities said.

headline: Priests Once Aligned With Russia Come Under Suspicion in Ukraine
abstract: The Ukrainian Orthodox Church was once a dominant force in the country, but now officials suspect that some priests may be collaborating with Russia.
lead_paragraph: RIVNE, Ukraine — A priest doused in green dye during a Sunday liturgy. Another yanked out of his western Ukrainian church as the police stood by watching. A church attacked by vandals, who filled it with foam, plastered the walls with portraits of Stalin and later set it on fire.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Gas prices are falling.
lead_paragraph: After climbing for months, gasoline prices have declined for 28 days in a row, giving consumers a welcome break. Energy analysts say American consumers are spending $140 million less on gasoline daily than they were a month ago. But the trend could easily reverse, especially if a hurricane knocks out a refinery on the Gulf Coast, since global oil supplies remain fairly tight.

headline: The Philippines Has a New Liar in Chief
abstract: Truth and accountability will not be hallmarks of Marcos 2.0.
lead_paragraph: When Ferdinand Marcos Jr. was sworn in as president of the Philippines on June 30, he took his oath in front of the former legislative building where his father entered politics and swore on the same Bible used by the elder Mr. Marcos at his 1965 inauguration.

headline: Corrections: July 14, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on March 9 about the discovery of the wreck of the Endurance, which sank in the Antarctic in 1915 during an expedition by the explorer Ernest Shackleton, misstated the point at which Shackleton joined Endurance on what would be the ship’s final voyage. He came aboard in Argentina; he was not on the ship when it left England. This correction was delayed, because the error was only recently brought to the attention of editors.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Firefighters Are Using Sprinklers to Protect A Treasured Giant Sequoia in Yosemite
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday July 14, 2022.
lead_paragraph: ‘I’ve counted a lot of dead giant sequoias, and I don’t like it. It’s like counting dead people. It clobbered me.’

headline: ‘That’s Between Them and God.’ 12 Pro-Life Voters on Abortion in America.
abstract: Twelve abortion opponents discuss the end of Roe.
lead_paragraph: Twelve abortion opponents discuss the end of Roe.

headline: 10 Pro-Choice Voters on Who’s to Blame for the End of Roe
abstract: Ten abortion rights supporters discuss the new American reproductive landscape.
lead_paragraph: Ten abortion rights supporters discuss the new American reproductive landscape.

headline: Municipal Workers Have Joined the Great Resignation
abstract: New York City employees are back in the office, and many of them are not happy about it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at why municipal workers in New York City are quitting. We’ll also meet someone who’s not rattled by rattlesnakes, on the job or off.

headline: Witnesses testify in Brittney Griner’s defense as her drug trial continues in Russia.
abstract: The case of an American sports star at the mercy of Russian justice has rippled across the world amid criticism from Washington that she has been wrongfully detained.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses for the defense praised Brittney Griner’s athletic prowess and character on Thursday in a courtroom outside Moscow, where the American basketball star — now one of the world’s most famous prisoners — is facing a possible 10-year sentence on drug charges.

headline: Israel is between governments (again). Will Biden’s visit help the interim leader get elected?
abstract: President Biden’s visit during an Israeli election campaign may have been unavoidable, given that voters are heading to the polls for a fifth time in under four years.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Biden, who prides himself on having known every Israeli prime minister over half a century, met on Thursday with a new one: Yair Lapid, the leader of a caretaker government.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Covering, and Contextualizing, Boris Johnson
abstract: Mark Landler went from the White House beat and President Trump to the London bureau, where Prime Minister Boris Johnson kept journalists just as busy.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Mark Landler, The Times’s London bureau chief, was out to dinner with family when he received word that Boris Johnson, Britain’s prime minister, was suddenly in deep political peril because of two cabinet resignations. He canceled his food order and rushed home to start writing coverage of the news.

headline: ‘French Girl Beauty’ Has a New Offering
abstract: Garance Doré, one of the original style bloggers, has released a beauty line based on her favorite pharmacy brands.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, Garance Doré went on a silent retreat. Over the course of six days at Spirit Rock in Northern California, she had a hard time not speaking to Emily Yeston, her roommate and business partner.

headline: Love and Carriage
abstract: A rarefied group of history buffs and horse enthusiasts meets in upstate New York for an annual drive with their horses.
lead_paragraph: I was never one of those little girls who devoured books or movies about horses, whether it was reading Anna Sewell’s 19th-century classic “Black Beauty” or watching a 12-year-old Elizabeth Taylor’s violet eyes sparkle with delight whenever she hugged her spirited gelding in “National Velvet.” The embarrassing truth is that I’m afraid of horses: of the way their eyes look out watchfully from the sides of their head, of their huge nostrils, of the possibility — faint but real — that they will sink their oversize yellow choppers into my soft flesh in a moment of skittishness or fear. As for horses and carriages, I had thought they were an artifact firmly of the past, like bustles and coachmen wearing powdered wigs.

headline: Netanyahu met with Biden, offering praise and a warning.
abstract: The U.S. president has often spoken fondly of Israel’s former prime minister, but relations between the two have also had low points.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has finished meeting with Israel’s opposition leader, former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Israel urges the U.S. to put pressure on Iran.
abstract: Prime Minister Yair Lapid asked the U.S. to show Iran that it would take military action if Tehran continued its nuclear enrichment program, highlighting Israel’s opposition to U.S.-backed efforts to persuade Iran through diplomacy alone.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Yair Lapid of Israel urged the United States on Thursday to show Iran that it would take military action if Tehran continued its nuclear enrichment program, highlighting Israel’s opposition to U.S.-backed efforts to persuade Iran through diplomacy alone.

headline: Avignon Festival Gets Its Buzz Back
abstract: With striking premieres in the main program and enchanting discoveries on the supplementary Fringe, the eminent event in European theater is flourishing after some difficult years.
lead_paragraph: AVIGNON, France — After two years of pandemic-related disruption, the Avignon Festival is well and truly back. As the event, a longtime highlight on the European theater calendar, got underway here last week, there were familiar sights everywhere. All around the small city center, buzzing crowds filled the streets, while blasé regulars zigzagged between performers handing out fliers for some 1,570 Fringe productions.

headline: ‘Putin’s War Must Be a Strategic Failure,’ Biden Says in Israel
abstract: Ukraine policy has been a point of friction between Israel and the United States.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Biden restated his determination that Russia fail in its Ukraine ambitions, speaking on Thursday during a four-day visit to Israel and Saudi Arabia in which he and other leaders discussed the international response to the war and the global grain shortage it has exacerbated.

headline: He Wanted a New Condo (With a Bathroom Sink) for Less Than $1 Million. These Were His Options.
abstract: Feeling not ‘established enough for a co-op board,’ an East Village renter searched one-bedroom apartments in newer buildings. By the time he found one, it was a home for two.
lead_paragraph: Feeling not ‘established enough for a co-op board,’ an East Village renter searched one-bedroom apartments in newer buildings. By the time he found one, it was a home for two.

headline: Poem: Portrait of D17: Female, 37 Years Old
abstract: A meditation on skulls, in which the skulls themselves get to have an opinion.
lead_paragraph: This poem is part of a sonnet sequence that meditates on Andrea Modica’s photographs of skulls unearthed from the Colorado Mental Health Institute in Pueblo. In this sonnet (there’s a dropped line in the poem, making it technically 15 lines — one more than a traditional sonnet), the speaker compares two kinds of skulls: anonymous skulls at the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum in Phnom Penh and the tagged and mounted skulls in Colorado. Paisley Rekdal’s poems are often struck with intellect, and this one is no different — in the second part of the poem during the volta, or the turn in a sonnet, the skulls are animated with their own opinions. The syntax mirrors a thinking mind. Note all the interruptions, from the em-dash after “rain,” to the commas, to the colon after “witnesses,” to the line breaks, as if to say that the only way to make sense of horror is to populate it with the turning language of logic.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What to Call Your Wife
abstract: A couple disagrees on how to get your spouse’s attention.
lead_paragraph: Ben writes: My wife, Maegan, hates when I use her name to get her attention. She prefers I call her “honeybee.” We were at a restaurant, and the hostess told me our table was ready. Maegan was a ways away, so I spoke her name loudly. (If shouting is a seven, this was a six.) She didn’t like it, but it worked. May I address her this way in time-sensitive situations?

headline: Meryl Streep’s One Weird Trick
abstract: The dramatic removal of eyeglasses is a cinematic cliché. On Streep, it’s a revelation.
lead_paragraph: The dramatic removal of eyeglasses is a cinematic cliché. On Streep, it’s a revelation.

headline: My Dog’s Death Taught Me Spiritual Detachment. Then My Sister Got Sick.
abstract: When she got cancer, she started joking about life without her. I was not amused.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after my parents died in 2017, I nearly lost custody of my dog, Zoe, in my divorce. When we were reunited, I remember telling her firmly, “You cannot die now,” even though she had just turned 15.

headline: The Big Ten Is Growing, but All I See Is Decline
abstract: The identities of collegiate conferences are disappearing like regional accents.
lead_paragraph: Philip Larkin once wrote that all historians of jazz are either H.G. Wells or Edward Gibbon — “onwards and upwards, or decline and fall.” It’s the relentless progress of Wells’s “Outline of History” or the inexorable doom of Gibbon’s Roman Empire.

headline: Which States Are the Most Safe and Secure for Renters?
abstract: A recent study examined natural disasters, eviction rates and rental laws to determine where U.S. renters could feel most at home.
lead_paragraph: The United States has experienced nine weather or climate disasters so far this year that have caused at least $1 billion in damages, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The agency also reported that above-normal temperatures were in the forecast for most of the country this summer. With extreme weather on the rise, people may be wondering which areas are safer than others to find a new home.

headline: Elon Musk Bought Twitter. Now He Must Own It.
abstract: A deal of this magnitude can generate value for Twitter and create stability for future mergers.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is trying to walk away from his $44 billion agreement to buy Twitter, but the Court of Chancery in Delaware, where the company is incorporated and is now suing Mr. Musk, should order him to buy the social media company.

headline: His Ship Finally Came In, but Should He Be on It?
abstract: The pandemic marooned Charles Falls Jr. on land for nearly two years. Now he’s setting sail again.
lead_paragraph: Since the Covid pandemic started, we’ve all had to make endless decisions about what is worth the risk — eat out or stay home, attend a best friend’s wedding or watch the livestream, go on vacation or cancel it again. But going into Year 3, that calculus has lost its urgency for many people. This summer’s chaotic travel season is evidence enough.

headline: In Battle to Beat Democratic Titans, a Lawyer in Sneakers Bets on Youth
abstract: New Yorkers are witnessing an epic primary clash between Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Carolyn Maloney. Suraj Patel is trying to eke out his own path to victory.
lead_paragraph: Suraj Patel has few illusions about what he’s up against as he takes on two titans of New York politics, Representatives Carolyn Maloney and Jerrold Nadler, in this summer’s blockbuster Democratic primary. But he does take hope from a theory about coffee shops.

headline: ‘Drive to Survive’ Made Americans Fall in Love With Formula 1
abstract: The Netflix show sold the European sport to a U.S. audience. But will the romance last after the series is gone?
lead_paragraph: One Thursday morning in May, the Formula 1 driver Valtteri Bottas was enjoying an alfresco breakfast with his girlfriend, the cyclist Tiffany Cromwell, on the secluded terrace of a South Beach hotel. It was a last bit of vacation before the start of practice sessions for that weekend’s Miami Grand Prix. Bottas and Cromwell had spent an hour biking along the beach. Now they were sitting under a trellis of bougainvillea, chatting casually in the way that romantic partners do.

headline: U.S. Electric Car Sales Climb Sharply Despite Shortages
abstract: A scarcity of semiconductors and raw materials held back production, but buyers remain enthusiastic.
lead_paragraph: Americans are buying electric vehicles at a record pace, undeterred by rising prices and long waits for delivery, a further indication that the twilight of the internal combustion engine is on the horizon.

headline: Janeane Garofalo Never Sold Out. What a Relief.
abstract: That concept might be the reason her trailblazing stand-up career has been overshadowed; it may also be the reason she’s still so sharp, our critic argues.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy Wednesday night in Brooklyn, after an introduction with a minimum of fanfare, Janeane Garofalo walked onstage at the Eastville Comedy Club and looked out at a dozen people so scattered that calling them a crowd seems like a stretch. She spotted one man by himself who had attended a show of hers a few days earlier and happily pointed him out.

headline: How to Invest When Inflation Is Bad and a Recession May Loom
abstract: While the news may indicate that the markets and economy are rocky, long-term investors can ride it out with a little luck and a lot of planning, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The news on inflation has been bad for months, but it’s recently gotten worse. On Wednesday, the government reported that in June the Consumer Price Index rose at an annual rate of 9.1 percent — the fastest pace since November 1981.

headline: The Magic of Your First Work Friends
abstract: Early-career connections can be life-defining. For young people entering the work force today, the connections over Zoom are shaky.
lead_paragraph: The things that Lisa Degliantoni learned at 22 from the two best friends she met at her New York City publishing job included but were not limited to:

headline: For a Woman in a Wheelchair, Abortion Access Was One More Challenge
abstract: Roxanne Schiebergen, a writer and actress, has become skilled at navigating New York City since she was a student at N.Y.U. Then came an unexpected pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Roxanne Schiebergen, a 30-year-old writer and actress who lives in New York, was in the bathroom of her Midtown apartment when she received a text from a close friend one day in May. The text included a screenshot of a marketing flyer promoting a “Bans Off Our Bodies” rally sponsored in part by Planned Parenthood. The photo in the ad showed four women — and the woman at the center was in a wheelchair.

headline: Toronto Steps Into Summer
abstract: It’s the city’s traditional high season and it is celebrating with newly opened hotels and restaurants and a revived live-performance scene.
lead_paragraph: Canada’s biggest city and North America’s fourth-largest metropolis, Toronto received more than 27.5 million visitors annually before the pandemic, making it Canada’s top tourism destination, according to Destination Toronto, the city’s tourism-marketing arm.

headline: Young Voters Are Fed Up With Their (Much) Older Leaders
abstract: Led by politicians often three times their age, many voters under 30 are hungry for new blood and new ideas.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Chadwick went to the polls in 2020 with the single goal of ousting Donald J. Trump. A 22-year-old first-time voter, she saw Joseph R. Biden Jr. as more of a safeguard than an inspiring political figure, someone who could stave off threats to abortion access, gun control and climate policy.

headline: The Housing Shortage Isn’t Just a Coastal Crisis Anymore
abstract: An increasingly national problem has consequences for the quality of American family life, the economy and the future of housing politics.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Washington have long failed to build enough housing to keep up with everyone trying to live there. And for nearly as long, other parts of the country have mostly been able to shrug off the housing shortage as a condition particular to big coastal cities.

headline: China’s Surveillance State Hits Rare Resistance From Its Own Subjects
abstract: Beijing’s swift move to censor news about one of the largest known data breaches shows keen awareness of how major security lapses can harm its credibility.
lead_paragraph: Chinese artists have staged performances to highlight the ubiquity of surveillance cameras. Privacy activists have filed lawsuits against the collection of facial recognition data. Ordinary citizens and establishment intellectuals alike have pushed back against the abuse of Covid tracking apps by the authorities to curb protests. Internet users have shared tips on how to evade digital monitoring.

headline: For New York’s Anti-Abortion Veterans, Roe’s Fall Is Not a Full Victory
abstract: Checking in with activists from sanctuary states who have spent more than 50 years fighting abortion.
lead_paragraph: For local veterans of the anti-abortion movement, the Supreme Court’s June 24 decision reversing Roe v. Wade came with a sobering reminder: In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, nothing had changed.

headline: Biden’s Saudi Lesson: The Only Path Runs Through M.B.S.
abstract: President Biden tried to isolate Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over human rights abuses. Now, the United States needs Saudi Arabia, and Mr. Biden is about to visit.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Saudi Arabia that President Biden will visit this week is a country being actively reshaped by the whims and visions of one man: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

headline: For Young Offenders, Restitution Debts Can Present Crippling Obstacles
abstract: A new report asserts that ordering juvenile offenders to pay compensation to their victims often derails their lives, and victims’ rights groups see shortcomings as well.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Arabella Guevara spent much of her adolescence paying for her mistakes.

headline: A strike on the Ukrainian city of Vinnytsia kills at least 23 people, officials say.
abstract: Dozens were wounded in the rocket attack on the city, according to emergency officials.
lead_paragraph: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — A volley of Russian cruise missiles hit a shopping center, a dance studio and a wedding hall in central Ukraine on Thursday, killing at least 23 people and setting off a frantic search for dozens more lost in the rubble, in a latest strike to hit a civilian area far from the front lines.

headline: How Sri Lanka’s Economy Collapsed
abstract: Amid food and fuel shortages, a protest movement has pushed for the resignation of the president and others tied to his family’s political dynasty.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, the political crisis in Sri Lanka has reached a critical point, with its president fleeing the country and protesters occupying his residence and office. Today, “The Daily” explores how the island nation, whose economy was once held up as a success story in South Asia, came apart — and why it’s a cautionary tale.

headline: The Impossible Task of Keeping Up With the Ingebrigtsens
abstract: The Kardashians of Norway are middle-distance runners who have competed on the global stage. But it’s Jakob, 21, who transformed from onetime prodigy to generational talent.
lead_paragraph: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. — Jakob Ingebrigtsen is surrounded by silence, all those empty spaces between workouts and competitions. As the fastest miler in the world, he is aware of the peculiarities of his profession.

headline: The Semiconductor Problem
abstract: The military relies on advanced semiconductors. The U.S. doesn’t make any.
lead_paragraph: The most advanced category of mass-produced semiconductors — used in smartphones, military technology and much more — is known as 5 nm. A single company in Taiwan, known as TSMC, makes about 90 percent of them. U.S. factories make none.

headline: What is the I2U2?
abstract: The name of a new partnership between India, Israel, the United Arab Emirates and the United States refers to the first letters of the four countries’ names in English.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — I2U2 sounds as though it might be a cross between a legendary Irish rock band and a droid from “Star Wars.”

headline: Brittney Griner’s case shows the limits of American power.
abstract: As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner’s continued detention in Russia, many in America have wondered publicly if U.S. officials could be doing more to secure Griner’s release. LeBron James, the argument goes, would have been freed long ago.
lead_paragraph: As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner’s continued detention in Russia, many in America have wondered publicly if U.S. officials could be doing more to secure Griner’s release. LeBron James, the argument goes, would have been freed long ago.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Dance and More
abstract: I’m a general assignment reporter on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a general assignment reporter on The Times’s Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: ‘Paws of Fury: The Legend of Hank’ Review: A Tail of Two Samurai
abstract: Michael Cera and Samuel L. Jackson lend their voices to this unlikely animated adaptation of Mel Brooks’s “Blazing Saddles.”
lead_paragraph: Michael Cera stars as an anthropomorphic dog, who is in training to be a samurai, and Samuel L. Jackson plays his washed-up feline mentor in Paramount’s latest animated family flick, “Paws of Fury: The Legend of Hank.” The film sounds like standard CGI family fare, until you learn that the movie, originally titled “Blazing Samurai,” is a PG adaptation of Mel Brooks’s 1974 satire of Western films and race relations, “Blazing Saddles.”

headline: ‘Mrs. Harris Goes to Paris’ Review: High Fashion for the Humble
abstract: This inspirational comedy starring Lesley Manville and Isabelle Huppert trades in a similar kind of British coziness as the “Paddington” movies, though it’s not nearly as effective.
lead_paragraph: In “Mrs. Harris Goes to Paris,” Lesley Manville returns to the world of high fashion in a reversal of her Oscar-nominated role in “Phantom Thread.” Her deliciously frigid character in that film — the forbidding manager of a British fashion house and foe to Vicky Krieps’s lowborn muse — would go catatonic were Manville’s Mrs. Ada Harris to waltz into the fitting room, asking for a “frock” with her cockney drawl.

headline: ‘She Will’ Review: Payback Is a Witch
abstract: A traumatized star is supernaturally primed for vengeance in this gorgeously ghostly thriller.
lead_paragraph: The first name we see onscreen in “She Will” belongs not to its director (Charlotte Colbert) or its star (Alice Krige), but to one of its executive producers, the horror maestro Dario Argento. And it doesn’t take long to recognize the ways in which the plot of this confident first feature (written by Colbert and Kitty Percy) might have appealed to Argento: The emphasis on dreams, the sly humor and — perhaps most of all — the despoilment of female beauty.

headline: ‘Costa Brava, Lebanon’ Review: Paradise Tossed
abstract: In Mounia Akl’s ambitious debut feature, a family’s attempts to escape the filth of Beirut go awry when the garbage follows them to their doorstep.
lead_paragraph: As civic emergencies go, few possess the symbolic clarity of a garbage crisis. They’re ugly. They stink. They signify dysfunction, rot and toxicity in ways that need no sorting.

headline: ‘Don’t Make Me Go’ Review: Sharp Curves Ahead for Next 2,000 Miles
abstract: John Cho and Mia Isaac play a father and daughter on a road trip in this twisty drama, which explores the gulf between familiarity and intimacy.
lead_paragraph: “You’re not going to like the way this story ends,” Wally (Mia Isaac), 15, warns the audience at the start of “Don’t Make Me Go,” a father-daughter drama of startling honesty and humor. Max (John Cho), Wally’s protective single dad, has learned that his headaches aren’t just from the struggle of parenting his restless teenager. A cancer diagnosis gives him one year to live — and instead of coming clean about his condition, Max packs up their wood-paneled Jeep for a road trip with an ulterior motive: To take a surprise detour to introduce Wally to her mother (Jen Van Epps), who ran away with Max’s best friend (Jemaine Clement) when the girl was an infant.

headline: ‘Persuasion’ Review: The Present Intrudes Into the Past
abstract: Dakota Johnson smirks her way through a Netflix adaptation of the rekindled romance in Jane Austen’s last novel, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: The great irony of this new, not-quite-modernized adaptation of Jane Austen’s final novel, “Persuasion,” is that it communicates its tense relationship to its 19th-century source material in a repressed, passive-aggressive manner — an approach oddly suited to Austen’s trenchant view of society. The film doesn’t take the creative leap to transpose the beloved story in the present day. Instead, in curiously excruciating fashion, the director, screenwriters, and star imply their discomfort with Georgian-era social norms from within the novel’s period setting.

headline: ‘Anonymous Club’ Review: The Joy of Creation
abstract: The Australian singer-songwriter Courtney Barnett goes on a world tour in this music documentary, and finds that a change is needed.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter Courtney Barnett started out as a DIY artist, home-recording energetic songs communicating knotty feelings. Early in this documentary, written and directed by Danny Cohen, a cheery interviewer leads into a question by saying that it’s not too common to hear artists “singing about panic attacks.” This reflects more on the limited listening experience of the interviewer than anything else, but you get the idea.

headline: Janet Yellen Says It’s in Russia’s Interest to Go Along With an Oil Price Cap
abstract: Facing sanctions on its exports, Russia could continue selling oil profitably under a cap, the U.S. Treasury secretary said, while global strains on supply and pressure on prices would reduce.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of a meeting of finance chiefs from the world’s major economies in Bali, Indonesia, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen continued to push for a price cap on Russian oil, calling it “one of our most powerful tools” to alleviate the painful leaps in energy and food prices.

headline: Italy’s Unity Government Teeters, as Mario Draghi Offers to Resign
abstract: The country’s president refused to accept the prime minister’s resignation, leaving the country in political limbo.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s golden period of stability suddenly seemed on the familiar precipice of chaos on Thursday after Prime Minister Mario Draghi tendered his resignation in response to a revolt by anti-establishment populists within his broad national unity government.

headline: Biden calls for a ‘lasting negotiated peace’ between Israel and the Palestinians.
abstract: He also reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Biden called on Thursday for a “lasting negotiated peace between the State of Israel and the Palestinian people” and reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.

headline: Science and Data Change Soccer’s Definition of Old
abstract: Top clubs have long looked to shed players once they hit age 30. But those presumptions rely on outdated logic, statistics show.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The exact location of the threshold has always been contested. At Manchester United, for a time, it lurked close enough to 30 for that to serve as a natural watershed. Once players hit their 30s, Alex Ferguson, the club’s manager at the time, tended to grant them an extra day’s rest after a game, in the hope that the break might soothe their creaking bodies.

headline: ‘Queen of Glory’ Review: Back to the Bronx
abstract: In the writer-director Nana Mensah’s amusing and astute feature debut, a death forces a reckoning for a brainy young Ghanaian-American living in both worlds.
lead_paragraph: Molecular neuro-oncologist Sarah Obeng is very smart. But in the subtle delight “Queen of Glory” — written and directed by its lead actor, Nana Mensah — the American daughter of Ghanaian parents can be foolish, too. Take her married boyfriend and university colleague, Lyle (Adam Leon): He’s simply not worthy.

headline: Amazon Moves to End a Long-Running Antitrust Case in Europe
abstract: The retail giant said it would stop collecting nonpublic data on rivals and give merchants more ways to reach customers.
lead_paragraph: Amazon tried on Thursday to end a three-year investigation by antitrust regulators in the European Union by offering to make a series of changes to its business practices and give rival merchants an easier way to reach customers on its website.

headline: What Californians Need to Know About Monkeypox
abstract: More than 150 cases have been reported so far in the state, and most are in San Francisco or Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve probably heard of monkeypox, the latest disease making headlines as it spreads across the world.

headline: Biden, Oil and the Middle East
abstract: Under pressure as tight oil supplies hurt the U.S. economy, Biden will go to Saudi Arabia for a meeting with M.B.S.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase reported earnings this morning that were lower than forecasts, as it set aside bigger reserves to cover bad loans, a possible ominous sign for the rest of the banking sector. Its C.E.O., Jamie Dimon, said the bank was suspending share buybacks. Morgan Stanley’s earnings also fell short of expectations.

headline: Twitter suffers a global outage at a delicate moment for the company.
abstract: The social networking site went offline on Thursday morning, affecting users worldwide. The interruption comes as the company is fighting Elon Musk over a proposed acquisition.
lead_paragraph: Twitter, the social media giant with 330 million active users, was back online on Thursday morning after reports of a worldwide outage that came at a sensitive time for the company, which is locked in a heated legal battle with the billionaire Elon Musk over its acquisition.

headline: My Friends Were Terrible Guests. Why Won’t They Apologize?
abstract: After allowing close friends the use of a getaway home, a reader struggles to forgive their poor behavior as houseguests.
lead_paragraph: I let friends stay at my lake house for a long weekend while I was away. I returned to six loads of dirty laundry, furniture moved all over the place and a pile of water toys in my shed — without so much as a thank-you note for letting them stay. I was upset and let them know it. Not only did they fail to apologize, they criticized my reaction (and questioned the amount of laundry they had actually left). I feel gaslit. These people are like family to me, but I’m not sure I can forgive them. Their response to my complaint was worse than the original inconsiderate behavior. What can I do?

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Bronstein
abstract: Take on David Bronstein in a recreation of an 18th World Championship game in Moscow, 1951. Solve for the best series of moves.
lead_paragraph: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

headline: A London Restaurant Inspired by Ghana’s Chop Bars
abstract: Plus: a clothing store with a Greek cafe, furniture fashioned from branches and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York City
abstract: This week’s available properties are in Downtown Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and Lenox Hill.
lead_paragraph: This week’s available properties are in Downtown Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and Lenox Hill.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York City
abstract: This week’s available properties are in Downtown Brooklyn, Hell’s Kitchen and Lenox Hill.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and on Long Island
abstract: This week’s available properties are a seven-bedroom mansion in Edgewater Park, N.J., and a four-bedroom farmhouse in Orient, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s available properties are a seven-bedroom mansion in Edgewater Park, N.J., and a four-bedroom farmhouse in Orient, N.Y.

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and on Long Island
abstract: This week’s available properties are a seven-bedroom mansion in Edgewater Park, N.J., and a four-bedroom farmhouse in Orient, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: With Few Able and Fewer Willing, U.S. Military Can’t Find Recruits
abstract: Fighting headwinds from the pandemic, the tight labor market and demographic shifts, the armed forces may fall further short of enlistment quotas this year than they have in decades.
lead_paragraph: FOUNTAIN, Colo. — The local Army recruiting station was empty. The normally reliable recruiting grounds at the nearby Walmart were a bust. With the Army still thousands of soldiers short of its recruiting goal, the station commander, Sgt. First Class James Pulliam, dressed head to toe in camouflage, scanned a strip-mall parking lot for targets.

headline: U.K. Issues an Unprecedented Heat Warning
abstract: For the first time, the country’s national weather service issued its most severe weather warning for heat, with record-breaking temperatures expected early next week.
lead_paragraph: Britain is bracing for its hottest day ever as a heat wave sweeps across Europe. Follow live updates here.

headline: A Photographer Follows Paul Revere Williams Into the West
abstract: The architect’s achievements transformed the landscape of Nevada but were obscured by racism. Janna Ireland’s exhibition changes that.
lead_paragraph: Paul Revere Williams came by his nickname “architect to the stars” over a career that saw his designs dot the wealthiest enclaves of Southern California, leaving a silver-screen-size impact during the decades coinciding with Hollywood’s golden era. He created homes for Frank Sinatra and Lucille Ball, among others, and helped erect elegant municipal, federal and commercial developments as far afield as Washington, D.C. In two best-selling books, he championed affordable housing for a new generation of homeowners.

headline: Sri Lanka’s President Resigns After Months of Protest
abstract: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka submitted his resignation by email from Singapore, although the political uncertainty continues.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka, who fled his country early Wednesday after months of fervent protests blaming him for the country’s economic collapse and widespread hardship, officially resigned on Thursday, setting off celebrations in his homeland.

headline: ‘Earwig’ Review: Danse Macabre
abstract: The latest trip down the rabbit hole by the French director Lucile Hadzihalilovic follows a young girl with teeth made of ice and her cadaverous caretaker.
lead_paragraph: Near the beginning of “Earwig,” the latest trip down the darkest of rabbit holes by the French director Lucile Hadzihalilovic, a 10-year-old girl admires a landscape painting, seated before it in an image similar to the famous scene from “Poltergeist.” Fascinated, she runs her fingers over the rough canvas and its vibrant colors; it’s a moment not unlike the experience of watching the film, which can feel like being hypnotized by disturbingly palpable still lifes from the unconscious realm.

headline: Has remote work changed your relationships with colleagues?
abstract: Tell us about your experience with work friendships when you’re not in the office.
lead_paragraph: Office occupancy across the United States is still less than 50 percent of its prepandemic levels. Many people are working from home, which comes as a relief to some workers while others find it harder to socialize with their colleagues. Some have found inventive ways of staying connected, whether through virtual gatherings, instant messaging or in-person retreats.

headline: Big Banks Prepare for Downturn, but Don’t See Recession Yet
abstract: As profits slowed at Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan Chase, executives said that lending to consumers and businesses remained healthy but that risks loomed “down the road.”
lead_paragraph: Slowing demand and sinking markets have put an end to a period of record-setting profits for the country’s biggest banks, but that doesn’t mean a recession is imminent, top bankers say, even if it may look like they are preparing for one.

headline: Man Exonerated in Malcolm X Murder Sues New York City After Talks Fail
abstract: Muhammad A. Aziz filed the $40 million claim on Thursday, seeking redress for a conviction that overshadowed 55 years of his life.
lead_paragraph: New York’s criminal justice system took 55 years to acknowledge that it had wrongly branded Muhammad A. Aziz as one of Malcolm X’s killers.

headline: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
abstract: The Oscar-winning actor will face a trial in June 2023 — a rare example of a celebrity #MeToo case reaching that stage in Britain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Kevin Spacey, the Oscar and Tony Award-winning actor, pleaded not guilty to charges of sexual assault on Thursday, British prosecutors said.

headline: How Mo Farah Outran His Sad Beginnings
abstract: The distance runner, who said this week that he was trafficked to the United Kingdom as a child, trained under Alberto Salazar on his way to becoming a four-time Olympic gold medalist.
lead_paragraph: My first meeting with him was inadvertent, clandestine. It occurred in Albuquerque in October 2010. I had traveled there to write about another runner, the American Dathan Ritzenhein, as he trained for that year’s New York City Marathon with his new coach, Alberto Salazar, a former star who had morphed into an eccentric tailor, making alterations to Ritzenhein’s posture and stride.

headline: ‘The Deer King’ Review: Medicine, Family and Empire
