lead_paragraph: The fastest inflation in four decades has Americans feeling dour about the economy, even as their own finances have, so far, held up relatively well.

headline: This Home-Renovation Show Wants to Get You Into Bed
abstract: The new Netflix series “How to Build a Sex Room” doesn’t just indulge fantasies. It helps people rediscover some intimacy in their homes.
lead_paragraph: As far as home improvements go, sex rooms are not generally considered smart financial investments. What future buyer would want anything to do with someone else’s adults-only romper room?

headline: The Weekender
abstract: How the images from the Webb telescope were selected. Also in this edition: Meryl Streep’s trick and the rebranding of Victoria’s Secret.
lead_paragraph: How the images from the Webb telescope were selected. Also in this edition: Meryl Streep’s trick and the rebranding of Victoria’s Secret.

headline: Parkland School Gunman Faces Death Penalty in Rare Trial
abstract: A Florida jury will decide if the young man who killed 17 people in 2018 will be sentenced to death.
lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates on the trial of the Parkland school shooting gunman, who faces the death penalty.

headline: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi makes the case for grilling cucumbers, new recipes for fried okra, and more.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. There is no outdoor gas grill not improved by a griddle pan set on the grates above the flames. You can use the smooth surface to cook fillets of fish, or to smash burgers down into bacon fat. It’s brilliant for toasting buns for lobster rolls or hot dogs, for searing pork and peaches, for crisping sweet potatoes with ginger and miso.

headline: The Problem in Coaching Style Without Substance
abstract: England’s 8-0 thrashing of Norway was a stunning triumph. But it also exposed a failure of leadership.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates of the Euro 2022 final.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include films about women in defense and a kidnapping prank gone wrong.
lead_paragraph: Anyse (Billur Melis Koc), an unfaithful wife, is caught with her lover by her husband, Sedat (Ahmet Rifat Sungar). After Sedat executes the man, Anyse flees to her family in Turkey, only to discover they’ve disowned her. Relegated to hiding in the woods, she must kill Sedat and the men helping him if she hopes to live.

headline: NASA Shows Webb’s View of Something Closer to Home: Jupiter
abstract: The powerful telescope will help scientists make discoveries both within our solar system and well beyond it.
lead_paragraph: The new James Webb Space Telescope can capture photographs not only of galaxies across the universe, but also of objects in our celestial backyard.

headline: Should Trump Be Indicted?
abstract: Readers argue that Donald Trump should be indicted and discuss why his base still supports him. Also: Manchin vs. Biden’s plans; a 10-year-old rape victim; abortion travel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Big Banks Send Mixed Signals on Economic Outlook
abstract: In their latest financial reports, Wells Fargo showed signs of trouble but Citigroup revealed results that were better than expected.
lead_paragraph: Two more big banks provided updates on the fragile state of the economy on Friday, with one showing signs of trouble and the other managing to capitalize on conditions that are hurting its peers.

headline: An American Climate Failure
abstract: The collapse of climate legislation is a blow to global efforts to address warming.
lead_paragraph: As millions of people on three continents baked in heat waves supercharged by climate change this week, one American politician, an ardent champion of the fossil fuel industry, doused any hopes of immediate climate action in Washington.

headline: 200 Years Later, Charleston Honors Denmark Vesey’s Attempted Uprising
abstract: Vesey tried to organize an insurrection in 1822 to free enslaved people, but was caught and hanged. Now several prominent Charleston institutions are honoring the bicentenary.
lead_paragraph: Denmark Vesey, a formerly enslaved man who bought his freedom after winning the lottery, tried to organize a slave rebellion in Charleston, S.C., in 1822, making plans to execute white enslavers and sail to freedom in Haiti. But Charleston authorities halted the insurrection and hanged Vesey, along with nearly three dozen others.

headline: Frontier Airlines’ bid for Spirit faces an advisory firm’s opposition.
abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services said a rival offer from JetBlue was more valuable, despite concerns about regulatory hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The prospects for a proposed sale of Spirit Airlines to Frontier Airlines appear to be under threat as a prominent shareholder advisory firm reversed its guidance on the combination of the two budget carriers, recommending on Friday that Spirit’s investors reject the deal.

headline: 3 Imprisoned for Fiery 1995 Subway Murder Are Exonerated
abstract: The three men were convicted as teenagers for killing a subway token clerk after setting the booth ablaze, but New York police detectives elicited false confessions from them, prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: The killing was shocking even for a New York City awash in violence at the time.

headline: Fresh Data Give Fed Wiggle Room on Rates at July Meeting
abstract: Inflation expectations eased, even as retail sales looked strong. That gives central bankers room to stick to their rate plan — or speed it up.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Federal Reserve have been speaking out in favor of a three-quarter-point interest rate increase at their meeting this month, while leaving open the possibility of a larger move if economic data came in especially strong. Fresh economic figures released Friday could give them reason to move in either direction.

headline: 20 Easy Salads for Hot Summer Days
abstract: Using vibrant vegetables and fruits at peak freshness is a great way to eat well — and inexpensively — throughout the season.
lead_paragraph: Summer has many charms — the sun lingers late, fireflies abound and vegetables and fruit taste so good, they don’t take much effort to turn into delicious, satisfying dishes. Thankfully, fresh produce hasn’t risen in price as much as other ingredients this year and is especially flavorful now.

headline: Lizzo Conquers Self-Doubt With an ’80s Jam, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Brent Faiyaz, Pink, Marcus Mumford and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

headline: Biden Administration Retreats on Threat to Withhold Arizona Relief Funds
abstract: The Treasury disbursed $2.1 billion in pandemic aid after warning it could be withheld because the state had used aid money to undercut school mask mandates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration backed off its threat to withhold pandemic aid money from Arizona after accusing the state this year of misusing the funds to undercut school mask mandates.

headline: Sables and Minks and Chinchillas Galore: Ivana Trump’s Opulent Style
abstract: Dennis Basso, a longtime friend and furrier, recalls his many collaborations with the first Ms. Trump.
lead_paragraph: “Ivana Trump’s look wasn’t for everyone,” the designer Dennis Basso said Thursday afternoon, a few hours after Ms. Trump’s death was announced by former President Donald J. Trump, her ex-husband, in a statement posted on his social networking platform, Truth Social.

headline: Biden Concedes Defeat on Climate Bill as Manchin and Inflation Upend Agenda
abstract: Rising prices, party infighting and the aftershocks from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine have undercut the president’s plans to speed an energy transition.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden bowed to political reality on Friday, conceding that he had been unable to persuade a holdout coal-state Democrat, or any Republicans in the Senate, to back legislation that had been his greatest hope to confront the climate crisis.

headline: Fretting Over Spelling and Fussing Over Spacing on Deadline at the British Open
abstract: Garry Harvey, who once played the Open and now engraves the claret jug, has mere minutes to prepare one of the most famous trophies in sports as millions watch.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The good news for Garry Harvey is that almost no one in this year’s British Open field has a name quite as long as Severiano Ballesteros — Spanish master of the short game, three-time Open champion and unwitting menace to a man with minutes to engrave one of golf’s most sacred trophies.

headline: ‘Son of Elsewhere’ Recounts Life as a Young Immigrant
abstract: Elamin Abdelmahmoud talks about his new memoir, and Sally Denton discusses “The Colony: Faith and Blood in a Promised Land.”
lead_paragraph: In “Son of Elsewhere,” Elamin Abdelmahmoud writes about growing up in Canada after moving there from Sudan when he was 12. On this week’s podcast, he talks about that experience, including his first interactions with his new peers.

headline: Recommended Reading on America’s Authoritarian Enclaves
abstract: Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and Robert Mickey’s “Paths Out of Dixie” help our columnist understand American democracy’s new crisis of authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: This week I have been reading about the United States in the 1960s and 70s, staying up late going back through Joan Didion’s “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and “The White Album,” and falling down rabbit holes of oral history interviews.

headline: After 350 Years of Tradition, a Boys’ Choir Now Admits Girls
abstract: The Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, is the latest English choir to start including female singers, a move some fear will reduce opportunities for boys.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, England — At 8 a.m. one recent Thursday, the boys of the Choir of St. John’s College, Cambridge, stifled yawns as they began their first rehearsal of the day with some vocal exercises. Soon, the room was filled with a host of “Ooo” and “Zah” sounds.

headline: Talking to the Dead Through Voice Mail: The Week in Narrated Articles
abstract: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Inflation Cooking
abstract: Chicken meatballs, tofu salad and more budget-friendly recipes.
lead_paragraph: Inflation is dominating the news, and all we seem to be talking about at New York Times Cooking (virtual) headquarters is how much groceries cost. My colleague Margaux Laskey has put together a list of 19 recipes that call for relatively cheap ingredients to help you through this time.

headline: Deshaun Watson’s Accusers Settle Their Claims Against the Texans
abstract: Thirty women reached settlements with the team Watson played for when he was accused of sexual misconduct during massage appointments. Four lawsuits against Watson are outstanding.
lead_paragraph: The Houston Texans have reached settlements with 30 women who have accused the N.F.L. quarterback Deshaun Watson of sexual misconduct in massage appointments, according to Tony Buzbee, the lawyer representing the women.

headline: With Tears and Hat Tips, Woods Bids Farewell, Perhaps, to St. Andrews
abstract: Tiger Woods missed the cut at the British Open, ending, he knows, what might have been his last competitive tournament on his favorite course.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — The roars at last ebbed when Tiger Woods reached his ball, if only because everyone knew the clamor could start again soon enough.

headline: ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Taika Waititi narrates a sequence from his film featuring a reunion between Thor (Chris Hemsworth) and Jane Foster (Natalie Portman).
lead_paragraph: Taika Waititi narrates a sequence from his film featuring a reunion between Thor (Chris Hemsworth) and Jane Foster (Natalie Portman).

headline: Watch Chris Hemsworth and Natalie Portman Reunite in ‘Thor: Love and Thunder’
abstract: The director Taika Waititi narrates a battle sequence that has the two connecting onscreen again.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: The Worst Place in the World to Drill for Oil Is Up for Auction
abstract: Oil exploration in the Congo rainforest would be a pollution disaster for communities that depend on it and for wildlife.
lead_paragraph: A vast rainforest stretches for 1,500 miles across central Africa. The mighty Congo River and its tributaries are the main highways into this hard-to-reach region.

headline: Civil Rights Memoirs
abstract: Three new books describe Blacks engaged in politics in the South.
lead_paragraph: A WAY OUT OF NO WAYA Memoir of Truth, Transformation, and the New American StoryBy Raphael G. Warnock288 pp. Penguin Press. $28.

headline: Four Ways the United States Can Still Fight Climate Change
abstract: With the president’s most potent tools to fight climate change stripped by Congress and the courts, the administration will now have to rely on smaller, less powerful actions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the largest and most powerful tools that President Biden had hoped to use to fight climate change now stripped away, the White House is assembling smaller, less potent policies that could still help the nation reduce its planet-warming pollution, though not at the levels that Mr. Biden once promised.

headline: Wonking Out: The Meaning of the Plunging Euro
abstract: This time, a weak currency does reflect a weak economy.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2001, my wife and I took a cycling tour in Burgundy. We loved the scenery, the wine, the food (except for the andouillette — yuck) — and the prices. The still-new euro was at a low point, worth fewer than 90 U.S. cents, and everything in France looked cheap.

headline: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Found Not Guilty in Federal Gun Case
abstract: Lawyers for the rapper argued that he did not know the weapon was in his car when he was pulled over and arrested on a separate warrant in California last year.
lead_paragraph: The chart-topping 22-year-old rapper YoungBoy Never Broke Again, born Kentrell D. Gaulden, was found not guilty on Friday of possessing a firearm and ammunition as a felon, concluding one of the two federal gun trials he had been facing.

headline: House Passes Two Bills Seeking to Ensure Access to Abortion
abstract: Neither piece of legislation has the votes to advance in the Senate, but Democrats intend them to draw clear lines on the issue for the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed two bills aiming at ensuring access to abortion in the post-Roe era, as Democrats seek to draw clear distinctions with Republicans on the issue heading into the midterm election campaign.

headline: The U.S. Has a New Crisis Hotline: 988. Is It Prepared for a Surge in Calls?
abstract: The United States is rolling out a reimagined suicide prevention number to address a national mental health crisis. But funding and staffing issues have left some questioning whether it’s ready.
lead_paragraph: Americans in distress have a new number to dial for help — 988, a revamped National Suicide Prevention Lifeline that is being billed as the 911 of mental health.

headline: Manchin Dangles Hopes of a Future Compromise. Democrats Revolt.
abstract: A day after the West Virginia senator scuttled plans to pass a climate and tax package, many in his party blamed him for the demise of their ambitions and expressed a lack of trust in him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a familiar, if excruciating, position for Democrats.

headline: Make the Most of Too Much Summer Squash With the Zucchini Slice
abstract: Popular in Australia and New Zealand, this cross between a frittata and savory quick bread is perhaps even better than either on its own.
lead_paragraph: If the phrase “zucchini slice” conjures an image of a round of the raw vegetable sitting next to the onion dip, it’s only because you haven’t been to Australia or New Zealand.

headline: Love Letter: Dear Friends and Strangers
abstract: When you’re stuck in an existential rut and a stranger needs a kidney.
lead_paragraph: What prompts someone to donate a kidney to a stranger?

headline: Biden and Saudi Crown Prince Ignore Question About Khashoggi
abstract: President Biden met Friday with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, who is believed to be responsible for the 2018 murder of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi dissident journalist and permanent resident of the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met Friday with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia, who is believed to be responsible for the 2018 murder of Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi dissident journalist and permanent resident of the United States.

headline: Biden Says ‘Ground Is Not Ripe’ for Mideast Peace Talks
abstract: President Biden’s comments Friday about a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict drew a mixed response. He cautioned Palestinians on starting new peace talks after announcing new steps toward Israeli integration within the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s comments Friday about a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict drew a mixed response. He cautioned Palestinians on starting new peace talks after announcing new steps toward Israeli integration within the Middle East.

headline: Review: In ‘Sex, Grift and Death,’ One-Acts That Test Perceptions
abstract: PTP/NYC, celebrating its 35th repertory season, returns to New York with short works by Steven Berkoff and Caryl Churchill.
lead_paragraph: Two strangers on a park bench by the beach, partnering in a vicious dance of seduction. A woman from a family of swindlers, lying her way through dates with a wealthy new beau. Mourners at a funeral, and the deceased man himself, facing the frightening notion of the future and the afterlife to come.

headline: How can I keep my pet cool and safe during a heat wave?
abstract: Extreme temperatures pose particular dangers to furry friends.
lead_paragraph: As extreme heat blankets large swaths of the globe, pet owners have particular cause for concern.

headline: Using Comedy to Push for Abortion Rights
abstract: Lizz Winstead, the “Daily Show” co-creator, has marshaled her contacts in the standup world to help supporters turn protest into action.
lead_paragraph: “Things are awesome — never better!” joked Lizz Winstead, the comedian, producer and abortion rights activist. “Sleeping well; no diarrhea. Things are awesome.”

headline: Texas and its power system prepare for more high temperatures.
abstract: Readings of 100 or more are forecast throughout the coming week in much of the state.
lead_paragraph: After several days when triple-digit temperatures tested the ability of the Texas electric grid to keep power flowing, another round of extreme heat threatens the state.

headline: Watch Live: Biden Delivers Remarks in Saudi Arabia
abstract: President Biden met with King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on his first visit to Saudi Arabia as president.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met with King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on his first visit to Saudi Arabia as president.

headline: Build Back Better Is a Health Care Bill Now
abstract: Only two provisions in a once-sprawling social spending package have survived; they would lower prescription drug prices in Medicare and insurance premiums for millions of Americans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Democrats in Congress had hoped to pass a broad domestic policy package that would expand the social safety net, raise taxes on corporations and the wealthiest Americans, and tighten regulation of climate-changing pollutants. But the decision by Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia to withdraw his support from other aspects of an already-shrunken package this week leaves nothing but health care on the table.

headline: L.Q. Jones, Who Played Heavies With a Light Touch, Dies at 94
abstract: His face was familiar, mostly in westerns, during a career that spanned five decades. He also directed the cult film “A Boy and His Dog.”
lead_paragraph: L.Q. Jones, a hirsute, craggy-faced, swaggering Texan who guilelessly played the antihero in some 60 films and dozens of television series, died on Saturday at his home in the Hollywood Hills area of Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Biden’s Mideast Message: Good News for Israel, Small Steps for Palestinians
abstract: To Israelis, President Biden’s visit was mostly a source of celebration of growing ties with Arab countries. For the Palestinians, Mr. Biden brought funding and sympathy — but no long-term plans.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Biden had contrasting messages for Israelis and Palestinians on Friday before departing Israel for Saudi Arabia, announcing new steps toward Israeli integration within the Middle East while cautioning Palestinians that now was not the time for new peace talks to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Living Through Texas’ Hottest Summer
abstract: The high in Dallas has been at least 100 degrees for 11 days this month, with no relief in sight. Here's how one New England transplant is surviving.
lead_paragraph: The high in Dallas has been at least 100 degrees for 11 days this month, with no relief in sight. Here's how one New England transplant is surviving.

headline: The president said he rebuked the Saudi crown prince for the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.
abstract: Mr. Khashoggi, a Saudi contributor to The Washington Post who was critical of the prince’s rule, was killed in Istanbul in 2018.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said Friday night that he brought up the murder of Jamal Khashoggi during his closed-door meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and told the prince that he considered him to blame.

headline: Largest Study to Date Shows How Covid Vaccines Affect Periods
abstract: For some, a side effect of getting vaccinated was a change in menstrual cycles — but experts say there is no cause for alarm.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of the participants of a recent study who were menstruating regularly at the time of the survey reported heavier bleeding during their periods after receiving the Covid-19 vaccine. Others who did not typically menstruate — including transgender men, people on long-acting contraceptives, and post-menopausal women — also experienced unusual bleeding.

headline: Soprano Withdraws From Opera, Citing ‘Blackface’ in Netrebko’s ‘Aida’
abstract: The American soprano Angel Blue said she would not appear at the Arena di Verona after the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko and other performers wore dark makeup in its production of “Aida.”
lead_paragraph: A leading American soprano, Angel Blue, announced this week that she was withdrawing from her planned debut at the Arena di Verona in Italy to protest its use of “blackface makeup” in a production of Verdi’s “Aida” that starred the Russian soprano Anna Netrebko.

headline: Beto O’Rourke broke a Texas fund-raising record with a $27.6 million haul, his campaign said.
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott, the Republican incumbent who maintains an advantage in cash on hand, raised nearly $25 million over the same period.
lead_paragraph: Beto O’Rourke set a new Texas fund-raising record for state office with a $27.6 million haul over four months in the governor’s race, his campaign announced on Friday, saying that it had outpaced Gov. Greg Abbott, the Republican incumbent, in the tightening contest.

headline: Are Middlemen Really Profit-Making Parasites?
abstract: Or do they make our lives easier?
lead_paragraph: We have a love-hate relationship with middlemen. We hate them — brokers or other intermediaries — because they can seem like profit-making parasites who needlessly insert themselves between customers and the people who actually make and do stuff. We try to get around middlemen by shopping at farmers’ markets, buying homemade goods straight from the makers on sites such as Etsy and directly supporting inventors and entrepreneurs by throwing money at them via GoFundMe.

headline: 5 Smart Comedy Specials From Veteran Stand-Ups
abstract: Joel Kim Booster, Nikki Glaser, Bill Burr, Fahim Anwar and Cristela Alonzo deliver strong hours ideal for summer viewing.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: I Need a Summer Hat That Isn’t a Baseball Cap. What Should I Wear?
abstract: Hats have become a semiological minefield. A reader wonders how to navigate it.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, in the 19th and early 20th centuries, a hat was a basic part of an adult wardrobe — the finishing touch as one went out the door, serving as both protection and social uniform.

headline: A Country Refuge for London Creatives
abstract: Somerset has re-emerged as an English weekend idyll, with inspired restaurants, stately homes turned hotels and contemporary art institutions.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to T Wanderlust, a new travel newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Twice a month, we’ll recommend global destinations and hotels worth visiting. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every other Friday, along with our T List newsletter each Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: Ask a Flight Attendant About Flying Now
abstract: Whether you have travel anxieties or you’re just curious about what really goes on behind the curtain, you can finally get your questions answered.
lead_paragraph: Flying can be a high-stress activity now. What if my flight gets canceled? What if the airline loses my luggage? On top of airline dramas, the risk of Covid-19 while traveling still looms uneasily.

headline: What Biden Got Right on His Trip to the Middle East
abstract: There is real value in making small steps through diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden campaigned and won as the antithesis to Donald Trump. To deliver on that promise in foreign policy, in his first year as president, he tried to offer “something for everyone,” as Anne-Marie Slaughter has argued: tough talk on China for the realists; a recommitment to NATO, to the Paris Agreement on climate, and to the World Health Organization for the liberal internationalists; an end to the forever wars; and, for the idealists, a willingness to speak up for human rights.

headline: Vaccine protection waned this spring but boosters helped, the C.D.C. reports.
abstract: “Booster doses should be obtained immediately when persons become eligible,” the C.D.C. scientists wrote.
lead_paragraph: The emergence of highly contagious Omicron subvariants this spring in the United States appeared to reduce the protection offered by vaccines against Covid hospitalizations, scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.

headline: Elon Musk Claps Back at Twitter’s Lawsuit Over $44 Billion Deal
abstract: Mr. Musk formally responded to Twitter’s attempt to force him to buy the company, arguing that there was no reason to hurry the case.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk accused Twitter on Friday of deceiving him about its service, obfuscating facts and not notifying him of executive changes, in his first formal response to the company’s lawsuit aimed at forcing him to complete a $44 billion acquisition of the social media service.

headline: The War on Ukrainian Culture
abstract: The Times critic at large tells us why Ukrainian culture plays an outsized role in the war.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Drug Kingpin Convicted of Killing D.E.A. Agent Is Captured in Mexico
abstract: Rafael Caro Quintero, an accused drug cartel leader, was convicted of killing Enrique Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and was wanted by the F.BI.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A drug kingpin convicted of orchestrating the torture and murder of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent was captured in northern Mexico on Friday, according to Mexican officials, bringing a case that has long been a source of tension with the United States one step closer to resolution.

headline: Mexican Activists Answer Calls for Abortion Pills From the U.S.
abstract: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the U.S. Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, the phones and social media accounts of abortion rights activists in Mexico have been inundated with desperate requests for abortion pills from people in the U.S.

headline: In a Flash of Fire and Shrapnel, a Smiling 4-Year-Old’s Life Is Snuffed Out
abstract: A toddler with Down syndrome was happily pushing a stroller through a Ukraine park before a Russian missile landed. “I want to shout out to the whole world,” an anguished survivor of the attack cried.
lead_paragraph: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine — They called her Sunny Flower. She had just learned her first words. She liked to clean the corridor at the speech therapy center she attended, and organize the toys. She always seemed happy.

headline: Biden Drops Plan to Name Anti-Abortion Lawyer Backed by McConnell as Judge
abstract: The White House quietly agreed with the Senate Republican leader to nominate Chad Meredith for a federal judgeship, but opposition from his fellow Kentuckian Rand Paul scuttled the deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is abandoning plans to nominate a Kentucky lawyer who opposes abortion rights and is backed by Senator Mitch McConnell to a federal court seat, citing opposition from Senator Rand Paul, Mr. McConnell’s home-state colleague.

headline: Ivana’s New York
abstract: In the 1980s and ’90s, Ivana was on a first-name basis with a city transfixed by fame and fashion.
lead_paragraph: In the more-is-more New York of the 1980s and 1990s, when Ivana Trump was at the height of her powers, “social media” consisted of party pages and gossip columns, and the best way to make your name was to go out. A lot.

headline: Demand for Monkeypox Vaccine Exceeds Supply, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The United States has ordered nearly seven million doses in total, but most of them will not arrive for months.
lead_paragraph: As the monkeypox outbreak grows in the United States, demand for the vaccine is outstripping the nation’s supply, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said at a news briefing on Friday.

headline: Ivana Trump’s Death Is Ruled Accidental
abstract: Ms. Trump, an ex-wife of former President Donald J. Trump, died by blunt impact injuries, according to New York City’s chief medical examiner.
lead_paragraph: Ivana Trump, the ex-wife of former president Donald J. Trump, died accidentally of blunt impact injuries to her torso, according to New York City’s chief medical examiner.

headline: China’s Economic Covid Slump
abstract: The country’s continued lockdowns are having consequences on its ability to do business.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic engine is shuddering. The country’s National Bureau of Statistics said today that the economy expanded by only 0.4 percent in the second quarter. It was smaller than expected and the lowest growth since the early months of the pandemic.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: The Knights of Medieval Times Will Carry Union Cards With Their Lances
abstract: The horsemen, courtiers, stablehands and other performers at ye olde New Jersey tourist attraction formed a new kind of medieval guild when they voted to unionize.
lead_paragraph: LYNDHURST, N.J. — In 11th-century Spain, a nobleman trying to put his hand up the queen’s skirt after a royal feast might be subjected to medieval torture methods.

headline: Staten Island Ferry Cuts Service, Linking Virus to Crew Shortages
abstract: Rush-hour trips will take about five minutes longer for the next couple of weeks.
lead_paragraph: The Staten Island Ferry system is temporarily running less frequently during rush hours — a service cutback that the New York City Department of Transportation linked to a surge in coronavirus infections among staff members.

headline: In Space, U.S.-Russian Cooperation Finds a Way Forward
abstract: The two countries’ astronauts will swap seats on each other’s rockets, and Vladimir Putin dismissed the leader of the Russian space agency, who had become known for bellicose outbursts.
lead_paragraph: When SpaceX next launches a Falcon 9 rocket to the International Space Station, one of the astronauts aboard will be Russian.

headline: Nikole Hannah-Jones and University Settle Hiring Dispute
abstract: Ms. Hannah-Jones, who won a Pulitzer Prize for the 1619 Project, had said she was considering legal action against the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
lead_paragraph: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has reached a settlement with Nikole Hannah-Jones, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist for The New York Times Magazine, after a dispute over tenure, the school said on Friday.

headline: 2 Arrested in String of Fatal 7-Eleven Robberies, Police Say
abstract: The crimes, which occurred at six 7-Eleven stores in Southern California on Monday, left two dead and three others injured, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two Los Angeles men were arrested on Friday in connection with a string of robberies at 7-Eleven stores in Southern California on Monday in which two people were fatally shot and three others injured in a crime spree that terrorized the region, the authorities said.

headline: Capturing the Cosmos
abstract: Turning distant galaxies into sound.
lead_paragraph: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: At the British Open, It’s the PGA Tour Faithful Against LIV Golf
abstract: “Everybody, it feels like, is against us, and that’s OK,” said Talor Gooch, a LIV golfer tied for eighth at seven under after the second round. Cameron Smith held the lead at 13 under par.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Tiger Woods was finishing up at the Old Course on Friday, perhaps for good, and Rory McIlroy was just getting started.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel to Dissect Trump’s 187 Minutes of Inaction During Riot
abstract: The House committee investigating the attack announced it would hold its next hearing on Thursday in prime time. It was not clear whether it would be the summer finale, as once expected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is planning to return to prime time on Thursday for what could be the finale of its summer hearing schedule: a session focused on former President Donald J. Trump’s 187 minutes of inaction as a mob of his supporters assaulted Congress.

headline: What Is the Free State Project?
abstract: Our guest writer Dan Barry explains the history behind a New Hampshire movement whose temporary victory galvanized a small town.
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter is a guest dispatch from Dan Barry, who wrote in The New York Times on Sunday about how the surprise victory of a hardcore libertarian movement in a small New Hampshire town led to swift backlash — and a harsh lesson in the importance of showing up to vote. Here, Dan explains the group behind the clash.

headline: Document Shows Uvalde Officials Sought Favorable Account of Police Action
abstract: Top Uvalde officials wanted to highlight the heroics of officers at Robb Elementary. The state police director refused to do so.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Days after the massacre at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, the leaders of the grieving city fumed during a closed-door meeting with Steven McCraw, the state’s top police official.

headline: The Republican National Convention Is Likely Headed to Milwaukee in 2024
abstract: The decision is not final and the Republican National Committee must approve the choice during its summer meeting early next month.
lead_paragraph: Republican officials are poised to choose Milwaukee to host their 2024 national convention, with the party’s site selection committee voting in favor of the city, a Democratic stronghold in a Midwest battleground.

headline: David Dalton, Rock Writer Who Lived the Scene, Dies at 80
abstract: An early writer for Rolling Stone, he traveled in the same circles as the Beatles, Janis Joplin and other stars, witnessing and documenting a time of cultural transformation.
lead_paragraph: David Dalton, who chronicled the rock scene as an early writer for Rolling Stone and brought firsthand knowledge to his biographies of rock stars from having lived the wild life alongside them, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 80.

headline: Biden’s Fraught Saudi Visit Garners Scathing Criticism and Modest Accords
abstract: In the most politically problematic trip of his presidency, Mr. Biden’s critics accused him of helping rehabilitate the reputation of a tarnished prince in exchange for numerous, but limited gains.
lead_paragraph: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — President Biden exchanged the shaken fist for a fist bump on Friday as he abandoned his promise to make Saudi Arabia a “pariah” and sat down with the crown prince he deemed responsible for the grisly killing and dismemberment of a columnist who lived in the United States.

headline: ‘Governors Are the C.E.O.s’: State Leaders Weigh Their Might
abstract: At a National Governors Association gathering, attendees from both parties speculated about 2024 at a moment of increasing frustration with Washington.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Maine — A single senator put parts of President Biden’s domestic agenda in grave danger. The president’s approval ratings are anemic amid deep dissatisfaction with Washington. And as both Mr. Biden, 79, and Donald J. Trump, 76, signal their intentions to run for president again, voters are demanding fresh blood in national politics.

headline: Prosecutor Warns Georgia Officials They May Face Charges in Trump Inquiry
abstract: The investigation could prove to be one of the most perilous legal problems facing the former president and his allies.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The breadth, speed and seriousness of the criminal investigation into election meddling by former President Donald J. Trump and his associates in Georgia were underscored on Friday by the revelation that two pro-Trump state senators and the chair of the state Republican Party were sent letters by an Atlanta prosecutor informing them they could be indicted, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.

headline: Mark Fleischman, the Last Impresario of Studio 54, Dies at 82
abstract: He took over the celebrated Manhattan club in the early 1980s and briefly became the self-described “ringleader” of an all-night circus.
lead_paragraph: Mark Fleischman, who presided over the raucous, drug-crazed denouement of the celebrity-studded Manhattan disco Studio 54 in the early 1980s, died on Wednesday in Switzerland. He was 82.

headline: 40 Years After Her Murder, ‘Princess Doe’ Has a Name
abstract: She was found dead in a New Jersey cemetery in 1982 and became known worldwide as Princess Doe. On Friday, she was identified as Dawn Olanick, 17.
lead_paragraph: For four decades, Princess Doe was known only as a girl whose short life ended violently.

headline: Comic-Con issues a mask mandate, not the costume kind, for event in San Diego.
abstract: Organizers said they expected more than 135,000 people at the convention, while the community level of Covid-19 in the county is high, according to the C.D.C.
lead_paragraph: Comic-Con International, which considers itself the oldest pop-culture convention in the world, is returning to San Diego for its first major in-person event since before the coronavirus pandemic began, and masks will be mandatory.

headline: Initiate Post Production?
abstract: Kameron Austin Collins rescues us with an endearing Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I always expect a challenge when I see Kameron Austin Collins’s byline, but I got into a nice flow working on this grid (though I’d never presume to be getting good at this, especially after last Saturday) and found its personality more amiable than angsty. Mr. Collins makes wonderfully creative themeless grids, full of catchy trivia references and thousand-dollar words. This puzzle also has several humorous touches that are worth a second look, if you’ve done well on your first round of solving.

headline: M.L.B. to Pay $185 Million Settlement in Minor League Wage Dispute
abstract: The agreement provides only a modest sum to most players but could speed up the overhaul of how minor leaguers are compensated in the future.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball agreed to pay $185 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by thousands of current and former minor league players over past wage claims.

headline: At Least 6 Killed in Montana Pileup During Dust Storm
abstract: More than 20 vehicles were involved after a windstorm caused “near-blackout” conditions, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: At least six people were killed and others were injured in southern Montana in a major car pileup on Friday afternoon during a windstorm that kicked up dust and caused “near-blackout conditions,” the authorities said.

headline: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
abstract: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.
lead_paragraph: Starting in first grade, students across Russia will soon sit through weekly classes featuring war movies and virtual tours through Crimea. They will be given a steady dose of lectures on topics like “the geopolitical situation” and “traditional values.” In addition to a regular flag-raising ceremony, they will be introduced to lessons celebrating Russia’s “rebirth” under President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Sharp Drop in Global Childhood Vaccinations Imperils Millions of Lives
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Parents don’t know the impact of measles, or of polio, so they start to pick and choose vaccinations. Parents are choosing not to do polio. They say, ‘It’s been 30 years with no polio, so do I need to do this?’”

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 16, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio who crossed state lines to get an abortion and became a flash point in the national abortion debate misstated Bill O’Reilly’s connection to The First, a conservative media outlet. He is a host for the outlet, not the owner.

headline: Jan. 6 Panel Issues Subpoena to Secret Service in Hunt for Text Messages
abstract: The House committee is seeking messages that an inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security said had been erased.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the attack on the United States Capitol issued a subpoena to the Secret Service late Friday seeking text messages from Jan. 5 and 6, 2021, that were said to have been erased, as well as any after-action reports.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Egypt’s Revolving Jailhouse Door: One Pretrial Detention After Another
abstract: An analysis of handwritten records shows that thousands of Egyptians have been detained without charge, sometimes for years.
lead_paragraph: An analysis of handwritten records shows that thousands of Egyptians have been detained without charge, sometimes for years.

headline: How We Counted Egypt’s Invisible Detainees
abstract: There was no public accounting of the prisoners in the black hole of Egypt’s indefinite pretrial detention. Until now.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times investigation found that Egypt is holding thousands of people in a system of pretrial detention that can be extended indefinitely, stretching Egyptian laws limiting such detention and allowing the government to imprison people without having to prove its case in a trial.

headline: How to Deal With a Difficult Doorman
abstract: What bothers one person may not bother another, but when enough residents band together to complain, action often follows.
lead_paragraph: Q: My co-op building has a new doorman who does not perform his duties. He never opens the door. He leaves packages unattended and overnight in the lobby. He’s loud and indiscreet, converses on the phone, is often away from the desk and can be hostile and defiant to shareholders and guests. What recourse do shareholders have? Can we withhold the portion of maintenance that goes toward his salary if his performance does not improve?

headline: The Dollar Is Extremely Strong, Pushing Down the World
abstract: The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing other currencies and unsettling the global economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing other currencies and unsettling the global economic outlook.

headline: Dead but Not Buried, Ex-President’s Body Sparks a Cross-Continental Fight
abstract: José Eduardo dos Santos ruled Angola for 38 years. But he died in Spain. A dispute over where to lay him to rest has divided his family and could decide the fate of his political party.
lead_paragraph: LUANDA, Angola — Even in death, Angola’s longtime ruler, José Eduardo dos Santos, is at the center of political infighting.

headline: What’s Wrong (and Sometimes Right) With American Men?
abstract: Isaac Fitzgerald’s “Dirtbag, Massachusetts” is a memoir about male misbehavior and the struggle to make sense of oneself.
lead_paragraph: Forgive us men, for we have sinned. Some of us more than others, few of us as prodigiously and joyfully as Isaac Fitzgerald, whose new memoir, “Dirtbag, Massachusetts,” chronicles his upbringing as the accidental byproduct of sin between two divinity students; his turbulent and violent childhood; his years of drugging, day drinking, scrapping, bartending and acting in porn; along with a sideline of missionary work in two Southeast Asian war zones. He describes his book as a “confessional,” although the only actual scene of confession we get is when young Isaac describes an early sexual encounter to an overly alert priest, who Isaac later suspects was masturbating while listening.

headline: 6 Months Into Term, Eric Adams Raises $850,000 for Re-election in 2025
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has traveled across the country to court donors, receiving contributions from casino and sports betting executives.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Eric Adams was confronted last month with troubling poll numbers, he gave an optimistic interpretation: He said he had earned a C grade from many New Yorkers.

headline: Another Pain Point in a Summer of Travel Woes: Getting a Passport
abstract: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.
lead_paragraph: It’s a summer of headaches for travelers: Airfares are surging, checked bags are disappearing, and flights are being canceled in record numbers. And now there’s another pain point to add to the mix. If you’re in need of a new or updated passport, your options are limited — and it’s likely going to cost you.

headline: A Middle Eastern Party Scene Is Thriving on Brooklyn’s Dance Floors
abstract: Several New York City parties offer spaces where anyone and everyone can let loose, come together and find comfort in Middle Eastern and North African music.
lead_paragraph: Just before midnight on a Friday in June, a short line formed outside Elsewhere, a music venue and nightclub in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Saphe Shamoun, one of the D.J.s performing that night, gingerly approached two women in the queue.

headline: A Warren Buffett Protégée Strikes Out on Her Own
abstract: Tracy Britt Cool spent a decade working closely with the renowned investor. She is now applying those lessons to her own firm.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Britt Cool always knew she wanted to work in business. So, not unlike the star of a high school musical asking Steven Spielberg for a part, she figured she should start at the top.

headline: The Key Insights From Our First Poll of the 2022 Midterms
abstract: A summary of the findings includes deep dissatisfaction among voters and potential fertile ground for new candidates in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Which side has the most energy heading into November? More polls will come as the midterm elections near, but for now we’ve wrapped up our first New York Times/Siena survey, and here are some notable takeaways:

headline: They Couldn’t Believe Their Eyes: The Ocean Was Glowing.
abstract: Satellites previously detected a giant bioluminescent bloom in the Java Sea. Researchers found a boat crew that sailed through it.
lead_paragraph: Naomi McKinnon knew something was up, but she was not sure what. She went below deck for a minute, then rejoined her two crewmates on watch.

headline: The World Economy Is Imperiled by a Force Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Well more than two years into the worst pandemic in a century, the accompanying economic shock continues to assault global fortunes.
lead_paragraph: This past week brought home the magnitude of the overlapping crises assailing the global economy, intensifying fears of recession, job losses, hunger and a plunge on stock markets.

headline: Did Nature Heal During the Pandemic ‘Anthropause’?
abstract: Covid precautions created a global slowdown in human activity — and an opportunity to learn more about the complex ways we affect other species.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
abstract: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.
lead_paragraph: HEATHROW — The travelers’ destinations were varied: a hotly anticipated vacation in Amsterdam, a conference in Ohio, a family reunion in Austria.

headline: Turbulence on the Ground at Toronto’s Pearson Airport
abstract: Airports around the world are struggling to keep pace with the summer travel boom.
lead_paragraph: The disorder at Toronto Pearson International Airport was visible from the sky.

headline: Can’t Talk, I’m Busy Being Hot
abstract: A social media movement inspired by the rapper Megan Thee Stallion strikes back at the gatekeepers of beauty.
lead_paragraph: Edwyna Estime was wearing a heavy, shapeless graduation gown. It was the color of charcoal and it reached all the way down to her ankles. And yet she had never felt hotter.

headline: An unspoken result of Biden’s meeting with Prince Mohammed: A setback in the Khashoggi case.
abstract: President Biden’s dropping of his resistance to speak with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seems to signal the end of official U.S. efforts to seek justice for the slain journalist.
lead_paragraph: Since entering the White House, President Biden had refused to meet with, and even speak to, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia, seeking to punish him with ostracism for the grisly murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in 2018.

headline: Salad Days
abstract: When it comes to making the perfect summer salad, sometimes less is more.
lead_paragraph: I have spent more kitchen hours than I care to admit trying, in vain, to recreate the Caesar salad dressing of a certain Midtown Manhattan lunch spot.

headline: Wildfires, and a Heat Wave, Sweep Across Europe
abstract: Fires in the south of France have burned more than 22,000 acres and prompted widespread evacuations. Britain was bracing for record high temperatures early next week.
lead_paragraph: Britain is bracing for its hottest day ever as a heat wave sweeps across Europe. Follow live updates here.

headline: Wind, Of Course, Goethe and Shame
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Hello, readers.

headline: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
abstract: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.
lead_paragraph: An Italian government crisis, once so frequent as to be a near nonevent, has exposed the fragility of a Europe contending with rising energy prices, a plunging currency, faltering leadership, and a war in Ukraine where time appears to favor Russia’s autocratic resolve over the West’s democratic uncertainty.

headline: Raving for Shrek, the Swamp Comes to Brooklyn
abstract: A party in East Williamsburg invited fans of the 2001 film to translate into reality their online obsessions with the titular ogre.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night at the Brooklyn Monarch, a music venue in East Williamsburg, the 1999 Smash Mouth hit “All Star” rang through the speakers to kick the party off around 10 p.m., causing the crowd to erupt into dancing and a singalong.

headline: Texas Man Charged in Four Decades-Old California Murders
abstract: Officials said DNA evidence helped lead to the arrest of the man, who was charged in the 1980 and 1995 killings of three women and a teenager.
lead_paragraph: DNA evidence helped crack unsolved murders, some dating to 1980, of three women and a teenage girl in California, leading to the arrest of a 75-year-old man in Texas, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 11, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Irish Eyes Aren’t Smiling
abstract: A nation once in the grip of religious extremism sadly watches America’s lurch to the right on abortion.
lead_paragraph: GALWAY, Ireland — I came to Ireland four years ago to cover the searing story of the Scarlet Letter in the Emerald Isle.

headline: Biden Says He Confronted Saudi Prince Over Khashoggi. How True Is That?
abstract: Mr. Biden is by nature a storyteller with a history of relating dramatic tales of conversations with foreign leaders that others in the room do not recall the same way.
lead_paragraph: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — As President Biden told the tale, it sounded pretty dramatic.

headline: Why Is the World’s Biggest Track Meet in a Small College Town in Oregon?
abstract: Eugene, Ore., has spent more than a century evolving into “TrackTown.” On Friday, the World Athletics Championships opened in this unlikely destination.
lead_paragraph: World championships in track and field generally take place in world capitals. Rome, Beijing, Moscow, Paris and London have all taken a turn hosting the biggest event in the sport other than the Olympic Games.

headline: Allyson Felix’s victory lap wasn’t about the medal.
abstract: Felix won yet another world championship medal, her 19th. “I think I felt all the emotions,” she said of her final competitive race.
lead_paragraph: Allyson Felix didn’t know exactly how she wanted to start or finish her farewell tour.

headline: Here’s what to watch at the world Championships on Saturday.
abstract: Marcell Jacobs, the Tokyo Olympics gold medalist in the 100 meters, and Sifan Hassan, the Toyko Olympic gold medalist in the 10,000 meters, both return to the global stage.
lead_paragraph: Some of the biggest stars of the Tokyo Olympics will compete at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., on Saturday. Sifan Hassan, the dominant distance runner, is expected to make her return to global competition in the women’s 10,000 meters. And the Olympic gold medalist Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy will face a trio of American sprinters looking to sweep the men’s 100 meters.

headline: Unpredictable Maryland Governor’s Race Pits Old Guard vs. Upstarts
abstract: Will a deep-blue state elect another Republican governor to succeed Larry Hogan? Tuesday’s competitive primaries will signal where the race is headed.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — Tuesday’s primary elections for Maryland governor come at a moment when Democrats are jittery, unsure of the future and perhaps willing to bet on a flashy, unproven commodity.

headline: Biden’s Mideast efforts on oil have a precedent: Jimmy Carter’s.
abstract: Jimmy Carter flew to Tehran in 1977 to meet the shah of Iran.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden met Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in Jeddah on Friday, he was following in the footsteps of presidents like Jimmy Carter, who flew to Tehran in 1977 to exchange toasts with the shah of Iran on New Year’s Eve.

headline: You Asked, I Answer
abstract: Readers are curious about local government, cameras, cooking and more.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, I (along with the team that brings you this newsletter) thought it would be fun to do something a little different. Instead of writing another take or analysis, I’ll answer a few questions about myself — things you might be interested to know. These are the types of questions that I encounter on social media and that I often see whenever I do live chats or question and answer sessions.

headline: What Joe Manchin Cost Us
abstract: The senator’s legacy will be climate destruction.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year and a half, I’ve dissected every remark I could find in the press from Senator Joe Manchin on climate change. With the fate of our planet hanging in the balance, his every utterance was of global significance. But his statements have been like a weather vane, blowing in every direction. It’s now clear that Mr. Manchin has wasted what little time this Congress had left to make real progress on the climate crisis.

headline: Read William J. Olson’s Memo to Trump
abstract: William J. Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo in December 2020 to President Donald J. Trump on how to seek to overturn the election.
lead_paragraph: William J. Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo in December 2020 to President Donald J. Trump on how to seek to overturn the election.

headline: Little-Known Lawyer Pitched Trump on Extreme Plans to Subvert Election
abstract: The role of William J. Olson in advising the president in late 2020, which has not previously been disclosed, shows how fringe figures were influencing him at a critical time.
lead_paragraph: Around 5 in the afternoon on Christmas Day in 2020, as many Americans were celebrating with family, President Donald J. Trump was at his Mar-a-Lago home in Palm Beach, Fla., on the phone with a little-known conservative lawyer who was encouraging his attempts to overturn the election, according to a memo the lawyer later wrote documenting the call.

headline: A Body of One’s Own
abstract: My daughter’s life (and mine) in a post-Roe world.
lead_paragraph: My daughter’s life (and mine) in a post-Roe world.

headline: Forget Nostalgia. The Glory Days Are Now.
abstract: No need to pretend a past era of Michigan football was better than it was.
lead_paragraph: Memory, as we know, is fallible, heavily influenced by context and our experiences. Still, it does offer us a version of the past, a certain truthiness. But nostalgia? Nostalgia is a big fat liar.

headline: Post-Lockdown, I’m Learning to Let Go of My Young Adult Kids — Again
abstract: When my adult children came home during Covid lockdown, I loved feeling I could protect them.
lead_paragraph: Last week, when it had been more than two days since I’d heard from my young adult children — Zoë, 26, and Isaac, 23 — I sent a text to our family chat: “Smoke signals, please.”

headline: The New York Times Is Reimagining Sunday Review
abstract: “By renaming the section Sunday Opinion, we’re recognizing the role it plays and making that clearer to readers.”
lead_paragraph: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

headline: What Turns a Person Into a Mass Shooter?
abstract: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks that focuses on alienation and other social and psychological factors.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Is That Ableist?’ Good Question.
abstract: No one likes to be scolded for using the “wrong” language. But we must be willing to change our habits as attitudes and language change.
lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to my hometown, San Francisco, I met up with two fellow blind writer friends — Haben Girma and Caitlin Hernandez. Haben is a human rights lawyer and author, the first and only deaf-blind graduate of Harvard Law School. Caitlin is a talented teacher and young adult novelist. I’d been friends with her since we met in a writers’ group in 2017, when she dubbed herself my pet millennial because I’m about 20 years her senior. She and Haben are both in their early 30s.

headline: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
abstract: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In an indication that Russian forces were ending what they called an operational pause in their invasion of Ukraine, the defense minister of Russia, Sergei K. Shoigu, on Saturday ordered his forces to intensify attacks “in all operational sectors” of the war.

headline: Eugenio Scalfari, Leading Italian Journalist, Dies at 98
abstract: As a founder of La Repubblica, one of the country’s major newspapers, and later as a columnist, he left a mark on civic life.
lead_paragraph: Eugenio Scalfari, one of Italy’s best-known journalists, who came to enduring prominence as a founder of the liberal newspaper La Repubblica, lobbing editorial salvos across the nation’s public life and over the high walls of the Vatican, died on Thursday in Rome. He was 98.

headline: As Biden Reaches Out to Mideast Dictators, His Eyes Are on China and Russia
abstract: Looking to make Moscow pay for its Ukraine war, and box China out of Mideast tech deals, the U.S. president tries to fall back on old Gulf alliances.
lead_paragraph: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — During his painful encounters with a series of Arab strongmen here in Saudi Arabia this weekend, President Biden kept returning to a single reason for renewing his relationship with American allies who fall on the wrong side of the struggle he often describes as a battle between “democracy and autocracy.”

headline: Picasso & Company: The Artists Who (Finally) Conquered America
abstract: Hugh Eakin’s new book, “Picasso’s War,” features plenty of cultural heroes and heroines.

headline: Golf’s Birthplace Faces a Risky Future on a Warming Planet
abstract: The Old Course, site of this year’s British Open, could be more vulnerable to floodwaters in the coming decades. Other links courses are even more imperiled.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — It is the rare golfer who does not fret over weather that could wash out a round or starve shots of distance.

headline: Head of Documenta Resigns Amid Antisemitism Scandal
abstract: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.
lead_paragraph: After a month of crisis that has roiled the art world, Sabine Schormann, the director general of the renowned contemporary art exhibition Documenta, resigned on Saturday from her post only 28 days into the exhibition’s 100-day run.

headline: What It Means to See America in Person
abstract: Trading the online nation for the open road.
lead_paragraph: BIGFORK, Mont. — I’m writing these words early in a darkened motel room, 2,460 miles from home, eight hours east of Seattle and 45 minutes south of Glacier National Park. Around me five other people are still asleep: My wife and four children, crowded onto queen-size beds, an air mattress and a pack-and-play. These have been our conditions for the last 16 nights, which we have spent claiming an important American birthright: The westward migration via minivan, the great cross-country drive.

headline: More accounts of abuses in so-called Russian filtration camps in new report add to international concern.
abstract: International concern is growing over reports of abuses involving Russia’s so-called filtration camps, including the eventual executions of some detainees, according to a new report from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
lead_paragraph: International concern is growing over reports of abuses involving Russia’s so-called filtration camps, including the eventual executions of some detainees, according to a new report from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

headline: What New Abortion Bans Mean for the Youngest Patients
abstract: One 10-year-old became the focus of debate, but more than 1,000 girls under 15 seek abortions each year. “How are we going to help the pregnant kids?”
lead_paragraph: She was just 10 years old, so young that many people were horrified when they heard it, and others refused to believe it. But the ordeal of the child rape victim in Ohio who had to cross state lines for an abortion, and the ugly political fight that followed, have highlighted two uncomfortable facts: Such pregnancies are not as rare as people think, and new abortion bans are likely to have a pronounced impact on the youngest pregnant girls.

headline: Can Galen Rupp outrun the shadow of a disgraced former coach?
abstract: Galen Rupp is the greatest American distance runner of his generation. For a long time, the disgraced coach Alberto Salazar guided him. Should that matter?
lead_paragraph: Galen Rupp is the greatest American distance runner of the 21st century.

headline: Texas and the Central Plains could see their hottest temperatures of the summer.
abstract: After an already sweltering summer that has shattered heat records across the U.S. midsection, this week could be the hottest yet.
lead_paragraph: After an already sweltering summer that has shattered heat records across the U.S. midsection, this week could be the hottest yet.

headline: Could a Scot Please Win the British Open One Day? Is That Too Much to Ask?
abstract: The last golfer from Scotland to win the British Open was Paul Lawrie in 1999 at Carnoustie, and his victory was somewhat of a fluke.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — They were having fun, perhaps too much fun, on the Old Course on Saturday at the British Open.

headline: It’s All on the Table
abstract: Greg Slovacek’s debut puzzle will hold you in thrall.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is one for the books. Greg Slovacek is a software engineer from San Francisco; this is his first published crossword. He finds puzzlemaking similar, in a way, to programming — both involve problem-solving within constraints — and he enjoys puzzles that have layers for a solver to uncover.

headline: Jak Knight, Known for the Netflix Series ‘Big Mouth,’ Dies at 28
abstract: Mr. Knight, who had been a successful stand-up comedian for several years, was also a writer for the ABC sitcom “Black-ish.”
lead_paragraph: Jak Knight, a stand-up comedian, writer and actor who first attracted wide attention as a voice actor and writer on the animated Netflix series “Big Mouth,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 28.

headline: Lily Safra, Star-Crossed Socialite and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
abstract: Her life was marked by tragedy, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, but that did not stop her from giving away millions.
lead_paragraph: Lily Safra, a Brazilian-born socialite and philanthropist who led a star-filled, star-crossed life with enough jet-setting ups and tragedy-filled downs to fill a dozen Danielle Steel novels, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, the banker Edmond J. Safra, died on July 9 at her home in Geneva. She was 87.

headline: Rory McIlroy Has a Big Day at the British Open. Viktor Hovland Follows.
abstract: McIlroy leapfrogged to the top of the leaderboard with a stunning bunker shot on No. 10 for eagle. He and Hovland were tied heading into the final round on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — Standing in one of the Old Course’s 112 bunkers on Saturday, Rory McIlroy was about to be right where he wanted to be: atop the leaderboard of the British Open.

headline: Fred Kerley Leads U.S. Sweep in 100 Meters at Worlds
abstract: Kerley won the gold and was followed by Marvin Bracy-Williams and Trayvon Bromell.
lead_paragraph: Fred Kerley did not know that he was the fastest man in the world when he crossed the finish line at Hayward Field on Saturday night. Like so much else in his life, he needed to wait and wonder.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Risk of Recession Growing, Driven by Tireless Virus
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone following the economic situation right now, including central banks, we do not have a clear answer on how to deal with this situation.”

headline: Corrections: July 17, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 17, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 24 this weekend about planting trees to fight climate change refers imprecisely to an action taken by Elon Musk. He changed his Twitter display name to “Treelon,” not his Twitter handle.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘The Driver Spent the 20-Minute Trip Telling Me Why I Shouldn’t Be Sad’
abstract: A cool ride home after a breakup, a celebrity sighting with a twist and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Griner Case Draws Attention to ‘Wrongful Detentions’
abstract: Dozens of Americans are believed to be held by foreign adversaries as political pawns in disputes with the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Brittney Griner. Austin Tice. The Citgo 6. And now, potentially, three American military veterans who were captured by enemy forces after traveling to Ukraine to fight Russia.

headline: A North Dakota City Attracted a Corn Mill. Then Came Questions About Its Chinese Owners.
abstract: Officials in Grand Forks are enthusiastic about the potential benefit to the economy, but the connection to China stoked a backlash.
lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — For years, the leaders of Grand Forks had their eyes on a patch of cropland north of town, not far from a pasta-making facility, a potato processor and a state-owned flour mill where farmers received top dollar for their wheat. That muddy field, they thought, would be the perfect place for another agriculture business.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: Meet the New Voice of Baseball
abstract: Joe Davis inherited Vin Scully’s job with the Dodgers. Now, he will replace Joe Buck at the All-Star Game and the World Series. He has done his homework, and he’s ready to shine.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The basketball game was postponed in the morning, meaning Joe Davis would not be on the air in the afternoon. This was in January in Ann Arbor, Mich., not far from his childhood home, but Davis kept his evening flight and headed early to the airport. If he could not call a game, why pass up a free day to study?

headline: In Rome, a New Museum for Recovered Treasures Before They Return Home
abstract: The Museum of Rescued Art showcases antiquities that were looted or otherwise lost before they go back to institutions in the regions from which they were taken.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Last month, Italian officials inaugurated a new museum here whose title sets a lofty agenda: the Museo dell’Arte Salvata, or the Museum of Rescued Art.

headline: Prime Minister Race in Britain Remains Unsettled in Wake of Johnson’s Downfall
abstract: Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, is the current front-runner, but Penny Mordaunt, a junior trade minister, is making a surprisingly strong run for the leadership position.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The last time Britain’s Conservative Party elected a new leader, Boris Johnson dominated the contest from wire to wire, a political celebrity so famous that many voters just called him Boris.

headline: Netflix, Still Reeling, Bets Big on ‘The Gray Man’
abstract: The streaming service hopes its latest release can be the start of a blockbuster franchise that attracts much-needed subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Anthony and Joe Russo like to go big.

headline: As the Planet Cooks, Climate Stalls as a Political Issue
abstract: Joe Manchin’s rejection of a compromise climate bill tells a familiar story: Voters and politicians put a higher premium on immediate issues, such as inflation and the economy, giving politicians a pass on global warming.
lead_paragraph: Summers in Maricopa County, Ariz., have become at times unbearable, Kyle Hawkinson said on Friday. Smog and haze hung heavily over Phoenix, and residents were bracing for fire season, when the heat and air pollution would only grow worse. Climate change, he said, is at least partly to blame.

headline: A Crop of New Novels About Race and Racism Finds Freedom in Satire
abstract: Authors of color have turned in recent books to humor and surreal conceits to explore racism, identity politics and the pain of being “on the other side of whiteness.”
lead_paragraph: In Chinelo Okparanta’s new novel, a young white man is disgusted by his bigoted, small-town parents. Some of his reactions are typical: He disavows their views and moves to New York City. Others, though, are decidedly strange: He starts calling himself G-Dawg, joins a self-help group for white people ashamed of their race — and begins to identify as a Black man from Africa.

headline: All Dolled Up for the Heat
abstract: Parties were held for the contemporary art market Platform and the Parrish Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t sell NFTs, and we won’t,” said Bettina Huang, co-founder of Platform, an online marketplace for contemporary art that celebrated its first anniversary on Wednesday at the Bowery Hotel. The website, also co-founded by David Zwirner’s two children, Marlene and Lucas Zwirner, showcases artists from smaller galleries.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Want to Do Less Time? A Prison Consultant Might Be Able to Help.’
abstract: For a price, a new breed of fixer is teaching convicts how to reduce their sentence, get placed in a better facility — and make the most of their months behind bars.
lead_paragraph: People heading to court often turn to the internet for guidance. In so doing, many come across the work of Justin Paperny, who dispenses advice on his YouTube channel. His videos offer preparation advice and help manage expectations, while providing defendants information to be able to hold their current lawyers accountable, and to try to negotiate a lighter sentence.

headline: Why a Middle-Class Lifestyle Remains Out of Reach for So Many
abstract: Inflation has unmasked the depths of our affordability crisis.
lead_paragraph: June’s just-released inflation data is startling. At 9.1 percent, it’s the highest year-on-year rate we’ve seen since 1981.

headline: In the Face of Fact, the Supreme Court Chose Faith
abstract: Kennedy v. Bremerton School District reflects the conservative majority’s brazen efforts to inflict its political and religious agenda on the rest of the country.
lead_paragraph: Imagine your boss fervently proclaiming his religious beliefs at the end of a companywide meeting, inviting everyone on the team who shares those beliefs to join in. You’re surrounded by colleagues and other higher-ups. Everyone is watching to see who participates and who holds back, knowing that whatever each of you does could make or break your job and even your career, whether you share his convictions or not. But hey, totally up to you!

headline: What Will Happen if Doctors Defy the Law to Provide Abortions?
abstract: Those who withhold care get conscience protections. What about those who want to provide it?
lead_paragraph: Days after Texas banned most abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy in September 2021, Dr. Alan Braid disclosed that he had “provided an abortion to a woman, who though still in her first trimester, was beyond the state’s new limit.” Dr. Braid wrote in a Washington Post opinion piece that when he was a medical resident before Roe v. Wade, he had seen “teenagers die from illegal abortions. One I will never forget. When she came into the ER, her vaginal cavity was packed with rags. She died a few days later from massive organ failure, caused by a septic infection.” Dr. Braid resolved, “I can’t just sit back and watch us return to 1972.”

headline: The Week in Business: Twitter Hits Back
abstract: Inflation in June was high. The euro tumbled to parity with the U.S. dollar. And central banks around the world are raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: In Elon Musk’s saga with Twitter, the end of one chapter is just the start of another. Shortly after signaling that he was backing out of his deal to buy the social media company, Mr. Musk was sued by Twitter. The company accused him of “knowingly, intentionally, willfully and materially” breaching their agreement. Mr. Musk’s lawyers said on Friday that Twitter’s request in the suit for an expedited trial in September was unreasonable and asked to delay it.
