abstract: More than a dozen Facebook videos posted by the Republican nominee for Pennsylvania governor espousing far-right positions have disappeared as the state senator shifts to the general election.
lead_paragraph: The videos were a sort-of virtual ride-along with Doug Mastriano as he crisscrossed Pennsylvania in the governor’s race, regaling viewers with his far-right musings about climate change, abortion and critics within his own party.

headline: How the Police Response Story Changed in Uvalde
abstract: A new report from the Texas legislature described a police response that differed from what was said the day after the shooting.
lead_paragraph: A new report from the Texas legislature described a police response that differed from what was said the day after the shooting.

headline: Why Can We Only Be Honest When We’re Anonymous?
abstract: NGL, a new anonymous-messaging platform, taps into our worst instincts.
lead_paragraph: It seems that every few years, a new anonymous-messaging platform enters the market; rapidly gains a fan base, investments and media attention; then crashes and burns. Usually, the cause is some combination of unfettered bullying, harassment or misinformation that blooms within the platform.

headline: On Donetsk’s front line, small gains and losses impose a heavy toll.
abstract: In the grinding battle for eastern Ukraine’s Donetsk Province,
lead_paragraph: In the grinding battle for eastern Ukraine’s Donetsk Province,

headline: C.I.A. Director Issues Warning After Possible Noose Is Found Near Facility
abstract: An object was discovered near a secret location in Virginia, in a building that houses businesses and other organizations.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, issued a warning to the agency’s work force last week after what appeared to be a noose was found outside a secret facility used by the agency in Virginia, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Confessions of a Political Swashbuckler
abstract: Lis Smith, a Democratic communications operative, has written a memoir that pulls back the curtain on how campaigns are won and lost.
lead_paragraph: Lis Smith is not your grandfather’s political consultant.

headline: Climate Politics Are Worse Than You Think
abstract: If only it were just about money.
lead_paragraph: Texas is often hot, but not like this: Current forecasts have the temperature in Dallas hitting 109 degrees Tuesday, with highs in triple digits well into next week.

headline: Zelensky Takes Aim at Hidden Enemy: Ukrainians Aiding Russia
abstract: In firing his intelligence chief and top prosecutor, President Volodymyr Zelensky signaled a more aggressive approach to a fifth column undermining Ukraine’s war effort.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Even as it engages in fierce fighting with Russia on the battlefield, Ukraine is also waging war on a different, more shadowy front: rooting out spies and collaborators in government and society who are providing crucial help to the invading forces.

headline: Debate Over Monkeypox Messaging Divides N.Y.C. Health Department
abstract: City epidemiologists say some public health messages have been misleading about the risks and have narrowed the city’s chances for containing the disease.
lead_paragraph: The spread of monkeypox has ignited a debate within the New York City Health Department over whether the agency should encourage gay men to reduce their number of sexual partners during this summer’s outbreak.

headline: London Braces as Temperatures Climb
abstract: Temperatures soared in London on Monday as a heat wave that had already been causing devastation in continental Europe arrived in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures soared in London on Monday as a heat wave that had already been causing devastation in continental Europe arrived in Britain.

headline: Can Batters Hit What They Can’t See? We Will Find Out.
abstract: Dodger Stadium at dusk can be one of the hardest places to hit in baseball. As if Clayton Kershaw and Shane McClanahan, the All-Star starters, needed any help.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The All-Star Game has visited 37 different ballparks, including some more than once, since its last edition at Dodger Stadium. Ten of those sites have been razed, and three others no longer host Major League Baseball games. Chavez Ravine still glows.

headline: The Anti-Abortion Movement’s Contempt for Women Is Worse Than I Imagined
abstract: Some Republicans reject even lifesaving abortions.
lead_paragraph: It’s getting hard to keep track of all the stories of women being denied care for miscarriages and otherwise having their lives endangered because of state abortion bans.

headline: Bystander Killed Gunman 2 Minutes Into Indiana Mall Shooting
abstract: The gunman used a rifle to kill three people and injure two others before he was shot dead. He had spent an hour inside a mall bathroom apparently preparing for the attack.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year-old man carrying a rifle and pistol with access to another rifle and more than 100 rounds of ammunition was killed by a bystander two minutes after he began spraying gunfire at diners inside a mall food court in Greenwood, Ind., the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Pulitzer Board Rejects Trump Request to Toss Out Wins for Russia Coverage
abstract: The board said it had found nothing to discredit the entries after reviewing the prize submissions from The New York Times and The Washington Post.
lead_paragraph: The board of the Pulitzer Prizes, the most prestigious award in journalism, on Monday rejected an appeal by former President Donald J. Trump to rescind a prize given to The New York Times and The Washington Post for coverage of Russian interference in the 2016 election and Russian ties to Mr. Trump’s campaign and members of his administration.

headline: After Turning Down $440 Million, Juan Soto Just Wants to Play
abstract: Juan Soto is 23 and is already one of the game’s best players. After extension talks broke down, he could be on his way out of town. Until then, he wants to concentrate on baseball.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Beíore Juan Soto met with reporters on Monday ahead of the 2022 Major League Baseball All-Star Game at Dodger Stadium the following day, he pulled out his cellphone and made a call. A few moments later, his agent, Scott Boras, appeared, also on the phone. With a few assistants in tow, Boras stood a few feet away from Soto as he answered questions, many of them about his future.

headline: Why some of track’s biggest names are not at the world championships
abstract: Many of the sport’s biggest names — Sha’Carri Richardson, Molly Seidel, Eliud Kipchoge and Sam Kendricks — are not competing in Eugene, Ore. this week.
lead_paragraph: The best runners, jumpers and throwers in the world are all in Eugene, Ore., this week, competing in the track and field world championships. At least, most of them. But not all.

headline: An ‘Impossible Dream’ Comes True, Again, for Marylouise Burke in ‘Epiphany’
abstract: The 81-year-old actress stars as an eccentric dinner party host. When she was a teenager, though, wanting to act was a secret she didn’t dare tell.
lead_paragraph: The staircase in Brian Watkins’s play “Epiphany,” at Lincoln Center Theater, goes up and up. Tall and imposing, it’s the kind of centerpiece to a set that makes you wonder, when you arrive for a performance, who is going to be climbing and descending it.

headline: Russia fines Google for failing to remove news it calls ‘fake.’
abstract: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court fined Google about $360 million (21.1 billion rubles) on Monday for failing to remove content the country deems illegal, including coverage of the war in Ukraine.

headline: Trump National Security Aide Expected to Testify at Jan. 6 Hearing
abstract: Matthew Pottinger, who resigned on the day of the Capitol riot, is expected to be among those at the prime-time session on Thursday, along with Sarah Matthews, a former deputy press secretary.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Pottinger, who was deputy national security adviser under President Donald J. Trump and the highest-ranking White House official to resign on Jan. 6, 2021, is expected to testify about that day at the House select committee’s prime-time hearing on Thursday, people familiar with the planning said.

headline: Quarterback Known as ‘AR-15’ Changes Nickname, Citing Mass Shootings
abstract: Anthony Richardson, a sophomore quarterback and rising star at the University of Florida, asked people to call him “AR” or not use a nickname at all.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Richardson, a University of Florida quarterback known as “AR-15” for his initials and his uniform number, has announced he is embracing a less violent image as he heads into a season in which he is projected to be one of the top players in college football.

headline: Protection
abstract: Andy Kravis delivers a corporeal challenge.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Andy Kravis is an excellent multipurpose constructor. This is his 26th Times crossword, and he has made puzzles for every day of the week, as well as a Puns and Anagrams variety grid. Today we get a lot of classic trivia and a theme that draws from an enormous pool of popular sayings, but the whole solve is fresh and zingy. I noted a few interesting paired clues, and I love the high-low mix of factoids: It all seems just chewy enough for a Tuesday.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 6, Episode 9 Recap: Bye Bye Love
abstract: Kim and Gus make some difficult decisions of the heart. Mike goes on a mission of mercy.
lead_paragraph: Let’s break with tradition and start at the end of this whipsawing episode, which delivers two quick jolts in its closing minutes.

headline: A cameraman became an accidental obstacle in the men’s steeplechase.
abstract: Soufiane El Bakkali of Morocco, the reigning Olympic champion, won the race.
lead_paragraph: Steeplechasers are familiar with obstacles. Over the course of 3,000 meters, they must clear 28 waist-high barriers and seven water pits. On Monday night, though, in the early stages of the men’s final, they found themselves contending with a different sort of obstacle: a cameraman who had wandered onto the track.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Wales breaks temperature records.
lead_paragraph: Temperatures in Britain neared a record high yesterday as blistering heat swept the country. By midafternoon, Wales had recorded its highest-ever temperature: The thermometer hit 37.1 degrees Celsius, almost 99 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: What to Watch For in Tuesday’s Primary Elections in Maryland
abstract: There are close contests in the Democratic and Republican primaries for governor, and in a few House races as the dust settles from redistricting. But the winners could take days to be called.
lead_paragraph: Marylanders are the only voters going to the polls on Tuesday, choosing major-party candidates for governor and the House of Representatives in the November midterm elections.

headline: Where Dalí Once Painted the Sea, Wind Turbines Are Set to Rise
abstract: Contentious plans to erect a wind farm off the northeastern coast of Spain are part of a tense debate over where to locate new renewable energy projects across Europe.
lead_paragraph: PORT LLIGAT, Spain — Moises Tibau clambered aboard his small wooden boat at dawn, pushing off from a craggy outcropping in front of the house where Salvador Dalí composed some of his most famous Surrealist paintings.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Muted Warnings as Virus Surges Across Country
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, July 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to count every raindrop to know it’s raining. And it’s pouring right now.”

headline: Corrections: July 19, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, July 19, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the Biden administration's stalled climate change legislation misstated the amount of NextGen’s planned spending to mobilize college students. The group says it will spend $15.1 million, not $1.5 million.

headline: The Fight Over Tearing Down a Landmark Red Church
abstract: West Park Presbyterian Church has been on the Upper West Side for almost 150 years. Now its congregation consists of 12 people.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Tonight’s All-Star Game means we’re halfway through the baseball season, and the Yankees and the Mets are in first place. We’ll see what one of our sports editors has to say about a Subway Series in October. But first we’ll look at a landmark church on the Upper West Side that is seeking permission to demolish its nearly 140-year-old structure for an apartment building.

headline: Bolsonaro Gathers Foreign Diplomats to Cast Doubt on Brazil’s Elections
abstract: President Jair Bolsonaro elevated his vote-fraud claims from a matter of domestic politics to foreign policy, heightening international fears that he would dispute the coming election.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil called dozens of foreign diplomats to the presidential palace on Monday to tell them that he believed the country’s voting systems could be rigged, a potential preview of his strategy for an election that is 75 days away and that polls forecast he will lose in a landslide.

headline: Trevor Noah Mocks Joe Biden for That Fist Bump
abstract: Noah called the president’s choice how to greet Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia “the whitest decision of all time.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: ‘Late Show’ Staff Arrested at U.S. Capitol Complex Won’t Be Prosecuted
abstract: The Justice Department said it would not proceed with charges of unlawful entry against staff members from “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested at a Capitol building last month.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors said late Monday that they would not prosecute staff members of “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” who were arrested last month at the United States Capitol complex on charges of unlawful entry.

headline: It Looks Awkward, but This Fish Has a Secret Glow
abstract: Lumpy, but brilliant under UV light.
lead_paragraph: What color is a lumpfish? The answer is more complicated than you might expect.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: U.S. Women Beat Canada to Claim Spot in Paris Olympics
abstract: The Americans’ victory in the final of the Concacaf W Championship avenged a bitter loss to the Canadians at last summer’s Tokyo Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The symmetry would not have been lost on any of them: the United States and Canada, two of the world’s best women’s soccer teams, meeting on a sweltering night and chasing a prize only one of them could win.

headline: Germany Is on Edge Waiting for Russia to Restart the Gas on Nord Stream 1
abstract: A maintenance shutdown of the pipeline, the main artery between Russia and Germany, is expected to end later this week amid heightened tensions.
lead_paragraph: Months of brinkmanship by Russia over the flow of natural gas to Germany and the rest of Europe could reach a high point later this week, when a temporary shutdown of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline is scheduled to end.

headline: Which Elected Leaders Should Do More on Climate? What Americans Say, in Four Maps.
abstract: Detailed survey data revealed that most Americans say Congress should do more to address global warming.
lead_paragraph: Detailed survey data revealed that most Americans say Congress should do more to address global warming.

headline: The Echoes and Echoes and Echoes of War
abstract: In his new story collection, “The Haunting of Hajji Hotak,” Jamil Jan Kochai explores the intergenerational impact of conflict.
lead_paragraph: Violence — whether between individuals or between nations — has a long, intergenerational tail. It haunts the lives of those who witnessed, participated in or fell victim to that violence, and it haunts their descendants. Jamil Jan Kochai is one of those descendants. He was born to Afghan refugees in a camp in Peshawar, Pakistan, after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and migrated to the United States as a child. He is currently a Stegner fellow at Stanford University, and his first novel, “99 Nights in Logar,” was an interconnected series of stories with the war as a backdrop. His debut story collection is also about war, but it’s about family, too, and how each generation forges its own stories in the wake of the generation that preceded it.

headline: Landscape Mode
abstract: Elvia Wilk’s essay collection is “fan nonfiction” that takes on myriad kinds of world-building.
lead_paragraph: Landscapes invite contemplation. Natural or built, eerie or spectacular, they’re spaces to project ourselves into. What if I lived there in the woods? What kind of person would I be if I lived by that seaside? What if I leaped off this cliff?

headline: How to Say Goodbye
abstract: In Malia Wollan’s final Tip column, some parting advice.
lead_paragraph: “You have to say goodbye in a way that the person will understand,” says Dionne Davis, 45, of Decatur, Ga., who has worked in child care since she was a teenager, first in preschools, and for the last 12 years as a nanny. In that time, she has said goodbye to a lot of children, some of whom she has cared for since birth. Choose words that honor the relationship and its context. “I would never say to a child, ‘I’m not going to work here anymore,’” Davis says. “I would say, ‘Miss Dionne is sad because I won’t get to play with you every day.’”

headline: Silence Brought Me a Community and an Escape
abstract: Society maintains that I am broken because of my deafness. I consider myself fortunate to have been given this ability to turn off the sound.
lead_paragraph: Every evening when I return home, I rush into my house and rip my hearing aids out of my head. No matter where I’ve been, the routine is the same. Sometimes I’m in such a hurry I can’t even stand to cycle through the settings on the power button, so I pop open the battery doors instead. Then I stash them on a high bookshelf out of reach of my toddler, where they stay until the next time I venture out.

headline: Long Ago, I Bought a Human Skull. What Should I Do With It?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on making commercial use of a person’s remains.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, as a middle-school science teacher, I bought a preserved human skull from an educational-supply company. I did so in part for my own and my students’ education and wonderment, and in part to have a fascinating conversation piece that I could put on my mantel. At the time, this was entirely legal. Since then, statutes have oscillated between permitting this commerce in human remains and outlawing it, though it has remained largely legal. Of course, there are now excellent plastic replicas available too.

headline: The Republican Ticket Is Being Helped by the Last People You’d Expect
abstract: The Republican Party isn’t capable of governing a democracy. And yet Democrats keep helping some of its most unhinged candidates.
lead_paragraph: Three simple facts will form the backdrop of the November midterms, and taken together, they are difficult to fully reconcile: First, Democrats are serious underdogs and may be defeated in a wave as devastating as the ones that wiped them out in 1994 and 2010. Second, Donald Trump, the undisputed leader of the Republican Party, has endorsed a slate of G.O.P. primary candidates who are unfit to hold public office in a democracy. Third, Democrats want to help him get those dangerous loyalists nominated to the Republican ticket.

headline: Wherever Juan Soto Goes, Remarkable Things Tend to Happen
abstract: After being grilled about turning down a $440 million contract, Soto won the Home Run Derby. All in a day’s work.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It takes remarkable self-assurance to turn down $440 million. No baseball player has ever earned that much in a single contract. Most people would eagerly sign, but Juan Soto, the outfield marvel for the Washington Nationals, said no. Even within the small galaxy of major league superstars, he stands out.

headline: After Truth and Reconciliation? Their Lives.
abstract: Eve Fairbanks’s decades-spanning portrait addresses three experiences of the “New South Africa.”
lead_paragraph: The journalist Eve Fairbanks’s sweeping work of narrative reportage, “The Inheritors,” opens in a shack in Soweto. There, a girl named Malaika, who has grown up in the “New South Africa,” readies herself for her daily two-hour morning journey from her township to school. Malaika’s mother fought for her daughter to have a better life, but now, as Malaika walks past trash piles and coal fires and boards the city bus at dawn, she wonders: What does such a life look like?

headline: This Political Neophyte Is a Lock for Congress. His Name Helps.
abstract: Rob Menendez Jr., 37, is running his first race for office for a New Jersey congressional seat that his father, Senator Bob Menendez, once held.
lead_paragraph: Brian Varela’s odds of winning the Democratic congressional primary against the son of a powerful United States senator were always exceedingly long.

headline: Why Housing Is So Expensive — Particularly in Blue States
abstract: The urban economist Jenny Schuetz breaks down America’s housing crises, the policies that could fix them and the politics standing in the way.
lead_paragraph: America is experiencing a housing crisis — or, more accurately, multiple housing crises. A massive housing shortage in major cities has resulted in skyrocketing rents. Low- and middle-income individuals find themselves priced out of the places with the most opportunity. Homelessness is rampant in cities across the country. Developers often face the steepest obstacles to building in the places where new housing is needed most. And young people are increasingly viewing homeownership, once a vital part of the American dream, as hopelessly out of reach.

headline: Joe Manchin Is a Symptom, but It’s the Senate That’s Sick
abstract: It’s no accident that climate legislation has repeatedly been passed in the House only to collapse in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-two percent of likely voters, according to the left-leaning polling group Data for Progress, want the federal government to increase its tax incentives for solar, wind and other clean energy projects. Sixty-nine percent of likely voters want the government to take steps to make electric vehicles more affordable for more people. And 60 percent of likely voters support policies that would regulate carbon emissions and force power plants to clean up their act.

headline: ‘We Were So Blindsided’: What New Parents Should Know About Parechovirus
abstract: Health officials warn that this common, but little-known, virus can pose a lethal threat to infants.
lead_paragraph: About two weeks after he was born, Kat DeLancy’s son, Ronan, became fussy and stopped eating as well as he had been.

headline: Students Are Learning Well Again. But Full Recovery? That’s a Long Way Off.
abstract: A new report estimates that it may take students at least three to five years to recover from the pandemic. Federal relief money will most likely have run out by then.
lead_paragraph: After the coronavirus pandemic sent a jolt through the American education system, interrupting the learning of millions of children, a new report offers a glimmer of hope: By the end of the last school year, many students had returned to a normal pace of academic growth for the first time since the pandemic began.

headline: ‘History Is Everything’: Making a Film About Black Maternal Mortality
abstract: The directors Paula Eiselt and Tonya Lewis Lee discuss their journey in making the documentary “Aftershock,” which shines a light on a national health crisis.
lead_paragraph: “Black lives matter because Black wombs matter!” Shawnee Benton Gibson chanted from the stage during a National Action Network rally in Washington, D.C., in 2020.

headline: ‘My Worldview Has Been Destroyed’: Chinese Banking Scandal Tests Faith in the System
abstract: The disappearance of ordinary savers’ money, and the government’s seemingly indifferent response, could pose a major test for the Communist Party’s legitimacy.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The saving opportunity with the rural bank in central China looked, to Sun Song, a 26-year-old-businessman, like a great find. It would be linked to his existing account at a large, reputable state-owned bank. The rural bank was also offering high interest rates, making it seem like an ideal place to park his roughly $600,000 in savings.

headline: 5 Great Restaurants to Visit in Basque Country
abstract: Álvaro Garrido, the chef of the Michelin-starred Mina restaurant and a Bilbao native, shares five favorite restaurants that exemplify the resilient spirit of Spain’s northern autonomous region.
lead_paragraph: In Basque Country, the pandemic has served as a reminder of the extent to which food forms the fabric of local life. Eating well is a priority throughout Spain’s northern autonomous community, and seems, to some local chefs, even more so now.

headline: Words of War: A Literary Lifeline for the Battlefield
abstract: Does poetry have any place in a war zone? For one correspondent, it is indispensable.
lead_paragraph: Even the newest of correspondents knows not to go into a war zone without the right training, the right gear and the right exit plan. But some seasoned reporters have learned that they need something more to sustain them through the bleak days and nights of carnage. Something to remind them of the humanity beneath the inhumanity. For some, it is poetry.

headline: Some Students Want Colleges to Provide the Abortion Pill. Schools Are Resisting.
abstract: Even in states that protect abortion rights, colleges are proceeding with caution.
lead_paragraph: Many colleges pride themselves on providing a range of sexual and reproductive health services for their students, including birth control, screenings for sexually transmitted diseases and even insurance coverage to terminate a pregnancy.

headline: The Effortless Way to Style a Coffee Table
abstract: Designers and home stagers make it look so easy. Here’s how they do it.
lead_paragraph: A coffee table isn’t just a place for your guests to set down their drinks.

headline: Plotting the Future of the Most Storied Studio in Jazz
abstract: The New Jersey recording space built in 1959 by Rudy Van Gelder is filled with history. Can it regain its glory without getting stuck in the past?
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J. — Hidden along a commercial strip north of the George Washington Bridge, surrounded by car dealerships and characterless corporate offices, is hallowed ground for jazz.

headline: One of America’s Most Seductive States Is Also One of Its Scariest
abstract: North Carolina holds an illuminating — and alarming — political mirror up to the country.
lead_paragraph: CLAYTON, N.C. — For a tidy snapshot of our messy country, you could do worse than North Carolina’s newly redrawn 13th Congressional District, where suburb yields to exurb and fields of tobacco and sweet potatoes somehow hold their ground. I had to drive only 15 miles of it to see two versions of America — and to see them at war.

headline: Can a ‘Magic’ Protein Slow the Aging Process?
abstract: Elevian is one of several companies searching for ways to increase life span — in this case, using a protein called GDF11. But challenges lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Upstart, a series about young companies harnessing new science and technology.

headline: How ‘Stop the Steal’ Captured the American Right
abstract: The movement to reinstate President Trump has gone far beyond him — and now threatens the future of American elections.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania State Capitol, in Harrisburg, is a Beaux-Arts landmark that on its eastern side echoes the west terrace of the U.S. Capitol, and the scene there on Nov. 7, 2020, four days after Election Day, strikingly prefigured the one in Washington two months later. On the plaza below, more than a thousand strong, were the Donald Trump faithful, in MAGA hats and every possible variation of red, white and blue clothing, waving the banners of the campaign. “Stop the steal!” they chanted. “Stop the steal!”

headline: The Players to Watch at the Evian
abstract: Five golfers who have a good chance to win the tournament, including the defending champion.
lead_paragraph: The premier female golfers in the world will tee off this Thursday at the Evian Resort Golf Club in France for the Amundi Evian Championship, the fourth of the LPGA Tour’s five majors in 2022.

headline: A fourth Covid vaccine is cleared for use in the United States.
abstract: The shots from Novavax are only for people who have not yet been vaccinated, which is likely to limit their uptake at first.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommended on Tuesday that a newly authorized vaccine from Novavax be used as an option for adults seeking a primary immunization against the coronavirus.

headline: Outbreaks in China prompt lockdowns and fears of more economic woes.
abstract: The emergence of more infectious subvariants of the coronavirus has triggered mass quarantines, including 2,000 tourists stranded in a popular beach resort town.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen Chinese cities are grappling with a spate of Covid-19 outbreaks driven by Omicron subvariants, prompting widespread lockdowns and mass quarantines of millions of people that could worsen China’s slumping economy.

headline: Indian Rupee Hits Weakest Level Ever Against the Dollar
abstract: The Indian currency has lost about 7 percent of its value against the dollar this year, a victim of higher energy prices and economic uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: The Indian rupee touched the weakest level on record against the dollar on Tuesday, another victim of higher energy prices and a stronger greenback.

headline: Two Companies Aim to Beat SpaceX to Mars With ‘Audacious’ Landing
abstract: Relativity Space, which could launch its first rocket soon, and Impulse Space, founded by a SpaceX veteran, optimistically say that together they can reach the red planet a few years from now.
lead_paragraph: SpaceX could lose the race to send the first private space mission to Mars. Maybe.

headline: Broken Climate Pledges and Europe’s Heat Wave
abstract: Has the era of global cooperation over planet-warming emissions ended?
lead_paragraph: A record-breaking heat wave is currently washing over Europe. In parts of Britain, the mercury has hit a freakishly high 100 degrees Fahrenheit or more.

headline: Out of Cash and Out of Fuel, Sri Lanka Runs on Patience
abstract: The rage at the failure and corruption of a ruling elite is matched by generosity and ingenuity to prevent complete collapse and anarchy.
lead_paragraph: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — The queues are ubiquitous — and orderly.

headline: Bigger Than Trump
abstract: Why election conspiracy theories have become central to the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, 2016 — during Donald Trump’s Republican primary campaign and more than four years before he would falsely accuse Joe Biden of election fraud — somebody registered the website www.stopthesteal.org. It may have been Roger Stone, the Republican operative who was advising Trump’s 2016 campaign and appears to have coined the phrase “Stop the Steal.”

headline: ‘Crisis and Decline’: Report Paints a Bleak Assessment of Australia’s Environment
abstract: Climate change, habitat loss, invasive species, pollution and mining have contributed to a drastic decline in the populations of some wildlife species.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Australia’s environment and wildlife are facing even greater threats than previously acknowledged, according to a new report that the environment minister said painted a “story of crisis and decline.”

headline: France Will Spend Nearly $10 Billion to Renationalize Electricity Company
abstract: The government offered to buy the shares it doesn’t already own in EDF, which operates all of the country’s nuclear plants, in the face of a worsening energy crisis after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: France plans to pay 9.7 billion euros, about $9.8 billion, to fully renationalize EDF, the state-backed electricity giant, in a move that the government said would allow it to bolster the country’s energy independence, overhaul its nuclear power program and invest in renewables.

headline: Firefighters battle an ‘explosive cocktail’ of wind and flames in southwestern France.
abstract: More than 2,000 firefighters are trying to contain raging wildfires that have burned nearly 80 square miles of vegetation and forced thousands to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: LA TESTE-DE-BUCH, France — More than 2,000 firefighters from around France were battling raging wildfires on Tuesday that have burned nearly 80 square miles of parched forest in the Gironde area of the country’s southwest and forced over 37,000 people to evacuate in the past week.

headline: ‘Desus & Mero’ Late-Night Show Ends After Four Seasons
abstract: Showtime said that the Bronx-bred hosts were “pursuing separate creative endeavors” after the duo collaborated on television shows, podcasts and a book.
lead_paragraph: The Showtime late-night talk show “Desus and Mero” will not be returning for a fifth season, the network announced on Monday.

headline: Why California Bans State-Funded Travel to Nearly Half of States
abstract: A 2016 law banning travel to states with anti-L.G.B.T.Q. policies is in the spotlight.

headline: The Cost of Extreme Heat
abstract: Britain this morning recorded its highest temperature ever, bringing parts of the country to a standstill and testing infrastructure.
lead_paragraph: The European heat wave that baked Italy, France and Spain over the past week has reached London, putting life on hold and testing infrastructure. Britain this morning recorded its highest temperature ever, as the heat led some schools, museums and doctors’ offices to close, and some trains and flights to be canceled. Forecasters reported temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius, or 104 degrees Fahrenheit, today in London. Officials issued Britain’s first “red” warning for extreme heat, declaring a national emergency in a country accustomed to temperate weather, where few homes have air conditioning. In the U.S., President Biden reportedly may declare a climate emergency as soon as this week, according to The Washington Post.

headline: Comparisons to Britain’s Summer of 1976 Abound. They’re Misleading.
abstract: Nostalgic memories of a long hot spell decades ago have become part of the currency of political debate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The sun beat down, the reservoirs dried up and, as a minister was appointed to deal with the drought, Britons were urged to restrict their ablutions to just five inches of bath water.

headline: On Long Island’s South Shore, a Leisurely Summer Dinner
abstract: The chef Andy Baraghani took a break from his cookbook tour to share some of the dishes featured in its pages with friends.
lead_paragraph: I’m one step through the doorway of Andy Baraghani’s kitchen and suddenly the air is perfumed with peonies, earthy dill and just-fried onions. The chef and food writer, 32, is eager to play with the first tastes of summer but is also determined to let the season’s bounty speak largely for itself. “I want my cooking to be effortless, and this time of year, you don’t have to do too much,” he says, popping a strawberry into his mouth and grinning.

headline: What Baby Boomers Want (Options!), Senior Housing Delivers
abstract: Shifting demographics are reshaping complexes built for older Americans, who are looking for a variety of rates and services.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic crushed the senior housing market, cutting occupancy rates and stalling construction. Now, as the market begins an uneven rebound, developers are adapting to the coming wave of aging baby boomers with a new crop of living developments.

headline: Dog Helps Rescue Owner Who Fell 70 Feet in California Forest
abstract: Saul, a black Border collie, helped lead search and rescue crews to his owner, who the authorities said had broken his hip and multiple ribs after falling from a ridge.
lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old man and his black Border collie, Saul, were on a hike last week near California’s Tahoe National Forest, surrounded by trees and steep canyons, when something went wrong. The man fell 70 feet from a ridge, breaking his hip and multiple ribs, the authorities said. He had no phone. Just a dog by his side.

headline: ‘The Day the Music Died’ Review: ‘American Pie,’ the Life of a Hit
abstract: Don McLean tries to clear up some misapprehensions about the eight-an-a-half-minute song that took on a life of its own, in this documentary.
lead_paragraph: Even those who don’t like Don McLean’s song “American Pie” have to admit that it’s a distinctive pop culture achievement. A nearly eight-and-a-half minute allegory that goes from mournful to infectious to mournful again, the monster 1971 radio hit is seemingly known to all generations and still sung at bar-closing times the world over.

headline: When We Consent, We Shouldn’t Feel Terrible After, Right?
abstract: We deserve more than sex that is merely legal.
lead_paragraph: One August afternoon in 2019, I performed in a short play meant to make incoming freshmen at my college aware of the kinds of challenges they might face during their first year of school. After the lights dimmed on a skit about eating disorders, the topic quickly shifted and the stage opened on a party scene. One thing led to another, and a male cast member whisked me away to his “bedroom” — a few chairs hastily stacked together. We traded clunky dialogue and then he leaned over and said: “I’m really enjoying getting to know you. … Can I kiss you?” As directed, I paused, then enthusiastically blurted out, “OK!”

headline: Amazon sues leaders of more than 10,000 Facebook groups it says churn out fake reviews.
abstract: The e-commerce site said the groups targeted its sites in the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Amazon filed a lawsuit against the leaders of over 10,000 Facebook groups it accused of publishing fake reviews on the e-commerce site, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Hayley Kiyoko Revs Up With Arcade Fire and Chills Out to ‘Friends’
abstract: The pop singer and songwriter has been doing some emotional spring cleaning as she prepares to release her second full-length album, “Panorama.”
lead_paragraph: The pop singer and songwriter Hayley Kiyoko’s fans call her “lesbian Jesus,” and she’s become known for boldly and unapologetically putting every facet of herself into her artistry. That wasn’t always the case, however.

headline: He Fought Boston’s Blue Wall of Silence. Now He’s the Commissioner.
abstract: Boston’s new police commissioner, Michael Cox, was the victim of an assault by fellow officers who mistook him for a suspect.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Before dawn on a January morning in 1995, the phone rang in the home of Michael A. Cox Sr., a Boston police officer. His wife answered, still groggy. He had been hurt. As two of his fellow officers rushed her to the emergency room, she asked what had happened.

headline: Mourning Technoblade: Fans Grieve a Minecraft Star They Never Met
abstract: The expert gamer built a following of millions of mostly young players on YouTube, without revealing his name or face.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, more than 10.4 million subscribers to a YouTube channel received a notification that usually brought good news: Technoblade, an expert Minecraft player, had posted a new video.

headline: Which of the following can the new James Webb Space Telescope not observe?
abstract: NASA’s newest observatory will reveal new discoveries about the universe, but it cannot see everything.
lead_paragraph: NASA’s newest observatory will reveal new discoveries about the universe, but it cannot see everything.

headline: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 4: On ‘The Real Reason the Minions Have Taken Over the World’
abstract: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Claire Guo, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
lead_paragraph: We received 1,059 entries from students from around the world for the fourth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Claire Guo, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.

headline: Kharkiv Tried to Return to Normal. Russian Shelling Wouldn’t Let It.
abstract: Ukraine repelled the effort to capture its second-largest city, but the artillery attacks did not stop. Many residents who left have returned but fear that a new offensive is imminent.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Alina Titova fell to her knees on the steps of the central railway station at her first glimpse of her home city after arriving back on the train.

headline: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
abstract: School is out for the summer — but in some cases, so are the bosses.
lead_paragraph: Alex Hyman pictured his summer internship as being one part “Entourage” and one part “The Office”: people screaming into telephones Ari Gold superagent style, others menacing their desk mates as unnervingly as Dwight Schrute did at Dunder Mifflin.

headline: The Burger J. Kenji López-Alt Can’t Improve (Only Tweak)
abstract: Oklahoma onion burgers, which cook in moments, are so perfect in their simplicity that they can’t be better, he writes.
lead_paragraph: Humans have been cooking meat with onions for at least as long as recipes have been recorded, but I’d argue that the combination was simplified to its primal core during the Great Depression, when Homer Davis and his son Ross invented what they called the Depression burger at the Hamburger Inn in El Reno, Okla.

headline: Bodega Clerk Who Fatally Stabbed Man Will Not Face Charges
abstract: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan’s district attorney, said a murder charge against Jose Alba could not be proved. Mr. Alba’s supporters said he acted in self-defense.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of mounting pressure, the Manhattan district attorney on Tuesday morning dropped a murder charge against a bodega clerk who fatally stabbed an attacker.

headline: Lizzo’s Empowerment Pop Gets Stuck in the Same Groove
abstract: “Special,” her second major-label album, gestures toward complexities that would broaden her image as the queen of the mirror pep talk, but retreats to her comfort zone.
lead_paragraph: Since her charismatic breakout hit “Truth Hurts” dominated the Hot 100 in 2019, the music of the Houston-raised singer, rapper, songwriter and flutist Lizzo has been a pop cultural omnipresence — a glossy sonic lacquer ready to provide any humdrum moment with a hater-repellent sheen.

headline: Here’s a secret about your neighbors
abstract: Many of us avoid talking about climate change because it feels so controversial. In fact, research shows that your neighbors are probably thinking about it, too.
lead_paragraph: Merciless heat is scorching much of Europe this month, with temperatures also hitting dangerous levels in parts of Asia and the Americas. It’s one of those times when global warming feels as undeniable as it feels scary.

headline: Manchin’s ‘Veto’ of the Climate Bill, as the World Heats Up
abstract: Reaction to Senator Joe Manchin’s rejection of a climate bill. Also: Liz Cheney; sensitive language; erosion of trust in experts; the right to travel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Migrants in Morocco Are Sentenced in Attempt to Cross Into Spanish Enclave
abstract: Thirty-three men, part of a larger group, were given 11 months in prison after a deadly border-crossing effort.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A judge in the northeastern Moroccan city of Nador sentenced 33 migrants to 11 months in prison on Tuesday and ordered them to pay small fines in connection with a mass attempt to cross into the Spanish enclave of Melilla last month, defense lawyers said.

headline: Sinkhole Swallows Van in the Bronx
abstract: The sinkhole opened up after a heavy rainfall and caused damage to a water main.
lead_paragraph: The sinkhole opened up after a heavy rainfall and caused damage to a water main.

headline: Bennie Thompson, chairman of the Jan. 6 panel, has tested positive for the coronavirus.
abstract: Mr. Thompson will not join his colleagues at a scheduled prime-time hearing on Thursday, though he instructed the committee to move forward as planned.
lead_paragraph: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the United States Capitol, announced on Tuesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and would not appear in person at what could be the committee’s last hearing of the summer.

headline: ISIS Fighters’ Children Are Growing Up in a Desert Camp. What Will They Become?
abstract: Leaving captured men, women and children in prisons and camps run by Kurds risks seeding a new global terrorism disaster, rights groups and the U.S. military warn.
lead_paragraph: AL HOL, Syria — Viewed from a helicopter, this enormous camp that holds the wives and children of dead or captured Islamic State fighters was a sea of white tents against the desolate landscape of drought-stricken northeastern Syria.

headline: A Behind-the-Scenes Eminence Shapes a Festival’s Future
abstract: Pierre Audi, the artistic director of the Park Avenue Armory, is coming into his own as the leader of the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France.
lead_paragraph: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — On a recent Monday afternoon, the Grand Théâtre de Provence here was almost empty, a few hours before a concert performance of Monteverdi’s opera “L’Orfeo.”

headline: Sashay Away!
abstract: An erstwhile influencer from Fiji clocked 28 million page views with a homemade video of him strutting a runway wearing a ladder, a bench and other household goods.
lead_paragraph: It has been two weeks or an internet eternity since Shaheel Sanil Prasad, a.k.a. Shaheel Shermont Flair, a former call center agent and part-time influencer from Suva City in central Fiji, posted one of the funniest catwalk videos ever to hit social media.

headline: Do Eye Creams Actually Work for Wrinkles?
abstract: Look for a few key ingredients in skin care products if you want to deal with wrinkles — but no product will keep your face crease-free.
lead_paragraph: Q: Does eye cream really prevent wrinkles?

headline: After Heavy Rains, a Sinkhole Opens in the Bronx
abstract: The hole appeared on Monday night, damaging a water main and swallowing a parked van.
lead_paragraph: A sinkhole appeared in the Bronx on Monday as rain and high winds rolled through New York City, growing throughout the evening and swallowing a parked van.

headline: Britain’s record-breaking heat comes amid a closely watched political campaign.
abstract: Political temperatures also rose on Tuesday as the field of candidates seeking to become Britain’s next prime minister was reduced by one.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s record-breaking heat wave came against the backdrop of an intensely watched national political contest, as the race to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson was winnowed to just candidates ahead of a critical vote on Wednesday.

headline: Money Managers Are in a ‘Dire’ Mood, Poll Finds
abstract: Investors surveyed by Bank of America have never been more pessimistic about the economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: Investors are hoarding cash and lowering their expectations for growth, as pessimism about the outlook for the U.S. economy has reached a “dire” level, according to a survey of 259 fund managers responsible for more than $700 billion in investments.

headline: How Penguins Beat the Heat and Went South
abstract: Scientists reconstructed some of the evolutionary steps that led penguins to quit tropical climates for the Antarctic life over millions of years.
lead_paragraph: Few animals have evolved to survive the unforgiving Antarctic like penguins. Species like the emperor penguin have overlapping layers of insulating plumage, tightly packed veins to recycle body heat and just enough paunch to weather wind chills that approach minus 80 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Vacations Bar & Rooftop, With Tropical Drinks, Opens in Bushwick, Brooklyn
abstract: An elegant French restaurant from a Benoit alumnus, an Italian West Village spot from a family of restaurateurs, and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: New York is blessed with rooftops galore for drinks and dining amid stupendous views.  Given a felicitous location, even the second floor will do as at this sprawling new bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with the Manhattan skyline as its backdrop. Come September, the building below will be turned into an all-seasons restaurant; for now, there is a bar on the rooftop, with a  second coming soon. (A third will be located downstairs.) It has a tropical influence, with greenery, weathered wood, green tiles, chessboard stone flooring and blue walls. Drinks and food are self-service, to order at the bar, with choices like fried smashed fingerling potatoes with aioli and brava sauce, shrimp cocktail, fish and chips, and a broccoli rabe hero. Drinks, all $12, include a Tropicale, made with Meyer lemon vodka, passion fruit liqueur, lime and guava juice; and the Proposal, made with pineapple rum, lime and simple syrup. Vantage Point Hospitality owns and runs Vacations with Annie and Andy Shaner, restaurant veterans who live in the neighborhood.

headline: Netflix Says It Lost Nearly 1 Million Subscribers, and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
abstract: The streaming giant, facing significant headwinds, had said it expected to lose two million subscribers in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Disaster has been averted at Netflix.

headline: Elon Musk and Twitter will go to trial over their $44 billion deal in October.
abstract: Twitter had sought to expedite the case by requesting a trial in September, which Mr. Musk had countered by asking for a trial in February.
lead_paragraph: Twitter and Elon Musk will go to trial in October over whether the billionaire must complete his $44 billion acquisition of the social media company, a Delaware judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jenny Schuetz
abstract: The July 19, 2022 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jenny Schuetz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: From Adam Pendleton, Pancakes That Taste Like Perfection
abstract: When it comes to cooking, the artist brings an attention to detail he normally saves for his studio practice.
lead_paragraph: In “One Good Meal,” we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis — and not just when they’re trying to impress.

headline: ‘Porn of the Self’: Novels of Female Angst
abstract: Cocktails, an addiction to erotica, workplace harassment and more.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen-year-old Raizl hiding her laptop beneath her covers while she basks in the glow of endless, muted porn is a picture burned into my memory as permanently as the shvantzes and shmundies are in the protagonist’s imagination (look them up). Felicia Berliner’s SHMUTZ (260 pp., Atria, $27) is about a young woman with a porn addiction that’s somehow even more forbidden than most.

headline: ‘Aftershock’ Review: A Moving Ode to the Black Family
abstract: Black mothers are dying from childbirth at alarming rates. A new documentary explains why.
lead_paragraph: There’s no getting around just how terribly sad it feels watching “Aftershock,” the new documentary from the directors Paula Eiselt (“93Queen”) and Tonya Lewis Lee. After all, it spotlights the tragic deaths of two Black mothers in New York City who died from childbirth-related complications — Shamony Gibson, in 2019, and Amber Isaac, in 2020 — leaving behind young children, partners, families and communities gutted by grief.

headline: British homes were built to retain heat. That’s becoming a problem.
abstract: Keeping homes cool in the country’s typically mild summers was never a priority.
lead_paragraph: For generations, homes in Britain were designed to retain heat, to make cold winters bearable.

headline: Facing Tepid Support, Bill de Blasio Drops N.Y. House Bid
abstract: Polls showed Mr. de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City who also prematurely ended a 2020 presidential bid, trailing in a crowded Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, abruptly ended a campaign for Congress on Tuesday, saying that voters were clearly “looking for another option” and that his time in electoral politics was over.

headline: Trying to Salvage His Climate Agenda, Biden Weighs Remaining Options
abstract: With his legislative plan for global warming in shreds, the president has come under pressure to use all other tools at his disposal.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will travel Wednesday to a shuttered coal-fired power plant that is now part of an offshore wind project in Massachusetts, where he is expected to deliver remarks on clean energy as his administration scrambles to salvage its climate agenda.

headline: Inflation: A Revolution of Falling Expectations
abstract: Surprising hints that this may turn out OK.
lead_paragraph: Macroeconomic policy in the United States has been subject to two great errors over the past half-century. The odds are that you’ve only heard about the first, the way the Federal Reserve allowed inflation to become entrenched in the 1970s. But the second — the way policymakers allowed the economy to operate far below capacity, needlessly sacrificing millions of potential jobs, for a decade following the financial crisis — was arguably even more severe.

headline: Questions About An Unsolved Murder Linger Over ‘Where the Crawdads Sing’
abstract: The release of a movie based on the best-selling novel renewed questions about the author, Delia Owens, her time in Zambia and the shooting of a suspected poacher there.
lead_paragraph: When Delia Owens, a retired wildlife biologist, released her novel “Where the Crawdads Sing” in 2018, no one anticipated a blockbuster. Owens, who is in her early 70s, had never published fiction before. Her publisher printed a modest run of 28,000 hardcover copies.

headline: New York City Opens Cooling Centers as It Braces for a Heat Wave
abstract: With Wednesday and Thursday forecast to reach highs of 100 degrees, cooling centers are scheduled to open to offer the public relief from the heat.
lead_paragraph: As New Yorkers brace for a week of extremely hot weather, cooling centers in air-conditioned buildings throughout the city will be open to the public from Tuesday through Thursday to offer relief from the heat.

headline: In ‘The Pink Hotel,’ Delusional Newlyweds Head Toward a Grand Reckoning
abstract: Liska Jacobs’s novel sets a honeymooning couple in a posh Beverly Hills establishment during a summer of unrest in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: One strange element of human behavior is that much of what we call “vacation” involves endlessly tinkering with our body temperatures. Think of the beach. You lie on a towel, grow hot, dip in the ocean to cool down, get out, reheat yourself, dip, cool down, repeat. The joy of recreation can’t be reduced to the fact that it’s really fun to swivel between hot and cold, but signature vacation moments often involve just that: snuggling up to a campfire on a cold night, plunging into a frigid lake on a sweltering afternoon, coming in from the snow to warm up with cocoa.

headline: 3 Ways Musk Can Support Free Speech
abstract: If Elon Musk buys Twitter, there are steps he could take to expand the boundaries of online expression.
lead_paragraph: Way back in the Paleolithic age of April, Elon Musk seemed excited to buy Twitter and said that he wanted to transform the site by promoting free speech.

headline: Hasbro reports rising sales on strong demand, despite higher prices.
abstract: The toymaker was able to raise prices to offset higher costs, but its revenue took a hit overseas because of a strong dollar.
lead_paragraph: Despite higher prices, people continued to spend on Nerf blasters, Power Rangers action figures and Magic the Gathering cards, helping Hasbro overcome rising costs for materials and freight, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Mapping Europe’s Heat Wave
abstract: Maps show where soaring temperatures have spread across Europe, many in areas unaccustomed to such extreme heat.
lead_paragraph: Maps show where soaring temperatures have spread across Europe, many in areas unaccustomed to such extreme heat.

headline: ‘Law & Order’ Crew Member Is Fatally Shot at Brooklyn Film Location
abstract: The man, who was enforcing parking restrictions on a Greenpoint block before filming was set to begin on Tuesday, was sitting in a car when he was killed by a lone gunman.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn film location for a ripped-from-the-headlines television crime show became a murder scene early Tuesday when a man who was enforcing parking restrictions connected to the production was fatally shot while he sat in a car, the police said.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Just Like Me, but Hotter’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: After a terrible year (I was attacked in my home then suffered through a difficult divorce), my elderly parents visited and helped me pull the ivy that had swallowed my backyard. My father said, “Don’t let that take over again, Irene.” Ten years later, while grappling with stubborn regrowth, I found dad’s hat — gnarled, mouse nibbled, rotted. I’d been missing him fiercely, wishing he were still here to guide me. Not one for assigning spiritual meaning to coincidence, I’ll take this particular tap on the shoulder. Thanks for taking care of me, dad. I’ll take care of the ivy. — Irene Ziegler

headline: Ritzi Jacobi, Maker of Mind-Bending Textile Art, Dies at 80
abstract: Her monumental wall hangings and soft sculptures incorporated fiber-based materials, like goat hair, as part of a “new tapestry” movement.
lead_paragraph: Ritzi Jacobi, a European pioneer of contemporary textile and fiber art who was best known for her monumental wall hangings and soft sculptures, died on June 19 at her home in Düsseldorf, Germany. She was 80.

headline: ‘A Dark, Dark Man’ Review: Murder and Corruption in Kazakhstan
abstract: This exceptionally grim police procedural recalls films like Bong Joon Ho’s “Memories of Murder” and Nuri Bilge Ceylan’s “Once Upon a Time in Anatolia.”
lead_paragraph: “A Dark, Dark Man” is set in a stretch of Kazakhstan where few people seem to live, yet corruption pervades every corner.

headline: How to Spend a Day in Brighton Beach
abstract: By car, bike or train, you owe yourself a beach trip powered by khachapuri.
lead_paragraph: I like to say that New York City is famously a beach town. It certainly has more beach access than where I grew up — landlocked metro Atlanta; that you can get to most of these beaches by subway, bus, bike or ferry is even better.

headline: Ann Shulgin, 91, Who Explored Psychedelics With Her Husband, Dies
abstract: The couple advocated the use of hallucinogens in psychotherapy and documented their experiences with hundreds of drugs in two widely read books.
lead_paragraph: Ann Shulgin, who alongside her husband, Alexander Shulgin, developed and experimented with hundreds of psychedelic drugs that he concocted in his California laboratory, then showed readers how to formulate them in a pair of massive books that attracted a cult following, died on July 9 at her home near Lafayette, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Scenes of Devastation Emerge From a Fire-Ravaged Southwestern France
abstract: Two wildfires have ravaged nearly 80 square miles of forests, forcing 37,000 people to evacuate. The flames were fanned by a heat wave also feeding blazes in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
lead_paragraph: LA TESTE-DE-BUCH, France — As firefighters battled raging wildfires for the eighth consecutive day in southwest France, scenes of devastation emerged from the ashes, underscoring yet another facet of the disastrous effects of the heat wave currently sweeping Europe.

headline: Iran warns Turkey against new incursion into northern Syria.
abstract: Iran warned Turkey on Tuesday against launching a new military operation in Syria just before the leaders of both countries attended a three-way summit meeting with Russia’s president.
lead_paragraph: Iran warned Turkey on Tuesday against launching a new military operation in Syria just before the leaders of both countries attended a three-way summit meeting with Russia’s president.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Visits Iran
abstract: Also, a banking scandal disrupts China and Spain debates a wind farm off its coast.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, visited Iran on Tuesday, underscoring how the war in Ukraine has altered the world’s geopolitics by helping to align two regional powers that have been isolated from Europe and the U.S.

headline: Claes Oldenburg Captured a Carefree (and Consumerist) America
abstract: Even viewers who did not know the artist’s name devoured his audacious sculptures of cheeseburgers, cherries and ice cream cones.
lead_paragraph: Of all the major American Pop artists, Claes Oldenburg was the only one who was born in Europe. He was still in grade school when his father, a Swedish diplomat, moved the family to this country. They settled in Chicago, a city that has a much-lauded architectural history and calls itself, not unjustly, the birthplace of the skyscraper.

headline: Dana Canedy, Publisher of Simon & Schuster’s Flagship Imprint, Has Left the Job
abstract: She was the first Black woman in the position, which she held for two years. Her hiring came amid a push for diversity in the industry.
lead_paragraph: Dana Canedy, the first Black woman to serve as publisher of Simon & Schuster’s flagship imprint, left her position after two years, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Why Russia Believes It Cannot Lose the War in Ukraine
abstract: An interview with Sergey Karaganov.
lead_paragraph: Sergey Karaganov is a prominent Russian political scientist whom I have known for almost 20 years in covering Russia and have interviewed many times as a window into Kremlin thinking. The academic director of the faculty of World Economy and International Affairs at Moscow’s Higher School of Economics and honorary chairman of Russia’s premier nongovernmental think tank, Mr. Karaganov warned for years about a potential conflict in Ukraine over NATO expansion. Since the brutal Russian invasion of Ukraine began in February, he has written articles and given interviews in broad support of President Vladimir Putin, so I interviewed him to better understand Mr. Putin’s aims in the conflict. Ukraine continues to suffer, and those who hope to support Ukraine must understand those aims as it tries to confront Russia’s aggression.

headline: Maryland’s primary election results are expected to be delayed.
abstract: Maryland is the only state that prohibits mail-in ballots from being processed until after the election, a prepandemic rule that lawmakers were unsuccessful in changing.

headline: Maryland Primary Election Results
abstract: See full results and maps from the Maryland primary elections.
lead_paragraph: See full results and maps from the Maryland primary elections.

headline: Spanish Authorities Seize a ‘Contraband’ Picasso at Ibiza Airport
abstract: Investigators said they found a 1966 work called “Trois Personnages” when they searched a passenger’s luggage.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Spain seized a drawing believed to be by Pablo Picasso valued at more than $460,000 from a passenger who failed to declare it to airport customs, the Tax Agency and Civil Guard in Spain said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Europe’s Heat Wave Shatters British Records and Drives Wildfires
abstract: Europe is ill prepared for extreme heat fed by global warming. For the first time on record, parts of Britain hit 40 degrees Celsius — 104 Fahrenheit — as did Paris for only the third time.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the first time on record, Britain suffered under temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius — 104 Fahrenheit — on Tuesday, as a ferocious heat wave moved northwest, leaving a trail of raging wildfires, lost lives and evacuated homes across a Europe frighteningly ill-equipped to cope with the new reality of extreme weather.

headline: A Mariupol teen wrapped in the Ukrainian flag has become a symbol of resistance.
abstract: It is a searing image: A 17-year-old boy wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and standing near a theater that was destroyed by a Russian airstrike in the razed southern city of Mariupol. The sky in the photograph’s frame is a clear blue and all around him is ruin and destruction.
lead_paragraph: It is a searing image: A 17-year-old boy wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and standing near a theater that was destroyed by a Russian airstrike in the razed southern city of Mariupol. The sky in the photograph’s frame is a clear blue and all around him is ruin and destruction.

headline: Ukrainian D.J. Spins Rare Music in N.Y.C.
abstract: Daria Kolomiec, a D.J. from Kyiv, is playing Ukrainian music in New York City clubs this summer.
lead_paragraph: Daria Kolomiec, a D.J. from Kyiv, is playing Ukrainian music in New York City clubs this summer.

headline: The C.D.C. shuts down its public Covid dashboard for cruise ships.
abstract: Passengers will now have to contact cruise lines directly to learn about ongoing outbreaks and virus mitigation policies aboard ships.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has ended its Covid-19 mitigation program for cruise ships in U.S. waters, the public health agency announced on its website.

headline: Iran Backs the War
abstract: In Tehran, Iran’s supreme leader gives Putin a strong endorsement.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: House Moves to Protect Same-Sex Marriage From Supreme Court Reversal
abstract: The legislation, which garnered some Republican support, would recognize same-sex marriages at the federal level. It faces an uncertain path in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday passed a bill that would recognize same-sex marriages at the federal level, with a bipartisan coalition supporting a measure that addresses growing concerns that a conservative Supreme Court could nullify marriage equality.

headline: Intelligence Agencies Say Russia Election Threat Persists Amid Ukraine War
abstract: Top F.B.I. and National Security Agency officials said that Iran and China also remained potent threats, mounting their own campaigns to undermine American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Top national security officials warned on Tuesday about the continuing threat of election interference from abroad, emphasizing that Russia could still seek to meddle or promote disinformation during the 2022 midterm races even as it wages war in Ukraine.

headline: On Sweltering New York Day, Rockaway Beaches Close Over Shark Sightings
abstract: As temperatures in the city climbed into the 90s this week, all of Rockaway’s beaches were closed for swimming because of shark sightings.
lead_paragraph: As temperatures in Queens climbed into the 90s, Rockaway’s beaches were closed on Tuesday afternoon for swimming because of shark sightings, officials said, leaving only the boardwalk open for beachgoers on the hot day.

headline: Secret Service Says Some Missing Jan. 6 Texts Are Unlikely to Be Recovered
abstract: The House committee investigating the attack on the Capitol had subpoenaed text messages from the agents’ phones and other materials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secret Service said it may not be able to recover a batch of erased text messages from phones used by its agents around the time of the attack on the Capitol last year, a development that comes amid intensified scrutiny over lapses in the agency’s accounting of its actions during the riots.

headline: Bannon ‘Decided He Was Above the Law,’ Prosecutor Says
abstract: The jury in Stephen K. Bannon’s contempt of Congress trial is being asked a simple question: Did he defy the House panel investigating the Jan. 6 attack by ignoring a subpoena?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After weeks of legal wrangling and heated speeches on the courthouse steps, the criminal trial of Stephen K. Bannon, a onetime aide to former President Donald J. Trump, opened on Tuesday as prosecutors told the jury they would have to answer a simple question: Did Mr. Bannon defy the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by blatantly ignoring a subpoena?

headline: Soaring Overdose Rates in the Pandemic Reflected Widening Racial Disparities
abstract: A new federal report found that fatal overdoses jumped 44 percent among Black people, twice the increase among white people, from 2019 to the end of 2020.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic’s devastating impact on drug overdose deaths in the United States hit people of color the hardest, with rates among young Black people rising the most sharply, according to a federal report that was released on Tuesday and that analyzed overdose data by race, age and income.

headline: Amid Campaign Revamp, Herschel Walker Stumps Without a Stumble
abstract: After a string of damaging reports, and briefly shunning publicity, the Republican Senate candidate was out on the trail again in rural Georgia.
lead_paragraph: OCILLA, Ga. — Herschel Walker, Georgia’s Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate, gave a 10-minute stump speech on Tuesday in which he told no new whoppers, made no obvious mistakes and allowed reporters to witness the whole thing.

headline: The Midterm Races That Give Democrats Nightmares
abstract: A new poll offers fodder for both parties to claim that voters are on their side in crucial secretary of state elections. Who’s right?
lead_paragraph: Professional Democrats have many fears about the 2022 midterm elections that keep them up at night.

headline: Putin Finds a New Ally in Iran, a Fellow Outcast
abstract: A three-way summit meeting in Tehran between the leaders of Russia, Iran and Turkey sent a clear signal that Vladimir Putin is pushing back against ostracism from the West.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin left Russia for a rare international trip on Tuesday and received a handsome reward: a meeting with a prominent world leader who voiced a full-throated endorsement for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Trump Electors Targeted in Georgia Criminal Inquiry
abstract: A prosecutor in Atlanta is investigating interference in the 2020 presidential election, an inquiry that has engulfed Donald J. Trump and many of his allies.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Atlanta have informed 16 Trump supporters who formed an alternate slate of 2020 presidential electors from Georgia that they could face charges in an ongoing criminal investigation into election interference, underscoring the risk of criminal charges that Donald J. Trump and many of his allies may be facing in the state.

headline: M.L.B. Commissioner Rejects Idea That Minor Leaguers Aren’t Paid Fairly
abstract: The league recently agreed to settle a wage dispute, but Rob Manfred cited recent “strides” in compensation. A player advocacy group called Manfred’s statement “callous and false.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Asked why Major League Baseball’s team owners do not pay minor league players a living wage — whether it was because they could not afford to or because they didn’t want to — M.L.B. Commissioner Rob Manfred suggested those players were actually compensated fairly.

headline: Abortion Provider Prepares Defamation Suit Against Indiana Attorney General
abstract: The doctor in the case of a 10-year-old rape victim says the attorney general acted with “reckless disregard of the truth.” A spokesman calls the claims “baseless.”
lead_paragraph: An Indianapolis doctor who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim is preparing to sue Attorney General Todd Rokita of Indiana for defamation after he said he would investigate her actions in the case, according to a statement released on Tuesday by her lawyer.

headline: U.S. Marshals Seek Man Mistakenly Freed in Shooting of Lady Gaga’s Dog Walker
abstract: James Howard Jackson, 19, was accidentally released from jail in April. The authorities are offering a $5,000 reward for tips that lead to his arrest.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Marshals Service this week announced a $5,000 reward for information that leads to the capture of a 19-year-old man who was charged last year with stealing two of Lady Gaga’s French bulldogs and shooting her dog walker — but was accidentally released from a Los Angeles jail in April.

headline: After Indiana Mall Shooting, One Hero but No Lasting Solution
abstract: When a bystander fatally shot an assailant at an Indiana mall, the country again debated the wisdom of easier access to guns.
lead_paragraph: It was an act of pluck and composure worthy of a scene in the movies. But this was real life: A heavily armed man emerged from the bathroom in a Greenwood, Ind., shopping mall on Sunday evening and began shooting — until he was killed by an armed bystander.

headline: Corrections: July 20, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, July 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on July 13 about the recovery of timbers from the so-called Beeswax Wreck omitted a credit to the news organization that first reported how researchers identified the Beeswax Wreck as the Santo Cristo de Burgos, a 17th-century Spanish galleon. The findings were reported on June 16 by National Geographic.

headline: Leading Russian Tennis Player Criticizes War in Ukraine
abstract: After calling the war a “nightmare” and coming out as gay in an interview, Daria Kasatkina, the highest-ranked Russian woman, said she worried for her safety if she returned to her home country.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.

headline: The highest-ranked Russian in women’s tennis calls the war ‘a full-blown nightmare.’
abstract: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, July 20, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “The thing I’ve always been taught by my parents is to be the first one in and last one out. But there’s no one else there.”

headline: Dan Cox, a Trump Loyalist, Wins Maryland’s G.O.P. Primary for Governor
abstract: Mr. Cox, who wrote on Twitter during the Capitol riot that Mike Pence was a “traitor,” defeated Kelly Schulz, who had been backed by Gov. Larry Hogan. The Democratic primary was too close to call.
lead_paragraph: Republican voters in Maryland on Tuesday made their state the latest to elevate a nominee for governor who denies the 2020 election’s legitimacy, choosing Dan Cox, a first-term state legislator who wrote on social media during the Capitol riot that Vice President Mike Pence was “a traitor.”

headline: Waves, Perhaps
abstract: Josh Kindler’s Wednesday puzzle offers a refreshing break in the middle of our week.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Josh Kindler, the constructor of today’s grid, who is making his debut in the New York Times Crossword. It’s absolutely wicked, and I hope you enjoy solving it as much as I did. For anyone looking to start constructing puzzles, here is my guide to resources. You can also find help in the Crossword Puzzle Collaboration Directory group on Facebook or the Crosscord Discord server.

headline: Miles Bridges Faces Felony Domestic Violence Charges
abstract: Bridges, a Charlotte Hornets free agent, was accused of assaulting his girlfriend in front of their two children. He was arrested in Los Angeles last month.
lead_paragraph: Miles Bridges, a Charlotte Hornets free agent, will be arraigned Wednesday on felony charges of domestic violence and child abuse, the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s Office announced Tuesday. Bridges, 24, faces one count of injuring a child’s parent and two counts of child abuse.

headline: DNA on Discarded Coffee Cup Leads to Arrest in a 1975 Homicide
abstract: Lindy Sue Biechler was stabbed 19 times more than four decades ago. The authorities in Pennsylvania said a coffee cup that David Sinopoli, 68, discarded this year provided investigators with crucial evidence.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 5, 1975, an aunt and uncle of Lindy Sue Biechler went to her apartment in Manor Township, Pa., eager to exchange recipes with their 19-year-old niece, who had returned from getting groceries about two hours earlier. On her front door, they saw blood.

headline: Michigan Coach Jim Harbaugh Speaks at Anti-Abortion Event
abstract: The remarks by Harbaugh, who was quoted as saying, “I believe in having the courage to let the unborn be born,” run counter to those expressed by the university’s interim president.
lead_paragraph: Jim Harbaugh, the University of Michigan’s head football coach, professed his anti-abortion views at a fund-raising event this week, becoming one of the first prominent sports figures to speak out against abortion since Roe v. Wade was overturned.

headline: What’s the Most Unusual Place You Have Ever Gone on a Date?
abstract: Share your story with the Modern Love Podcast, and you may be featured in a future episode.
