lead_paragraph: Perry Rubenstein, a gallerist who rose rapidly in the New York art world of the 1980s, then fell into disgrace in the 2010s after a failed transition to Los Angeles ended with his conviction on two counts of embezzlement, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 68.

headline: Like the Rest of Us, Biden Learns to Live With the Risks of the Virus
abstract: The president’s symptoms improved somewhat, a day after he tested positive for Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One after another, President Biden hugged and kissed them.

headline: N.B.A. Mostly Keeps Low Profile in Public Campaign to Free Brittney Griner
abstract: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, has been detained in Russia since February. The N.B.A., which founded the women’s league in 1996, has said it is working behind the scenes to help Griner.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. is a $10 billion corporation that has the power and reach to promote not just its teams and players but to provoke discussion and debate around social issues. It has used that influence most prominently to fight racism in the United States.

headline: A Hidden New Threat to U.S. Elections
abstract: Some Republican-led counties are refusing to certify election results — a move that could throw American democracy into chaos if it becomes widespread.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than nine weeks since the Pennsylvania primary. The election is still not certified.

headline: Man Charged With Threatening Racist Violence Against Buffalo Supermarket
abstract: The arrest of the man, in Washington State, came a week after the reopening of a different Buffalo grocery store where a gunman killed 10 Black people in May.
lead_paragraph: A Washington State man threatened twice this week to unleash racist violence on a Buffalo supermarket, officials said on Friday. The threats came two months after a gunman allegedly driven by white supremacist hatred killed 10 Black people at another store in the city.

headline: Adidas and Puma to University of Oregon Frats: ‘Nice House, Bro’
abstract: The track and field world championships are being held in Eugene, Ore. Without an abundance of hotels, some sports companies moved into fraternities.
lead_paragraph: The fraternity brothers of Sigma Chi had company this spring. A construction crew would arrive for work each day with a small armada of drills and electric saws. It should be noted that the brothers of Sigma Chi are not known around the University of Oregon as morning people.

headline: Jan. 6 Hearings Invoke Patriotism to Urge Voters to Break With Trump
abstract: On Thursday, the Jan. 6 committee made the case that Donald J. Trump’s conduct had been a violation of his Oath of Office.
lead_paragraph: The Jan. 6 hearings at times have resembled a criminal trial in absentia for former President Donald J. Trump. On Thursday night, the proceedings suddenly felt more like a court-martial.

headline: The First and Only Grocery Store in Fire Island Pines
abstract: For nearly 70 years, Pines Pantry has been a one-stop shop for fresh fish, baked goods and lube.
lead_paragraph: This is a special Fire Island edition of the 212, T’s rubric devoted to New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, for our Summer Entertaining issue.

headline: T-Mobile Reaches $500 Million Settlement in Huge 2021 Data Breach
abstract: The company, which said the hacking had affected 76.6 million people, agreed to pay $350 million to settle claims and spend $150 million to bolster security.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile has agreed to a settlement totaling $500 million in a class-action lawsuit filed by customers after the company disclosed in August that sensitive data had been breached in a cyberattack.

headline: Jail Officer Charged in Killing Claims Gel Pellets Felt Like Glass Shards
abstract: The officer said he fired defensively at a car in the Bronx after being hit with pellets from what turned out to be a toy gun. An 18-year-old man was killed.
lead_paragraph: A New York City correction officer charged with killing an 18-year-old man in the Bronx told the police that he fired a single bullet after being hit in the back with what felt like glass shards or bullet fragments, according to accounts provided at his arraignment on Friday.

headline: Method of Music Education
abstract: John Lieb’s Saturday puzzle sends me around the world for an entry.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s fitting that we’ve had some scorching Saturday grids this hot July; today’s is no exception. I felt optimistic at the start after finding several inroads, but I got hopelessly stuck in a central spot. The end result was a slow solve time that was as slow as it is when I get a couple of bits of short fill and then stare blankly for a while at a puzzle.

headline: Baltimore Prosecutor Defeated in Democratic Primary Amid Legal Woes
abstract: Marilyn Mosby, who rose to national prominence for her handling of the death of Freddie Gray, was indicted in January on charges of perjury and financial misconduct.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Mosby lost her bid for a third term as Baltimore’s top prosecutor on Friday, ending a tenure that had thrust her into the national spotlight but was marred by legal difficulties.

headline: Sydney McLaughlin Broke Her Own World Record. Again.
abstract: McLaughlin, the reigning Olympic gold medalist, won her first world championship in 50.68 seconds at Hayward Field.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not so long ago, when Sydney McLaughlin was challenged whenever she planted herself in the starting blocks for the 400-meter hurdles. She knew she would face stiff competition from the likes of Dalilah Muhammad, a graceful runner with an impressive list of achievements.

headline: Wes Moore Wins the Democratic Primary for Maryland Governor
abstract: Mr. Moore, a celebrity author and former nonprofit executive, will aim to take back the office for Democrats after eight years under Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican who is term-limited.
lead_paragraph: Wes Moore, a celebrity author and former nonprofit executive who campaigned as a political outsider, has won the Democratic primary for governor of Maryland.

headline: Spouses of world leaders to join Ukraine’s first lady in a discussion on postwar lives.
abstract: The spouses of world leaders will be talking about the postwar reconstruction of Ukraine this weekend during the second Summit of First Ladies and Gentlemen, hosted by Olena Zelenska, the nation’s first lady.
lead_paragraph: The spouses of world leaders will be talking about the postwar reconstruction of Ukraine this weekend during the second Summit of First Ladies and Gentlemen, hosted by Olena Zelenska, the nation’s first lady.

headline: Two Dead and 1 Missing After Flash Flooding in New Mexico
abstract: The floods came as heavy rainfall struck an area that had been burned by the state’s largest recorded wildfire. More rain is expected across the state next week.
lead_paragraph: Two women were killed and another person was missing in New Mexico after flash floods swept through an area that had been burned by the state’s largest recorded wildfire, officials said on Friday.

headline: The State Department says two Americans died recently in Donbas.
abstract: Two Americans recently died in Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region, the U.S. State Department said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Two Americans recently died in Ukraine’s eastern Donbas region, the U.S. State Department said on Friday.

headline: Corrections: July 23, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 23, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Amazon’s acquisition of One Medical clinics misstated the year that Amazon acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy. It was 2018, not 2019. The article also misstated the plan used by patients of Iora Health, a company acquired last year by One Medical. Iora serves senior patients enrolled in Medicare, not Medicaid.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Luxury Rental Buildings Take ‘Working From Home’ to the Next Level
abstract: Developers are adding professional office spaces to the list of amenities in their mostly new buildings in cities around the country.
lead_paragraph: When Christopher Dossman and his wife, Yao Li, were looking for an apartment in New York last year, they compiled the usual list of preferences: washer/dryer, proximity to a grocery store, subway access. But a top priority for them was a work-from-home space.

headline: How the Government Is Failing Americans Uprooted by Calamity
abstract: Climate change is creating a growing class of displaced Americans, and the federal government is struggling to decide how to help them.
lead_paragraph: LAKE CHARLES, La. — Two summers ago, Hurricane Laura wrecked Betty Swope’s modest bungalow at the edge of Lake Charles, a city surrounded by oil refineries in southwest Louisiana. The Federal Emergency Management Agency helped at first, paying for Ms. Swope and her son Adrian to stay in hotels, then putting a trailer in their yard and providing about $7,000 toward fixing their house.

headline: A Museum Opens Its Garden to the Public
abstract: After a $13 million renovation, the Morgan Library & Museum has opened its oasis to the public.
lead_paragraph: After a $13 million renovation, the Morgan Library & Museum has opened its oasis to the public.

headline: ‘Just Think Rome’: The Morgan Library & Museum Opens Garden to the Public
abstract: After a $13 million renovation project, the institution, once the private residence and library of the financier, J. Pierpont Morgan, has opened its garden oasis to the public.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in its 116-year history, the Morgan Library & Museum in Midtown Manhattan has opened its garden to the public.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Uprooted by a Hurricane, and Again by FEMA
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 23, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “I mean, make up your mind. Are you going to help us, or are you going to get all your trailers back?”

headline: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Saturday.
abstract: Watch the men’s 4x100-meter relay.
lead_paragraph: Can the U.S. men, fresh off a sweep of the 200-meter podium, run away with another team medal in the 4x100-meter relay?

headline: Can I Force My Landlord to Install Window Boxes for Air-Conditioners?
abstract: It sounds like a simple enough request, but few things about New York City’s rent regulation rules are simple.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a ground-floor, rent-stabilized apartment in Harlem, with a window in the living room and another in the bedroom. For years, the security bars on both windows lacked emergency egress and space for a window-unit air-conditioner. I requested emergency egress for the bedroom window and a gate to accommodate air-conditioning in the living room, but when the landlord replaced the building’s windows, he put an emergency gate in the living room window and standard bars in the bedroom window, so neither accommodates air-conditioning. I’m stuck with a portable air-conditioner, which is much more expensive than a window unit. Can I compel the landlord to install bars that allow for air-conditioning?

headline: Liz Holtzman Wants Another Crack at Congress, 50 Years Later
abstract: She shattered glass ceilings, voted to impeach Nixon and helped chase out Nazis. But can Ms. Holtzman overcome one more political hurdle: her age?
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Holtzman has heard the doubters, the skeptics and the New Yorkers who were mildly surprised that she is still alive, let alone up to the challenge of running for Congress at age 80, half a century after she became one of the youngest women ever to serve there.

headline: A Powerhouse Team of Stars, Ring or No Ring
abstract: With Jim Kaat and Tony Oliva set for Hall of Fame induction, the Minnesota Twins of the 1960s and ’70s will shine in Cooperstown despite no World Series titles.
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — A humble little baseball sits at the bottom of a display case for David Ortiz on the third floor of the Hall of Fame. No hologram, no elaborate markings. In thick black ink, just below the red-seam horseshoe, someone scrawled “First HR.” Under that, in lighter pen: “Big Show.”

headline: After Roe, Pregnant Women With Cancer Diagnoses May Face Wrenching Choices
abstract: Urgent questions arise about how care of pregnant women with cancer will change in states where women are unable to terminate pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: In April of last year, Rachel Brown’s oncologist called with bad news — at age 36, she had an aggressive form of breast cancer. The very next day, she found out she was pregnant after nearly a year of trying with her fiancé to have a baby.

headline: Interstate Abortion Travel Is Already Straining Parts of the System
abstract: Even in some states where abortion remains legal, wait times for appointments are long because of increased demand.
lead_paragraph: The reversal of Roe v. Wade did not affect the legal status of abortion in New Mexico, where seven clinics are still operating. But that does not mean an abortion is easy to obtain there.

headline: We Need to Keep Building Houses, Even if No One Wants to Buy
abstract: Right now, builders have too many homes and not enough people to sell them to. In the long term, the United States has the opposite problem: Not enough houses for all the people who want them.
lead_paragraph: The United States has a deep, decades-old housing shortage. Also, at the moment, homebuilders across the country are pulling back on development because they can’t sell enough homes.

headline: A Taste for Cannibalism?
abstract: A spate of recent stomach-churning books, TV shows and films suggests we’ve never looked so delicious — to one another.
lead_paragraph: An image came to Chelsea G. Summers: a boyfriend, accidentally on purpose hit by a car, some quick work with a corkscrew and his liver served Tuscan style, on toast.

headline: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
abstract: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The day before Shinzo Abe was assassinated, Tetsuya Yamagami sent a letter saying that the Unification Church had ruined his life, “destroying my family and driving it into bankruptcy.”

headline: One Day in the Heat: What Cooling Off Looks and Feels Like in New York
abstract: How do you stay cool when the weather is so hot? The answers are as diverse as the city itself.
lead_paragraph: Parasols, paper fans, flowing dresses, floppy hats, portable neck fans. Everywhere, water: bottles sweating beads of condensation, water guns spraying in parks and inside apartments. Fire hydrants transforming into sprinklers.

headline: Comics That Read Top to Bottom Are Bringing in New Readers
abstract: The explosion of web comics has been driven by tapping into an audience the industry had long overlooked: young, female readers.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the fans who powered the comic book industry made weekly pilgrimages to their local comic shops to buy the latest issues about their favorite caped-and-cowled adventurers. These Wednesday Warriors, named for the day new installments typically land on shelves, still do. Voracious readers of printed comics, they skew older — and are mostly male.

headline: China Evergrande C.E.O. Resigns After Loans Come Under Scrutiny
abstract: The resignation was the latest setback for the embattled Chinese property developer, which is expected to announce a plan to restructure its debt of more than $300 billion.
lead_paragraph: China Evergrande, the embattled Chinese property developer, said late Friday that its chief executive had resigned, the latest setback for the company as it struggles to manage its crushing $300 billion in debt.

headline: The Times’s Theater Critic Reviews Stratford’s New Theater
abstract: The Stratford Festival in Ontario opened a glamorous new theater last month that prioritizes the theater itself, not just what surrounds it.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Green, the chief theater critic for The New York Times, has just returned from the Stratford Festival in Ontario, where the 2022 season started with the opening of a new theater.

headline: Missiles strike Odesa, hitting a critical port for global grain supplies.
abstract: The explosions risk destabilizing an international deal meant to reopen shipping routes seen as critical for easing concerns over world food supplies
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — A string of explosions rocked Ukraine’s southern city of Odesa on Saturday, hitting one of the country’s most important ports less than 24 hours after a deal was signed to secure the transit of millions of tons of grain through Black Sea routes.

headline: Loving an Addict, While Caring for Myself
abstract: Readers react to a guest essay critical of the concept of codependency and tough love.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, as a celebrated Chinese director prepared to film a movie, his team sent the novelist Geling Yan a 33-page script with her name printed on each page. Ms. Yan said that made sense to her because she had written the Chinese-language novel that inspired the film.

headline: Russia and Ukraine trade attacks as fighting shifts to the south.
abstract: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian and Ukrainian forces both launched strikes with long-range weapons in the south of Ukraine overnight into Saturday, apparently aiming for supply lines and antiaircraft weapons behind the front lines on both sides as the center of gravity in the fighting has shifted in recent days from the country’s east to the south.
lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Russian and Ukrainian forces both launched strikes with long-range weapons in the south of Ukraine overnight into Saturday, apparently aiming for supply lines and antiaircraft weapons behind the front lines on both sides as the center of gravity in the fighting has shifted in recent days from the country’s east to the south.

headline: After Parkland, One Question Remains: What Is Justice?
abstract: Four years after the Hoyers lost their youngest child in the Florida school shooting, a jury will decide whether the killer should get the death penalty. The Hoyers had to decide, too.
lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Sometime after 1:30 a.m. in a hotel conference room, the law enforcement officer’s eyes — even before his words — told Tom and Gena Hoyer that their youngest child was gone, killed in a mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

headline: Indoor Games
abstract: When it’s more comfortable inside than out, it’s time to play games.
lead_paragraph: A colleague recently drew my attention to a story that ran in The Times a couple of years ago about the late 1960s board game Group Therapy, in which players take turns drawing cards that pose intimate questions and psychological challenges. (A sample: “You have been accused of overintellectualizing your hang-ups. Respond — without falling victim to that criticism.”)

headline: Four Things Nations Can Do to Conserve Energy
abstract: European Union officials have called on countries in the bloc to sharply reduce their natural gas consumption. These are some of the strategies they could use.
lead_paragraph: This month, temperatures in Britain reached a record 40.3 degrees Celsius, or 104.5 Fahrenheit, capping a brutal heat wave that scorched Europe and sent electricity demand soaring.

headline: Below an Israeli City, a Musical Harmony Belies the Tensions Above Ground
abstract: In an underground reservoir built 1,233 years ago in a city that saw sectarian riots last year, visitors hear a beguiling musical composition that combines Arab love songs with Hebrew poetry.
lead_paragraph: RAMLA, Israel — In a subterranean reservoir, underneath the Israeli city of Ramla, the stone walls echo with an Arab-Jewish harmony at odds with the frictions of the world above.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 18, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: How can older adults stay safe during a heat wave?
abstract: Older adults are particularly vulnerable to the dangers of extreme heat. A majority of heat-related deaths in the United States occur among people who are older than 65, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, so those individuals need to be especially vigilant amid rising temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Older adults are particularly vulnerable to the dangers of extreme heat. A majority of heat-related deaths in the United States occur among people who are older than 65, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, so those individuals need to be especially vigilant amid rising temperatures.

headline: There Are 100 People in America With Way Too Much Power
abstract: Here’s how to put them in their place.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of my Tuesday column on the Senate, I gestured toward the idea of making it into something like the British House of Lords, which has limited power to veto legislation or make policy. Most democracies with bicameral national legislatures have done something similar, empowering their lower, popular chambers and weakening their upper chambers.

headline: Amid Sri Lanka’s Crisis, Cricket Carries On
abstract: The success of the men’s national team has offered solace to the country, and one fan called the players “brand ambassadors during this time of hardship.”
lead_paragraph: As a political crisis and economic meltdown ravaged Sri Lanka, the computer science student Aadhil Siddhique was among the legions of people there who found relief in the simple pleasures of an old ritual: cricket.

headline: President Biden’s Human Rights Dilemma
abstract: The complications of keeping campaign promises.
lead_paragraph: It was a fraught fist bump.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Monkeypox Spread a Global Health Emergency
abstract: There have been more than 16,000 cases in 75 countries, overwhelmingly among men who have sex with men.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in two years, the World Health Organization has taken the extraordinary step of declaring a global emergency. This time the cause is monkeypox, which has spread in just a few weeks to dozens of countries and infected tens of thousands of people.

headline: Try to Resist the Call of the Doomers
abstract: The best way to spur action is to begin from a place of optimism.
lead_paragraph: In Greek mythology, Cassandra was a Trojan princess who was given a great gift by the god Apollo: the ability to see into the future. But when Cassandra refused his advances, he added a curse. He made it so no one would believe her prophecies. When she predicted the fall of Troy, for example, and attempted to expose the Greek soldiers hiding in the Trojan horse, people ignored her, calling her vision “ruinous madness” — to their doom.

headline: The Cruel Irony of Inhalers That Make Climate Change Worse
abstract: Some inhalers use greenhouse gases to help deliver medication into the lungs. The good news is there are alternatives.
lead_paragraph: Drought and extreme heat, both exacerbated by climate change, have paved the way for prime fire conditions across the Western United States. As wildfire season ramps up and smoke re-emerges as a serious health threat, experts are encouraging people to get smoke ready. This includes stocking up on air purifiers and filters and, for those with lung disease at highest risk, refilling medical devices like inhalers.

headline: Climate Change Is Not Negotiable
abstract: President Biden’s best course is to take the same regulatory path Barack Obama was forced to follow.
lead_paragraph: The American West has gone bone dry, the Great Salt Lake is vanishing and water levels in Lake Mead and Lake Powell, the two great life-giving reservoirs on the Colorado River basin, are declining with alarming speed. Wildfires are incinerating crops in France, Spain, Portugal and Italy, while parts of Britain suffocated last week in temperatures exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Why It Matters That J. Lo Is Now J. Aff
abstract: I like the romance of Bennifer 2.0 as much as the next person, but her name change makes me wince.
lead_paragraph: It could be the plot of a Jennifer Lopez romantic comedy: Boy meets girl. Boy and girl date, fall in love, get engaged … but, alas, the nuptials are not to be. Boy and girl go their separate ways, each getting married, having children, getting divorced. They remain the “one that got away” to each other. And then, older and wiser, they fall in love again.

headline: Russia Strikes Odesa Port, Stirring Doubts on Deal to Export Grain
abstract: The string of explosions in Ukraine’s most important port came less than 24 hours after the two countries struck a deal on grain shipments, and prompted accusations from Ukrainian leaders that Russia could not be trusted.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — A string of explosions rocked Ukraine’s southern city of Odesa on Saturday, hitting one of the country’s most important ports less than 24 hours after Russia and Ukraine signed a deal to secure the transit of millions of tons of grain through Black Sea routes.

headline: Meet the Canine Officers Guarding American Agriculture
abstract: With international travel returning to prepandemic levels, these floppy-eared hounds are sniffing out deadly diseases and pests at border crossings one mango or sausage at a time.
lead_paragraph: DULLES, Va. — As a throng of travelers at Dulles International Airport elbowed their way to the baggage carousel on a recent sweltering afternoon, a federal officer zeroed in on a tired woman, sniffed her suitcases and sat down.

headline: Turkey’s Leader Remains a Headache for Biden Despite Aiding in Ukraine Deal
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey assisted in brokering an agreement to unblock Ukrainian grain but has alarmed U.S. officials on other fronts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Russia and Ukraine reached an agreement on Friday to unblock Ukrainian grain exports, Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, played the role of benevolent statesman.

headline: Rapidly Spreading California Wildfire Forces Thousands to Evacuate
abstract: The Oak fire, near Yosemite National Park, has more than tripled in size since Friday and threatens thousands of structures.
lead_paragraph: A rapidly growing wildfire in California near Yosemite National Park has more than tripled in size since Friday night, threatening thousands of structures and bringing evacuation notices for 3,800 residents, the authorities said.

headline: In Jan. 6 Hearings, Gender Divide Has Been Strong Undercurrent
abstract: An investigation that has revealed grave threats to democracy, plotted and carried out mostly by men, has a heavily female cast of narrators who have paid a public price for speaking out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before Sarah Matthews, a former deputy White House press secretary, even opened her mouth to testify on Thursday before the select committee investigating the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol, the House Republican Conference attacked her on Twitter as a “liar” and a “pawn” of Democrats.

headline: On the Docket: Atlanta v. Trumpworld
abstract: Eighteen months into a criminal investigation of election interference by Donald J. Trump and his allies, a Georgia prosecutor is beginning to show the broad contours of her inquiry.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The criminal investigation into efforts by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn his election loss in Georgia has begun to entangle, in one way or another, an expanding assemblage of characters:

headline: Utah University Admits ‘Shortcomings’ in Handling Domestic Abuse Case
abstract: The University of Utah acknowledged missteps in how it responded to concerns about the safety of a student, Zhifan Dong, 19, who was killed in February.
lead_paragraph: Zhifan Dong had only been at the University of Utah for a few months when she raised the first alarm: She told a residential director at the university’s housing department that her ex-boyfriend, who lived in the same dorm building, had assaulted her in a downtown Salt Lake City motel room.

headline: Conductor Dies After Collapsing During Performance in Munich
abstract: Stefan Soltesz was in the middle of Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” when he fell from his podium shortly before the end of the first act.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Stefan Soltesz, a prominent and in-demand Austrian conductor, died on Friday night after collapsing during a performance at Munich’s main opera house.

headline: Why Trump Is Weakening
abstract: Ron DeSantis and the Jan. 6 committee are exposing the limits of his grievance strategy.
lead_paragraph: In Donald Trump’s quest to sustain his dominance over the Republican Party, his claim to have been robbed of victory in 2020 has been a crucial talisman, lending him powers denied to previous defeated presidential candidates. By insisting that he was cheated out of victory, Trump fashioned himself into a king-in-exile rather than a loser — an Arthur betrayed by the Mordreds of his own party, waiting in the Avalon of Mar-a-Lago to make his prophesied return.

headline: Google Fires Engineer Who Claims Its A.I. Is Conscious
abstract: The engineer, Blake Lemoine, contends that the company’s language model has a soul. The company denies that and says he violated its security policies.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google fired one of its engineers, Blake Lemoine, on Friday, more than a month after he raised ethical concerns about how the company was testing an artificial intelligence chatbot that he believes has achieved consciousness.

headline: Michael Henderson, Funk Bassist Turned Crooner, Dies at 71
abstract: He was a sideman with Stevie Wonder and Miles Davis before embarking on a successful second career as a singer of soulful, romantic ballads.
lead_paragraph: Michael Henderson, a self-taught bassist who performed and recorded in the 1960s and ’70s with Stevie Wonder and Miles Davis, then remade himself as a popular soulful balladeer and songwriter, died on Tuesday at his home in Dallas, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta. He was 71.

headline: Suspect in Zeldin Attack Is Arrested on Federal Charge
abstract: The suspect, who had been released without bail shortly after the Thursday attack on Representative Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate for New York governor, will be held pending a hearing next week.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of using a sharp weapon to confront Representative Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, on Thursday night has been arrested on a federal assault charge, officials said.

headline: U.S. Taking Emergency Steps to Protect Sequoias From Wildfires
abstract: The U.S. Forest Service will expedite plans to clear brush that fuels fires and take other measures to protect the centuries-old trees.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Forest Service said on Friday that it would take emergency action, including removing low-lying vegetation that can fuel fires and other measures, to protect giant sequoia groves that are threatened by wildfires.

headline: Going Somewhere?
abstract: Ross and Jessie Trudeau(!) invite us on a long, happy journey.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Monumental congratulations are in order here, before anyone pats themselves on the back for their solve: Today’s constructors are tying the knot this weekend, perhaps at the moment you read this. (Was that a dove that just fluttered by? The rustle of a bridal bouquet, the scent of damask roses? I’ll stop).

headline: Representing a Nation on TV, and a Running Team on Instagram
abstract: Distance running is a relentlessly individual sport. But professional running teams, and their polished Instagram accounts, are upending that dynamic.
lead_paragraph: At the track and field world championships, distance runners compete on behalf of their countries. What’s less visible to the average fan is that most are also competing for their shoe company sponsors, which largely provide the funding that makes track and field a viable career. Even less visible to the average fan — especially if you aren’t on Instagram — is that a growing number of them are competing on behalf of professional running teams.

headline: Mississippi Fires Lawyer Trying to Recoup Misused Welfare Funds
abstract: The lawyer had issued a subpoena that could reveal details about the involvement of a former governor and a football star in the scandal.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A lawyer working for a Mississippi state agency and trying to recoup tens of millions of dollars in misused welfare funds was fired on Friday after he issued a subpoena that could turn up details about the involvement of prominent Mississippians — including the former Governor Phil Bryant and the retired football star Brett Favre — in one of the ugliest scandals to shake the nation’s poorest state in recent years.

headline: Wait Begins for Falling 23-Ton Rocket Booster After China Space Station Launch
abstract: China successfully docked a new lab module to its space station. But no one knows where debris will land from the rocket stage that sent it to orbit.
lead_paragraph: Another big Chinese rocket launched to space on Sunday at 2:22 p.m. Beijing time, and once again, no one knows where or when it will come down.

headline: American Women Run Away with Gold in the 4x100-Meters. American Men Settle for Silver.
abstract: Christian Coleman, Noah Lyles, Elijah Hall and Marvin Bracy settled for silver after a botched handoff exchange.
lead_paragraph: In another men’s relay hindered by a butchered handoff exchange, the U.S. settled for a silver medal in Saturday’s 4x100-meter relay. They finished in 37.55 seconds.

headline: Last Stand at Azovstal: Inside the Siege That Shaped the Ukraine War
abstract: For 80 days, at a sprawling steelworks, a relentless Russian assault met unyielding Ukrainian resistance. This is how it was for those who fought, and for those trapped beneath the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: The two Mi-8 helicopters tore across enemy territory early on the morning of March 21, startling the Russian soldiers below. Inside were Ukrainian Special Forces fighters carrying crates of Stinger and Javelin missiles, as well as a satellite internet system. They were flying barely 20 feet above ground into the hottest combat zone in the war.

headline: Quotation of the Day: What is Justice? One Parkland Family’s Agonizing Journey.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “For such a long time, you are raising your kids, and that feels like your purpose. And then suddenly, one day, one of your purposes is gone.”

headline: Corrections: July 24, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 24, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the perform­ance of municipal bonds this year referred incorrectly to the state tax deductibility of income from nationwide municipal bond funds for residents of California. For Califor­nia residents, the deductibility depends on the amount that a particular fund invests in California municipal bonds and U.S. Treas­uries; California residents would not get a deduction in every case.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Conceptual Covers That Push the Conversation
abstract: The creative director of The New York Times Magazine explains her team’s approach to visualizing each issue and shares how they decide to take risks.
lead_paragraph: Asked how far in advance she works on a cover of The New York Times Magazine, Gail Bichler paused to let herself be amused by the question, laughed and said: “Like, what do I want it to be?”

headline: ‘The High Point Was Sitting on Our Grandmother’s Deck’
abstract: Remembering the 1964 World’s Fair, an aloe plant at the bus stop and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Pope to Offer a Long-Sought Apology to Canada’s Indigenous People
abstract: Pope Francis will travel to an Indigenous community in Canada to apologize for the church’s role in residential schools that tried to erase Indigenous culture, and where thousands of children died.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Pope Francis is traveling to Canada this week to ​apologize to ​Indigenous communities for the Roman Catholic Church’s role in ​the country’s notorious residential school system, ​​where thousands of Indigenous children died, and countless others were sexually and physically abused.

headline: Triple-Digit Temperatures Break Records in the Northeast
abstract: Daily record highs were set in cities along the East Coast, including Boston and Newark, which was on its fifth day of triple-digit temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Several cities in the Northeast saw record-high daily temperatures on Sunday as a nationwide scorching peaked in many places around the United States.

headline: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Sunday.
abstract: Catch the men’s 5,000 meters, the women’s 800 meters and the women’s 4x400-meters.
lead_paragraph: We’ve arrived at the final day of the world championships here in Eugene, Ore.

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: No More Pet Store Puppies? New York May Finally Ban Sales.
abstract: A bill prohibiting the sale of dogs, cats and rabbits in New York pet stores, passed by the Legislature in June, awaits a decision from Gov. Kathy Hochul.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of postcards, with visceral images of underfed golden retriever puppies living in filthy conditions, are flooding the governor’s office in New York. A huge email campaign has been launched by national animal rights groups.

headline: Why Big Tech Is Making a Big Play for Live Sports
abstract: Competing for rights to broadcast games from the N.F.L. and other leagues could be hard for broadcast and cable companies that “aren’t playing by the same financial rules.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More than a decade after Apple disrupted the music industry and Amazon upended retail, the tech heavyweights have set their sights on a new arena ripe for change: live sports.

headline: After Recent Turmoil, the Race for Texas Governor Is Tightening
abstract: A series of tragedies and challenges have soured the mood of Texans and made the governor’s race perhaps the most competitive since the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Texas — One of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history. The revival of a 1920s ban on abortion. The country’s worst episode of migrant death in recent memory. And an electrical grid, which failed during bitter cold, now straining under soaring heat.

headline: ‘Parentese’ Is Truly a Lingua Franca, Global Study Finds
abstract: In an ambitious cross-cultural study, researchers found that adults around the world speak and sing to babies in similar ways.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all seen it, we’ve all cringed at it, we’ve all done it ourselves: talked to a baby like it was, you know, a baby.

headline: Ties Between Alex Jones and Radio Network Show Economics of Misinformation
abstract: The Genesis Communications Network built a lucrative business alongside the radio host, whose show the company has syndicated for more than two decades.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Pretty in Any Color: Women on the Court Make the Style Rules
abstract: Players in women’s basketball are styling themselves how they want, because they can. Their choices also can be lucrative.
lead_paragraph: Angel Reese considers herself “a pink kind of girl.”

headline: It’s Getting Hot in Here
abstract: Some of the best looks from the parties held for Kith, Kenzo, Shayne Oliver and the Ali Forney Center.
lead_paragraph: Fashion took over the party scene last week. Kith, the sneaker retail temple, unveiled its collaboration with Spider-Man, who turned 60, with a pop-up store in Queens that featured limited-edition hoodies, sweaters, T-shirts and skateboards.

headline: Fears rise for a rights activist captured while fighting for Ukraine.
abstract: Russian propaganda has demonized Maksym Butkevych, a former journalist and campaigner who was taken prisoner in the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk.
lead_paragraph: Maksym Butkevych made his name in Ukraine as a journalist and human rights activist, campaigning on behalf of refugees and internally displaced people and serving on the board of Ukraine’s chapter of Amnesty International.

headline: Jonas Vingegaard Wins Tour de France, Completing His Sudden Ascent to Top
abstract: Vingegaard, 25, won cycling’s most prestigious race on his second attempt, setting up a new rivalry with the two-time champion he dethroned, Tadej Pogacar.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Head down and legs churning, Jonas Vingegaard crossed the finish line of the penultimate stage of the Tour de France on Saturday and cupped his hand over his mouth, as if to stifle a gasp. He had done what he had come to do, and his astonishing accomplishment was sinking in.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Books About Sex That Every Family Should Read’
abstract: The author Cory Silverberg bucks decades of conventional wisdom on how to teach children about intimacy.
lead_paragraph: How do you teach your child about sex? It’s a perennial question that has spawned hundreds of illustrated books meant to demystify sexual intercourse.

headline: There’s More Than One Way to Ban a Book
abstract: A serious strain of self-censorship has taken root within the left-leaning publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, Vladimir Nabokov’s “Lolita” was banned in France, Britain and Argentina, but not in the United States, where its publisher, Walter Minton, released the book after multiple American publishing houses rejected it.

headline: This Week in Business: Amazon’s Latest Acquisition
abstract: Netflix reports a drop in subscribers, but it could have been worse. The Fed announces its next rate increase. And we’ll hear how strong, or weak, the U.S. economy is.
lead_paragraph: It is theoretically possible to go through a day patronizing only Amazon-owned companies: You might buy groceries at Whole Foods, listen to a book on Audible on your commute, check your Goodreads account and then, of course, visit Amazon.com. Now, the e-commerce giant is making a new push into health care. Amazon announced on Thursday that it had reached a $3.9 billion deal to buy One Medical, a network of primary care clinics, as part of its quest to become a major player in the industry. The deal is the first acquisition under Andy Jassy, who became chief executive a year ago after Jeff Bezos stepped down. Mr. Jassy’s approach to the role has been much different from his predecessor’s, but on this decision, he hasn’t diverged too drastically from Mr. Bezos. One Medical is not the first health-care-related company Amazon has purchased. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.

headline: Sri Lanka’s Uprising
abstract: What led to the recent protests.
lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka’s recent upheaval offers an extreme example of the world’s recent problems. Covid disrupted the country’s major industries, particularly tourism, and then leaders failed to adapt — setting off a chain of economic calamities, including food and fuel shortages. The crisis prompted protests, culminating in the president’s resignation and the installation of a new president on Wednesday.

headline: ‘An abyss of fear’: A report accuses Russia of further abuses against civilians.
abstract: Human Rights Watch cataloged a litany of torture, inhumane treatment, arbitrary detention and disappearances in southern Ukraine and said that the atrocities could amount to war crimes.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces have tortured and beaten civilians in the areas of southern Ukraine that they control, part of a series of abuses that may amount to war crimes, Human Rights Watch said this weekend in a report that further undermined the public case repeatedly made by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for the invasion.

headline: From ‘Dirty Dancing’ to ‘Scandal,’ On-Screen Abortion Stories Carry Sway
abstract: Abortion is common and safe, but you might not know it from watching TV or movies.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since the fall of Roe v. Wade, people have supported abortion access and rights in many ways, including spreading information about abortion pills and defending brave doctors. My contribution has been thinking about TV and movies.

headline: New Breastfeeding Guidelines: Helpful or Ill Timed?
abstract: Readers discuss Jessica Grose’s criticisms of a new American Academy of Pediatrics policy statement. Also: An uneasy feeling in the world; military recruits.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Ease into things with casual but fun Chicago-style hot dogs, then make plans for pantry pasta and kung pao chicken later on.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Not for me the long-simmered Sunday sauce and meatballs, at least not at the end of a sweaty summer weekend. I go big on Saturday nights this time of year, smoking meat and making pizzas over live fire, steaming clams and corn, assembling platters of tomatoes, serving buckles and watermelon. When Sunday evening arrives, tapping at its watch and pointing out what’s on the schedule for Monday, I’m eager for simplicity.

headline: Too Many New Yorkers Can’t Swim. It’s Time to Change That.
abstract: New York City is letting down its residents by nixing swimming lessons.
lead_paragraph: When sharks began appearing along New York beaches this summer, officials sprang into action.

headline: Carleton Varney, Interior Designer Known as Mr. Color, Dies at 85
abstract: He was trained by the maximalist decorator Dorothy Draper, who favored bold colors, and he inherited her aversion to the bland and the beige.
lead_paragraph: Carleton Varney, the ebullient interior designer whose enthusiastic use of color in hotels, castles, palaces and the habitats of film and theater royalty — and one president — earned him the nickname Mr. Color, died on July 14 in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85.

headline: A French University Confronts Medical Crimes and Its Nazi Past
abstract: A report on the University of Strasbourg’s takeover by Nazis during World War II and on medical crimes they committed there sheds light on a period that had been mostly scrubbed from official memory.
lead_paragraph: STRASBOURG, France — For decades, students at the prestigious University of Strasbourg swapped rumors that human remains from Nazi victims, preserved as anatomical or pathological specimens, were still somewhere on campus.

headline: Pakistan’s Deadly Flood Season Worsened by Climate Change and Bad Infrastructure
abstract: Monsoon rains have devastated Pakistan’s economic hub, Karachi, adding urgency to pleas to better equip cities to handle more frequent extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Year after year in Kausar Niazi Colony, a slum in the port city of Karachi, Murtaza Hussain and his neighbors watched as monsoon rains flooded into their homes, damaging furniture, televisions and other precious valuables.

headline: On U.S. Foreign Policy, the New Boss Acts a Lot Like the Old One
abstract: The Biden administration has charted the same course as the Trump administration on strategic priorities like China, the Middle East and U.S. military deployments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A fist bump and meeting with the crown prince of Saudi Arabia. Tariffs and export controls on China. Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. American troops out of Afghanistan.

headline: Diana Kennedy, Authority on Mexican Cooking, Dies at 99
abstract: Her books taught Americans about the regional nature of the cuisine. Also: “There is always someone who wants to know how to clean an iguana, so why not?”
lead_paragraph: Diana Kennedy, an Englishwoman whose 1972 cookbook “The Cuisines of Mexico” revealed the glories of regional Mexican fare to American readers, died on Sunday at her home in Michoacán, Mexico. She was 99.

headline: ‘Seagull’ Review: Blurring the Lines of Fiction
abstract: Elevator Repair Service’s Chekhov revival has promising ideas about art, experimentation and truth, but the production inevitably falls flat, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: If only I could find someone who loves me enough to gift me a dead bird in a brown paper bag.

headline: Review: Finding the Heat in ‘Sacred Earth’
abstract: At Ragamala Dance Company’s nature-themed performance at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn!, the strongest connection was between music and dance, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: At BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! on Friday night, the air was muggy but periodically cooled by breezes. “Sacred Earth,” the work that Ragamala Dance Company performed in the Lena Horne Bandshell in Prospect Park, felt like the reverse: mostly mild with some hotter currents.

headline: Five Cocktails to Help Beat the Heat
abstract: Bartenders based in New York City, Miami, London, Paris and Barcelona provide drink recipes perfect for high summer.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to entertaining, drinks can be trickier than food. Anyone can have a surprising salad ingredient or a closely guarded low ’n ’slow barbecue procedure. Far fewer hosts think outside the wine-beer-soda box. But it can be done. Here, five leading international bartenders and mixologists share creative summer drink recipes you could easily make and that, whether for a riff on a Waldorf salad or a strawberry spritzer, will keep your guests cool, refreshed and, perhaps most importantly, impressed.

headline: Edward Feiner, 75, Dies; Revolutionized Look of Federal Buildings
abstract: As the government’s chief architect, he prioritized good design in the construction of hundreds of courthouses and office buildings.
lead_paragraph: Edward A. Feiner, who as the chief architect of the U.S. government revolutionized the public image of countless federal agencies by hiring renowned architects to design hundreds of courthouses, government laboratories, border stations and office buildings, died on July 1 in Falls Church, Va. He was 75.

headline: In a Memphis restaurant, no relief from the heat.
abstract: The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory for Memphis on Saturday that will continue through Sunday evening, with temperatures expected to hit nearly 100 degrees with high humidity.
lead_paragraph: The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory for Memphis on Saturday that will continue through Sunday evening, with temperatures expected to hit nearly 100 degrees with high humidity.

headline: ‘We Survived Another Night’: In Ruined Suburb, Solace in a Small Community
abstract: In a largely abandoned apartment complex on the outskirts of Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-biggest city, the people who stayed behind find comfort in their surroundings and each other.
lead_paragraph: SALTIVKA, Ukraine — On a recent Saturday morning, Yevhenia Botiyeva weeded the flower bed outside her apartment building, a routine she has taken on since she returned home in late spring.

headline: Oregon athletes find a creative way to make money: Housing rentals.
abstract: Now that college athletes can profit from their fame, some University of Oregon runners are getting paid to help visitors staying in town for the track and field world championships.
lead_paragraph: As the track and field world championships made their first appearance in the U.S. at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., this month, some University of Oregon athletes decided to creatively capitalize on their fame and the lack of abundant housing in this quaint college town.

headline: We Can’t Afford Not to Prosecute Trump
abstract: He will never willingly walk away from the presidency. It was the greatest grift of his life.
lead_paragraph: We all learn from failure.

headline: Review: ‘The Silent Woman,’ an Opera About Putting on an Opera
abstract: Bard SummerScape unveiled a rare staging of Richard Strauss’s opera, composed amid the Nazis’ rise to power.
lead_paragraph: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “Ha! A silent woman?,” sings the basso buffo Morosus in Richard Strauss’s “Die Schweigsame Frau.” “You’ll only find her in a churchyard under a stone cross.”

headline: Huff, Pant, Sweat: High Heat Shortens the New York City Triathlon
abstract: Organizers take more precautions for athletes, volunteers and emergency workers.
lead_paragraph: Excessive heat disrupted the New York City Triathlon on Sunday, forcing organizers to shorten the race and make other accommodations for safety.

headline: Russia Tells Famine-Fearing Africa It’s Not to Blame for Food Shortage
abstract: Badly needed grain has been piling up in Ukrainian ports since Moscow invaded, but Russia’s top diplomat is in Africa saying the West is to blame.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia likes to cast himself as the leader of a global movement rising up against domination by the United States and its allies. On Sunday, his top diplomat brought that message directly to Africa, hoping to turn the hunger and social strife across the continent to Russia’s advantage.

headline: At Least 17 Migrants Die After Boat Capsizes Off Bahamas
abstract: The tragedy highlights migrants’ growing use of dangerous sea routes to reach the United States.
lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — At least 17 Haitians, including a child, died Sunday after their boat capsized off the Bahamas on its way to Florida, the latest tragedy amid a spike in the number of migrants trying to reach the United States by sea.

headline: Maggie Rogers’s Higher Calling
abstract: Musicians often talk about seeking the divine in their work. The 28-year-old singer-songwriter went to Harvard to study it as she made her second major-label album, “Surrender.”
lead_paragraph: Like a lot of artists during the early days of the pandemic, Maggie Rogers was living a sequestered, solitary life. She had retreated to coastal Maine, trying to alleviate the burnout of touring for her 2019 major-label debut “Heard It In a Past Life,” with little plan to write. “I was hiding out,” she said. “At a complete loss for words.”

headline: Biden’s Covid Symptoms Continue to Improve, Doctor Says
abstract: Public health officials have pointed to his case — which an adviser said was caused by BA.5 — as a reminder of the risk posed by the highly transmissible subvariant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden continues to “improve significantly” after testing positive for the coronavirus on Thursday, his physician, Dr. Kevin O’Connor, said on Sunday.

headline: He Runs a New York Real Estate Empire. Did He Steal It?
abstract: Homeowners across the city say they were swindled out of their properties. But courts have been slow to act.
lead_paragraph: Over the past dozen years, Sanford Solny has built a New York real estate empire, snatching up small residential buildings across the city that churn out hundreds of thousands of dollars in rent.

headline: Congo to Auction Land to Oil Companies: ‘Our Priority Is Not to Save the Planet’
abstract: Peatlands and rainforests in the Congo Basin protect the planet by storing carbon. Now, in a giant leap backward for the climate, they’re being auctioned off for drilling.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The Democratic Republic of Congo, home to one of the largest old-growth rainforests on Earth, is auctioning off vast amounts of land in a push to become “the new destination for oil investments,” part of a global shift as the world retreats on fighting climate change in a scramble for fossil fuels.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seeks Support in Africa
abstract: Also, the W.H.O. declares monkeypox a global emergency and China launches a rocket into space.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, set off on a tour of four African countries — Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo — seeking to place blame on the West for war-related grain shortages that have sparked fears of famine.

headline: Bob Rafelson, Director of ‘Five Easy Pieces,’ Dies at 89
abstract: A central figure in the New Hollywood movement, he was also the co-creator of the TV pop group the Monkees and featured it in a movie, “Head.”
lead_paragraph: Bob Rafelson, an iconoclastic director and producer who was a central figure of the New Hollywood movement that jump-started American cinema in the wake of the 1960s counterculture upheavals, died on Saturday at his home in Aspen, Colo. He was 89.

headline: All the Pieces Seemed to Align for the Liberty Except One: Winning
abstract: Despite a more stable home at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a new coach and stars in place, the team has struggled with injuries and gaining traction in the competitive New York sports market.
lead_paragraph: The Liberty had seemingly done everything right.

headline: Heat Waves Sweep the Northeast Over Sweltering Weekend
abstract: Newark sets a record with five straight days of temperatures above 100 degrees, and other parts of the country, like Oklahoma, also experienced triple-digit heat.
lead_paragraph: Scorching temperatures swept the Northeast on Sunday in the region’s first prolonged heat wave of the summer, with a record-breaking five straight days of triple-digit temperatures in Newark and blistering heat in Boston; Providence, R.I.; and Manchester, N.H.

headline: What Prancer and Dancer Do
abstract: Michael T. Buerke makes his New York Times Crossword debut, and he may be familiar to some of our readers.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — It never fails to make me smile when a crossword solver decides to try constructing a puzzle. This evolution from player to game maker is special, because it shows that the person is deeply invested and sees crosswords as more than just two-dimensional tests of vocabulary.

headline: ‘Everybody Is Dug In’: Kansans Fiercely Debate the First Post-Roe Vote on Abortion
abstract: The Aug. 2 ballot question will decide whether the State Constitution will allow legislators to ban or further restrict the procedure.
lead_paragraph: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kansas voters will decide next week whether to remove protections of abortion rights from their State Constitution, providing the first electoral test of Americans’ attitudes on the issue since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

headline: As Jan. 6 Panel’s Evidence Piled Up, Conservative Media Doubled Down
abstract: Many of Donald J. Trump’s allies in the media believe the reports about violence and criminal conduct committed by Trump supporters have been exaggerated.
lead_paragraph: After the Jan. 6 committee’s final summer hearing last week, the talk on the sets of CNN and MSNBC turned to an intriguing if familiar possibility about what might result from the panel’s finding. The case for a criminal prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump, many pundits said, was not only justified but seemed more than likely given the evidence of his inaction as rioters sacked the Capitol.

headline: Marvel Studios Unveils ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’
abstract: The studio announced news of the film’s release on Saturday at the pop-culture convention Comic-Con International in San Diego.
lead_paragraph: Marvel Studios has unveiled a trailer for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” — the long-awaited sequel to its hit film “Black Panther” — which it said would open in cinemas in the United States on Nov. 11.

headline: These are some of the cities that set heat records on Sunday.
abstract: A summer heat wave spread across the East Coast and parts of the South and Midwest.
lead_paragraph: Cities across the United States set temperature records on Sunday as a summer heat wave spread across the East Coast and parts of the South and Midwest.

headline: For the Hall of Fame’s New Class, Timing Was Everything
abstract: While David Ortiz sailed in as a first-ballot Hall of Famer, the year’s other new inductees had to wait for decades — four did not live to see the honor.
lead_paragraph: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — When John Jordan “Buck” O’Neil Jr. wrote his memoir, in 1996, he called it “I Was Right On Time.” It was a challenging, counterintuitive title for the life story of a man barred from playing Major League Baseball because of his skin color.

headline: An American killed in Ukraine was moved to volunteer by his heritage, a friend says.
abstract: Joining the fight “was something that he needed to do,” a close friend said of Luke Lucyszyn.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian commander over the weekend identified two Americans who were recently killed in the nation’s eastern Donbas region.

headline: Yes, I’m Pregnant. No, I Don’t Need Your Thoughts.
abstract: But chances are, you’ll tell me anyway.
lead_paragraph: I was very happy to be pregnant, and I considered it my business and nobody else’s.

headline: From Flight Attendant to Funeral Planner: New Beginnings in the Covid Era
abstract: The pandemic upended careers in Hong Kong and around the world, forcing or inspiring people to make radical changes in their lives.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Before she became a funeral planner, Connie Wong was a flight attendant for a Hong Kong airline. The sudden end of a career she had cherished for six years brought its own kind of grief, she said.

headline: As a Deadline Looms, the Dominican Republic Ponders a Draft
abstract: No country would be more affected by an international draft than the Dominican Republic. The players, coaches and trainers there remain divided as the issue comes to a head.
lead_paragraph: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic — Like so many children on this baseball-mad island, Fraidel Liriano wanted to sign with a Major League Baseball team and eventually play at the highest level. It could earn him and his family life-changing money.

headline: Jakob Ingebrigtsen Wins the 5,000. ‘I Wanted to Prove that I’m a Better Runner.’
abstract: Ingebrigtsen found redemption against a decorated field that included Jacob Krop of Kenya, Oscar Chelimo of Uganda and Grant Fisher of the U.S.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Jakob Ingebrigtsen has collected a small constellation of tattoos on his arms and legs. A crescent moon near his right biceps. A compass on his left forearm. A palm tree and the face of a dog above his right knee. A serpent on his left thigh. The tattoos are a source of fascination for track and field fans.

headline: No Corrections: July 25, 2022
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: New York May Ban Pet Store Puppy Sales, a Practice Critics Call Abusive
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “The last bastion of nonpartisanship is puppies and kittens.”

headline: 2 Killed in Los Angeles Park Shooting, Officials Say
abstract: Five other people were injured when shots rang out during a car club show, the Los Angeles Fire Department said. Authorities were considering whether “numerous” people fired shots.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and five were injured when one or more people opened fire during a car club show in a Los Angeles park on Sunday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: In a close race, Athing Mu comes away with an expected win.
abstract: Mu has become the first American woman to win the 800-meter world championship title, finishing with a time of 1:56.30
lead_paragraph: For the first time in her professional career, the American runner Athing Mu looked as if she could lose an 800-meter race.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: Russia looks to Africa.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, began a tour of four African countries yesterday. He is visiting Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo this week, where he seeks to blame the West for war-related grain shortages, which have sparked fears of famine.

headline: Postseason Hope Weighs Heavily on Seattle Mariners Fans
abstract: The team’s 14-game win streak buoyed our columnist’s hope that the franchise could break a postseason curse. A visit from the Houston Astros brought on a familiar sinking feeling.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The familiar sinking feeling returned quickly, in the first inning of the first game of the most anticipated Mariners homestand in a long, long while.

headline: American Track Athletes Showed Up. Did American Fans?
abstract: Track and field officials were hoping that having the world championships on U.S. soil would help reignite American interest in the sport. But progress takes time.
lead_paragraph: Kara Winger arrived at the track and field world championships as one of the most decorated javelin throwers in American history. A nine-time national champion, she had persevered through injuries, including two knee surgeries, to compete at four Olympic Games.

headline: As Ukraine Signs Up Soldiers, Questions Arise About How It Chooses
abstract: Recruiters approach young men on the street, but the standards are not always clear and there are reports of unwilling men being signed up while some eager to fight are turned away.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — At a subway station, a recruiting officer named Oleksandr, one of dozens deployed to different spots around Kharkiv, pulled young men out of the crowd recently, checking documents and determining whether they were eligible for military service.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Irma Vep’ and ‘Riverdale’
abstract: A mini-series from Olivier Assayas wraps up on HBO. And the long-running CW show based on the Archie comics ends its penultimate season.
lead_paragraph: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 25-31. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Covid and Monkeypox: Where New York City Stands
abstract: The BA.5 variant is going strong, but many New Yorkers no longer fear the coronavirus in the same way.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today, one topic: the state of the viruses — Covid-19 and monkeypox.

headline: Myanmar Executes Four Pro-Democracy Activists, Defying Foreign Leaders
abstract: They were the country’s first executions in more than 30 years. Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the ousted civilian leader who was detained during last year’s coup, remains in prison.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s military regime announced Monday that it had executed four pro-democracy activists, the first executions in the Southeast Asian nation in more than three decades and what was seen as the latest attempt to instill fear in a resistance movement that has continued to battle the junta since it seized power in a coup last year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: 2020 Election Deniers Seek Out Powerful Allies: County Sheriffs
abstract: Conservative activists are working to recruit the law enforcement officers to their cause. Several sheriffs have already clashed with election officials.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — An influential network of conservative activists fixated on the idea that former President Donald J. Trump won the 2020 election is working to recruit county sheriffs to investigate elections based on the false notion that voter fraud is widespread.

headline: Gen Z Designers Made It Big on This App. Now They’re Graduating.
abstract: Depop, a social shopping app, was a springboard for many young designers during the pandemic. Some are now taking their success elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When Shirley Tang started selling handmade clothing in 2020, she knew just where to do so online: Depop, an app at the forefront of social shopping.

headline: Tunisians Vote on Constitution That Could Threaten Their Democracy
abstract: The new charter would enshrine into law a vast expansion of executive power under President Kais Saied in the past year.
lead_paragraph: Tunisians voted Monday in a referendum on a new constitution that would greatly expand the powers of a president who, over the past year, has pushed aside the other branches of government to rule alone.

headline: Adams Blames Migrants for Shelter Woes. Critics Say That’s Too Simple.
abstract: There’s anecdotal evidence of an uptick in asylum seekers in New York City’s homeless shelter system, but advocates say it’s convenient to blame them.
lead_paragraph: Early last week, Mayor Eric Adams called for federal assistance to help with what he said was a flood of 2,800 asylum seekers who were making it difficult for New York City to fulfill its legal obligation to provide housing to those in need, known as the right to shelter.

headline: ‘I’m Always Worrying’: The Emotional Toll of Financial Stress
abstract: Experts share tips on how to feel empowered and manage stress as prices continue to rise.
lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Stuck
abstract: She remains a political partner to Joe Biden when America needs her to be a governing partner.
lead_paragraph: Just months after being sworn in as president in 1953, Dwight D. Eisenhower gave an unusual task to his vice president, Richard Nixon.

headline: For Elaine Castillo, Reading Is Politics
abstract: The essays in “How to Read Now” pose earnest questions about interpretation, inheritance and human understanding.
lead_paragraph: “White supremacy makes for terrible readers,” Elaine Castillo writes in her essay collection, “How to Read Now.” The sentence, like the book’s title, is both a dig and a dare, which blooms into an urgent plea: “We need to change how we read.” For Castillo, born in California to Filipino immigrants, this “we” is “generally American”; her book is directed toward the marginalized communities that make up a large part of this country.

headline: How to Talk About ‘Extreme Weather’ With Your Angry Uncle
abstract: What if everybody else is just as terrified to discuss climate change as I am?
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Articles on how to talk about the warming planet with climate skeptics always thrust me into a state of mild anxiety. I live in Tennessee, where the governor professes not to understand what’s causing the country’s extreme weather. Right-wing pundits on the airwaves and right-wing trolls on social media dominate what passes here for public discourse on climate. Republicans funded by obscene oil profits keep doing the industry’s bidding.

headline: How the Path to Homeownership Runs Through Mexico
abstract: San Diego residents are moving to Tijuana to get more for their money. Some hope to save for down payments on houses that are way out of reach north of the border.
lead_paragraph: TIJUANA — Gustavo Galvez has dreams of owning a home in San Diego, Calif. His path toward homeownership, however, includes a detour: While he saves for a down payment, he plans to spend the next several years renting in Tijuana, Mexico.

headline: This Georgia Prosecutor Has Donald Trump in Her Sights, and She’s Not Stopping
abstract: The Jan. 6 hearings have turbocharged Fani Willis’s investigation.
lead_paragraph: Now that the House Jan. 6 committee’s initial hearings have concluded, this is a useful time to evaluate their actual impact. For that, we should look not to Washington but well south of the Capitol, to Atlanta.

headline: There’s Hot, and Then There’s Hot as … Politics
abstract: In healthy democracies, the fringe bends toward the center. In our democracy, the center always seems to be lurching toward the fringe.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. Damn, it’s hot.

headline: Shopping for Sunshades
abstract: Because it’s hot out there.
lead_paragraph: During a heat wave, we could all use some relief from the sun.

headline: Chaos and Creation: Inside the Making of Yeezy Gap
abstract: In 2020, two fashion brands announced an unusual alliance. Now that goods are finally hitting stores, is Yeezy Gap a corporate-creative cautionary tale, or a new model for fashion to come?
lead_paragraph: It was almost 90 degrees in Times Square on Thursday morning when a scene began to play out on Broadway that was so unexpected it could have been a mirage: 100 people were wrapped around the block outside the Gap, waiting for its doors to open.

headline: QAnon Candidates Aren’t Thriving, but Some of Their Ideas Are
abstract: While few with ties to the conspiracy theory are winning their primaries, themes pushed by QAnon followers have become Republican talking points.
lead_paragraph: PRESCOTT, Ariz. — Pamphlets, buttons and American flags cluttered booth after booth for political candidates at a conference center in Prescott, Ariz., this month. But the table for Ron Watkins, a Republican candidate for Congress who rose to fame for his ties to the QAnon conspiracy theory, sat empty.

headline: His Audio Speakers Are Coveted by Supreme, Mark Ronson and Prada
abstract: Devon Turnbull is the founder of Ojas, a high-end audio company. Previously, he was the streetwear pioneer behind Nom de Guerre.
lead_paragraph: Mark Ronson was renovating his West Village townhouse last summer when an urgent question arose: What type of audio speakers should he — a Grammy and Oscar-winning songwriter and record producer — procure for his living room?

headline: Sharp Contrasts With Other Jan. 6 Inquiries Increase Pressure on Garland
abstract: The continued revelations from the House select committee and the rapid pace of the Georgia investigation have left the Justice Department on the defensive.
lead_paragraph: In the last week, local prosecutors in Atlanta barreled ahead with their criminal investigation into the effort by former President Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn the 2020 election results in Georgia, targeting fake electors, issuing a subpoena to a member of Congress and winning a court battle forcing Rudolph W. Giuliani to testify to a grand jury.

headline: ‘There’s Something in the Air’ in Italy’s Salento
abstract: In this southernmost region of the country’s bootheel, the Ionian Sea is to the west, the Adriatic to the east, and the countryside is filled with stone walls and twisted olive trees, fields of long golden grass and wildflowers.
lead_paragraph: “Go to one of the inland cities today,” advises the burly fruit seller as he hands me a barattiere, a mixture of melon and cucumber that’s indigenous to Puglia, the region that forms the stiletto heel of Italy’s boot. “The sand will be blowing today on both the coasts, and you won’t be able to see the lovely colors of the sea.”

headline: Dimes Square Gets the Hotel It Deserves
abstract: Nine Orchard is a boutique destination for a neighborhood that isn’t sure it’s a neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: “I won’t tell you the molding story, but there’s a lot to the molding,” Andrew Rifkin said, standing inside a room in Nine Orchard, the new hotel on Canal Street between Orchard and Allen Streets. Mr. Rifkin is also proud of the custom ceramic toilet paper holders (“You need a place to put your iPhone while you’re in the toilet”), the round tables in rooms “wherever we can fit them — they’re hospitable”) and the apples and Saratoga Water that greet guests.

headline: Death of a Crypto Company
abstract: The downfall of Celsius Network tells the story of an industry that became the thing it was trying to reject.
lead_paragraph: Born in response to the 2008 financial crisis, cryptocurrency was supposed to be a form of money that eliminated the traditional gatekeepers who had overseen the tanking of the economy.

headline: The Next Abortion Fight: Mailing Pills
abstract: More than half of U.S. abortions are conducted using pills. How will that change as red states ban the medication?
lead_paragraph: With Roe v. Wade overturned, many of the most intense battles over abortion access will involve the mailing of pills into Republican-run states.

headline: Sixth Teenager Charged in Central Park Jogger Case Is Exonerated
abstract: Steven Lopez had a robbery charge linked to the 1989 attack cleared from his record.
lead_paragraph: A forgotten co-defendant of the Central Park Five, who, like them, was charged with the rape of a jogger in a case that shook New York City and the nation, had a related conviction overturned Monday in downtown Manhattan.

headline: U.K., Eurovision Runner-up to Ukraine, Will Host Song Contest in 2023
abstract: Organizers had ruled out Ukraine from hosting next year because of safety concerns from Russia’s invasion.
lead_paragraph: Eurovision organizers confirmed on Monday that Britain would host the popular song contest in 2023 instead of war-torn Ukraine, which as this year’s winner would have traditionally hosted next year’s event but was ruled out because of safety concerns.

headline: Where China Is Changing Its Diplomatic Ways (at Least a Little)
abstract: As relations with the U.S. and Europe plummet, Beijing is beginning a new wave of diplomacy in Africa, where it dominates trade with resource-rich nations.
lead_paragraph: Whirlwind visits to crisis-riven nations in Africa. A sleek training center for the continent’s up-and-coming politicians. The prospect of major debt forgiveness for a favorite African country.

headline: Cooling the Economy Without Crushing It
abstract: Several signs of economic stress may keep the Fed from raising interest rates to a full percentage point.
