headline: Charlotte Pomerantz, Inventive Children’s Book Author, Dies at 92
abstract: Her imaginative use of words and lively rhymes entertained young readers, sometimes with a subtle message included, drawn from her own life.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Pomerantz, who brought an ingenious use of language and the occasional sly subversive touch to stories about mud-loving pigs and parachuting cats written for young children, died on Sunday at her home in Charlottesville, Va. It was her 92nd birthday.

headline: Pacific Northwest Restaurants Struggle as Temperatures Spike
abstract: Punishing heat has owners closing early, canceling outdoor dining and wondering about their future in a region where air-conditioning is not the norm.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the temperature in the tight kitchen at Blotto, a pizza restaurant in Seattle, reached 108 degrees. Like many restaurants in the city, Blotto does not have air-conditioning. Facing due west, it gets hours of the summer-afternoon sunlight.

headline: Pain Doctor Found Guilty of Sexually Assaulting Patients
abstract: Ricardo Cruciani was known as a gifted neurologist. But Manhattan prosecutors said he took advantage of his patients’ chronic pain.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Ricardo Cruciani built a reputation as a gifted and esteemed physician who could relieve chronic pain when other doctors could not.

headline: Blinken Resists Push to Label Russia a Terrorist State
abstract: The Biden administration is wary of making the designation despite strong calls from Congress and pleas from Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate supports it unanimously. So does House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, along with Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, and the Ukrainian Parliament.

headline: Biden’s Vaccine Plan for Fall
abstract: And a look at the postpandemic economy.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is planning to distribute vaccines that have been retooled to fight Omicron in September.

headline: Fed’s Kashkari says officials are ‘a long way’ from backing off inflation fight.
abstract: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said the Fed had more work to do in trying to control price increases.
lead_paragraph: Neel Kashkari, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, suggested on Friday that markets had gotten ahead of themselves in anticipating that the central bank — which has been raising interest rates swiftly this year — would soon begin to back off.

headline: A Ukrainian appeals court reduces the life sentence of a Russian soldier tried for war crimes.
abstract: His case became a milestone of Ukrainian justice as the war raged on: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin, a 21-year-old Russian soldier, was sentenced in May to life in prison after pleading guilty to shooting a 62-year-old riding a bicycle in northeastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: His case became a milestone of Ukrainian justice as the war raged on: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin, a 21-year-old Russian soldier, was sentenced in May to life in prison after pleading guilty to shooting a 62-year-old riding a bicycle in northeastern Ukraine.

headline: Explosion Kills Dozens of Ukrainian Captives at Russian-Held Prison
abstract: At least 50 captured fighters died in a blast at a prison in eastern Ukraine, with no clarity on exactly what happened and each country blaming the other.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — For the Russians, the Ukrainian fighters held prisoner at Correctional Colony No. 120 are a trophy. For the Ukrainians, they are war heroes.

headline: A Disputed Blast Kills P.O.W.s
abstract: Russia and Ukraine accuse each other of committing a war crime.
lead_paragraph: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

headline: ‘The Only Woman’ in the Room
abstract: From journalists to politicians, activists to artists: Centuries’ worth of photos depict women holding their own in a man’s world.
lead_paragraph: “Why her and only her?” the Oscar-nominated documentarian Immy Humes writes in the introduction to THE ONLY WOMAN (Phaidon, $29.95). She is looking at a 1961 photo of the filmmaker Shirley Clarke with her cast and crew, all 22 of them men. “What does her onliness mean?”

headline: To 9/11 Families, Saudi-Backed Golf Event Is ‘Another Atrocity’
abstract: The families are furious that former President Donald J. Trump once blamed Saudi Arabia for the terrorist attacks, but is now allowing his golf course to be used for its LIV Golf event.
lead_paragraph: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — A somber and tearful group of protesters stood between two American flags behind a public library, in stark contrast to the festivities at a golf tournament three miles down the road. They made their statements and promoted their cause, but declined to take the fight to the gates of Trump National Golf Club Bedminster.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Stuart Woods, Prolific Best-Selling Thriller Author, Dies at 84
abstract: His mysteries featured extravagant characters like Stone Barrington, a libidinous New York lawyer who, like Mr. Woods, hung out at Elaine’s.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Woods, a prolific, prizewinning mystery writer who churned out multiple best sellers during what his memoir duly described as “an extravagant life,” died on July 22 at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 84.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of Moral Monsters
abstract: For “The Hangman and His Wife,” her biography of the prominent Nazi Reinhard Heydrich, Nancy Dougherty interviewed his widow.
lead_paragraph: What is the fatal attraction they exert on us, the Nazis? We continue to read books and watch documentaries about them many decades after they coolly commenced upon exterminating the Jews — a genocide that in terms of its duration and thoroughness remains unparalleled in the bloody annals of history. (A close instance would probably be the extermination of the Armenians by the Turks during World War I, about which Hitler said, in one of his incendiary speeches: “Who, after all, speaks today of the annihilation of the Armenians?”)

headline: The Future of Food
abstract: How the agriculture industry could go from farming to “ferming.”
lead_paragraph: From “The Daily” newsletter: One big idea on the news, from the team that brings you “The Daily” podcast. You can sign up for the newsletter here.

headline: House Passes Assault Weapons Ban That Is Doomed in Senate
abstract: Coming on the heels of a spate of mass shootings, the vote gave Democrats another opportunity to draw a sharp distinction with Republicans before the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Responding to a string of mass shootings, a divided House passed a ban on assault weapons on Friday, moving over the near-unanimous opposition of Republicans to reinstate a prohibition that expired nearly two decades ago.

headline: Larry Josephson, Champion of Free-Form Radio, Dies at 83
abstract: His dyspeptic morning show helped make WBAI-FM in New York a vibrant, eccentric, alternative radio haven. “I was the first angry man in morning radio,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Larry Josephson, a cranky practitioner of free-form radio on noncommercial WBAI-FM in New York who helped shape the station into a vibrant, eccentric, alternative radio haven, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Democrats’ Plan to Win in 2022 Looks a Lot Like 2020 and 2018
abstract: Stacey Abrams is again providing a blueprint for national Democrats to follow. But can it work at a time of deep unhappiness with Washington?
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter is a guest dispatch from Georgia, where my colleague Maya King covers politics across the South.

headline: Blinken and Lavrov Discuss Griner in Their First Call of the War
abstract: Ukraine said it was ready for Black Sea grain shipments to resume, while the top Russian and American diplomats talked about a prisoner swap involving the basketball star Brittney Griner.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — The top Russian and American diplomats spoke on Friday for the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, to discuss a possible prisoner swap involving the American basketball star Brittney Griner. Although no breakthrough was reported, it marked a resumption of direct communication between Washington and Moscow.

headline: Fox News, Once Home to Trump, Now Often Ignores Him
abstract: The former president hasn’t been interviewed on the Rupert Murdoch-owned cable network in more than 100 days, and other Republicans often get the attention he once did.
lead_paragraph: It’s been more than 100 days since Donald J. Trump was interviewed on Fox News.

headline: Breaking Agreement to Use a Condom Is a Sex Crime, Canada High Court Rules
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling is one of the strictest in a recent spate of measures addressing deceptive condom use, as courts try to define consent.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — It is a crime to renege on a promise to wear a condom during sex without a partner’s knowledge or consent, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled this week.

headline: ‘We Need Help’: Death Toll Rises in Devastating Kentucky Flooding
abstract: Hundreds of stranded residents were rescued by aircraft and boats, Gov. Andy Beshear said. There is more rain in the forecast.
lead_paragraph: HAZARD, Ky. — Shirley Stamper, 74, awoke to the sound of wild banging beneath her house. Floodwaters were swallowing her remote mountain community and Ms. Stamper, along with her mother-in-law, Ethel Stamper, 94, needed to get out, immediately.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: All thrills, no filler this week. You want smuggling, you want entrapment, you want murder? Check, check, check.

headline: Russian National Charged With Spreading Propaganda Through U.S. Groups
abstract: Federal authorities say the man recruited several American political groups and used them to sow discord and interfere with elections.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Russian man with a trim beard and patterned T-shirt appeared in a Florida political group’s YouTube livestream in March, less than three weeks after his country had invaded Ukraine, and falsely claimed that what had happened was not an invasion.

headline: At a LIV Golf Event, Thin Crowds and a Tense Start
abstract: The controversy over the new golf series, which is backed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, isn’t going away. But on the course, fans enjoyed the easygoing camaraderie among the players.
lead_paragraph: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — Standing over his ball on Friday, Phil Mickelson, the prized acquisition of the new, Saudi-backed LIV Golf series, lined up his opening tee shot in the breakaway circuit’s event at Trump National Golf Club Bedminster.

headline: All of Aaron Judge’s Homers, From 1 to 42
abstract: Judge, the slugging Yankee outfielder, is having an incredible year. We are tracking his pursuit of other Yankees greats.
lead_paragraph: In the second inning of an afternoon game at Yankee Stadium, Aaron Judge got a 95-mile-per-hour fastball from Jonathan Heasley of the Kansas City Royals and muscled it just over the wall in right for a home run.

headline: White House Communications Director, Set to Depart, Decides to Stay
abstract: Kate Bedingfield, who announced this month that she was stepping down, abruptly changed her mind and said on Friday that she had decided to remain at the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At this point in an administration, with the president’s poll numbers in the tank and a daunting midterm election on the horizon, the usual staff news around the White House is a roster of who is leaving. But in an unusual twist, the news on Friday was who is not leaving after all.

headline: Trump Backs Tudor Dixon in Michigan’s Chaotic G.O.P. Governor Primary
abstract: The winner of the Aug. 2 primary, which has been in turmoil since May, will take on Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, this fall.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Tudor Dixon in Michigan’s Republican primary for governor, giving Ms. Dixon, a former media personality, a boost as the crowded field heads into the final weekend of campaigning.

headline: Pac-12 Commissioner Keeps It Professional, but Pointed, After Defections
abstract: George Kliavkoff, the Pac-12 commissioner, said the move by U.C.L.A. and U.S.C. to leave the conference for the Big Ten was a money grab that sold out athletes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When the Pac-12 Conference’s schools congregated Friday at a downtown theater for the summer ritual of football media day — and yes, all the coaches were invited — it carried the air of an awkward family reunion.

headline: Keep It Together
abstract: Lance Enfinger debuts with a sharp Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I need an adjective that means tough yet breezy for puzzles like this, Lance Enfinger’s first Times construction. Brisk, maybe? Or bracing? At first glance, it looks like a steep, uphill battle, but if you get a longer entry or two, you can build some momentum. It’s enjoyable, and there are some excellent touches — interrelated trivia, a couple of great terms and a cetacean idiom that was new to me. I’m also a sucker for the triple span, and this one is well done. (Like a nice filet mignon! Just kidding.)

headline: Gang Leaders Convicted in Shocking Murder of Boy Dragged From Bronx Deli
abstract: Mistaken for a gang member, Lesandro Guzman-Feliz, 15, was hacked to death with knives and a machete in a killing, captured on video, that horrified the city.
lead_paragraph: Two top leaders of the Trinitarios gang were found guilty of murder on Friday for ordering a deadly attack on a 15-year-old boy who was dragged out of a Bronx deli four years ago and hacked to death with knives and a machete.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Germans Tiptoe a Path to Energy Conservation
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 30, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “If you think, OK, swapping out the shower head, thawing out the freezer or turning down the heater, none of that makes a difference — you are deceiving yourself. It is an excuse to do nothing.”

headline: Corrections: July 30, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 30, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about President Biden’s health secretary’s suggestion that states bear responsibility for a flawed response to a rise in monkeypox cases incorrectly attributed a comment about the challenges of coordinating a national response to monkeypox. Adriane Casalotti, the chief of public and government affairs for the National Association of County and City Health Officials, spoke about the issues, not Theresa Spinner, a spokeswoman for the group.

headline: Europe’s Race to Secure New Energy Sources Is on a Knife’s Edge
abstract: A long-term switch to more renewable sources has been overtaken by a short-term scramble to stave off a crisis.
lead_paragraph: As Russia tightens its chokehold on supplies of natural gas, Europe is looking everywhere for energy to keep its economy running. Coal-fired power plants are being revived. Billions are being spent on terminals to bring in liquefied natural gas, much of it from shale fields in Texas. Officials and heads of state are flying to Qatar, Azerbaijan, Norway and Algeria to nail down energy deals.

headline: Vessels await word that they can carry the first grain shipments out of Ukraine.
abstract: ODESA, Ukraine — The first shipments of grain since the beginning of the war in Ukraine have been loaded onto freighters at Ukrainian ports on the Black Sea, getting ready for their first voyages in more than five months.
lead_paragraph: ODESA, Ukraine — The first shipments of grain since the beginning of the war in Ukraine have been loaded onto freighters at Ukrainian ports on the Black Sea, getting ready for their first voyages in more than five months.

headline: Heavy Rain Causes Deadly Flooding Across Iran
abstract: The monsoon-like rains, unusual for the typical dry season in the region, have killed more than 50 people, caused heavy damage and shut down major roadways.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains in Iran that began Wednesday have set off flash floods and landslides in 21 of the country’s 31 provinces, killing at least 53 people, heavily damaging hundreds of villages, cutting off access to major roads and forcing the evacuation of an ancient city, officials say.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Powwow Season in Full Bloom
abstract: From spring to summer, Native American families travel the country to celebrate and compete in competitions  wearing intricate garments assembled across generations.
lead_paragraph: From spring to summer, Native American families travel the country to celebrate and compete in competitions  wearing intricate garments assembled across generations.

headline: Seeking Relationship, Therapy Required
abstract: For some singles, a potential partner who isn’t working on their mental health is not an option.
lead_paragraph: Like most daters, Elyse Fox, 32, a model who lives in Brooklyn, is looking for a partner who is kind, attractive, smart and funny. She is hoping he likes to travel, is ready for commitment and communicates well. But she has one nonnegotiable: He must be working on his mental health, preferably in regular therapy.

headline: Banana Yoshimoto Wants You to Feel Again
abstract: In “Dead-End Memories,” five stories about lonely women who encounter ghosts, infidelities, betrayals — and human connection.
lead_paragraph: The five stories in Banana Yoshimoto’s collection “Dead-End Memories” — first published in Japan in 2003, it is her 11th book to be translated into English — are strange, melancholy and beautiful. At the center of each is a woman negotiating the quiet fallout of personal history.

headline: How Soon Is Too Soon to Ask My Landlord About a Rent Increase?
abstract: Simply asking a landlord about how much the rent will go up shouldn’t change the landlord’s calculations — the decision has likely already been made.
lead_paragraph: Q: For nine years, my husband and I have rented a market-rate apartment on the Upper West Side. The building recently changed ownership, and during the transition apartments were intentionally left vacant until the new owners took over. Now that new management is running the building, comparable units to ours are renting at much higher rents than what we pay. Our lease comes up for renewal in October and we are concerned about the potential increase we could face. Should we ask the landlord about the renewal terms early, or is it better to wait? How might we approach the conversation?

headline: Using Fiction to Summon the Glittering, Golden Age of Hollywood
abstract: Anthony Marra’s “Mercury Pictures Presents,” his long-awaited second novel, is a homage to the movies and to his immigrant family.
lead_paragraph: After a funeral on Long Island not too long ago, the author Anthony Marra and his family gathered somberly at the grave site for the burial. But there was a moment of unexpected slapstick when an older relative began to fret about the graveyard’s confusing layout. Suddenly she yelled in a thick New York accent: “How the hell do I get out of here?”

headline: Debris From Uncontrolled Chinese Rocket Falls Over Southeast Asian Seas
abstract: Space watchers had tracked the 23-ton rocket stage’s path in Earth orbit this week because of the slight possibility that it could come down over a populated area.
lead_paragraph: Debris from a large Chinese rocket re-entered Earth’s atmosphere over the Indian Ocean at 12:45 p.m. Eastern time, according to the U.S. Space Command.

headline: A $30 Alarm Can Stop a Silent Killer. Why Many Hotels Don’t Install Them.
abstract: Three carbon monoxide deaths at a resort in the Bahamas called attention to the dangers of the odorless gas. In the U.S., where it often takes multiple poisonings for hotels to install alarms, a debate about detector policies has been intensifying.
lead_paragraph: He was not the first guest to fall ill in Room 205. Just when Pawel Markowski thought that nothing could shake him more than nearly losing his life to a carbon monoxide leak at a hotel in Catoosa, Okla., his lawyer sent him the Fire Department’s report.

headline: Retail’s ‘Dark Side’: As Inventory Piles Up, Liquidation Warehouses Are Busy
abstract: Consumers are buying fewer discretionary goods and returning more. To clear their shelves, retailers are selling to liquidators at steep discounts.
lead_paragraph: PITTSTON, Pa. — Once upon a time, when parents were scrambling to occupy their children during pandemic lockdowns, bicycles were hard to find. But today, in a giant warehouse in northeastern Pennsylvania, there are shiny new Huffys and Schwinns available at big discounts.

headline: In Flood-Stricken Kentucky, the Search for Victims Intensifies
abstract: As the weather cleared temporarily in the state’s eastern region, rescuers worked with aircraft, boats and vehicles to reach those stranded.
lead_paragraph: The response to some of the worst flooding in Kentucky’s history entered a pivotal phase on Saturday, as the search for victims accelerated over a battered stretch of central Appalachia.

headline: Biden Savors Much-Needed Victories. But Will the Highs Overshadow the Lows?
abstract: With the midterm elections around the corner, the challenge for President Biden is to make sure his latest successes resonate with Americans who remain deeply skeptical about the future.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and his top advisers have tried for months to press forward amid a seemingly endless drumbeat of dispiriting news: rising inflation, high gas prices, a crumbling agenda, a dangerously slowing economy and a plummeting approval rating, even among Democrats.

headline: How Did a Two-Time Killer Get Out to Be Charged Again at Age 83?
abstract: Marceline Harvey is accused of dismembering a woman in Brooklyn. Her life was defined by a tormented relationship with women and herself — and a simmering anger.
lead_paragraph: The person before the parole panel in June 2019 was tall and slim, in far better shape than 81 years of life might have suggested. Mild and polite, the supplicant seemed nothing like the murderer who had spent decades in prison, first for shooting a girlfriend dead in 1963, and then for stabbing another in 1985, stuffing her corpse into a bag and leaving it in Central Park.

headline: Democrats Got a Climate Bill. Joe Manchin Got Drilling, and More.
abstract: Along the way to the $369 billion package, the West Virginia senator secured an array of concessions for his state and for the fossil fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a twist of fate, Congress is suddenly poised to pass the most ambitious climate bill in United States history, largely written by a senator from a coal state who became a millionaire from his family coal business and who has taken more campaign cash from the oil and gas industry than any of his colleagues have.

headline: Gangs Advance on the Seat of Haitian Government Power: ‘Haitians Are Hostages’
abstract: Over 470 people have been killed, injured or are missing in recent violence, according to the U.N., as gangs expand their control and threaten the presidential palace.
lead_paragraph: Gangs are increasing their chokehold on Haiti’s capital, using bulldozers to raze entire neighborhoods, overwhelming poorly armed police and taking their violence to within blocks of the seat of government.

headline: What’s Next for LeBron James Jr.?
abstract: Coaches recruiting the high school point guard known as Bronny will have a lot to navigate, including his famous father’s ties to Nike, ESPN and the state of Ohio.
lead_paragraph: NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. — As LeBron James sat on a folding chair in the corner of a recreation-center basketball court last week, he often appeared to be in a state of agita.

headline: A Polish Priest’s War Against Abortion Focuses on Helping Single Mothers
abstract: The Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk sees little effect on women’s decisions whether to have a child from a 29-year abortion ban. What may matter more is support for women who choose to have a child.
lead_paragraph: SZCZECIN, Poland — Abortion has been banned in Poland for 29 years, but that has done little to prevent women from finding access to the procedure, leaving the Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk a busy man.

headline: Not Just Any Bag
abstract: A New York company, Anybag, finds an elegant way to turn plastic bag waste into a functional tote. Miranda Kerr, Adidas and Ralph Lauren are fans.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of a series examining Responsible Fashion, and innovative efforts to address issues facing the fashion industry.

headline: A European official denounces ‘inhumane, barbaric acts’ as dozens of prisoners of war are killed.
abstract: As international outrage swelled, Ukraine on Saturday called on global organizations including the United Nations and the International Committee of the Red Cross to quickly investigate an explosion that ripped through a Russian prison camp holding dozens of Ukrainian soldiers, leaving only charred bodies and twisted metal bunks.
lead_paragraph: As international outrage swelled, Ukraine on Saturday called on global organizations including the United Nations and the International Committee of the Red Cross to quickly investigate an explosion that ripped through a Russian prison camp holding dozens of Ukrainian soldiers, leaving only charred bodies and twisted metal bunks.

headline: Francis Calls Abuse of Indigenous People in Canada a ‘Genocide’
abstract: The pope reinforced his denunciation of the abuse committed by Roman Catholic-run schools in the country. He also acknowledged that his advancing age might force him to travel less in future.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE PAPAL PLANE — Pope Francis has called the devastation visited on generations of Indigenous people in Canada by European colonizers — carried out with the blessing of the Roman Catholic Church — a “genocide” as he returned to Rome after a six-day trip to the North American country.

headline: Excitement, Then Ambivalence, For the Pope’s Visit to Quebec
abstract: Thousands gathered on Wednesday to see Pope Francis ride by the Plains of Abraham park. But a mass the following day was not a big draw.
lead_paragraph: QUEBEC CITY — The smell of cigarette smoke, fruity vape juice and sunscreen might have been a flashback for visitors returning to the sprawling Quebec City park where, two weeks ago, an annual summer music festival drew boisterous crowds.

headline: Podcast Recommendations
abstract: Try out a new podcast or two, courtesy of Morning readers.
lead_paragraph: What makes a good podcast? I’ve been mulling this question over the past few weeks since I asked readers of The Morning to recommend their favorites.

headline: Eavesdropping, Worms and Outrageous Fortune
abstract: Our critic recommends old and new books.
lead_paragraph: Hello readers,

headline: As Ukraine defends in the east and south, a U.S. official says Russia’s war effort is failing.
abstract: A senior U.S. Defense Department official said there was growing evidence that steep Russian losses had left some units ill-prepared to fight.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian military repelled attempted Russian advances in eastern Ukraine and pounded critical Russian logistical hubs overnight into Saturday as Russia continued to bombard towns and cities along the 400-mile front line.

headline: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
abstract: Entries for the week of July 25, 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

headline: Ukrainian officials compile evidence that they say shows Russia was behind prison camp blast.
abstract: Ukrainian officials said on Sunday that there is mounting evidence that an explosion at a Russian penal colony that killed dozens of Ukrainian prisoners was ordered and carried out by Russian forces, citing newly released satellite photos as evidence that the soldiers were not killed in a missile strike.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials said on Sunday that there is mounting evidence that an explosion at a Russian penal colony that killed dozens of Ukrainian prisoners was ordered and carried out by Russian forces, citing newly released satellite photos as evidence that the soldiers were not killed in a missile strike.

headline: Prisoners describe harsh treatment in the Russian camp where an explosion killed dozens.
abstract: Prisoners recently released from a Russian prison camp where an explosion killed dozens of Ukrainian soldiers late Thursday have described torture and hellish conditions. Guards provided just enough food for prisoners to survive and meted out regular beatings, they say.
lead_paragraph: Prisoners recently released from a Russian prison camp where an explosion killed dozens of Ukrainian soldiers late Thursday have described torture and hellish conditions. Guards provided just enough food for prisoners to survive and meted out regular beatings, they say.

headline: G.O.P. Feuding and Chaos Endanger the Party’s Chances in Michigan
abstract: A handwritten letter from Betsy DeVos, last seen trying to remove Donald Trump from office, elicited an 11th-hour endorsement. But is that enough to make peace among Michigan’s warring Republicans?
lead_paragraph: PONTIAC, Mich. — “Dear Mr. President,” the letter began.

headline: I Would Have Liked Childhood More Without the Pressure to Grow Up
abstract: Let’s not make being a kid harder than it already is.
lead_paragraph: If you asked me what I wanted to be when I was a kid, I probably would have told you an archaeologist, or a ballerina, or ideally both, simultaneously. But in reality, what I wanted to be most was an adult. I wanted to be 35. Or 22, which, when you’re 10, is basically the same thing. Anything, absolutely anything, other than a child.

headline: The Best Extracurricular May Be an After-School Job
abstract: Personally, I learned more working outside school than I did in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: Lots of American teenagers need to work after school to help support their families. But there’s a case to be made that those who don’t need to work should get a job anyway.

headline: Monkeypox Is About to Become the Next Public Health Failure
abstract: The outbreak doesn’t bode well for America’s response to future pathogens.
lead_paragraph: When about 100 cases of ‌‌monkeypox had been confirmed or suspected in Europe‌ in May, it was clear the virus was spreading outside the areas where it was previously seen‌‌. Some on social media ‌‌suggested it might already be ‌spreading rapidly in communities in Europe and the ‌United States. These reports should have been a code red for federal infectious disease response.

headline: New Risks Facing Doctors and Their Pregnant Patients
abstract: Readers discuss how new abortion laws will affect treatment of miscarriages and life-threatening pregnancies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Case Against Commercial Logging in Wildfire-Prone Forests
abstract: Logging tends to increase, not decrease, extreme fires.
lead_paragraph: When the Oak fire swept through more than 10,000 acres southwest of Yosemite National Park last weekend, it burned through forests where widespread logging, including commercial thinning, accelerated in recent decades. Much of the forest canopy had been removed, exposing the remaining vegetation to more direct sunlight and creating hotter, drier and windier conditions that favor the spread of flames.

headline: Boeing Gets F.A.A. Go-Ahead for Plan to Resume Deliveries of 787 Dreamliner
abstract: The planes were grounded for more than a year over quality concerns. The agency will still inspect them before they are handed over to customers.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Friday cleared the way for Boeing to restart deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner, which were paused more than a year ago because of quality concerns.

headline: The Wonderfully Mundane Joys of Summer
abstract: Kids getting to be kids again.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, The Wall Street Journal had a feature about parents who were splurging on summer fun for their kids — expensive birthday parties, all-out road trips — in part to make up for the joy lost during the early days of the Covid pandemic. It’s an understandable urge. Our kids missed out on a lot over the past few years; why not spoil them if we’re able to?

headline: Ukraine Calls for Investigation Into Prisoner Deaths as Outrage Grows
abstract: Ukrainian authorities gathered evidence that they said showed Russia had orchestrated an explosion that killed at least 50 of their soldiers.
lead_paragraph: As global outrage grew over an explosion that killed at least 50 Ukrainian prisoners held at a Russian detention camp, Ukrainian authorities called for an international investigation on Saturday while marshaling evidence that they said would prove that Russia had orchestrated what they described as a “terrorist attack.”

headline: Palestinian Flags Aren’t Illegal in Israel. They Still Get Torn Down.
abstract: Israeli police, lawmakers and settlers are increasingly targeting the flag, which Palestinians say is a broader attack on their identity.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Amid a sea of Israeli flags at the entrance to the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem’s Old City, Abdullah al-Hajj walked toward a group of far-right Jewish marchers, some of them yelling racist chants, and raised the Palestinian flag above his head.

headline: How the Kremlin Is Forcing Ukrainians to Adopt Russian Life
abstract: In Russian-occupied regions in Ukraine, local leaders are forcing civilians to accept Russian rule. Next come sham elections that would formalize Vladimir V. Putin’s claim that they are Russian territories.
lead_paragraph: They have handed out Russian passports, cellphone numbers and set-top boxes for watching Russian television. They have replaced Ukrainian currency with the ruble, rerouted the internet through Russian servers and arrested hundreds who have resisted assimilation.

headline: Language Evolves Right Before Our Ears. It’s Very ‘Satisfying.’
abstract: How pickleball and A.S.M.R. may have helped the youngs refine our language forward.
lead_paragraph: Recently, my daughters and I were walking by some people playing pickleball. If you’re not familiar, the game involves a plastic ball being thwacked crisply back and forth, the sound being somewhere between the pop of Ping-Pong and the whop of a smacked Wiffle ball.

headline: In Widening Crackdown, Renowned Journalist Arrested in Guatemala
abstract: José Rubén Zamora, an award-winning journalist and president of the elPeriódico newspaper, was arrested at his home in Guatemala City.
lead_paragraph: In another sign of growing political repression in Guatemala, the authorities have arrested an award-winning journalist who was critical of the government and raided the offices of the newspaper he founded.

headline: America Has a Problem and Beyoncé Ain’t It
abstract: On “Renaissance,” the pop star’s seventh solo album, she finds escape, rebirth, community, pleasure and control in decades of dance music steeped in Black queer bravado.
lead_paragraph: It’s too much, this being alive. Too heavy, too uncertain, too chronically cataclysmic, too bellicose, too unwell, too freighted with a possibility of the perception of error. The word of the last few years — in American activist and academic circles, anyway — has been “precarity.” Which gets at ideas of endangerment, neglect, contingency, risk. Basically: We’re worried. And: We’re worried you’re not worried enough. Like I said: It’s too much.

headline: Protesters Breach Iraqi Parliament for Second Time in a Week
abstract: Iraqi supporters of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr pulled down concrete barriers and packed the Parliament floor, protesting a rival bloc’s efforts to form a new government.
lead_paragraph: Iraqi supporters of the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr pulled down concrete barriers and packed the Parliament floor, protesting a rival bloc’s efforts to form a new government.

headline: Biden Tests Positive for Coronavirus Again in ‘Rebound’ Case
abstract: The president tested positive on Saturday morning and will once again isolate, although his symptoms have not come back, the White House physician said.
lead_paragraph: President Biden tested positive for the coronavirus again on Saturday morning, becoming the latest example of a rebound case after taking the Paxlovid treatment that has otherwise been credited with broadly impressive results in fighting the virus and suppressing its worst effects.

headline: Can We Resist the Age of the Algorithm?
abstract: To resist, our culture needs less Netflix and more Miranda Priestly.
lead_paragraph: I have few stronger opinions about movie characters than my view that Miranda Priestly, the demanding fashion-magazine boss in “The Devil Wears Prada,” is actually the heroine of the movie. Not an uncomplicated heroine, certainly not a nice person. But a figure to be celebrated nonetheless: a demanding, uncompromising aesthete whose decisions ripple through the wider culture, whose idiosyncratic taste can affect the palette of the world.

headline: Mary Alice, Tony Winner for Her Role in ‘Fences,’ Dies at 85
abstract: A former Chicago schoolteacher, she appeared on TV in ‘A Different World’ and ‘I’ll Fly Away,’ winning an Emmy in 1993.
lead_paragraph: Mary Alice, an Emmy- and Tony-award winning actress who brought a delicate grace and a quiet dignity to her roles in Hollywood blockbusters (“The Matrix Revolutions”), television sitcoms (“A Different World”) and Broadway plays (“Fences”), died on Wednesday in her home in Manhattan. She was 85, according to the New York City Police Department.

headline: Followers of Iraqi Cleric Occupy Parliament Again, Demanding Reforms
abstract: Unable to form a government 10 months after elections, Iraq has been roiled by the street protests of the nationalist cleric Moktada al-Sadr, who withdrew from the government but again seeks to influence it.
lead_paragraph: BASRA, Iraq — Iraqi protesters loyal to the nationalist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr thronged Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone for the second time in a week on Saturday to prevent the formation of a new government. They scaled concrete barriers and pushed past security forces to get into the Iraqi Parliament, filling the empty seats of representatives and shouting their support for Mr. Sadr: “Son of Mohammed, take us wherever you want.”

headline: You Want to Clean Up the House? Same Here
abstract: How to improve the House of Representatives.
lead_paragraph: A lot of you responded quite strongly to last week’s newsletter on defanging the Senate of most of its power. Not a negative response, necessarily — you just had a lot of ideas! And as it happens, I agree with many of those ideas. Perhaps the most common one is related less to the Senate than to the House of Representatives. Many of you were adamant that if the goal is to bring the locus of policymaking back to the House, then the House, too, must be more democratic than it is, and that part of making the House more democratic is ending partisan gerrymandering.

headline: Alex Jones Puts Company Behind Infowars Empire Into Bankruptcy
abstract: The conspiracy broadcaster faces a judgment of as much as $150 million for defaming Sandy Hook families.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Facing a potential $150 million judgment and two more damages trials for defaming the families of people killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting, the conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones on Friday put his Infowars empire into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

headline: Prince Charles’s Charity Accepted Millions From Family of Osama bin Laden
abstract: Clarence House confirmed that the terrorist’s brothers donated money to the royal charity, but denied reports that the prince had personally brokered the deal or made the decision to accept it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, faced new scrutiny over the financing of his charities on Saturday after a report found that one organization had accepted a donation of 1 million pounds ($1.21 million) from the family of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Why? Well, Why Not?
abstract: Jesse Goldberg’s puzzle will really make you wonder.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Jesse Goldberg is a software engineer in San Francisco. This is his third crossword for The Times (and his second Sunday puzzle — his first, from almost exactly a year ago, was lovely and pulled quotations from a famous French kitchen, if you missed it). Many solvers will be familiar with this puzzle-loving constructor’s daily routine: Solve Wordle, check Wordlebot, play Spelling Bee, solve the crossword, in that order.

headline: Flooding Across Iran Leaves Dozens Dead
abstract: Days of heavy rain triggered flash floods and landslides across most of Iran’s provinces, marking the nation’s deadliest water-related episode in a decade.
lead_paragraph: Days of heavy rain triggered flash floods and landslides across most of Iran’s provinces, marking the nation’s deadliest water-related episode in a decade.

headline: ‘We Keep Getting Hit’: Flooded Kentucky Grows Weary After Another Natural Disaster
abstract: A series of catastrophes has struck communities that were already struggling, raising fears that rebuilding will be arduous and require substantial outside help.
lead_paragraph: HAZARD, Ky. — Firefighters and National Guard crews have swarmed into eastern Kentucky after days of deadly flooding, rescuing by the hundreds people who found themselves trapped in the perilous water.

headline: A 17-Year-Old Is Killed and 4 Are Hospitalized in River Tubing Stabbing
abstract: The suspect, a 52-year-old man from Minnesota, had left the scene but was taken into custody after a witness identified him, the authorities said. A motive was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and four others were hospitalized on Saturday after they were stabbed in their mid-sections while tubing on the Apple River in Wisconsin, a popular summer spot that attracts visitors from across the region, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: July 31, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 31, 2022.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 24 this weekend about Barbados includes an outdated reference to the country’s publicly traded debt. BlackRock is one of the largest holders of the debt; it is no longer the largest holder of the debt. A picture caption with the article misstates the volume of coconuts a recycling center receives each week. The facility receives more than 100 tons each week, not eight. Another picture caption with the article misstates part of the name of a research center. It is the Walkers Institute for Regenerative Research, Education and Design not the Walkers Institute for Regenerative Research and Design.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: ‘Unfortunately, the Packet Got Caught in the Branch of a Tree’
abstract: A walk-up ritual goes awry, balloons at Queens Plaza and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: As Latin America Shifts Left, Leaders Face a Short Honeymoon
abstract: All six of the region’s largest economies could soon be run by presidents elected on leftist platforms. Their challenge? Inflation, war in Europe and growing poverty at home.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In Chile, a tattooed former student activist won the presidency with a pledge to oversee the most profound transformation of Chilean society in decades, widening the social safety net and shifting the tax burden to the wealthy.

headline: Kansas Abortion Vote Tests Political Energy in Post-Roe America
abstract: On Tuesday, Kansans will decide whether to pass a constitutional amendment that could lead to far-reaching abortion restrictions or an outright ban on the procedure.
lead_paragraph: OLATHE, Kan. — In the final days before Kansans decide whether to remove abortion rights protections from their State Constitution, the politically competitive Kansas City suburbs have become hotbeds of activism.

headline: What’s a Critic Doing in a War Zone?
abstract: A Times critic at large traveled to Ukraine to see how artists “defend what we have taken for granted.”
lead_paragraph: A news organization needs all sorts of journalists and professionals to cover a war zone effectively: reporters and photographers who can gather information, local journalists and interpreters to gain access to sources, security experts and drivers to help everyone stay safe. One person you almost never need is a critic.

headline: Trained, Armed and Ready. To Teach Kindergarten.
abstract: More school employees are carrying guns to defend against school shootings. In Ohio, a contentious new law requires no more than 24 hours of training.
lead_paragraph: RITTMAN, Ohio — Mandi, a kindergarten teacher in Ohio, had already done what she could to secure her classroom against a gunman.

headline: When There’s Arsenic in the Water, but ‘We Have Nowhere to Go’
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency found that water at a mobile home park that mostly serves agricultural workers contained almost 10 times the allowable limit of arsenic. But housing alternatives are hard to find.
lead_paragraph: THERMAL, Calif. — Three times a week, Pascual Campos Ochoa, 26, loads up a duffel bag with a brown fleece blanket and a plastic container of oatmeal. A van picks him up from the dusty trailer park where he lives — where stray dogs wander among the carcasses of old cars and working electricity is not a given — and takes him to a clinic for kidney dialysis.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trained, Armed and Ready. To Teach Kindergarten.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 31, 2022.
lead_paragraph: “The last thing I want is for people to think we are just a bunch of gunslinging teachers who want an excuse to carry guns in schools....I love my kids. I’m going to do everything I can to keep them safe.”

headline: The Problem With Survivor Memoirs
abstract: In “Acceptance,” Emi Nietfeld pushes back against the American presumption that survival should depend on personal excellence.
lead_paragraph: Overcoming adversity is a classic plot arc among recent blockbuster coming-of-age memoirs — from Tara Westover’s “Educated” to Viola Davis’s “Finding Me” to Cheryl Strayed’s “Wild.” It’s a satisfying story type, and often a deceptively tidy one. With her debut memoir, “Acceptance,” Emi Nietfeld enters the genre ambivalently, paying careful attention to what gets elided in stories like hers: the cruelty of a society that makes survival contingent on excellence.

headline: Leave My Disability Out of Your Anti-Abortion Propaganda
abstract: The dignity of disabled lives and a woman’s right to choose are two separate issues.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, when my mother was pregnant, an ultrasound revealed troubling abnormalities: the fetus’s organs were misarranged. This condition, she was told by her doctor, correlated with a wide variety of disabilities that could cause the baby to die at birth. The doctor told my mother that she could seek an abortion. She wanted her to know her options.

headline: Will the Biggest Publisher in the United States Get Even Bigger?
abstract: The Biden administration is suing to block Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster. A United States District Court will decide if the sale can proceed.
lead_paragraph: When the largest publisher in the country, Penguin Random House, struck a deal in the fall of 2020 to acquire its rival Simon & Schuster, publishing executives and antitrust experts predicted that the merger would draw intense scrutiny from government regulators.

headline: In ‘Yoga,’ Emmanuel Carrère Tries, Fitfully, to Capture Thought’s Flow
abstract: In his latest book, the French author celebrated for his deeply personal accounts of tragic events embraces meditation as a means of learning to write “without fabrication.” But telling the truth is complicated.
lead_paragraph: The first sentence of Emmanuel Carrère’s novel “Yoga” outlines the whole book, so I give nothing away by saying that it is about trying to write what Carrère calls “a subtle little book on yoga,” an effort derailed, over the course of four years, by terrorism, the refugee crisis, the loss of his editor and a “melancholic depression” so deep that he is committed to a psychiatric hospital. Yet it is also a book about yoga, about the ways in which meditation means, to borrow a phrase from Lenin, as Carrère does, “working with the available material.”

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
abstract: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
lead_paragraph: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: A New Yorker’s Opposition to Abortion Clouds Her House Re-Election Bid
abstract: Representative Nicole Malliotakis, the city’s lone Republican House member, has tried to maintain some distance from the Supreme Court ruling on abortion.
lead_paragraph: As the lone Republican in the New York City congressional delegation, Representative Nicole Malliotakis has adopted certain stances that would make her an understandable outlier in a deeply Democratic city.

headline: Gen Z Knows What It Wants From Employers. And Employers Want Them.
abstract: To tap into the creativity of younger workers, and to offset a labor shortage, companies are offering four-day weeks, club memberships and work-from-anywhere flexibility.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Ross is a 26-year-old who lives in a small town in upstate New York. She describes herself as artistic and creative. She paints in her free time, and she has worked as a mermaid for children’s parties, swimming in a tail she made herself.

headline: United Auto Workers Seek to Shed a Legacy of Corruption
abstract: After his predecessors’ imprisonment, the union’s president is being challenged for re-election in the first direct vote by its membership.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For the United Auto Workers, the last five years have been one of the most troubling chapters in the union’s storied history.

headline: A Cyberattack Illuminates the Shaky State of Student Privacy
abstract: At a moment when education technology firms are stockpiling sensitive information on millions of school children, safeguards for student data have broken down.
lead_paragraph: The software that many school districts use to track students’ progress can record extremely confidential information on children: “Intellectual disability.” “Emotional Disturbance.” “Homeless.” “Disruptive.” “Defiance.” “Perpetrator.” “Excessive Talking.” “Should attend tutoring.”

headline: A Baseball Museum That Is ‘Better Than True’
abstract: The Baseball Reliquary in Los Angeles, a mischievous cousin of the Hall of Fame, took its share of blows but is set for a comeback. Its artifacts remain as real as your imagination.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Now on display at the Los Angeles Central Library through November in an exhibit titled “Something in Common.” There is a San Diego Chicken costume, a half-smoked cigar from Babe Ruth that likely — maybe? possibly? — was spirited from a Philadelphia brothel in 1924 and a baseball signed by Mother Teresa. The real Mother Teresa? Well … maybe not.

headline: Polo Season in the Hamptons
abstract: The best looks from the “Uncoupled” premiere, All Star Code benefit and the Polo Hamptons match.
lead_paragraph: What’s summer in the Hamptons without a little polo? On July 23, Christie Brinkley hosted the annual Polo Hamptons match and cocktail party at the Maria and Kenneth Fishel Estate in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The horse-loving crowd came ready to cheer in floral dresses and wide-brimmed floppy hats.

headline: Pelosi Heads for Singapore, but Is Silent on Taiwan
abstract: Speculation about a stop in Taiwan, where she would be the highest-ranking U.S. visitor in decades, has jangled nerves in both Beijing and Washington.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi was expected to appear in Singapore on Monday as part of a closely watched tour of Asia that has stoked fears, including at the highest levels of the American government, of dangerously heightened tensions with China over the possibility that she would make a stop in Taiwan.

headline: In the I.C.U., Dying Sometimes Feels Like a Choice
abstract: The complex nature of death when machines keep us alive.
lead_paragraph: My patient’s wife had just one question: Was her husband dying?

headline: Eric Greitens May Just Get What He Deserves
abstract: At some point, toeing the line can’t excuse sketchy, creepy, violent and possibly illegal behavior.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Republican voters in Missouri will send a signal to G.O.P. leaders nationwide about what they will and won’t accept in a top candidate in the party’s current, Trumpian era: Namely, do they want a Senate nominee who exists in a perpetual swirl of scandal, including fresh accusations of domestic violence?

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Inside the Push to Diversify the Book Business’
abstract: For generations, America’s major publishers focused almost entirely on white readers. Now a new cadre of executives like Lisa Lucas is trying to open up the industry.
lead_paragraph: For generations, America’s major publishers focused almost entirely on white readers. Now a new cadre of executives is trying to open up the industry.

headline: We Are Living in Richard Nixon’s America. Escaping It Won’t Be Easy.
abstract: Remember when there was talk of Joe Biden as a transformational figure?
lead_paragraph: It seems so naïve now, that moment in 2020 when Democratic insiders started to talk of Joe Biden as a transformational figure. But there were reasons to believe. To hold off a pandemic-induced collapse, the federal government had injected $2.2 trillion into the economy, much of it in New Deal-style relief. The summer’s protests altered the public’s perception of race’s role in the criminal justice system. And analyses were pointing to Republican losses large enough to clear the way for the biggest burst of progressive legislation since the 1960s.

headline: The Spread of Book Banning
abstract: Explaining the increasing politicization of the book banning debate.
lead_paragraph: Book-banning attempts have grown in the U.S. over the past few years from relatively isolated battles to a broader effort aimed at works about sexual and racial identity. Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth Harris cover the publishing industry. I spoke to them about what’s behind this trend.

headline: Fidel Ramos, Philippine President Who Broke With Marcos, Dies at 94
abstract: Considered a ruthless Marcos henchman,  he was later hailed as a national hero for breaking with the dictator, and went on to preside over an economic boom.
lead_paragraph: Fidel V. Ramos, a military leader who succeeded Corazon C. Aquino as president of the Philippines, and from 1992 to 1998 presided over robust economic growth, exceptional political stability and reconciliations with Communist insurgents and Muslim separatists,  died on Sunday in Manila.  He was 94.

headline: This Week in Business: Recession Fears
abstract: Meta reported its first-ever revenue decline. The Fed agreed on another supersize rate increase. And oil company earnings are booming.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was not a great day for the company formerly known as Facebook. First came a lawsuit from the Federal Trade Commission and then, the company announced its first-ever revenue decline since it went public. The F.T.C., led by Lina Khan, one of Big Tech’s biggest critics, is suing Meta to block it from buying Within, a virtual reality company that would aid the leap by Meta’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, into the metaverse. In the suit, the F.T.C. accused Meta of trying to buy a company that it should have to compete with. Meta responded that the agency had put together a case “based on ideology and speculation.” Later, the company reported that its second-quarter revenue was down 1 percent from the previous year, results that Mr. Zuckerberg put into the context of an “economic downturn that will have a broad impact” on digital advertising. Still, he appears relentless in advancing his vision for the next era of his business, and he has told employees that anyone who is not on board can leave.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Celery Victor from a celebrated bar in Brooklyn, sheet-pan feta and chickpeas, and more recipes.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. One of the great things to eat in New York City right now is a dish called celery Victor, served at Inga’s Bar in Brooklyn Heights. It’s a cold salad based on one that came out of a San Francisco hotel more than a century ago: braised stalks of celery in vinaigrette, with anchovies. At Inga’s Bar, fresh celery, greens and herbs join the plate, along with big chunks of Parmesan and dabs of pickled mustard seeds.

headline: A Nigerian Street Vendor Is Beaten to Death in Italy as Witnesses Stand By
abstract: The killing, in a seaside town on the Adriatic, has shocked Italians because of its brutality and because of the indifference of those looking on.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In May 2021 Alika Ogorchukwu, a 39-year-old Nigerian living in Italy, was hit by a car while he was riding his bicycle, an accident that forced him to use a crutch to move around.

headline: For American Girls, Many Meanings
abstract: Exploring what the dolls mean in today’s world. Also: Charging Donald Trump; politics and sports rules; Kamala Harris; a British-Irish wit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: One of Ukraine’s richest businessmen is killed in the port city of Mykolaiv.
abstract: Oleksiy Vadaturskyi, whose company built storage facilities and infrastructure necessary for exporting grain, was killed with his wife in a missile strike.
lead_paragraph: MYKOLAIV — The first air raid alarm rang out over Mykolaiv at 1:01 a.m. and for the next four hours, explosions thundered as Russian missiles rained down on this already battered southern port city.

headline: McKinney Fire Growing Quickly in Northern California
abstract: A raging wildfire in Klamath National Forest in California, fueled by strong winds from thunderstorms and high temperatures, grew to more than 51,000 acres.
lead_paragraph: A raging wildfire in Klamath National Forest in California, fueled by strong winds from thunderstorms and high temperatures, grew to more than 51,000 acres.

headline: Food Is Identity. For Korean Chefs Who Were Adopted, It’s Complicated.
abstract: Koreans raised by American families are exploring a heritage they didn’t grow up with through restaurant cooking — and finding both fulfillment and criticism.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Katianna Hong is tinkering with her grandmother’s matzo ball soup for a second time. The first time, she adapted it for a staff meal while she was executive chef at the Charter Oak in the Napa Valley.

headline: In Libyan Town Searching for Justice, a Struggle Even to Find Graves
abstract: Libya’s political chaos has left little room for the reconciliation that many residents see as necessary for peace. Few places feel that more than Tarhuna, where a murderous band of brothers reigned for years.
lead_paragraph: TARHUNA, Libya — It is hard to find a starker illustration of the failures of Libya’s political leaders than Tarhuna, a town set between the Mediterranean coast and the desert where seven brothers from the Kani family and their militiamen detained, tortured and killed hundreds of residents in a five-year reign of terror.

headline: Covid. A Coma. A Stroke. José Parlá Returns From the Edge.
abstract: After a lengthy recovery, the artist comes back with the most vigorous work he’s made: “It took me a really long time to understand what had happened to me.”
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — During the three months last year that the artist José Parlá was in a medically induced coma after contracting Covid-19, he had vivid dreams that he later found difficult to process: managing a Miami hotel circa 1980 and navigating a kidnapping plot involving his brother and the Hong Kong triads. “I was perceiving these dreams not as dreams but as memories,” he said. “Events that I believed had happened but weren’t real.”

headline: Review: ‘Cat on a Hot Tin Roof’ Knows Its Good Angles
abstract: The Ruth Stage’s production understands the violence and identity crisis at the core of Brick’s character, but other elements fail to cohere.
lead_paragraph: We know from his personal writing (and context clues) that Tennessee Williams was into trade: hypermasculine men who are just as likely to have sex with men as they are to break their necks. These seductive brutes are strewn throughout his work, just as essential and memorable as his fading belles. There is no Blanche without Stanley.

headline: Bill Russell, Who Transformed Pro Basketball, Dies at 88
abstract: A Hall of Famer who led the Celtics to 11 championships, he was “the single most devastating force in the history of the game,” his coach Red Auerbach said.
lead_paragraph: Bill Russell, whose defensive athleticism at center changed the face of pro basketball and propelled the Boston Celtics to 11 N.B.A. championships, the final two when he became the first Black head coach in a major American sports league, died on Sunday. He was 88.

headline: McKinney Fire Becomes California’s Largest of 2022, Burning 51,000 Acres
abstract: The fire sent a huge cloud called a pyrocumulonimbus 39,000 feet into the air. Storm winds, high temperatures and drought conditions helped it grow over the weekend, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A fast-growing wildfire fueled by strong winds from thunderstorms and high temperatures in Northern California has grown to more than 51,000 acres in two days, becoming the state’s largest wildfire so far this year and forcing evacuations in rural neighborhoods.

headline: The Red Cross says it still doesn’t have access to the prison camp where dozens of Ukrainians died.
abstract: The Russian Defense Ministry had said it would allow the United Nations and the Red Cross to visit the site.
lead_paragraph: The International Committee of the Red Cross has not received confirmation that it will be allowed to visit the detention center where dozens of Ukrainian prisoners were killed in an explosion, the organization said in a statement on Sunday.

headline: For India’s Effort to Ban Disposable Plastic, One State Offers a Playbook
abstract: Tamil Nadu’s relative success in outlawing single-use plastic is due largely to relentless policing.
lead_paragraph: CHENNAI, India — Amul Vasudevan, a vegetable hawker in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, thought she was going to go out of business.

headline: Man With Loaded Assault Rifle Arrested Outside Iranian Writer’s Home
abstract: Masih Alinejad, a journalist who lives in Brooklyn, was the target of an international kidnapping plot last year, according to a federal indictment and the writer.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested on Friday after he was found with a loaded AK-47 assault rifle outside the Brooklyn home of an Iranian American journalist who was the target of an international kidnapping plot said to be orchestrated by an Iranian intelligence network last year, according to the journalist, a court document and a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Banana Boat Recalls Hair and Scalp Sunscreen Over Low Levels of Carcinogen
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said consumers should immediately stop using the product if it came from any of the three batches recalled.
lead_paragraph: The parent company of Banana Boat recalled batches of a sunscreen spray because they contained trace levels of benzene, a carcinogen, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said. Consumers were urged to stop using the products.

headline: ‘Everything Has Healed’: Jacob deGrom Is Finally Ready
abstract: After more than a year away because of injuries, deGrom is expected to start for the Mets on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: After what will have been a wait of 391 days, one of the best pitchers in baseball is finally expected to take the mound in a major league game. Jacob deGrom, a two-time winner of the National League’s Cy Young Award, who last pitched for the Mets on July 7, 2021, is scheduled to make his return from injury Tuesday night against the Nationals in Washington.

headline: A Town’s Housing Crisis Exposes a ‘House of Cards’
abstract: In the Idaho resort area of Sun Valley, there are so few housing options that many workers are resorting to garages, campers and tents.
lead_paragraph: HAILEY, Idaho — Near the private jets that shuttle billionaires to their opulent Sun Valley getaways, Ana Ramon Bartolome and her family have spent this summer living in the only place available to them: behind a blue tarp in a sweltering two-car garage.

headline: As Ukraine Orders Civilians to Evacuate the East, Residents Face a Grim Choice
abstract: The president’s announcement is the broadest government directive issued thus far in the war, coming after months of relentless Russian bombardment.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK PROVINCE, Ukraine — Thuds from the artillery pounding Ukraine’s embattled east reverberated in the distance, yet it was the shouts of playing children on a recent afternoon that echoed across the yard near the front line.

headline: Nichelle Nichols, Lieutenant Uhura on ‘Star Trek,’ Dies at 89
abstract: She was among the first Black women to have a leading role in a TV series. She later worked with NASA to recruit minorities for the space program.
lead_paragraph: Nichelle Nichols, the actress revered by “Star Trek” fans everywhere for her role as Lieutenant Uhura, the communications officer on the starship U.S.S. Enterprise, died on Saturday in Silver City, N.M. She was 89.

headline: Last Conviction in Salem Witch Trials Is Cleared 329 Years Later
abstract: The exoneration of Elizabeth Johnson Jr., the last person whose name was not officially cleared, came from the efforts of an eighth-grade civics teacher and her students.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Johnson Jr. is — officially — not a witch.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Civilians in Donetsk Are Urged to Evacuate
abstract: Also, Nancy Pelosi heads to Singapore and global issues challenge Latin America’s rising left.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine ordered hundreds of thousands of civilians living in Donetsk province to evacuate their homes after months of relentless Russian bombardment.

headline: Former Kremlin adviser is hospitalized in Europe.
abstract: Anatoly Chubais, who resigned and left Russia in March, had grown numb in his hands and legs.
lead_paragraph: Anatoly Chubais, who resigned as a top Kremlin adviser shortly after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, was hospitalized on Sunday in a western European country in critical condition with the symptoms of a rare neurological disorder. Mr. Chubais had suddenly grown numb in his hands and legs, his wife, Avodtya Smirnova, told the Russian journalist Ksenia Sobchak.

headline: Morning Person
abstract: Garrett Chalfin makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome and congratulations to today’s constructor, Garrett Chalfin, on making his New York Times Crossword debut as a rising high school senior. Mr. Chalfin joins the growing ranks of constructors who debuted as teenagers, becoming the 59th to do so.
